title: Family Notices
content:
FUNERALS.
THE FRIENDS of the late Mr. JAMES HORAN
are invited to attend his Funeral ; to move
from his late residence, Dowling and Albion streets, Surry
Hills, TO-MORROW (Sunday) AFTERNOON, at 2
o'clock, to the Necropolis. C. KINSELA and SONS,
Undertakers, 118, South Head Road.
LOYAL ROSE OF AUSTRALIA LODGE, 4024,
I.O.O.F.M.U.—The Officers and Brothers of the
above Lodge, together with the officers and brethren of the
various other Lodges, are invited to attend the Funeral of
their deceased Brother, JAMES HORAN, to meet at the
Hall TO-MORROW (Sunday) AFTERNOON, at half-
past 1 o'clock.
H. KINSELA, N.G. ; BENJ. JOHNSON, Sec.
THE FRIENDS of the late Mr. JAMES RICHARD-
SON are invited to attend his Funeral ; to move from
his late residence, Denison-street, Kingston, on SUNDAY
AFTERNOON, at half-past 2 o'clock, and proceed to
Newtown Station for the Necropolis. J. and G. SHYING
and CO., Undertakers, 719, George-street South.
THE FRIENDS of Mr. JOHN RICHARDSON are
invited to attend the Funeral of his late beloved
BROTHER, James ; to move from his late residence,
Denison-street, Kingston, on SUNDAY AFTERNOON,
at half-past 2 o'clock, and proceed to Newtown Station for
the Necropolis. J. and G. SHYING and CO., Undertakers.
ANCIENT ORDER OF FORESTERS.—The Mem-
bers of Court Morning Star, No. 3002, and the
members of the various Courts of the Order, are requested
to attend the Funeral of our late departed Brother, JAMES
RICHARDSON. Members to meet at Host Webster's
Hotel, Newtown, on SUNDAY, at 2 o'clock p.m.
WILLIAM ROLSTON, C.R.
VALENTINE DAVIS, Secretary.
THE FRIENDS of Mr. JOHN CUTLER are invited
to attend the Funeral of his late beloved BROTHER-
IN-LAW, the late Mr. James Richardson ; to move from
his late residence, Denison-street, Kingston, on SUNDAY
AFTERNOON, at half-past 2 o'clock. J. and G. SHY-
ING and CO., Undertakers.
THE FRIENDS of Mr. SAMUEL, CLAPINSON are
invited to attend the Funeral of his late beloved
BROTHER-IN-LAW, the late Mr. James Richardson ;
to move from his late residence, Denison-street, Kingston,
on SUNDAY AFTERNOON, at half-past 2 o'clock. J.
and G. SHYING and CO., Undertakers, 719, George-st. S.
THE FRIENDS of Mr. EDWARD SWINSON, sen.,
are invited to attend the Funeral of his late beloved
SON-IN-LAW, Mr. James Richardson ; to move from his
late residence, Denison-street, Kingston, on SUNDAY
AFTERNOON, at half-past 2 o'clock. J. and G. SHY-
ING and CO., Undertakers, 60, Riley-st., Woolloomooloo.
THE FRIENDS of Mr. EDWARD O'HARA are
respectfully invited to attend the Funeral of his
deceased SON, Edward James ; to move from his resi-
dence, No. 80, Harrington-street, THIS (Saturday)
AFTERNOON, at half-past 2 o'clock, to Necropolis.
JAMES CURTIS, Undertaker, 59, Hunter-street.
THE FRIENDS of the deceased Mr. GEORGE
HITCHCOCK, sen., are respectfully invited to
attend his Funeral ; to move from his late residence,
Albion Cottage, Booth-st, Balmain, on SUNDAY AFTER-
NOON, 17th instant, at a quarter to 3 o'clock. THOMAS,
Undertaker, 141, York-street, near Wesleyan Chapel.
THE FRIENDS of Messrs. JOHN J., THOMAS, and
HENRY GILCHRIST are invited to attend the
Funeral of their late beloved Uncle, the late Mr. JAMES
HORAN ; to move from his late residence, Dowling and
Albion streets, Surry Hills, TO-MORROW (Sunday)
AFTERNOON, at 2 o'clock, to the Necropolis. C. KIN-
SELA and SONS, Undertakers, 118, South Head Road ;
737, George-street, opposite Christ Church ; and 363,
Sussex-street South.
THE FRIENDS of Mr. PHILIP PAULL are re-
spectfully invited to attend the Funeral of his late
beloved WIFE, Martha Jane ; to move from his residence,
No. 8, Myrtle-street, Shepherd's Paddock, and proceed to
the Mortuary, THIS (Saturday) AFTERNOON, at a
quarter to 3 o'clock. C. KINSELA and SONS, Under-
takers, 737, George-street, opposite Christ Church ; 118,
South Head Road, near Crown-street ; 363, Sussex-st. S.
FUNERALS. FUNERALS. FUNERALS.
Mobbts. C. KINSELA and SONS, Undertakers, beg
to infsjiu their friends and the public in gcncril that
having the best Btate hearses, ostrich plumes, and monrninir
coaches, together with all other requirements appertaining
to iho -trade, this places them in a position to furnish funerals
nutho same respectable manner as heretofore, and choapor
than any other establishment in the colony. Noto tho
address-737, George-street, opposite Christ Church; l18,
South Head Road; and 363, Sussex-street South.

title: LIQUORS.
content:
I LIQUORS., .",'; 'I
I [l\ W. C0SEN8' CIRCUXAIt.] ' -, ' I
} .,.'..'. . .' !;.April9l |
'j Be same inactivity wh'cb bas characterised tue trade lu wiaes
and spirits, since tue opening of the year, continues, and dealers
only purchase such quantities as will suffice for immediate re-
quirements. Prices remsia without alteration, hut, In the event
of any pressure to realise, prices would have to be in favour.of
the buyer. ' The bonded stock of brandy in London shows a fo
duction compared with April, 1872, of about 11,600 hogsheads
of thin y a decrease reaching 2480 butts-upon port a slight
increase of 88 pipes, and French 2673 hogsheads. Brandy
in lair request but no advance of price is' noted. Bum
slightly lower ior all but Jamaicas, wkloh, maintain their
values. Gin has advanced. In wines, quotations unchanged
Sherry: But for the political state of Spain tho prices of sherry
would probably have advanced, the last vintage having yielded W
sliort and unsatisfactory a crop. Fine wines with quality and
character are (difficult to he found even at full quotations. The
export fromrCediz is still considerable. . !
Fort-The long delay in shipments caused by the impayable
state of the, river Douro has ceased, and several BUamers-hvve
cleared Isden with wine. The market U fairly'active; low wines
very scarce at stlffer rates. . !
' With reference to other wines no facts calling for, special com-
ment aro advised. , ' ' j
Brandy.-The brandy market, both at Cognac and in London,
har been without .¡movement; prices, however, are un-
affected-the demand is quite of a retail* chtraotcr. .The prognss
of the vines will be watched with interest. ' ' ,
Bum.-For Jamaica the demand is steady, and prices are
unchanged, but other qualities are a shade cosier In price.
British Glnhss advanced. >

title: Family Notices
content:
In order to guard against imposition, notices
of Births, Marriages, and Deaths must be
authenticated by some reliable person to
secure their insertion.
Births.
CLARKE.—On May 17, at Summerhorne,
South Glenorchy, the wife of George E.
Clarke : a daughter.
KOERBIN.—At 41, Bathurst-street, the wife
of Otto Koerbin : a daughter. Both doing
well.
Marriages.
BOOTHMAN—MOSS.—On the 20th May, 1843,
at St. David's Church, Hobart, by the Rev.
Wm. Bedford, Edward Westlake Boothman,
to Lucy Amelia Moss. (Golden wedding.)
Deaths.
HAINES.—On May 18, at her residence, 39,
Macquarie-street, Susan Elizabeth, wife of
Harry Haines ; aged 40. The funeral will
leave above address at 2.30 p.m. TO-
MORROW (SUNDAY).
JOSEPH.—On May 18, at her late residence,
Riversdale, Clarence Plains, after a long
and painful illness, Margaret, the beloved
wife of Benjamin Joseph. The funeral
will leave for St. Matthew's Church on
THIS DAY, at 2 p.m. Friends are
respectfully invited to attend.
Funeral Notice.
BUCKINGHAM DISTRICT,
M.U., I.O.O.F.
The Members of the various Lodges in the
above-named District are respectfully re-
quested to attend the funeral of the late
wife of Brother HENRY HAINES, which will
leave her late residence, No. 39, Macquarie-
street, TO-MORROW (SUNDAY) AFTERNOON,
at 2.30 o'clock.
EDWIN G. JACKSON, P.C.S.

title: THE MEETING OF THE EMPERORS.
content:
(reuter's telegrams.)
THE MEETING OP THE EMPERORS.
LOiS'DON. SBi"T. 15.
Tho Russian and Gorman official journals
yesterday published articles on the meeting
of the Emperor and the Czar at Dantzic on
the 9th instant. The opinion generally ex-
pressed in the articles is, that the meeting
may be regarded as a pledge of the peace oi
Europe.

title: MOONLIGHT PROMENADE CONCERTS.
content:
MOONLIGHT PROMENADE CONCERTS.
To the Editor of the Herald.
Sm,-Havingbeen present at two ef the above concerts,
and viewing with great pleasure Mr. Gassner's great
exertions in tbe cause of charity, I think that it would
not be out place if the patrons and officers of those
institutions which have received help from the above
source, would tender a complimentary return to Mr.
Gaesner and the members of the band. What I would
venture to suggest is that Mr. G. be asked to prepare
a programme and give a concert, the proceeds of
which to be devoted, either in purchasing a testi-
monial, orto be given in some shape or other to Mr.
G. and his brother musicians.
Hoping this will bring the matter under the notice
of those before mentioned,
I am, Sir, yours, &c,
J. T. B. W.

title: SPECIAL SITTING AT NISI PRIUS.
content:
Special Sitting at Nisi Pnivs.
Before Ilib Honor tho Chiet Justice and n jury of
finir.
COOK V. 11Y11NEÍ, AND ANOTHEK.
Tho trial of this case, which had already lasted two
days, was resumed and concluded.
It was on action bj- Simon Cook, a farmer of Illawarra,
against James Bj-mcs and William Byrnes, proprietors of
tho Mount Pleasant Colliery, to recover damages for the
pollution of a creek or small stream of fresh water which
ran through tho plaintiff's land, by coal from tho defend-
ants' worts. Tho plaintiff'B declaration put tho case in
two ways, first, that the creek had been wilfully polluted
by tho casting of coal therein ; secondly, that tho damiegti
had been the result of ncgltgenco. Tho defendants had
pleaded-first, a general doninl that thej- had dono any
injury to tho plaintiff ; secondly, that whatever injury had
been inflicted lind been the unavoid.iblo result of what thoy
had done in the lawful conduct of their businoss as coal
lumera.
Sir William Manning, Q.C., Mr. Darloy, and Mr. Salo-
mons, instructed by Mr. Maguire, appeared for the plaintiff;
and Mr.,Butlor, instructed by Messrs. Allen, Bowden, and
Allen, for the defendants.
Tho plaintiff was the lessee of Spring G rovo, a farm of
fifty acres, at Fairy Meadow, Wollongong district,
in the vicinity pf the Mount Pleasant Colliery. His
case was that a small stream of water which ran through
his and other lands in that neighbourhood had been ren-
dered unfit for uso bj- tho deposit of n largo quantity of
slocOc coal from the collierj' in question, ana that his farm
had boen otherwise injured from the samo cause. Tho
defendants' caso was that there had been no such injury,
and that although the creek might have boon partially fillod
up by slack coal, this had not been the result of any care
lossnoss on tho part of tho emploj-ccs at the colliery, but of
n land slip, the result of a flood, for which tho defendants
were not responsible. The evidenco was very voluminous,
and in'many respects very conflicting. Tho amount really
in question was a small one, but tho object of tho contest
was rather, it would appear, to determine tho genorol ques-
tion whether or not tho proprietors of cool mines in that
district were to be held responsible for damages of this cha-
racter. According to the plaintiff and his witnesses the
creek had clearly been damaged by the presence of a
quantity of slack coal which hod como down from an
immense henp noar the mouth of the mine-a result bl ought
about by the carelessness of the minors in allowing bo vast
an accumulation at such a place. Tho supply of water from
this creek had previously been regular ana abundant. Tho
water, although a littlo hard for washing purposes, hail
been excellent for every other kind of domestic use, but
since the conl had come down it had been quito useloss.
Tho waterholes had boen completely filled up, so that the
constancy of tho supplj- of water was to it great extent put
an end to, and such as was still to bo had was very bad.
The flood, too, bad carried tho slack coal over some of tho
cultivated land, and hod destroj-cd or damaged tho crops.
Cook had about forty head of cattle which had boen accus-
tomed to drink at this stream, but which could
now scarcely use ii. He had boon compelled
therefore to sink a well. Ho had offered to toke £20
in full compensation for these injuries, and for this sum to
clear out the bed of tho creek himself, but tho defendants
had refused lo give him that amount and had offered only
£10. According to tho defendant«' wltnosses the water of
this creek, which had always been a littlo brackish,.had
been in no way injured by tie influx of slack coal, which
was far less than had been represented, and was occasioned
solely by a landslip during a flood which hod brought down
at the samo time a largo quantity of soil. The spread of
slack coal over tho land to a small extent had rather a
tendency to increaso its productiveness than otherwise, and
tho catUo had in no way suffered. The^offer of £10 had
been tendered, it was sworn, without prejudico-that is to
say without admitting any liability-and only in tho hope
by dealing liberally with tho plaintiff to save all trouble and
expense. Samples of tho water from . this
creek were exhibited in Court, whioh sample«
presented a very uninviting appearance. It was contended
tint they had not been fairly token, but that the water must
havo been btorcd up, but this was denied. Some of this water
was analysed by Mr. Watt, from whose evidence it would
appear that its" foulness aid not in all probability result
from tho presence of coal, but from that of organic matter.
It further appeared that watcrcrcsscs wore growing plen-
tifully in the creek, and that decomposed vegetable matter
might in dry weather help to make the water bad. Tho
water of the creek, according to Mr. Watt, was naturally
brackish, and tho slack coal from this'mino when settled
(as it. would, settle) ,at. tho bottom of theiBtreain when
' 'net flowing rapidly- would'« not pollute it as alleged.
There was nirtfccr evidence that a stream of water coming
.ut of the same seam of coal was quite pure, and was con-
stantly used for domestic purposes. Seme of the coal was
broken up in Court and placed in tumblers ef water, upon
which it left a slight scum, although without otherwiso
rendering the water apparently impure. The impurity, J
however, va« most positively «vom to by the plaintiff'« *
**"?"-~-i _.
.witnosBcs. Somo evidence was gone into on the part of tho
I ?'_.nti(T lo show that tho lond-slip, if it did canso tho dam-
age (which was denied), lind been the result of some mis-
management of tho excavation. This was mot by direct
contradiction on tho(pnrt of tho defendants. Tho ovidenco
was directly contradictory na to the quantity of slack coal
in tbo heap nenr the colliery, and in nearly ovcry other im-
portant particular, even ¡is to tho local features of tho
gi omul.
His IIokoh directed the jury that the plain ques-
tion for their deteniiiuation was whothor or not tho
plaintiff hnd mndo ont any claim to damages for
injurj" sustained by him through any want oi duo core on
tho p'nrt of tho defendants' employes. Evory man had a
right to work n coal mine, but ho was bound so to monago
it as that his neighbours should not bo injured. Against
lend slips nud floods no amount of caro could guarel ; but
tho miners wero bound to exctciso duo caro and forethought
so ns when buch accidents took placo their neighbours
might bo «s little injured as possiblo by any escapo from tho
minc.
The jury, without leaving tho box, found a verdict for the
defi'iidnnts.

title: NEW ZEALAND.
content:
NEW ZEALAND.
NOTES ON PASSING EVENTS.
[KItOM OUU OVWX COWIES I-ONDKNT.)
AUOKT.AXJ), 20th January.
Tin; news from lho East Coast is hy no means
so good Ihis last week. At Opotiki, there is a
return of a stale of filings which is very far from
pleasant in the recommencement of hostilities
by (he natives in the line of murdering any
European or loyal native they can catch. All
along they were of course ripe for this, if the
opportunity had been considered favourable, and
the fact that for a considerable time nothing of
the sort was tried went to show that they were
deterred by fear from the course. They have,
it appears, entered upon it again, and this, more
than anything of more decided want of success
to our troops or loss to our men, is the real bad-
ness of the news.
The Auckland papers are a little too much
affected hy it, I think, and seem to lay stress
upon it as if it involved the loss of prestige, and
the undoing of work supposed to be done
already; but 'there is no good ground for sup-
posing that any change at all affecting the
ultimate position of the campaign has taken
place.
Colonel Lyon, who commands at Opotiki,
has, I believe, already taken measures to
repress the forward movement of the rebels,
and a short time will, 1 have no doubt, see
them driven back once more to their fastnesses
where they were to have been attacked some
weeks ago-a course which, if taken, would, no
doubt, have put a stop to the present evils.
Although a good many ambushes have been
set by the rebels, we only know of one victim
having been secured-a Maori of the native
contingent, named Johnson, who was toma-
hawked and brutally hacked to pieces. There
are more than suspicions entertained regarding
the position of many of the natives professedly ,
friendly in the district. No doubt, many arc
traitors, but that is not so remarkable as the
readiness with which we seem always to trust
these people again.
Lower down the coast the last stronghold of
one section of the natives seems to have fallen
to our attack with but trifling loss ; and we may
now consider that, with the exception of the
force at Opotiki, which is a conglomerate of a
good many sections of rebels,-there is now no
fear of a formidable resistance being offered to
our aims on the East Coast. Of course, it is true
that these people arc very easily moved from
place to place, and a little vigour displayed at
Opotiki rntiy soon cause the re-appearance of
ícbcls at Turanga-mii or at Waiapu. This, in
fact, is a main difficulty of our position, and one
not easy to provide against but by constant care
and watchfulness.
On the "West Coast, at "Wanganui, it is grati-
fying to find that something vigorous is at last
being done. The operations of General Chute
have not been characterised by any startling
display of military science or of original genius,
but they have been vigorous and well-timed,
and as such have produced better effects than
many more correctly planned operations would
hove done.
The loss of another field officer in Colonel
Hassard, of the 57th, is a great pity, as the
officers hare been very heavy sufferers already
in comparison with the men in this war. How-
ever, the moral effect on the natives of finding
Ile soldiers able to storm pas off-hand and
follow them boldly into the bush will be excel-
lent indeed. To the colonist, too, it is no small
gratification to find that the troops are to have
tile chance before they go to remove the re-
proach which was made against them of being
afiaid of the bush and of native forts. It is no
pleasant position for people of British race at
any time to hear sims cast upon the good name
of the British aimy, of which they arc proud
almost by instinct. A little beating will be
enough for the AVaneanui natives, for they arc
a chicken-hearted race, too cruel to be really
brave, and so esteemed even by their own
people.
1 hope General Chute may see their submis-
sion complete before the troops are all with-
drawn from the colony.
In my account of my experiences of the
northern part of this island (which is the result
of a careful personal inquiry into the facts), your
readers will have learned most of the local facts
of interest al present.
The discovery of a fine vein* of copper at the
lower Thames, in the neighbourhood of the
place where gold has been found in payable
quantities, but inaccessible, owing to native
jealousy, is a fact of some importance.
Copper has been known to exist for some
time in the neighbourhood, and the
proprietor (native) of the land is quite willing
to have it worked. It is said that there is a
good deal of the silver with the copper, which
will of course enhance the importance of the
discovery, if correct.
I am informed that a cominmy, with a capital
of £20,000, is in course of formation to work
the New Zealand flax on the plan discovered by
Mr. Purchas, some of which was in the Sydney
maiket previous to the Avar, and commanded
excellent prices. The present effort promises
well, as some of the best names in Auckland are
concerned.
AUCKLAND, 2'Jlh January.
To-day is the twenty-seventh Anniversary of
the founding of this colony, and all Auckland is
holiday-making in consequence. The weather
seems not to have proved particularly favour
i able to the regatta, which is our way of holding
high festival here on this occasion each year,
I and the absence of the old Maori element to a
great extent from the scene lakes much from
the romance of the affair. Formerly
it was the Maori festival j.ar excellence,
but for the last two years the natives
have not been on sufficiently cordial terms,
excepting to the North-and the Northern
natives never did much in canoe-racing-to come
in any considerable numbers to the regatta.
Were the Northern tribes removed or unfriendly
we should soon be much in the position of the
Australian cities, where an aboriginal native is a
comparatively rare sight.
The position of matters on the West Coast is
veiy greatly improved by the operations "of the
troops under General Chute. In a former
letter I gave some details of his earlier
operations in taking the pas at Manu
taki and Manapawa, where Colonel Has
sard, of the 57th, was unfortunately mor-
tally] wounded. These successful operations
were, however, only preliminary to his larger
scheme, which he has now, in great measure,
accomplished. That was to penetrate from
Wanganui to Taranaki by an inland route, and
to take all the fortifications, and destroy all the
houses and plantations he could find on the
way. Starting with about 750 men in all, of
whom about 500 were her Majesty's troops,
and 250 colonial forces, either natives or Forest
Bangers, he forced his way through serious
difficulties of all sorts, the chief of which was.
the want of food, which was moro than once
very seriously felt, to the extent of obliging the
troops to eat horse-flesh, as tho commissariat
J»
fe "*- -*
could.not keep up with them. On the march
about ten days seem to have been consumed'
and it is stated that in the various fights that
occurred on the route not less than 150 natives
were killed. Every fortified place was assaulted
and taken by storm, on the principle established
by the colonial forces on the East Coast, and in
all cases the defenders of the pas seem to have
been panic struck at the apparition of soldiers
actually rushing a pa before a single shot had
been fired at it from the traditional great guns.
General Chute had reached New Plymouth at
our latest dates, and had been received with the
greatest possible enthusiasm, which displayed
itself in the form ol triumphal arches and ad-
dresses.
The General's work, however, is not yet done
by any means. This march indeed is but the
first blow, which must be followed up with
others in rapid succession, unless it is to be
forgotten. He is quite aware of this happily,
and is about to recommence his march back
again, only taking the coast line instead of the
inland route.
At Warca, near the Patia Uiver, and on the
wonderfully fertile plateau that stretche3 away
southwards from the base of Mount Egmont,
there is reason to believe that the natives will
be found in very considerable force, and with
formidable works of defence. The country is
difficult, owing to the heavy scrub of manuka
and flax which occupies most of the district
and the natives are so fully competent to take'
advantage of this that it may safely be said
that the heaviest part of the work is yet to
come.
A continuance of the same fearless tactics
will, however, in the opinion of every compe-
tent judge, lead to the complete and early
success of the operations at Warca as elsewhere,
and loo much credit can scarcely be given to'
General Chute for the ready and able way in
which he lias adopted and applied to regular
military practice the lessons to be learnt from
the experience of the colonial forces.
The native contingent on the East Coast has
been gaining fresh laurels, and the rebels we
may hope have been gaining new experiences
within the last few days. The rebels who were
defeated so often by the combined native and
colonial forces under Major Frazer, retreated on
the difficult country at the head of the river '
Wairoa, where in the very inaccessible district
round the Waikarcmoana Lake, where the river
takes its rise, they considered themselves safe
from molestation. Such was not the view of
either Major Frazer or the friendly chiefs who
followed them up with about 400 fighting-men.
On the 11th and 12th days of this month a
severe scries of skirmishes were fought close to
the banks of this large and romantic lake
where the rebels had erected a pa of some
strength. The struggle seems to have been
severe, and the arts of the defending party were
so clever that it seems hard that they
should have proved so ineffectual. On the
second day the victory of our men was so well
established that the rebels, having lost their pa,
took to their canoes, and favoured by the fine
weather-in windy weather the lake is too
stormy for ennocs-made their escape, leaving
forty-one dead bodies behind them. Many, no
doubt, were wounded in the affair on their side,
as thirteen were on ours. The greatest chief of
the Wairoa was left dead by the rebels, as well
as five or six men of leading rank. Amongst
the loyal dead (twelve) there were no men of
note ; but old lhaka, a great chief and warrior,
who was, in fact, commander-in-chief, was
rather badly wounded in the thigh.
There is no news of further fighting at
Opotiki, but some may be daily expected. The
escape of some fifty-three native prisoners from
the hulk at Wellington, effected hythe removal
of a port and dropping into the water or a boat
on a stormy night has caused some sensation.
The principle of keeping these men shut up in a
hulk doing nothing beyond eating and sleeping
has long been condemned by the colonists, and
this second escape may perhaps stir up the
Governor to consent to some more reasonable
plan. They were offered to Otago as hard-labour
men, it may be remembered, bul the offer was
not accepted owing to a mistaken notion that
the chiefs would not work. The old proposal to
deport them to the Chatham. Islands
seems better than allowing the poor wretches to
make their escape and lose a large percentage
by drowning in the attempt-no less than six
out of the fifty-three arc known to have lost
their lives.
'Hie confiscation of half a million »f acres at
Opotiki, will throw into the Government's hands
some of the first land in New Zealand, and the
settlement of half the 1st Waikato Regiment
upon part of it will give security, and therefore
value to the remainder, which can at no distant
date be sold for a good price. The province
of Auckland is promised a further loan of a quar-
ter of a million to enable her" to deal satisfac-
torily with the ceded Waikato territory, but
how the money is proposed to be used by the
Provincial Executive does not yet appear.
Mr. Weld, the late Premier of this colony,
has announced his retirement from public life
owing to ill-health. Had he done so before he
headed a Ministry he would have carried far
deeper regrets with him than he now can do
from most of the colony.
From the papers, per tho Prince Alfred steamer, wo quote
as follows :
Under the head of Native Intelligence, in the Southern
Cross, that journnl publishes somo "gleanings" on the
nativc question, which are not without thoir significance, and
for the accuracy of which it vouches.
Wo learn that many Europeans havo recently ponotratod
into tbo bcai t of the disturbed districts, amongst the Pal
Mnrire fanatics. With several of those tourists, wo have
had an opportunity of speakincr. Starting from Auckland, and
going up to tho Waikato and Thames countries, ono remark
is made by all tourists-namely the diminished numbors of
tho natives. On being questioned regarding the cause of
their decrease, they state that the loss by war did not nearly
so much niTect them as tho loss by disease. Affeotiona of
the throat and chest have been the chief agency in carrying
off (he native people ; and as they have, as a rule, gono book
to the licentious and communistic practices, in voguo
twenty-five or thirty years ago (amongst othors, the whare
piihi), theie can bo little doubt that the mortality witt
increase. . ,
Several gentlemen who penetrated into a comparatively
unknown country, in tho interior, were treated ovcrywhere
with marked respect and kindness. They attribute tats to
what took place a short time previously at Matamata, wita
Thompson. It would appear, as the natives report, that a,
deputation from all tho inland tribes, numbering about tut)
men, waited on Thompson, asking him to lead the tnbos ut
an attack on Auckland. Thompson isBaid to liave asked
.'Do you know tho way to Auckland?" After a pauso,
the deputation repliod-" No ; but wo look to you to shoir
us tho wav." Thompson said-" I tried to take Aucklani
once, and! lost one eye. If I try to take it again I fear to
'otc tho other eyo. I made war on Auckland once, ano
Waikato is gone: if I mako war again I may lose
ho Waiho (Thames)." The deputation said no
more. Thompson then added-" As yea represent
all the native tribes and villages inland, mw
that vou aro here, I may ns well toll you what I want
you 'to do. When any Europeans want to go
through your disfrute, they are not to be touched. \ ou.
aro not to murder onv ; you aro to help thom and treat morn.
with kindness." Thedepulatton loft, carrying thismessaga.
to their villages; and the tourists to whom we refer hoard it
in a remoto district, through which Hereopa, with tho tewi
of a European, travelled only two day« previously. This
Bpeaxs volumes for Thompson's influence. .
Our informants often spoke on war subjects ; and oa being
questioned whether it was peace or war, the natives invau
ably answered, " It will bo peace or war as Thompson
decides." They are quito ready to fight-, and do not appear
I to think themselves lese ablo to drive tis into the sea, witt»
diminished numbers, than boforo thawar. .
| From Ngatimaniopoto wo learn that Rowi is anxious tor
peace, but that his fighting chief-his " back;bono -
wants war. The tribe is divided.-; and wo are convince! mat
an acceptable agent would hnve. no dtfUouUy in eeourwg «BQ

title: Advertising
content:
[ADVKimsKMKNT.]
To Captain Carrigaic, of the ship Wanata.
Bia,-Wo the undersigned dcsiro to return you our most grate-
ful thanks for your courteous, kind, and exemplary feeling
towards each passenger throughout tho voyage. Wo Bhall not
easily forget your Indefatigable cxortionB to promote our well
being and happiness, particularly at critical periods, when your
very presence gavo us utmost confidence in our safoty. It now,
Sir, remains with us to testify our sincere affeotion for your per-
sonal worth, by presenting you with a gold Albert chain, whioh
we hopo you will bo pleased to accept In the cheerful way In
which it baa been given. Wo now bid you a fond adieu, and wish
you to retain your high position in the Blaok Ball Lino scrvioo,
to conduct tho remainder of our friends to tho land of our adop-
tion.
Bigncd on behalf of the passengers.
Robert Mcgarvy Patrick Raino
Alexander Atwill Mathlas Farrell
Totrick Murphy Patriok Phelan
John Gallagher John M'Mullln. , j

title: BRIGHAM YOUNG'S MESSAGE.
content:
BRIGHAM YOUNG'S MESSAGE. '
THE message of Brigham Young, delivered according
to the Salt Lake iVetci, "orally, on Monday, Feb-
ruary 22nd, to the Senate and House of Represent-
atives of the State of DeBeret," at Salt Lake City,
occupies nearly one and a halt columns of that paper.
We make the following extract :
We have met in the capacity of a State Legislature
with a view to preserve our organisation, and with an
eye to the time when, in the wisdom of God, He will
move upon the minds of Senators and Members of
Congrecs to give us oar legal, national, and legitimate
rights. We wait with patience to see this done.
Perhaps to some it «vould seem unnecessary to keep
up this organisation ; but it is that we may preserve
our identity as a part of the nation that we assemble
annually in this capacity. If the machinery
is kept in order, when the time shall come
for the water to be turned upon it there will
be no difficulty in starting it. It is not so much
to enact laws and to sit in a Legislative capacity that
we now meet, as to recognise our rights ; and in
doing so we do no more than others have done and no
more than is our right to do. If we who live in this
country were disposed to meet in this capacity three
hundred and sixty-five days in the year, it would con-
cern nobody but ourselves, except meddlers and those
who wish to infringe upon the rights of our neighbours.
In a republican government like ours it is our right to
meet as we do to-day. We have the undoubted right
to meet together and consult upon those points,of
governmental affairs that pertain to our future peace,
end to gather the necessary information to enable us
to proceed further in the'duties of life. Whether,lin
the providences of God, we Bhall be admitted aa a
State or not we leave with him. He will do as He
pleaseB ; the hearts of all living are in His hands, and
whattver condition He permits us to live in we shall
accept and conform to. Gentlemen, in coming together
to-day as the representa'ives of Deseret, we have the
proud satisfaction of knowing that we represent a people
capable in every respectif governing and controlling
themselves. We in this country have achieved a
freedom and independence such as are rarely pos-
sessed by any people in these days. We raise our
own bread and eat it ; we make our bridges and
streets and pay fur them ; we erect our public
buildings, develope our resources, sustain our Govern-
ment and officers, and are not in debt. That
which is accumulated as income from taxation is
appropriated for the benefit of the people. We have
no bondB in market for greedy financiers to speculate
in, to prove a cause of embarrassment to ourselves
or a vexation and announce to our children. Our
legislators have been wise enough not to go beyond
their ability, and burden the people with a heavy
indebtedness without having resources to refund the
same. Should we be aelmitted as a State, I look for
the snn.e policy to be pursued ; we shall
not fall into debt, _ but always live within
our mennB. This is the secret of succesB
with men, communities, and nations. Take men
in any capacity whatever, whether singly or
otheiwisc, and you will find that if they live within
their means they will be independent and powerful.
It is so in the case of a single individual, ana it is in-
creased))- so with a community or nation. We, as a
people, have had wisdom enough to perceive and act
upon this. A people or Government rtat will suffer,
itself to get entangled through avarice or other causes,'
and bring upon ita people war and indebtedness, and
then poverty and distress, proves that it is not capable
of exercising the proper lights of government. But a
nation that can maintain peace within i's borders and
with its neighbours, exhibits knowledge, wisdom, and
power that muBt eventually call forth the respect and
admiiation of the world. Thus far we have been able
J .to piestive ourselves from such contingencies. It is
true that war has been made upon us ; but the sword
of indignation has fallen harmless at our feet. Yet
o,ur own .wisdom did not produce this; it was by the
powtr and wisdom of God, which He imparts to those
who live eo as to receive them that they may preserve
themselves. j
ON POVEBTV.-111 informed in political economy,
the poor are worse informed in all matters of domestic
economy. Having scant wages to live upon, they
rarely spend those wages in the most prudent and
profitable wav s. They are too often the prey to their
own perverted tastes, and to the tricksters who trade
upon those tastes. They buy bad food, and cook it
badlj ; their bodies ore dirty," their clothes are dirty,
their hcmeB are dirty. Disgusted thereby, and
afflicted by the hopelessness of their condition, it is
almost a tule for them to stifle their feelings in un-
wholesome drink ; and thus they pass, from bad to
woice. Every clergyman, every dector, every one who
knows anything of the dwellings of the poor, can give
us instances. without number of the waste
ar.d unthrift that there abound. People whese
earnings are barely enough, with the strictest
economy, to supply their most pressing needs;
practise no economy at all. Families that
have, perhaps, twelve or fifteen shillings a, week
to subsist on, do not get more than eight or ten
shillings' worth of actual subsistence. The rest is
squandered foolishly or viciously. For this the poor
themselves are very little to blame, How can they
be expected to do better when they have never been
taught, when their cares are so overwhelming, when
they have every inducement to despondency and
none to hope ? Yet this is surely a matter in which
charitable persons, charitable women especially, might
exercise their charity with unspeakable advantage.
Much they do ; but very much more has to be done
befe re any important change can be wrought in the
eccnomic habits of our mulions of poor. So muoh
that any thorough reformation must be despaired of,
unlees another branch of education-in correction of
the third sort of ignorance here to be alluded
to, and the most ruinous of all-is also zealously
promoted. No great improvement in the con-
dition and prospects of the poor can be hoped tor
until they are taught to exercise ordinary prudence
in limiting the size of their families in accordance
with their means of decently and healthily maintain-
ing those families. Tbis ÍB not the occasion for dis-
cussing the general question of Malfhusianism, as it
is called. The great law of population, first enunciated
by the Rev. Thomas Robert Malthus in 1798-that
whilst, in the most favourable circumstances, the
food-producing powers of land can only he expected
to increase in an arithmetical ratio, population always
Ur.ds to incieaeo in a geometrioal ratio; and that
accordingly, unleBB the area of population can be
adequately extended, its proper growth U inevitably
restricted by famine, plague, war, and other in-
voluntary checks, if not by voluntary checks
resorted to by man himself-is SB simple and
ir controveí tibie as the Newtonian law of gravition.
At any rate, though many have ridiculed
it, and many more haTe ignored it, no one has
ever seriously attempted to controvert it. Multitudes
have rejeced it without consenting to reason upon it;
but all of the few who have reasonably considered it,
have been ferced to adopt it. The precise bearings of
the law and its detailed applications, however, include
many problems that have yet to be settled. We do
not vet know how rnanv inhabitants our own country,
for instance, can be fairly expected to maintain in
that measure of comfort which all human beings haye
a right to claim ; nor have the possibility and ex-
pedience of drafting off to other and thinly peopled
districts those of our offspring for whom there is no
room in. the me ther country, been properly taken
account of; nor have the special means by which the
law shall be ec forced been dulv investigated and
defined. These questions and others like them are
worihy of careful consideration, and will have to be
considered before long. But we need not, and may
Ineit, wait for that time before recognising the force of
trc law in its relation to the present state of the poor. I
- Vndtrtht C'totcn. t
BALANCE OF-THE ANIMAL AND VEOBTAHLE KINODOMS
IN AK AQUARIUM.-In Chamber ft Miscellany we find
the following :- In remarking .upon the result;
of his experiments, Mr. Warrington observes, " Thus
we have that admirable balance sustained between the
animal and vegetable kingdoms, and that in a liquid
element. The fish, in ita respiration, consumes the
oxygen held in solution by the water as atmospheric
air, furnishes carbonic acid, feeds on the insects and
ycung snails, and excretes material well adapted as a
rich food to the plant, and well fitted for its luxuriant;
growth. The plant, by its respiration, consumes the
carbonic acid produced by the fish, appropriating the
carbon to the construction of ita tissues and fibres«
and liberates the oxygen in its gaseous state to sustain
the healthy functions of the animal life; at the same
time that it feeds on the rejected matter, which has
fulfilled its purposes in the nourishment of the _ fish
and snail, end preserves the water constantly in a
clean and healthy'condition. While the slimy snail,
finding its proper nutriment in the decomposing
vegetoble matter and minute confervoid growth, pre-
vents their accumulation by removing them ; and by
its vital powers" converts what would otherwise act as
a poison into a rich and fruitful nutriment, again to
constitute a pabulum for the vegetable growth, while
it also acts the important.- part of a purveyor to its
finny neighbours." This perfect adjustment in the
economy of the animal and vegetable kingdoms,
whereby the vital functions of each are permanently
maintained, is one of the most beautiful phenomena
ef organic nature. In the marine aquarium, the pre-
sence of molluscs is as necessary as in the fresh-water
aquarium, to prevent an excessive growth of con
fen a.-, which otherwise soon make the water turbid
witn their innumerable green seeds or spores, and
obscure the glass by establishing themselves upon it
in vast colonies. The common periwinkle, topshell,
and limpet are very suitable for this purpose.
TUB New York Tribune uses the tallest language in
reporting the ceremony of the 4th instant. Mr.
Lincoln's words are recalled as " beautiful and elo-
quent," and " the sad spectacle of a drunken Vice
President" is flung at the back of the out-going
Chief Magistrate. There is not much exaggeration in
this ; indeed, it is not until the Tribune reporter
arrived in the ball room of the Waite House that he
wiitCB " high falutin." Then, possibly the united
effect of the scene and champagne induced him to pen
the following rapturous description of the Inaugural
Ball:-"Thebrilliant scene presented within and with-
out the building, radiant in colour, glowing with light,
brilliant like tropical flowers or the plumage of hum-
ming birds, and ever shifting and varying like a many
hued and constantly-changing kaleidoscope. Fahr faces,
lovely forms, penetrant perfumes diffused as the
brilliant robes moved about their wearers ; distin-
guished men, bearing names renowned in war, states
manship, letters, and the other activities of our
crowding life, clothed in the martial uniform, wearing
the orders and diplomatic insignia of their own
sovereignties, or, better still, in the simple if sombro
dress of the American citizen ; all these and much
more met and mingled here. Great waves of music
puh-ated along the heated and perfumed atmosphere,
and the witching mazes of the dance, and the moro
bewitching forms of the dancers-the ladies of coursa
-with all the brilliancy and beauty of colour and
fe rm, made up a scene worthy of pencil or pen*, yet
both must fail in any attempt to render it fitly."
POSITION OF THE WAK MINISTER.-The Royal
Older which defines the relation of the Commander-
in-Chief to the Queen, the Army, and the War Office^
was published on Saturday. Now that it has been
biought to light, the discovery of the Sangraal should
not be despaired of. Member after member of the
House of Commons has gone in search of it, blun-
dered, gone far astray, lost himself, and then re-
turned to sit down in dumb resignation. The jealousy
with which its official guardians kept their secret, and
their blank complacent look while the representatives
of the public were stumbling about in the dark after
it, vveie admirable in their way, but they are now
things of the paBt. The Order has become
a public document, and now that it is
submitted to the judgment of the country we
expect to hear no more of the dispute whether ^4
the Army is or is not under a dual government.
The Roj al Order, which is dated Balmoral, October,
1861-five years after the Duke of Cambridge had
been appointed to the chief command-defines the
position of his Rojal Highness in no mere incidental
mssner. The purpose for which it was framed is
declared to be "to prevent any doubts as to the
powers and duties of the Commander-in-Chief."
The Order does not, however, set forth what those
powers and duties are, but after staling to what
they relate-the government of the Army and the
administration of military affairs-it directs that
" they ßhall be excepted from the Department of
the Secretary of State for War." A second para-
graph of the Order completes the purpose of the
tim, by strictly appropriating to the Commander
in-Chief all the powers and business relating to the
matters - aforementioned. The latter are "to be
deemed to belong to hiß office," and to be ad
mini&teied, "subject to our (the Royal) general
control over the government of the Army, and to the
responsibility of the Secretary of State." Responsi-
bility for what ? Of course not for the act of the
Commander-in-Chief, whose powers and duties are
excepted from the Department of the Secretary of
State for War, but, as the* Order further explains,
" for the exercise of our Royal prerogative in that -
behalf, and subject to any powers formerly exercised
by the Secretary at War. No words could more
plainly mark out the position of a great and in-
dependent e fficer of the State, who has the power of a
Minister without a Minister's responsibility. We do
not now ask whether this is an objectionable arrange-
ment, or the best that could be made ; we are only
'calling attention to the evidence of the fact. The
meaning and intention of the Older are beyond
doubt, and so far BB they go they are in derogation
of the principle of responsible government which
Englishmen are sSipposed to value highly.-Daily
Neus.
THE DECAY 01 THE HOUSE OI COMMONS.
It is very unsatisfactory to find that before the new
Houses of Parliament have been fully completed, they
are actually decaying in parts ; and the same esti-
mates include votes for the building itself, and for the
appliances to arrest the progress of destruction. The
stone of which it is constructed was taken from a
Yorks!: ire quarry on the recommendation of a com-
mission appointed to inquire into the subject, but
almost immediately after being placed in position, this
particular stone began to shew signB of decay. The
facade of the building was marked by large patches,
and the Gothic tracery of the architecture was sadly
disfigured. So far back as 1857 various processes for
preserving the stone were tried on different parts of the
building, and subsequently Professor Faraday and Sir
Roderick Murchison were requested to give their opin-
ions on the relative merits of such methods. They con-
curred in awarding the pre-eminence to the process
of M. Szerelmy, of which the particulars are, of
course, a secret. Professor Faraday, in his report,
said that so far as a judgment could be formed upon
two years' experience, he believed that the process
would sustain its character for a lengthened period, of
time. '' I do not find," said the learned professor,
"in other parts of the building," where M. Szerelmy'»
application is more than two years old, any signs of
exfoliation, or defection of the prepared face of the
stone, or any grounds for fear in that respect." The
process has been applied with equal success to the
iron of the roof, which was deteriorating at an equally
rapid rate. Part of it had been coated with »ino or
galvanized iron. This had scarcely been fixed when
it showed signs of preihature oxydation. M.
Szerelmy's preparation was applied to one of the
affected parts, and also to the gilding of the clock
tower. On a careful examination last year, it was
found that the portion treated with the preservative
material was perfectly sound, while the rest of the roof
had suffered more or less from atmospheric influences.
The First Commissioner of Works has accordingly
directed that the remainder of the roof should be
covered with the composition. Meanwhile the stone-
work shews signs of disintegration, and there is som«
ground for the anticipation that, so far as external ap-
pearances are concerned, the new Palace at West-
minster will shortly look as ancient as the venerable
Abbey, which reckons as many centuries as Sir
Charles Barry's costly building can reckon years,
M. Szerelmy's process is capable of application to
many kinds of building materials. Experiments have
been tried on stone, brick, iron railings, and timber,
with very gratifying results. Pieces of timber coated '
with the preparation have been sunk for two year» in
he water at Portsmouth, and are now perfectly sound.
Textile fabrics are also rendered waterproof and in-
destructible by it.
Ar-pAux-iNo ENTERTAINMENT.-Mr. Howard Paul,
who is always indulging in some form of eccentric
advertising, announces in the Daily TsUgraph that he
will give JE6 fur a short sharp title for hil Entertain-
ment at St. James's Hall. We will present him with
one end forego the prize. " Cheek ! " That's short
and sharp enough, and in Mr. Paul'« case more or
less appropriate-which cannot be said of all titles.
Quiz.
A Cockney at the Falls of Niagara, when asked
how he liked the Falls, replied-" They're 'antoine
-quite so ; but they don't quite hanser my hexpecta
tions ; besides, I got vetted, and lost my 'at. I pieter
to l9ok at 'em in the ¿engraving, in 'ot weather, and
in the 'ouse." *

title: MOONLIGHT PROMENADE CONCERTS.
content:
MOONLIGHT PROMENADE CONCERTS.
To the Editor of the Herald.
Sm,-Havingbeen present at two ef the above concerts,
and viewing with great pleasure Mr. Gassner's great
exertions in tbe cause of charity, I think that it would
not be out place if the patrons and officers of those
institutions which have received help from the above
source, would tender a complimentary return to Mr.
Gaesner and the members of the band. What I would
venture to suggest is that Mr. G. be asked to prepare
a programme and give a concert, the proceeds of
which to be devoted, either in purchasing a testi-
monial, orto be given in some shape or other to Mr.
G. and his brother musicians.
Hoping this will bring the matter under the notice
of those before mentioned,
I am, Sir, yours, &c,
J. T. B. W.

title: THE LOSS of the BARQUE ONW ARD.
content:
THE LOSS of the BARQUE ONWARD.
' [BY TELEGRAPH.]
(PROM OUR OWN CORRESPONDENT.) . .
* . _ _ BRISBANE, FRIDAY.
Tho A. S. N. Co.'s steamer Yaralla arrived hero this
morning. On her passage from Braodsound to Mackay
iho rescued twelve men witli* a whaleboat, off, Cr
talc, part of tho crow of tho barquo Onward, lost
.on tho 15th September, at Blond's Reef, Now Cale-
donia. They wero twenty days in the whale-
boat, the provisions being biscuits soaked with salt
wator. Sixty hands all-told loft tho wreck in fivo boats,
and thoy' separated on the fourth day, the male,
William Bryant, being in chargo of tho whale-boat.
Tho parly wero beating about in the boat for two days,
looking for Huon Island, and tho other boats, for which
island they wero steering. Bryant was afrnid the bis-
cuits would run short, and thoy ran for the Queensland
coast, crossing tlio Barrier about cast of Bell
Bay and made High Peak Inland. Thoy went into
Port Bowen mid Shoal Water Bay, but" finding no
chanco of relief ran before a S.E. guio and landed on
G Islo on Sunday, tho Oth instant, 6inco
which timo thoy have lived on oysters and
fresh water, of which lhere wero plenty on tho island.
When taken on board Iho men were in a very weak
condition. Heavy rain fell oueo during the passage,
and this enabled them to get a supply of fresh water.
The name-: of the men aro William Bryant, mato;
Thomas Gibb, carpenter; and George Smith, Andrew
Cockrans, ablo seamen ; Samuel Goldsden, ordinary sea-
man, and seven kanakas. Tho number on board the
barquo when lost was thirteen whites and forty-seven
' kanakas.

title: WOMEN IN TURKEY.
content:
"WOMEN IN TURKEY.* .
(From the Times.)
[ Whoever Osman Bey may be, it cannot be denied
that he has written an amusing and instructive book.
His second title, " Major Vladmimir Andrejevioh,"
seems to imply that he is one of those Russian exiles
who, finding their political or social opinions too ad-
vanced for their native country have fled to Turkey,
taken root in her soil, and there flourished. Against
this theory of his foreign origin must be set the fact
that he writes of the Turks as a Turk-an
enlightened one, be it remarked. "Nourri dans
le sérail, j'en connais les détours," he says
of himself - speaking of " our " family,
"our" harem, and "our' slaves as though
he had been to the manner bred; while in one in-
stance, when telling us that it is the nature of that
unhappy class which guards Turkish harems to be
either mild and melancholy, or wild and demoniacal,
he mentions that his mother, being the fortunate
possessor of one of the latter kind, got rid of him and
his malignant presence in her household by making
him a present to one of the Sultanas. For the rest,
Osman Bey seeing to have had powerful protectors
among the Pashas-old H- Pasha (Hafiz Pasha)
having been his great friend - to have been
on the Staff and to have served a great
deal in the precincts of the Sultan's Palace.
Supposing him, therefore, to be a real personage,
which there seems little reason to doubt, Osman Bey
was in a position to know his subject and to be
capable of writing with authority, founded on expe-
rience, on " Women in Turkey." ne can hardly,
indeed, remember the bad old times when the Slave
Bazaar existed as a public institution at Constanti-
nople, when Circassia belonged to Turkey, and when
the fair maidens of that land, were so common as tobe
comparatively cheap. He had a friend, in-
deed, who used to tell him of the old
state of things, a sort of Turkish Legree—Hadji
Abdallah, of Morocco, a venerable ruffian, near a
century old, whose latter days seem to have been
spent in compelling recalcitrant ladies in the various
harems of Stamboul to be better behaved. Slight
cases of this kind he treated on the spot with stick
and whip ; more obstinate offenders he took in hand
at his own house by starvation and dungeons, and
torture; and it was generally remarked that when
these ladies returned they were 'singularly obedient.
One visit to the old Hadji's house was enough, for, as
one of them confessed, she was afraid lest she should
have been buried alive, a little accident which had
often happened in Hadji's dealings with obstinate
ladies. That was what he did towards the end of his
days. His earlier life had been spent in carrying off
slaves in every possible way, begging, borrowing, and
stealing them, and then selling them in the Slave
Bazaar, in which business he had acquired an ample
fortune.
But to return to Osman Bey, as his experience of
Constantinople does not carry him back more than
twenty or thirty years, it is rather of new Turkey
that he writes than of the old. Though he can re-
member the wild justice which even the mild Abdul
Medjid dealt out to one or two of the friskiest
Sultanas and their favourites, the days of the sack
and the bowstring were pretty nearly over before he
knew Turkish life. It is enlightened Turkey that
he describes, and though he handles his native or
adopted country with comparative tenderness, he can
find no enlightenment for Turkey until the two great
plague-spots of the Ottoman system—the degradation
of women and the existence of slavery—have been
healed. Nor let any reader imagine, that his treat-
ment of these two evils is light and trivial. His book
is no prurient collection of anecdotes raked together
from the hotbed of the harem. He begins from the
beginning, and points out the inherent vice of Ma-
homet's system, in which, while recommending true
believers to have but one wife, he permits them to
have four, and even to add to that number innumera-
ble concubines. In a word the Prophet tried to
cure the evils of polygamy as it existed
before his time in the East and failed.
He gave his followers good advice, while he winked
at the bad practices which he denounced. Slavery,
too, he found engrained in the civilization of the East,
and though he ameliorated it so that the lot of slaves
in Turkey, according to Osman Bey, is comparatively
easy, still he permitted it, and there it exists side by
side with polygamy as one of the curses of modern
Turkey. There can be no real enlightenment in a
country, no element of stability in a system which
at one and the same time looks on woman as an inferior
being and regards her as a chattel or plaything, and
keeps large classes of the community in bondage for the
profit of a peculiar class. Until these flagrant wrongs
have been remedied, Osman Bey sees no prospect for the
continuance of the Ottoman Empire, the existence
of which he declares has been only prolonged by the
jealousy of the Great Powers which surround it.
Were it left to itself, it woudd dissolve into as many
fragments as there are nationalities which profess the
Mussulman faith.
Having thus disposed of polygamy and slavery in
principle, Osman Bey, as one who well knows all
the ins and outs of domestic life in Turkey, pro-
ceeds to give a very lively and amusing descrip-
tion of the Turkish household, as shown in the
respective relations of man and wife, or rather of
a man and his wives. Under the instances of Izzed
Bey and Zerah, an imaginary couple, he shows how
a legitimate Turkish marriage-that is, when a young
well-to-do Turk marries a young lady his equal in
social position-comes after all to be very like what
the proverb tell us is the' fate of those who are rash
enough to buy a pig in a poke. When Izzed Bey
informs his mother or best female friend of his desire
to marry, he need trouble himself no further in the
matter till she comes back, and tells him that she has
found in Zera, a moon-faced, plump young lady, the
object of his affections. It may seem absurd, but Osman
Bey declares it to be true, that it is part of the young
Turkish nature to fall vidlently in love on the spot
with this imaginary object, whom Izzed Bey has
never seen and never will really see till the fatal
moment when, in the bridal chamber, he lifts the rose
hued veil and beholds in the object of his affections
either a houri or a ghoul, or, it may be, a nondescript
something between the two. But so it is ; Izzed
Bey is at once enamoured, worships the tip
of his mistress's little finger when poked
out of a lattice, or her eyes as she whirls by
him in a carriage. So the courtship proceeds till
all is settled between the mothers and a handsome
sum paid down by the bridegroom. At last the
happy day arrives, and all the world hastes to the
wedding to behold the bride standing upright,
veiled from head to foot : to admire the presents,
and to make remarks not always complimentary on
the bridegroom, who has to run the gauntlet of the
sharp tongues of all beholders. Thus the day wears
on, until the happy pair are left alone, and Izzed
Bey lifts Zerah's veil, and either discovers that he
is the happy possessor, of charms which, reckoned
in the Turkish fashion, would be worth, if the bride
were a slave, some three or four thousand pounds,
or the unhappy owner of one or those scraggy, very
plain persons who at the same valuation would be
dear at fifty shillings. In the first case it is quite
possible that the union of Izzefd and Zerah may be
long and happy ; in tho last, it is not likely to last
many moons in a country where mere physical
beauty goes for so much, and where the women are
singularly uneducated
But what is to be done, setting beauty on one
side, if what is known in England as incompati-
bility of temper springs up between the new-married
couple ? Are the Turkish mon and wife bound to
live on chained together? Not at all, if it is the
husband's wish. He has only to say, " Get away with
three; banish thee from my house," and the
poor thing must take heeself off there and then and
never darken his doors again. That is the Turkish
law of divorce, and, be it observed , it is not reciprocal.
No woman can repeat the same words and be rid of a
brute of a husband. One right she has which was
made much of by John Stuart Mill—she has the
entire disposal of her property, whether as a wife or
as a divorced woman ; but, as Osman Bey well points
out, the general condition of women in Turkey is so
absolutely one of dependence on the male sex that a
wife can hardly spend her own money without the
consent or assistance of a husband ; and
if divorced finds herself so preyed on by
adventurers that she is forced in self-defence to
find another husband in order to free herself from
their machinations. But, of course, this speedy divorce
between Izzed Bey and Zerah is not common. Every
ill-assorted union in Turkey is not cut short by those
dreadful words. The unhappy pair may still live to-
gether, and the husband, at least, be made happy.
How? By that gloss called polygamy, which accom-
panies the text of the Koran, which recommends all
true believers to have but one wife Izzed Bey, if he
has the will and the means, may have four wives all
at once, and supplement them with as many slaves
as his pocket can procure. Zerah will always be
his "first" wife; but he may take to him another
called "the second," a third called "the middle
one," and a fourth who rejoices in the title of " the
little one," and who, though the last, is usually not the
least in the dear love of her lord. And here arises
one of the great economical objections to polygamy
its expense. Some people in Europe know how costly
Les Femmes en Turquie, par Osman Bey (Major Vladimir
AndreierUlil. P*ds : Catmwi, Levy, and Co. 1878.
one wife can he ; but here, under one and the same
roof, there may be four,-all, be it remarked, with
separate rooms, slaves, and establishments for them
and their children ; all clamouring for fine clothes
and sweetmeats and trinkets, and all expecting
a carriage in which to take the air and
eunuchs on gaily-caparisoned horses to ride
after them. Quite apart from the intrigues of
these ladies against one another, it is clear that
polygamy is a question of money, and at once implies
one law of marriage for the rich and another for the
poor. The ordinary working Turk, if you can sup-
pose so lordly a race ever to work, rubs on with one
wife and a slave or two ; a happier man, no doubt,
than Izzed Bey, who, discontented with Zerah, marks
each step of his rise in life by taking to him a new
wife, until before he is buried himself he may, like
Osman Bey's old patron, Hafiz Pasha, have married
and buried more wives than he could reckon on his
fingers.
And after 'the legitimate wives come the slaves ;
slaves both female and male. As to the first the
Turk hates trouble. But legitimate marriage with
an equal such as we have described in the case of
Izzel Bey and Zerah takes time and trouble. It is
somothing like that heavy form of marriage called
" confarreatio," which got to be so tiresome to Roman
patricians. Why have all this worry when you can
go to some private slave-dealer, for though there is no
slave bazaar, slaves are bought and sold every day at
Constantinople ? Why not go to some modern Hadji
Abdallah and choose for yourself, not at all on the
pig-in-the-poke principle, but by natural selection
face to face ? That is how many of the Turkish
harems are filled with white female slaves, all more or
less valuable in the wife market. It is a horrid
practice, and the Turks ought to blush at it ; only
we remember that young ladies, though, not slaves,
are often bought or sold for wives in other European
countries. As for the male slaves, they are chieily
negroes, and so are the lower female slaves who do
all the hard work in the household, for no Turk
will work if he can help it, and so he must have
slaves. In his own household Osman Bey gives us
an amusing instance of the uselessness of a free
Turkish woman who came in to help. This unfor-
tunate creature was forced to give up the place, be-
cause whenever she had taken off her veil and was
just settling down to her work some man would
pass through the room, when she had at once to
huddle on her veil and turn her back to the in-
truder lest he should behold her face. At last,
in throwing on her veil while she held a lighted
candle in her hand, she set herself on fire, and had
to be put out by Osman Bey himself. The difficulties
of free female labour under such conditions may be
imagined. Our housemaids are bad enough, but what
would they be if they had to jump up and veil them-
selves every other minute lest John or Thomas should
behold their very ordinary faces ? Slaves, therefore,
are necessary to the Turk, both in his marital, his
social, and his domestic relations. They are an institu-
tion, and so long as the present Ottoman system
continues, slaves must form part of the daily existence
of the Turk.
That is, so long as the present Ottoman system con-
tinues, but how long can it be capable of continuing
—we do not say in the recesses of Asiatic Turkey, but
in that portion of the Empire which touches European
civilization, and which, therefore, may and must be
civilized ? The first step to that civilization will be
the emancipation of women from their present thral-
dom ; for, as Osman Bey well insists, " civilization is
the joint work of both sexes, and to degrade the one
is to fetter and prevent the healthy action and energy
of the other." The time has come when the
Turk must look at home, and consider what
he really is if he is to continue any longer
a European Power. He must reform and
remodel his social and domestic relations along with
his political system. It is not a question of religion,
for Mahomet, in spite of his fifteen wives, recom-
mended monogamy to his disciples. Polygamy, too,
as we have seen, is a question of money. Few Turks
.can have more than one wife. If they had, the in-
equality of the sexes would be so great that half the
men in the country would be cutting the throats of
the other half for the sake of their women. But how
is the reform to begin ? Not assuredly by any
of those sham concessions which are so well
exposed by Osman Bey in his book. Poly-
gamy in Turkey will not be extinguished by
any such feeble innovations as what he calls
" Diplomatic Polygamy" inaugurated, we believe, by
Redschid Pasha, by which plan each high functionary
was to have one diplomatic presentable wife who ap-
peared in society, while he retained his other three
old wives in separate retreats near Constantinople.
This, quite apart from its absurdity, resolved itself,
again, at last into a question of expense.
The new reform in Turkish polygamy must begin
where its evils are most apparent, and where it will
produce the greatest effect on the subjects of the
Sultan. That spot is no less than the Seraglio of
the Sultan himself, of which Osman Bey treats
in the third part of his book. In the harem, or
woman's part of the Seraglio, he has never set foot ;
but he knows every corner of the mabein, or male
quarter, of that immense palace, and he does not
hesitate to say that the social and domestic reform
of Turkey must begin within its walls. What with
the harem with its seven classes of Sultanas, from
the Sultana Valide to the Imperial Princesses with
their separate establishments of ladies and eunuchs,
there are not far from 2000 souls in the harem of
the Sultan. Then on the male side, between
buffoons, musicians, eunuchs, cooks, and dwarfs,
the Commander of the Faithful has more than
1000 attendants to wait on him. Fancy 3000
souls and bodies, all extravagant and grasping, and
reckon how many purses it must cost to maintain the
establishment in the Seraglio. One little fact, if it
be a fact, may show how wasteful the Sultan's ways
are. According to Osman Bey, it wouid he con-
sidered high treason against the dynasty of Othman if
the Sultan ever wore any article, of dress twice. From
the fez on his head to the slippers on his feet he must
have new clothes every day of his life. His tailors
must have no sinecure ; and as for the Sultan himself,
how he must suffer from new coats and pantaloons on
every day ; never allowed to keep any article of his
dress till' he can get fond of it ; and then if he be
enlightened to wear shoes, how his feet must be tor-
tured by a new pair every day. His 400 wives and
their quarrels and their children must be bad
enough, but new shoes every day would be worse.
Seriously speaking, all this barbarous and useless
extravagance must be swept away; the Augean
stable of the Seraglio must be cleansed. The new
Sultan will have hard work to make both ends meet
in future. Let him try to effect that useful process
by a reform which has became a necessity for the
preservation of his Empire.
SroJiTiNoLoitE.-The discovery of bows and arrows,
and also the remains of apparently favourite hunting
dogs in the burial-places of the early Celts, seem (the
Gardeners' Magazine remarks) to prove the war that
was waged by our ancestors against the wild animals
which infested the wide British forests, as well as
with the object of obtaining food. History also tells
that it became a pleasurable puisuit with the early
chiefs, nobles, and kings. The country at that date
was filled with such animals as the wolf, bear, boar, wild
cattle, ns well as the deer, wild swine, goats, &c, which
afforded objects of chase. The wolf, it is well known,
was once very common in England. The month of
January was by the Anglo-Saxons called Wolf
monat, as, according to an old writer, " people aro
wont always in that moneth to be more in danger to
be devoured of wolves than in any season els of the
yeare." This animal was looked upon as a type of
courage and ferocity, and, as implying those qualities
which in those days were so highly esteempd, it was
frequently adopted as a name. Thus we find Ethul
wulf, the noble wolf; Berthwulf, the illustrious
wolf, &c. Great pains were taken to exterminate this
dangerous and destructive animal, which appears to
have been first taken in hand by King Edgar, who
commuted the Welsh tribute from gold and silver to
300 wolves' heads. -Edward the First, too, gave re-
wards for their destruction, and, according to Camden,
lands were held by some persons on the tenure of
hunting and killing them. The wild boar was no less
ardently pursije'd. In connection with the boar was
an old supprstrtion that its tusks were hot, and burned
anything which they touched. The heat .of his
teeth was said to inflame any wounds he made,
and burn the hair of the dogs'. Although the hare
was hunted by the ancient Greeks, it was some time
before it became an object of chase with our fore-
fathers, by whom it was considered unclean and unlit
to eat. Ciesar mentions the great numbers of these
animals which he found in Britain. In early times
the fox, whose thieving character had alrcndy ob-
tained for him a bad name, was tiapped, dug out,
speared, or attacked with clubs and arrows, and it
was not till long after that ho obtained the distinction,
of being chased in the modem style.
German Medical Students.- The Official Alma
nack informs us that the number of medical
students entered at the various German schools during
the past year was 0116. Vienna still stands at the
head of the list with 756 students, while Berlin counts
only 281, coming sixth on the list after Prague.
Strasbourg has 222 students ; Heidelberg, 84 ; while
Rostock, the lowest on the list, has -only 34.
Medical Examiner.
i

title: Family Notices
content:
FUNERALS.
THE FRIENDS of the late Mr. HUGH GRESTY
are invited to attend his Funeral ; to move from his
late residence, Church-street, Parramatta, THIS (Friday)
AFTERNOON, 30th instant, at 4 o'clock, JAMES
WILLIS, Undertaker.
THE FRIENDS of Mr. ROBERT HUDSON are
respectfully invited to attend the Funeral of his late
beloved SON, CHARLES RUPERT ; to move from his
residence, No. 92, Buekingham-street, and proceed to the
Ashfield Cemetery, THIS (Friday) AFTERNOON, at
half-past 2 o'clock. C. KINSELA and SONS, Under-
takers, 737, George-street, opposite Christ Church ; 118,
South Head Road, near Crown-street ; and 363, Sussex-
street South, near Oddfellows' Hall.  
THE FRIENDS of Mr. NICHOLAS STAPLETON
are requested to attend the Funeral of his infant
SON; to move from Victoria-street THIS DAY (Friday),
at half-past 3 p.m.
