title: The Sydney Morning Herald.
content:
. Ofce Ssönca iWornítts jQerattu
THURSDAY, OCTOBER 5, 1871.
THE terrible events of Paris have set all
persons accustomed to inquire into the causes
of things to endeavour to expound those which
Have led to this fearful episode in the history
of civilization. The strength of the rebellion
and the destruction which it wrought, the
terrible sacrifice of life in its suppression,
and the apparent reappearance of its elements
in another form, have filled the world with
wonder and with alarm. "Where is it all to
end?
The highest form of civilization existing in
Europe has, by common consent, been attri-
buted to Paris. The moat perfect examples
of skill, both in science and in art, have been
furnished by its population. It was the most
beautiful city, and had the greatest range of
pleasures of every kind, and in the most perfect
order. Europe received from the French
theatre its popular plays, It received from
the same source its universal fashions. Luxury
pf all kinds was carried to the highest per-
fection in Paris. Nowhere was the art of
cookery capable of producing such diet. In no
'country could all the adornments of the house,
of the person, of the table, be so readily
'assembled. The rich people of eveiy nation
hastened to Paris to partake of these splen-
dours and these pleasures, which continued
throughout the season without intermission.
The citizens of this great metropolis of gaiety
and enjoyment looked with complacency on the
. gathering of all people to pay homage to their
intelligence, skill, and boundless resources.
.Those who look back two or three years to
'what Paris was-say, when the Great Exhibi-
tion attracted all the world-and what Paris
has become, may well be stunned with aston-
ishment or moved with pity. All this
splendour and plensure passed away, and the
city finally fell under the power of its loweßt
inhabitants, who endeavoured to gain its con
tiol, to subject its wealth, its intelligence, its
refinement, all it possessed, to a domination
which, when embodied in the persons of
ihose who wielded it, strikes the mind with
absoluta terror.
A splendid paper has been contributed to
the Revue des Deua Mondes, by M. E. CAKO,
on one phase of this great phenomenon,
entitled, " The End of Bohemia, or the lite-
rary Influences in these Last Events.*' This
treatise attributes the Communist Revolution
to the ascendancy of that class created by the
refinements and the yicissitudes of the great
city. A Bohemian signifies, in French phrase,
a writer living by ephemeral literature, an in-
ferior artist of any kind, a member of the
medical or legal orders without patients or
clients.-any person, in short, thrown upon
the casualties of a calling, and dependent
day by day upen the fluctuating success of a
profession. It is from this class have arisen
the writers who have corrupted, or at least
expressed the ¡corruption of, Parisian society.
I They are principally persons who have no
recognised position, no established reputation,
who live day by day having this question
continually recurring, Where shall we dine, and
how shall we pay for our meal ? They live on
the margin of society, in isolation. They are
devoured by envy. Their chances are an
election to the academy of France, or a place in
the hospital or^in the morgue. These persons,
having no recognised status in society, have
made themselves the expounders of every senti-
ment which divides and corrupts it. They
have produced a literature only copied faintly
| in the English publications. All the bad
passions of mankind have been analysed and
laid open in the mocking tone of those who share
them, who have boasted of them, and who haye
been destroyed by them. They have professed
no moral principle, they have offered no ideal,
they have animuted no effort for the improve-
ment of mankind. They have put, without
disguise, the defects and disordeis of society
into the language of derision, and, while they
have lessened the respect for human nature
as a whole, they ha\e been equally opposed to
all those institutions which have been de-
signed to raise the fallen and solace the dis-
tressed. Their lessons have been intended to
excite a hatred against the persons of men, an
envy of their good fortune, and of those
superiorities which arise from knowledge or
industry. The only tone in which they have
been known to addiess the unhappy portions
of society has been calculated not to relieve
but to exasperate their resentment. They
have said to the vicious that they have been
made so by the organization of society; to
those who have found it difficult to live, that
the rich have taken away their natural right to
their portion in this world. All that society
has secured by united labour foi the go»d of
the State has been treated as deductions from
the daily enjoyment of the workman. The
employers of labour have been always spoken
of as criminals, who are joined together in con-
spiracy against the operatives.
The consequence of thiB kind of "education,
continued for twenty years under the shadow
of an Imperial system, was to produce a fixed
hatred of everything that existed and a
desperate determination to reverse, to over
tlnow, and to sweep all that had been ex-
hibited as the representative of wealth or dis-
tinction. It is this literature which has found
in tiie daily Press a full development for the
last two years. The relaxation of the
laws and the fall of the Empire gave
still fuller scope for these opinions.
The conduct of many prominent persons
afforded the text of satire and denunciation.
During the siege of Paris the clubs were j
ruined, and the Bohemian class made them the
medium of their propagandism. Men, women,
and children attended these assemblies, and
the most extravagant oratory found the
warmest reception. There were two classes of
speakers. Commonly the orators of the work-
ing class had somo degree of sincerity. But the
old leaders weie mete actors ; they were
. obtaining a living or a place without any
faith in the principles which they proclaimed.
They had experienced a long trial of patience.
Their contribution* to the Press could not in
ordinary times provide them with bread. The
revolution carne lo float them upon the surface.
When the Commune was proclaimed they
seized its guidance. They appropriated
the profits upon which they could
lay their hands, and, without believing in the
permanence of anything, turned to present
account the wild rage of those who were
incapable of discerning their delusions. The
number of men of this class who assumed
omeo in the Commune was remarkable. They
had a degree of education, of science, and
knowledge of society, but they had long been
nmong the disinherited. What a change,
then, to become, even for three months, the
dignitaries of a great city, and to command
an army of 100,000 men.
A remarkable development of the Commune
was the prominence it gave to some female
politicians. The emancipation of woman was
a grand cry. Lectures were delivered and
journals published by them in this interest.
The incidents of the last revolution show how
frightful was the demoralisation of Communist
women. i
Among the stimulants of mischief with
which the Bohemian had been long familiar
is to be reckoned the use of absinthe. This
dangerous liquor produces a special kind of
frenzy more pernicious than ordinary spirits,
and more maddening than opium. It is im-
possible to say how far even this agent of
human degradation is responsible for the crimes
of the revolution.
The author attributes the character of this
insurrection to the utter absence of religious
principle in the Bohemian class. While the
savons and philosophers have been propound-
ing the doctrines of atheism in elegant lan-
guage, and as the means of liberating the
mind from all prejudices, the lower classes
of writers have accepted their conclusions, and
surrounded them with all the decorations of
an obscene literature. Every excitement to
the indulgence of the passions has been pro
¡ duced in their writings ; and their whole
s) stem - has been based on negations. Is
there a GOD? No. Is there a future
state'? No. IS there a soul? No. Is
there responsibility for tinknown actions'?
There is none. Is theie any compensation
for patient suffering? Never. Is there any
reason for the relations of social life ? No
These have been the set of principles with
which Communism has started There are
numbers who have professed to substitute
others for them ; but these at present have
remained in all their deadly influence, and
havö shown themselves in the terrible events
of this last civil war.
AN , interesting discussion took place a few
.months ago in the Ilouse of Commons in
relation to harbours of refuge on the English
coast. The question involved the considera-
tion of a large variety of facts, commercial,
humanitarian, and national. The debate arose
on a motion by Lord C. J. HAMILTON, whose
object was to obtain a grant of public
money for the construction of a harbour of
refuge at Filey in Yorkshire. The policy
of making further grants of public money
to construct and improve harbours of refuge
on the coasts of Great Britain and Ireland
had been the subject of inquiry and solici-
tation during the previous fourteen years.
A committee recommended that national money
should be granted for the construction
of harbouis of refuge, and that funds
should also be voted towards the extension
and improvement of existing harbours. It
was also proposed that a commission of
inquiry should -visit the coast for the pur-
pose of inquiry. This was delayed by
change of Government ; but the commis-
sioners having been appointed, brought up
a report recommending that £2,365,000
should be granted, with loans at a low
tate of interest for harbours, on condition
that cci tain stated local suma should be
raised to meet the national grants. These
facts were stated by Lord HAMILTON, who
also gave an account of the numerous
attempts which had been made in vain to
give practical effect to the report of the
commissioners, which, however, was opposed
on the ground that it was " altogether too
sweeping." Mr. MILNER GIBSON, when Pre-
sident of the Board of Trade, incurred con-
siderable odium by his opposition, and when
sailors were drowned on the coast, there
were those who did not hesitate to speak
of the widows of those unfortunate
seamen, as " MILNER GIBSON'S widows."
Attempts to induce the House to adopt the
report of the commissioners were renewed in
each session from 1862 to 1865, and the sub-
ject was revived in 1866 and 1869, but without
any results satisfactory to its promoters.
Among the commercial facts adduced during
the debate it was stated that the trade was
most extensive on the north-east coast, and
that its harbours were barred, and there-
fore not approachable at all tides. It was
ghen in e-vidence that the entire tonnage of
British sailing vessels clearing coastwise from
ports in England was 8,162,000 tons ; coast
wajs and foreign together, 15,796,00<>; and
that the annual loss to the nation by wrecks
ivas a million and a half sterling. But since
that e\idcnce was given there had been a very
laige increase in the foreign as well as in
the coasting trade. The total foreign and
toasting trade in 1857 was 23,178,782 tons
(Blitish ships), or an average per month
of 1,931,565 tons. But in February of the
present year, the total foreign and coasting
trade was 5,156,000 tons. Taking the coasting
trade only there was a considerable increase
shown. In 186-9, the coasting trade for the
month of February showed 2,587,000- tons.
In February, 1871, it represented 2,684,900
tons. Lord HAMILTON, speaking of the
fisheries on the coast, quoted from the report
oí the Commissioners of Fisheries in 1866,
to show that the annual value of the fisheries
on the east coast was £2-,000,000, and that
"the north-east coast fisheries were of the
same extent as the supcrfitial area of
Ireland, and were annually increasing in
value to the extent of £10,000 per
annum." The Boaid of Trade re-
turn showed, iL that the number of re-
gistered fishing boats in England was 16,195,
representing 127,013 tons, and employing
I 47,290 men, and 7467 boys."
These figures, indicating the large commercial
interest at stake, were not disputed, and facts
were given te show how gieat are the advan-
tages which may be expected from an improve-
ment of the harbours on the coast. As in this
colony in regard to railways, so there appears
to have been in the House of Commons on
this matter much local rivalry, and
the question divided itself into two main
branches - first, as to the expediency
of spending large sums of money on one
harbour of refuge, when (it was arguod)
" unless '.they were multiplied almost ad
wßnitum they would be of very little use;" |
and, second, as to how far Government
assistance ought to be extended towards the
improvement of harbours. It was stated by
one member that the Government had advanced
money on easy terms to the Tyne Harbour
commisioners. Another observed that the
sum of £1,600,000 had been spent during the
last few years in improving the approach to
the Tyne Uiver so as to render it a good
harbour of refuge ; that most of the
money was made a local charge ; and
that, in consequence of the improvements
effected, a herring fishery had been estab-
lished there. By an Act passed in 1861,
money may be granted for harbour improve-
ments on condition that it be repaid, with
interest, in twenty years. The Tyne Harbour
commissioners had availed themselves of
these harbour loans; but it was remarked
that they had not done so to such an ex
lent as they would otherwise have been
glad to do had the interest not been in-
creased. They obtained £100,000 at 3J per
cent., and another £100,000 at 3.J per cent. ;
but the Government after that refused to
lend to them at less than 5 per cent.,
and the commissioners became reluctant to
borrow on those terms.
From a national standpoint it was argued
that Filey ought to bo made a harbour of
refuge. It was contended that the events
of the past few months had altogether
altered the military position of the country;
that England had now to look for danger
norn the East, and that therefore the |
construction of a naval station on the east
coast was a matter of serious moment. It
was also remarked by the mover that
Filey was recommended by the committee of
1857 from a strategetical point of view-1
that it would be good as a look-out, and
safe for shipping in time of war. Several
authorities were quoted showing the import-
ance of a naval station on the east coast,
and these were supplemented by arguments
based on local considerations.
The humanitarian reasons urged recall the
dangers and sacrifices annually made in the
cause of commerce and navigation - the
terrible disasters which occur to vessels baffled
by winds and unable to weather rocky
points - ships with torn sails and broken
masts left to the fury of a gale - the
foundering of vessels unable to find a
pott of refuge, and long lines of coast
black with wreck. The members were
reminded of " scenes of agony which
beggared description," and certainly the loss
of life shown is most lamentable. All this
was admitted by the Government. Mr.
GLADSTONE quoted from a Parliamentary
paper the number ©f shipwrecks which had
occurred during eleven years, showing that
1480 lives had been lost on the south coast,
1240 on the north coast, and 2772 in the
Irish Sea. But the inference he drew from
the figures was, that there was no
material différence to be traced be-
tween those portions of the coast which
had harbours of refuge, and those which had
not. The policy of the Government was
clearly stated to be in favour of an improve-
ment in the mercantile marine, and it was
held that a reckless plan for a wholesale
creation of bar-harbours would have the effect
of retarding that improvement. It was argued,
however, on the other side, that much re-
mained yet to be done, inasmuch as it could'
not be denied, in the face of wrecks so
numerous, that many ships went to sea in
an unsafe condition.
But the most fatal objection to the propo-
sition appeared to be its local- application ;
and upon this point Mr. GLADSTONE and
Mr. LOWE spoke out boldly. The former
said he could not do otherwise than euter
his protest against local propositions of the
kind, " because they were a fruitful source
of political demoralization." Mr. LOWE said :
-" The noble mover did not propose to fol-
low the general spirit of the recommendation
of the Commission, but picked out one iso-
lated point, with respect to which the Consoli-
dated Fund was to contribute all, and local
resources nothing. A more fatal blow, not
only at the Exchequer, but at the reputation
of that House, could not be imagined. He
had some experience on such a point. He had
been a member of a Colonial Assembly, the
greatest part of the time of which was taken
up in discussing measure» such as the noble
lord now proposed, involving the application
of general revenue to local purposes, such as
the making of a road in one place, or the con-
struction of a railway in another. The main
time of the Legislature was occupied in that
most discreditable manner, and he, therefore,
ventured from practical experience to warn
the House not to encourage such motions as
the present, for it would find no course so
injurious to the respect and estimation it
should be held in by the 'public as countenanc-
ing the grant out of the general revenue of the
country of money to be expended for local
purposes."
TUB SYDNEY MONTHLY OVERLAND MAIL.
The Summary of colonial DOWS for transmission to
Europe by the Btoomship Kaugoon will bo published in this
journal to-uiorrow (Friday) morniagi tho Cth instant.
Advertisers are particularly requested to send in their
favours early this (Thursday) ovening. Alterations ia
advertisements ordered for more than one insertion mast
be sent in before G p.m. this day, Thursday.
TUB HERALD SUMMARY.-Orders- for extra
copies should be lodged with the ohirk at tho counter, this
(Thursday) ovening. Our friends from the country are
reminded that orders to post for England will bo too lato

LARRIKINS AT PADDINGTON.-Under this
head a correspondent complains that on arriving, at the
Church ef _tagla_d school OB Monday noising to com-
mence business as usual, he found the windows of a
recently erected lavatory " thoroughly guttoi/'-" an
offering doubtless to the goddess of muoblof. There is
some ambiguity about Hie epistle. The operation of
"thoroughly gutti-g" a window requires explana-
tion, and what tho " offering " to the " god-
dess of mischief " oouM have boen, is not very olear ; bat
the letter as a whole leads to the inference that semothing
ought to bo done to suppress "larriHnism" at Padding-
ton. No doubt the Inspector-General of Police, it he fully
realise the force of the sent-loe, will give an emphatio ne-
gative to the inqniry of our correspondent ; " must wo
pale our inefloctual tiro, before cowardly doapotio ruülan
ism ï "

title: Family Notices
content:
Funerals.
THE FRIENDS of Mr. JOHN ABBOTT are respect-
fully invited to attend the Funeral of his late beloved SON,
Cecil Osgar John Abbott, to move from his residence, Parra-
matta Road, Homebush, THIS SATURDAY, at 2 o'clock, to
proceed to the Homebush Station, thence to the Necropolis. J.
and G. SHYING and CO., Undertakers, 140, L'pool & Oxford sts.
THE FRIENDS of Mr. DANIEL KERRIGAN are
respectfully invited to attend the Funeral of his deceased
beloved wife WIFE, Emma ; to move from his residence, Kerrigan-
terrace, Eveleigh-street, Chippendale, THIS AFTERNOON, at
2 o'clock, to Necropolis. THOMAS, Undertaker, 111, York-
street.
THE FRIENDS of the Rev. F. HIBBERD are in-
formed that the Funeral of his fifth DAUGHTER, Emma
Elizabeth, will take place THIS (Saturday) AFTERNOON, at a
quarter-past 2 o'clock, from his residence, 263, Elizabeth-street,
and proceed to the Necropolis. WALTER STEWART.
THE FRIENDS of Mr. JOHN HALLINAN are res-
pectfully invited to attend the Funeral of his deceased be-
loved WIFE, Catherine, THIS (Saturday) AFTERNOON ; to
move from his residence, Ultimo-street, off Bay-street, at half-
past 2 o'clock, to the Petersham Cemetery. T. DIXON, Under-
takers, 25, Oxford-street.
THE FRIENDS of Mr. JOHN BRADY, Royal Albert
Hotel, George-street North, are respectfully invited to
attend the Funeral of his beloved SISTER, Catherine Hanlan ;
to move from her late residence, No. 8, Ultimo-street, off Bay-
street, at 2.30 p.m., SATURDAY, the 4th December, 1880.
THE FRIENDS of the late Mr. JAMES McLAUGH-
LIN are respectfully invited to attend his Funeral, to move
from his late residence, George-street, Petersham, THIS
SATURDAY, at half-past 3 o'clock, for the Catholic Cemetery,
Petersham. J. and G. SHYING and CO., Undertakers, 747,
George-street South; and 140, junction of Liverpool & Oxford sts.
THE FRIENDS of Mr ADRIAN HOOK are re-
spectfully invited to attend the Funeral of his late beloved
DAUGHTER, Eva Lavinia ; to move from his residence, No. 29,
Gloucester-street, TO-MORROW, Sunday, at 1 o'clock, for the
Necropolis. J. and G. SHYING, and CO., Undertakers, 747,
George-street South ; and 140, junction of Liverpool & Oxford sts.
THE FRIENDS of Mr. ALEXANDER SMAIL are
invited to the Funeral of his SON, Sydney Robert ; to move
from his residence, Kent-street North, on SUNDAY AFTER-
NOON, at a quarter-past 1 o'clock, for Necropolis. WALTER
STEWART.
THE FRIENDS of JAMES, JOHN, WILLIAM, and
GEORGE SMAIL are respectfully invited to attend the
Funeral of their NEPHEW, Sydney ; to move from his parents'
residence, 113, Kent-st., on SUNDAY next, at quarter-past one.
THE FRIENDS of Mr. HENRY E. WHITBREAD
are respectfully invited to attend the Funeral of his late be-
loved SON, Walter Dawson ; to move from his residence, No.
?61, George-street West, TO-MORROW, Sunday, at a quarter-
before 2 o'clock, for the Necropolis. J. and G. SHYING and
CO., Undertakers, 747, George-street South.
THE FRIENDS of GEORGE and JOSEPH HALL
are respectfully invited to attend the Funeral of their beloved
FATHER, Thomas Hall, of Burwood, late of Richmond, which
will leave the Infirmary on SUNDAY, at half-past 1.
THE FRIENDS of Mr. WILLIAM GLENN are re-
spectfully invited to attend the Funeral of his late beloved
SON, Harold Atkin ; to move from his residence, 6, Walker-street,
Redfern, TO-MORROW (Sunday) MORNING, at a quarter to 9
o'clock, to Waverley Cemetery. W. and H. KINSELA, 118,
Oxford-st, near Crown-st., and George-st., opp. Christ Church.

title: BONADA.
content:
i l BONADA. ' , , (
I frnOM A' COIIRBSFONDENT.] ' ' ' I
[ BARTON'S BEEF.--Since-my last report a new'rhÀnàger
has been appointed for Barton's Reef Gold Mining Co.,
end tie work teems to be pushed ahead with some vigour,
'i hey are still getting splendid stone from the 40 foot lovel.
The company aro ulse erecting] a battery of six head'of
stamps ;, tho machinery is nettly all on ; the ground; it is
expected to bo at work in about a month's time, [
We understand McsBrs. Cox' and Rouso havo purchased
a fourth of M'Clymont and party's ground (16'acres).
Ihey intend putting m a tunnel to cut tho roof at j st dopth
of about 300 feet. Carter and party are still raising fiist
class stone. On account of tho bad state bf the reads they
bave been unable to get their stone into the barks, so that
they havo postponed their crushing for an indefinit« period,
'lhey aro down to a depth of 43 'feet The reef has
increased in thickness very muoh, averaging. 2 feet, and
showing gold as freely as ever. J( " ,i
Holioid and party, adjoining, are still sinking. for the
reef, and have every indication of cutting it oro long. '
No. 1 North, Smith and party, aro still driving at a dopth
of 67 feet, lhey havo cut several leaders, and expect to cut
the main reef in other 3 feet at most. .,
No. 2, Campbell and patty, are idle.
Goninon's Reef.-The prospectors are still vigorously
Sushing forward the work. They aro now about 60'feet
eep ; broke down about 4 tons of stone to-day, averaging
fully 20 inches in thickness, and showing an encollent
prospect, lhey ore also putting in a tunnel along the reef
to the south at a dopth of 40 feet, and are in about 26
feet.
{ No. 1 North, after being at a standstill for a month,
resumed work about three weeks ago, but havo not brokon
down any stone yet. > '
i Reports aro nfo of maohinery being shortly to be erected
on this reef, but of which I cannot speak definitely. I trust
in my next to be able to give you moro particulars.
' 4tfi July. r I

ST. LEONARDS ESTATE,
Amuri district, Nelson, adjoining Canterbury.
No. 1.-Tho HOMESTEAD Block, about 24,446 acres ;
of this about 4111 ncies aro subdivided into 19 pad-

The plantations of conifers and hardwood, mixed, cover

The garden is about 3 acres, .ind* well stocked with fruit

About 80,000 young foi est trees have been reared, and

On this block aro erected tho manager's house of 10

No. 2.-THE KAIWARRA Block, about 19,189 acres;

garden.

No. 3.-THE HURUNUI Block, about 6851 acres;
enclosed within fences, and the Hurunui Riyer.

lish grass.

No. 4.-THE PAHAU Block, about 5675 actes.
A considerable portion of this block is rich swamp, 120
acres of which have been ciopped with oats, and aro now

lish grass (once ploughed), tho remainder being drained and
sown with grass.
A paddock of about 180 acres is fenced off, tho rest of the
block being undivided.
There is an excellent stockyard on this block, and a
thriving plantation of about 8 acres.
Stock-about 4000 sheep.
No. 5-SHEARING PADDOCK Blook, about 4094
acres, all enclosed in a ring fence ; 50 acres have

No. 6-i-ISOLATED HILL Block, about 17,722 acres.

No. 7-MOUNT PALM Block, about 11,935 acres;
sheepyards used for drafting largo flocks erected on
this block.
Stock-9000 sheep.
No. 8-NORTH CAPE Block, about 1610 acres, of
which about 650 acres have been ploughed and sown
with English grass ; 150 acres swamp drained and
sown, and 100 acres swamp partly undrained.'
Stock-2000 cross-bred sheep.
No. 9-SOUTH CAPE Block, about 796 acres, of which
about 350 acres havo been ploughed and sown with
grass, and 100 acres aro rich swamp, drained and
sown.
Thero is a ploughman's hut of 2 looms, and 4-horse
stable; also a plantation of 3 acres on thisfclock.
Stock-1000 cross-bred sheep.
AGRICULTURAL FARMS.
There aro 19 of these, varying in si¿e from MO acres, 150,
200, up to 500 acres of splendid rich soil, and -well worthy
the attention of agriculturists, and investors desirous o'f
securing really cood properties. The settlement of the
district now taking place, and which will bo much increased
on the extension of the railway, must in a very short time
greatly enhance the value of property.
27 SUBURBAN LOTS, adjoining the township of
Rotherham, varying in extent from 3 to 15 acres.
115 BUILDING SEC 1TONS.-TOWNSHIP OF
ROTHERHAM.
Tho site of this township has been fixed in an excellent
position to secure the benefit of the greatest traffic; it
possesses many natural advantages for contre of population,
and w11 doubtless becomo a placo of considerable im-
portance.
Torms-One-third cash, balance in six equal annual pay-
ments, bearing interest at tho rate of 7 per cent, per annum,
payable half-yearly.

title: THE CRISIS AT CONSTANTINOPLE,
content:
THE CRISIS AT CONSTANTINOPLE,
I -'?
(Trum the Special Corrcsjmnlent of the Standard.) \
TUE European Consuls have been so profoundlj' im-
pressed by the misery of the refugees, who are
crowded together in Constantinople, and are, more-
over, so apprehensive that the epidemics which
have already made their appearanco amongst us
will increase in intenbity and fatality, that they
haye met for the purpose of considering how the
existing and yet impending evils niny best be
averted. It is believed that they will urge the
Government to adopt some such plan as that which
1 am about to describe. They will recommend that
for the purpose of restoring the refugees to their
homes, or where that cannot be done, for the purpose
of sending them into Asia, the Government shall
obtain an advance of from £200,000 to £250,000 from
the local bankers ; and that with a view to give the
local bankers due security for the repoj-roent of the
advance, tilo dutj' on all goods passing through the
Custom-house shall he raised from 8 per cent.-the
present uniform rate-to 10 per cent., the additional
2 per cent, being applied to the payment of the
adv ance. They will also propose that the »um raised
for tile benefit of the refugees Bhall ho administered
bj- a mixed European Commission. The scheme is
excellent. The additional tax is not great, and it
woidd bopaid chiefly by the well-to-do classe». The
money raised would be well and even remuneratively
expended, since it would be expended in the transport
of labour to the fields which are almost denuded of
those who should till them. Constantinople would
thus be relieved of a very great aud pressing danger.
But I do not think it is at all probable that
the scheme can he carried out. The existing
Customs duties are established under treaties with
foreign Powers, and even if European diplomacy
could be induced to reconsider those treaties
with a view to their amendment, it would
hardly complete its task in the lifetime of the
refugee». I fear that to the greater part of these un-
fortunates the grave alone can bring relief. I see
much of them, and the more I see of them, the more I
am impressed by their patient, and even cheerful,
resignation under trials which daily become more and
more intense. The situation is always becoming worse,
for the conduct of the Bulgarians is such that none of
the Mahometan refugees will return to their homes,
whilst most of the Moslems who have not already left
Bulgaria, aro preparing to fly from the brutality of the
Slavs. In addition to this, an exodus is now
taking place from Epirus and Thessaly, so we aro
likely to be overwhelmed by a fresh crowd of 'fugi-
tives. Meanwhile, the Porte continues to bring fresh
recruits to the capital, in which, and in the neighbour-
hood of which, there are now one hundred and eighty
battalions of Turkish soldiers.
The dissensions among the Ministers have arisen to
such a height that the Administration is paralysed,
and nil business stands still, while the partisans of
Russia and those of England struggle for the
mastery. I ara told that yesterday the Council had
under consideration n fresh Note from Russia,
making a final demand for the strategical position»
described in my previous letters, and that it had
also under consideration a counter Note from
England, protesting against the cession of these
positions to Russia, and stating that if they were
ceded it would he necessary to take immediate
measures for the protection"of English interests
against the combined hostility of Turkey and Russia.
The Council could como to no decision with regard to
these note», and when it broke up Mehmed Ruchdi,
who has recently been made a Minister without a
portfolio, and who is expected bj- some to replace
Ahmet Vefyk, proceeded to the Sultan to inform him
of the subject which the Council had had under con-
sideration. The Sultan, in the hope of gaining time,
proposes to ask the mediation of the French Ambas-
sador, but the strategical positions which Russia and
England demand are so important to cither nation,
that the mediation of the French Ambassador is net
likely to be effectual. At the same time, the conduct
of Austria gives the Porte other causes for uneasiness,
Austria demands to be allowed to occupy Bosnia and
the Herzegovina, avhere the insurrection has assumed
dangerous proportions, and is preparing to move her
troops. The Porto refuses the required permission,
and throws on Austria the responsibility of the
disastrous consequences which must follow from the
occupation. This, however, is not likely to prevent
the occupation. Lastly, Italy is taking a very
lively inteicst in the insurrection in the Greek pro-
vinces, and is showing phainly her fixed determina-
tion to be present when the time arrives for the
partition of Turkey. Under these circumstances, the
Russian party gains strength &»ily, and -will probably
triumph. The Sultan and the Pachas are clinging,
naturally enough, to their capital, and will do any
thiiiE it only tiley may retain their hold upon it.
Apparently the Russians are far f rombeing unwilling to
allow the Sultan to have a further tenure of power in
Constantinople, and they are thus in a position to bid
attractively for a Turkish alliance.
I had written thus far when the news was brought
to me that all Mr. Layard's efforts to maintain Ahmed
Vefyk in power have failed. Sadyk Pacha is named
Prime Minister, andtheSheikK-id-Islamhas asobeen'
replaced by Molah Bay. It seems to me that these
changes point to a Russian, alliance., and.» Hussion,
(occuja&ujjfionstantmctDleA.'.,

title: MILL'S DISSERTATIONS AND DISCUSSIONS.
content:
MILL'S DISSERTATIONS AND DISCUSSIONS.
{From the London Review.)
ONE of the most remarkable facts which the
historian of the future must take into account
in estimating the forces that have governed
progress in our age and country is, in spite of
Mr Buckle, the individual influence of a great
man. At whatever department of thought we
glance, we distinguish, by comparison with the
conditions of twenty years ago, the unmis-
takable stamp of one mind. Within the period
named, the experiential school of philosophy,
which had almost disappeared from the country
of Locke, driven out by a crude deluge of
German transcendentalism, has been raised
almost to scientific perfection, has been formu-
lated, criticised, cleared of obscurities. In-
ductive logic, since Bacon's time practically
regnant in England, has vindicated as well a just
philosophical supremacy The great problems
of social and intellectual freedom have been
boldly shaped into a grand code of tolerance, to
which even bigots are now compelled to yield
at least a lip worship Among our public men
and writers a broader view of responsibilities,
class pretensions, and national claims has begun
to prevail Both in theoretical and practical
politics the narrow selfishness, which aped
Utilitarianism but was really its antithesis, has
been to some extent discarded and now, if we
have not quite escaped the taint of party bitter
ness in political discussion,we have at all events
the gratification of seeing that the number is
ever increasing of thinkers and even statesmen,
who set philosophy above intrigue and petty
private interests On the whole we are
justified in the boast - though we see
more promise as yet than performance
that this generation is less the slave of
prejudices and formulas, more earnest, more
thoughtful, more logical than that which imme-
diately preceded it It would be difficult to
over-estimate the share in this distinct and
welcome advance which is due to the personal
influence of Mr John Stuart Mill.
Mr Mill's earlier appearances as an anony-
mous wrnter were of a very varied kind
Poetry, history, and fiction, were among the
subjects of his keen impartial criticism But
after the publication of his great works on
political economy and logic, wc find that he
limits his labours to the severer walks of study,
in which he has become illustrious is an
authority 'Hie third volume of his collected
essays, which lies before does not include
any enuc d discussions such as these on Alfred
de Vigmy in the first volume, and on Michelet's
History of France in the second Politics and
metaphysics divide tins latest republication of
Mr Mill's periodical writings Under the
former he id ni ty be included the valuable papers
"'Thoughts on Parliamentary Reform," and
"Kettnt Writers on Reform," winch appeared
during tht discussions attenelant on the appear-
ance ol Mr Disraeli's Bill of 18V), as also ' A
Few Words on Non-intervention," and " Hie
Contest in Amené i," rejinnted from /Vene; t
JUai/tizitir 'Hie el.iboi ite and exhaustive
criticism on ' Vustin s Lectures on Juris
piudcncc" occupies to s0nie extent a neutral
ground between the foregoing strictl) political
et-sajq, and the two importint contributions to
mental science whim lorni pirt of the same
volume-tin disstnations on Ham's Pi)clio
log)," and " Grotc's Plato '
The governing principle of all Mr Mill's
teaching, whether in polities, in social science,
or in philosophy, may be fairly descrubed as an
enlightened and systematised individualism li
we assume, »t is tlie almost tinivcrsjl custom
with Englishmen, that any attempt to base
society on the idea of fraternity must be per
nicious. and is to be denounced as Socialist and
revolutionary, we shall find in Mr Mill's system
the most admirable type of modern develop
ment Where the political economy of others
is hard anti narrow, his takes a broader view,
and docs not arrogate an irrational dominion
over the higher instincts of human nature
Thus we find that ulonc, after Adam Smith, Mr
Mill has put Ins favourite science into i form
not repulsive to those bene'olent aspirations
which no science can extinguish in man In
the same way he has softened down the harsher
traits of the utilitarian philosophy, as it derived
itself from Bentham In politics, the tin
Radicalism of his fathtr, James Mill, and his
school, has been vivified and informed with i
new soul by that noble chapter in the " Political
Economy ' on ' '1 he Probable Futurity of tne
Labouring Classes, ' by the " Essay on Liberty,
and the ' Representative Government" And
those students ol mental philosophy who wotilel
have rejected the gross materialism of Hartley
and Condillac can recognise in the refutation
of Hamilton a metaphysical theory which
neither revolts the logical sense nor the
spiritual nature It is this apt combination of
the strictest principles of individualism with a
generous enthusiasm for everything that is just
and noble, which has gained for Mr Mill his
wide and potent sway over the mind of
England Resting as that sway does, on the
free allegiance of the mest enlightened and the
most ardent spirits among the younger genera
tion of Englishmen, it must, beyond question,
be extended and strengthened with mere lapse
of time How far this philosophy can be con
sidered an ultimate growth admits of more
doubt It ein only be supplanted, however, ii
at all, by a system based on the solidarity of
mankind, and on theories which only a few
thinkers in this country regard as other than
hopeless unattainable dreams
Almost cvtiy page of ihe volume befoie us
furnishes us with in example of Mr Mills
power over opinion To him is due the grow-
ing interest felt by the public in Mr. Hare's
scheme of personal representation, and the
glowing toleration accoided to its discussion
'lins plan is very cekariy the very apothcosis of
individuihsm in the domain of practical politics,
and, as such, will never meet with the approval
of those who regard rather the action of the
popular will through masses than the divlsion of
the State into little groups of personal interests
It is so very improbable that we can go so far in
the wat of recasting our institutions as to adopt
Mi Hare's ingenious machinery, that the ques
tion is practically taken out of the sphere of
useful debate, since we believe even Mr Mill
himself, in bringing it under the nonce of the
House of Commons, rather desires to assert
the principle than hopes to establish the
actual change A more real benefit, in our
present effort to complete some satisfactory
representative Reform, may be derived from
Mr Mill's sensible statement of the advantages
of grouping, in a redistribution of seats Wh lt
ever ma) be the fate of the fianeluse clauses of
the present Government Bill, no one believes
that Mr Disraeli's redistribution plan has an)
chance ol fav omable acceptation In this
point, however, the scheme of last year was
very little better, and was open to all the ob
jections which Mr Mill ably urges against
Lord John Russell's Bill of 1852 in view of
some probable modifications of the grouping
system being proposed by one or other party,
the following remarks on the radical vice of
previous propositions will be found interest-
ing -
" "i et, if the principle of combining several boroughs
was once admitted, what course could be more obii
t>ovb than to taut all the present boroughs, and nil
unrepresented towns of more than a certain amount of
population (bay, for example, oOOO), and leaving out
all those, w hellier existing as boroughs or still tobo
created, avhose importance entitles them to one mem-
ber, or more than one, of their own, to arrange the
others in groups according to geographical conveni-
ence, care being taken lo give to each group something
like the same number ol electors No reason is appa-
rent tilly this plan was not adopted, except the mis-
placed scruple against merging two existing boroughs
into one if what is now i borough is to beeomo
one ol a group, what difference can it make to the elec-
tors whether thev ure bound up with existing, or only
with newly enfranchised re electors 5 What couldbe
more abnurd than lhat dine anil ( hippeiitiam both
nommant n boroughs, and actually conterminous,
should (as m 1 ord John Hut-sell s scheine} subsist as
a «ort ol e'ouble bt»r, with each it« se par ile svstom of
planète, or that Amtbbury and Djvvnton should be
recalled from schedule A to furnish a supplementary
constituency to the little boiough of Wilton, instead
of adding it to the adinccnt city of Salisbury > The
proper iif.(,rcgate number of members for Bmall towna
being first, after due consideration, determined, all
pim o of «ueh bi?c ns to be politically entitled to the
designation of towns should bp admitted to a Bhare
in it 1 he greater the number of places included in
euch district the better prospect of a creditable choice
Hie local influences of families and corporations
would then have more chance of neutralising one
another, and with the aid of stringent measures
against all forms of corruption, tnere would bo some
prospect that the choico of representatives might
octiisioiiftllj be made on public rather than on pnv ite
grounds
'Hie papers in this volume, which onginally
appeared in I ra^r s Mm/iutur, were so widely
rend in their original form, that we need hardly
do more th in point to the fact of their rcpub
hcr.tion In " llecent W riters on Bcforni '-a
criticism on the theories of Mi Austin, Mr
Hare, and Professoi Lorimer-was developed
that philosophical bias in favour ol plural
voting which was outlined in the " Bcpre
sent itive Government, ' but to which, perhaps,
experience in practical legislation has since
weakened Mr Mill's ittachnicnt A more
import int production in every sense was the
eloquent and keen sighted examination of the
American contest lins more than inytlnng
else tint was published on either side of the
Atlantic, set clearly before the educated mind
of Lngland the real issues involved in the Civil
War We are wise ifter the event, but even
had facts disproved Mr Mill's forecast, we
should still admire the generous sympathies
which nrompt sucha passage as this -
' For these renions I innnot join with thoüc who
cry ' Peace, peace I cannot wish that this war
should not have leen engaged in by tho North, or
that, being engaged in, it should be terminated on
any conditions but such as would retain the whole of
the territories as free soil I am not blind to the
possibility that it may require a long war to lower the
arrogance mad tame the nggressive ambition of the
slnvc owner«, to the point of either returning to the
Union, or consenting to nniainoutof it with their
present limits Hut war in a (,ood ciusc is not the
(,n Mest ivii which a nation enn suflcr War is an
uglv thing but not the ugliest of things , the decaj ed
nnd degraded state cf moral and pntnotic
feeling which thinks nothing worth a war, is
worse \A hen a people are used n« mere
human instruments for bring cannon or thrusting
bayonets, in the service anil for the selfish jnir
poFcs of a master, sue li war degrades a people A
war to piotect other hum in beings against tyrannical
uijustiii - a wnrto give victory to their own idea of
ri(,ht and pooel, and «Inch is their own war, carmel
on for an honest purpose hy their free choice-is eilten
the means <f their regeneration A man who ha«
nothing which he is willing to fight for, nothing
?which he chtcs more about than he docs about his
pcriional safe tv, is a miserable creature who has no
chance ofbeing free, unless mnde and kept so bv the
i xe rtioi s it better men than himself As long as
justice anel mnisticc have not terminated their ivor
renewing t ghi for nsceiiilniuj m the alfairs of m in
kind, human beings must be willing, when need is, to
do battle for the one against the other I am far
frevn faying that the present struggle on the pitt
ol ti c Northern Ameritan* is whollj of this cxn ted
cliniacter, that it lins arrived at the stnge of being
altogether a war for iiistite a war of principle lint
t) ere was from the beginning, and now is, a large
infusion of that elimrnt in it, and this is increasing
will mi reuse, and, if the vvnr lasts, will til the end
predominate Should that time come, not only will
the greatest enormity which still exists among min
kind as an institution rrccive far earlier its coup de
gruce than there lias ever, until now, appeared any
probability of, but in effecting this the 1 ree States
will have raised themselves to that elevated position
in the stnle of morality Bnd dignity which is derived
from great sacrifices consciously made in a virtuous
cause, and the sense ot an inestimable benefit to all
future ngc«, brought about bj their own voluntary
rfiorts "
In this brilliant appreciation of the great
cause which was the ob|cet of the American
contest, the individu ihsm of Mr. Mill's
philcsoph) shjifi somewhat out of sight
and it seems no less over-mastered in
the " Exposition of the theory of Non-
intervention 'Hie common Badical creed
would scarcely admit of the large exception
which Air "Mill lays elown as neccssiry to the
proper working of what may be called Cobden
ism 'Ihough the prospect opened up in this
passage be alluring, we feai that it is, for the
present dt least, unatt unable -
"Hut the ease of a people struggling ngamst a
foreign voice, *>r ngiiinst a native tyrannv upheld bj
foreign arms illustrates the reisons for non interven-
tion in an opposite way , for in this case the reasons
themselves do not exist A people most attached to
freedom, tho most capable of iliftndinr and of miking
a good use of free institutions, nmv he unable
to contend stiticWullr for them a^unst the
military strength of another nation much more power-
ful lo assist a people thus kept down is not to
eiisiuri) nie uanna ui lorccs on windinie permanent
niMiiliiiancc i t freed mi in v c iiuttrj deptiuls, but t >
redress ihnt balance when it is already unfurlv and
violentlj diBtmbcil Hie doctrine of non intervention
to be a li "inmate priiicinle of morilitj, must be
ncctptedbj all govtriiiiicnts 1 lip despots must con
sent to be bound bj it as well as the free Sítales
Unless thev do the profession ol it bj free countries
comes but to this miserable issue-, that the wrong side
maj help the wrong but the nDht must not help the
right Intervention to enforce non intervenu m is
alwavs rightful, iilvvavs moral, if not always prudent
Though it bo a mistake to "ive lreedom to a people
who ilo not value the boon, it cannot bul be right to
insist that if >thi j do v ailie it, thej ah ill not
be hindered from the puisuit ot it by foreign
coerrton It might nut have been right tor
Lnglnnd (even apart from the question of prudence)
to 1 ave tiiken part with Hungarj m its noble struggle
ngamst Ausiriu , although the Austrian Government
in Hungary was in some sense a foreign joke But
when, the Hungarians having shown themselves likely
to prevail in tins struggle, the Kussian despot inter-
posal, and joining his force to that of Austria, de
livered back the Hungarians, bound hand and foot, to
their exnsperated oppressors, it would have been an
honourable and virtuous- act on the part of Lngland
to have declared that this should not be, and that if
Russia gave assistance to the wrong side, England
would aid the right It might not have been consultent
with the regard which even nation is bound to pay to
its own safety for Lngland to have taken up this posi-
tion single-handed But Lngland and Prance together
could have done it, and if thej had, the HusBian
armed intervention would never have taken place, or
would have been disastrous to ItuBsia alone ,
while all that those Powers gained by not
doing it, was that thej had to bght Kussia five years
afterwaids under more dilhcult circumstances, and
without Kungari for an tilly Hie hrst nation which,
being powerful enough to make its voice effectual, has
the spirit and courage to saj that not a gun shall be
fired in Luropc bj the soldiers of one Power against
the revolted subjects ol another, will be the idol of
tile friends ot freedom throu"hout Europe That
declaration alone will insure the almost immediate
emancipation of every people which desires liberty
sufhcientlj to be capable of maintaining it and the
nation which gives the vv ord vv ill soon hnd itself at the
head of an alliance of free peoples, bo strong as to defy
the eflorts of anj number of confederated despots to
bung it down Ihe pn/e is too glorious not to be
matched sooner or later by some free country , and
the time may not be diBtant when England, if she
does not take this heroic part because of its heroism,
will be compelled to take it from consideration for her
own safety
We might pause with pleasure over Mr
ALU's " Criticism of Austin's Jurisprudence, '
in which the utilitarian theory of positive hw is
formulated Wc might examine the two com-
panion essays on "Bain's Psychology" and
Grote's " Plato," which, like the famous criti
cisirs on ( olerulge and Bentham, correct and
supplement cich othei , and, with the " IX
rnunation of Hamilton's Philosophy," complete
Mr Mill's metaphysical system But we have
said enough, and quoted enough, to show that
this volume is one which will eminently repiy
the t isk of penis d-th it it is no way mfen >r
to any of Mr Mill's previously published works
May we heie cull the attention of the author
and publishei to an eimssiwn which seriously
detracts from the value ol Mr MiU's works as
at present printed ? Wc mean tho absence of
an index. In the ease of books which are so
constantly required for reference as well as
study, this is a grave defect-one, let us hope,
that will be remedied in future editions.

title: MOONLIGHT PROMENADE CONCERTS.
content:
MOONLIGHT PROMENADE CONCERTS.
To the Editor of the Herald.
Sm,-Havingbeen present at two ef the above concerts,
and viewing with great pleasure Mr. Gassner's great
exertions in tbe cause of charity, I think that it would
not be out place if the patrons and officers of those
institutions which have received help from the above
source, would tender a complimentary return to Mr.
Gaesner and the members of the band. What I would
venture to suggest is that Mr. G. be asked to prepare
a programme and give a concert, the proceeds of
which to be devoted, either in purchasing a testi-
monial, orto be given in some shape or other to Mr.
G. and his brother musicians.
Hoping this will bring the matter under the notice
of those before mentioned,
I am, Sir, yours, &c,
J. T. B. W.

title: The Sydney Morning Herald.
content:
®t>e cSgÖttCB JÄcrmwg p/îralïw »
TUESDAY, JANUARY 19, 1875.
We commented, a few days ago, on the fucij
thatr Sir Redmond Barhy had been sworn-in
as ActiDg-Governefvof Victoria almost immedi-
ately upon the departuie of Sir George
Bowen-a fact that in itself, under the eil .
cumstancee which rendered immediate action,
by an Administrator of the Government Impe-
ratively necessary, was in no degree incom-
patible with the existence of a discretionary
right on the part of the Ministry to have
held, under different circumstances, the dormant
commission in abeyance. Later events
have shown still more clearly that the
whole'Question requires, to, be more carefully
looked into, and that contingencies may aribe
which,involve doubt as to whether they have
been adequately (as they have not been ex-
pressly) .forseen and provided for.
- Ihe difficulty in Ifew South Wales arose
from doubts as to whether the telegram from
the Secretary of State, which the Govern-
ment interpreted as 'constructively sanctioning
their arrangements,<,was sufficient to cure tha
omission on the part of the Queen's instruc-
tions or commission to provide expressly for
the absence of the 'Governor during a longer
period than a month without ¿ailing in ai
Acting-Governor to take his place. The
difficulty in Victoria was not as to the
swearing in of Sir Redmond Babiiy. That
was disposed of by the force of circumstances
which left the Ministry but one course to
follow. The difficulty there arose from tho
absence of the Chief Justice (the Acting-Go-
vernor designate) at the time when an Acting
Governor had to be sworn in, and from his
return whilst the duties of the office were being
discharged by the senior Judge, the official
designated by the commission to take the
office if the Chief Justice were ab.ent.
Was Sir W. Stawell, the Chief Justice, to
assume the Acting-Governorship on his return,
or was Sir Redmond Baeiiy, in whom the
powers of Governor were legally vested, to
retain and exercise them ? Doubt was felt
amongst the lawyers as to whether the power*
of the commission under which Sir Redmond
Bakey had been appointed were not exhausted
bj his appointment. These doubts, however,
were overruled. Sir W. Stawell was sworn
in on the 11th, Sir Rldmond Bakry art
ministering the .oaths. And it is said that in
the event of any embarrassment occurring,
a telegram will be sent to London, asking for
[the execution of a fresh commission.
As this is cutting the Gordian knot, instead
of untying it-a process thati may be ver)
¡agreeaole to ,'Ministries tin Victoria, but is
hardly excusable' on constitutional 'principles-~
the difficulty remains still undisposed of. Let
us, then, inquire into its nature more closely,
The Argus describes Sir W. Stawell as
" assuming " the administration of the Govern-
ment, But how was it possible for hira to
assumo it ? Did Sir Redmond Barry give it
up, or was it taken from him, or did it pass
from him by the operation of the commission? I
The last supposition is untenable. If Sir
GroROE Bowen had leturned before Sir W.
Stawell, this sort of self-acting transfer i
would certainly have taken place. Sir Red- I
mond Barry having become Acting-Governor
during the Governor's absence only,- the
Goveinor, in viitue of his own commission^
would have resumed his full powers on te
entering the territory of Victoria aB a matter of
course. Sir George Bowen was Governor
before he left, was Governor whilst absent, and
would have been Governor on his return, his
commission having been neither cancelled nur
withdrawn, but simply suspended as to its
operation during his absence. Not so with
Sir W. Stawell. He "assumed" the ad-
ministratorship ; he did not resume it, because
it was not his to resume. He had not held it
before. If he had held it before, and had then
left the colony, and if Sir Redmond
Barry had then become administrator
in his place, there would have been
an analogy between the two cases, and Sir
W. Stawell might have claimed, like the
Governor, the right to resume the powers
which by his absence he had become tempo-
rarily incapable of exercising. As it was,
when he reiurned, he returned as Chief Justice,
not as Acting-Governor. He could not become
Acting-Governor till he was Bworn in. He
could only take office by assumption, not
by resumption, as Sir George Bowen
could. Sir George Bowen, on returning,
would have resumed power as Sir George
Bowen in virtue of a personal appointment
by a commission still operative. Sir W.
Stawell could neither reaBon1 nor assume aa
Sir W. Siawell. lie had not been
personally named in any commission. And the
onl} circumstances under which he could have
claimed a right to assume the administratorship
as Chitf Justice-as the official designated to
fill the vacant office-were manifestly when the
office wat, \acant. But was it vacant? ' !
Ai Sir Rj.dmoîsd Barry was not absent on
Sii W. t>TAWH.L's return, and not suffering
Irom incHpucitv, a vurancy could not have
existid unless he had been deprived of the
office or resigned it. But, having taken the
oaths, «ho was.to deprive him of the office had]
lie chocen to hold it, adopting Marsh ii
MacMamon's motto, "J'y suts;j'y reslc'1'"
He could have held his footing in
the Malakhofi' agnvnst anybody short
of the Secretary of Stnte. The sup;
position, then, is that ho re_igned.(
But will that resignation hold together on'
being shaken ? When Sir George Bowen
left the colon), he did not resign the Gover-I
nort-hip. He simply went away, and left the
office to fall into the hands of the official first
I in rank designated to fill itj' whensoever
'hat official should he duly eworn in J
[ But Sir Redmond Barky did hot go away.]
If he resigned, he resigned and still
remained, able, if not willing, to discharge the
duties of the office. But had he the powei'
thus to resign and remain? He_ was, bo to,
speak, seised of the business of administration,
and had he a right of his own motion to relieve
himself of it, and hand o\er his duties to
another who, bo long as Sir Redmond was
Acting-Governor, was his subordinate ? If Sir¡
George Bowen had resigned he would have'
sent in his resignation to his superior officer,)
the Secretary of State, and have awaited
his reply. Sir Redmond Barry, derivingj
his authority as Acting-Governor from the
same source, could presumably resign it only
in the same manner. Resignation, apart from
supervening incapacity, implies a reference^
to an authority competent to accept or decline«
it. But there was no such authority in Vic-
toria in Sir Redmond Barry's case. He
could not tender his resignation to the j
Ministry, for their status was not superior;
to his own. When once he had been,
s worn in, they were rather under his
authority than he under theirs. He could not
tender it to Sir W. Stawell, of whom
as defacto Governor, whilst Sir W. Stawell,
was only Chief Justice, he took precedence.'
On the whole, the theory of resignation seems
as little tenable as that of transfer by the mere
force of the commission, which, if our reasoning
be correct, could only have taken place if Sir1
W. Stawell had been the Acting-Governor,
first sworn in, and had returned after a tem-*
porary absence, during which Sir Redmond i
Barry had been his hourn (mens. A j
vacancy might have been created readily]
erpugh, ifSir Redmond Barry, who is now I
in New South Wales, had arranged for an'
earlier i isit, and quitted Victoria the day before '
Sir W. Stawell's arrival, or if the Govern-
ment had delayed swearing in Sir W.
Stawell until after his departure. But he
remained, and the question is, how while he
remained could the office become legally
vacant ? '
It appears to ,us that, just as it was only
though the absence of Sir W. 'Stawell
when an Acting-G o vernon ,was required, that
Sir Redmond Barry obtained the office, bo,
when Sir'Redmond Barry had once obtained
it and been duly sworn in, it was only by his
departure from t the colony, or by supervening
incapacity, that Sir W. Stawell could rightly
assume it. ' Sir Redmond Barry became
Acting-Governor because the swearing
in of an Acting-Governor was requirod
by , the public interest. But no such
necessity aroBe. on the return of Sir
W. Stawell, because the office had been
filled and itB duties were being discharged' in
the manner provided hy the Royal Instructions
und Commission. The provisions of the Com-
mission and the Instructions were intended to
show how a vacant office was to be filled, and
not, when the office had been duly filled, to
create a vacancy in order to substitute another
officer for the one in whom the powers attach-
ing to the position legally vested.
\ Wir at a mine of wealth there would be in the
\inej aids of Australia if only we had a market
I under our lee, such as France has in Europe.
I'the day may come perhaps when in America,
¡if not in Europe,, Australian wines maybe a
popular drink, but at the present time the costs
'of production and carriage aVe against us, and
dhe reputation 'of our vineyards and wine
icellsrs is not high enough, and in the main the
! market for Australian wines is still in Aus-
tralia. *
j As some compensation for the disasters it has
'latelv undergone, France was last year blessed
with an unusually splendid vintage. Notwith-
standing the oidium, notwithstanding the
¡phjlloxera, and notwithstanding hailstorms,
'the vintage was productiv e to an extent which
has only once been equalled, and that was in
¡the year 18G9. The produce is estimated at
170,000,000 of hectolitres, and sr a hectojitre ;s
Twentr-two-1-4 gallons," ttíiB'Ms "s equal1'* to'
1,540,000,000 gallons. The growth of
the trade out of which France makes
so much money will be visible by |
noticing tViat in 1854, that is only twenty years
ago, the product was only eleven millions of
hectolitres; in tho following year it rose to
fifteen; during the eleven years from 1863 to
1878 inclusive, it rose to an average of fifty
three millions ; "but in 1873, which was a very
bad j ear, it dropped to thirty-six millions, and
now, in the following year, it is very nearly
double, hating risen to seventy millions.
There are only ten departments in France
which produce no wine, and the vine covers
4} per cent, of the whole surface of the
country, or in round numbers about five million
acres. There are, however, three chief wine-
growing districts, namely the Bordelais, Bur-
gundy, and Champagne, and the produce from
those districts has not yet been rivalled by any
other part of the world. The number of
people employed in thia industry is in propor-
tion to the acreage covered, for it is reckoned
to give occupation to no fewer than seven
million labourers ; that is to say, one industry
in .France alone, and that an industry which
produces an article of luxury, finds wages for
more than three times the whole population of
Australasia. '
Nor is there any fear at present of France
over-producing. There is an indefinite market
for all the good wine that is made, although it
is possible that a great or sudden glut might to
some extent lower the price, in order to allow
.-?ales to be effected rapidly. But in its wine
Fiance has an article which tbe world
eagerly buys ; and, as the world is grow-
ing richer every year, and becoming more
and more luxurious, there is more and
more eager demand for wines of the' best
quality. In this way, France is taxing the
whole world to help it to pay its debts ; and
everyone who sips his claret or his champagne
assists towards the pa} ment of that satisfaction'
which Bismarck and Von Moltkk exacted. <
It is impossible not to notice in this yield of
(he French vineyards how much the commerce
of the world has gained by the greater humanity
of modern methods of war. When we read
ancient history, we hear of conqueTorB who
..eemtd insatiable in their revenge, who razed
cities to the ground, and who ploughed up the
cultivated fields and sprinkled them with salt.'
and who seemed never to be able to do enough
lo tatisfy themselves that the people who had
piovoked their wrath should be ruined hope-
lessly. If the samo spirit had animated modern
war-if the Germans, not content with conqu_
luig, had sought only to devastate-if they,
had pulled up the vines and destroyed
the wine-presses, in how different a
situation would France have been! How
heavy would have been the pressure of
the taxation, and how cramped the resources
lo meet that taxation. What numbers would
have been out of employment, and what years
would have been waited by capitalists till vines
could have been replanted and again become
productive ! But, as it was, the German occu-
pation did. not appreciably affect the vintage,
which even, during the disastrous year of thç
war kept up its''average. <** * ,
It is quite true that this more humane pian
mils the conqueror quite as well as it suits* thfct
conquered. The victor takes it out in monej
inptead of having his payment in revenge. lV
Geimany had destroyed the productive industij'
of France, it would have had to content itself
with a far smaller indemnity. The credit of
France would have been too prostrate for it io
have raised the necessary loans with the'
promptness that it did, and Germany i1-'
iewar.de,d for not having destroyed French ¡
vineyards by the receipt of hundreds of million«
of French gold. Doubtless to a Christian
spiiit this mode of reí enge is more satisfactory,
and to the wine-drinkers of the world it is moie
satisfactory also.
It is impossible also in connection with this
subject not to notice how much of the wealth ',
of France is due to it being a producer for the
luxury of the world. In the way of exporting
the necessaries of life it does not do mucn,.
and produces mainly for its own popu-
lation. It exports but little of com' or of
meat ; but with regard to all that comforts the
stomach or adorns the person, France stands
in the first rank of producers. It is the grand
purveyor of luxury, and, in a world that is
getting every year richer and more luxurious,
it does not fail to find a splendid market.
France, though it has no monopoly of the busi-
ness in luxuries, has the undisputed lea-1.
Italy provides many objects of art, and English
manufacturers are improving yearly in tbiii
productions of taste and ingenuity. Still it is to
France that the world turns for models and foi
its choicest objets de luxe; and there seems no
likelihood ' of its pre-eminence in this depart
ment being interfered wi li. The French
manipulators seem to have as great an aptitude
for work of this sort as their soil and climate
have aptitude for a special class of wines. The
commercial position of France in these respects
| brings it wealth, in spite of all its foreign wai s
and its intestine discords, and of the damage in-
evitably done to trade when capital is alarmed
by insecurity and labour is oppressed bj
taxation.
