title: The Sydney Morning Herald.
content:
ODc £fiUneg ifloniíits peíala.
WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 8, 137C.
In yesterday's issue avo published a letter of
Mr. CnACKNELi/s on the second cable question.
The letter, as our readers Avili have observed,
although addressed to the Government of this
colony, comes to us by AA'ay of Victoria. On
several occasions during the last, few months
we have been indebted to Victorian sources of
information for the official correspondence of
Noav South "Wales. Matters Avithheld from
the public by our own Government are com-
municated to the Government of tho neigh
I bouring colony. By that Government they
aro sent to the Press, and in this way, in
regard to the cable question at least, we have
got to know Avhat is going on in ofticial
circles in Ncav South Wales. We are not
aware whether this anomalous state of
things is attributable to too much communi-
cativeness in the one Government or to too
much reserve in the other. It is, however, a
state of things which can scarcely bo said to
bo satisfactory.
Anything that relates to the improvement
of telegraphic communication between these
colonies and the mother-country is just now of
the utmost importance, and if there is any in-
formation in the hands of the Government in
regard to a great question of this lund, the i
people of this colony are, to Bay the least, as
fully entitled to it as the people of Victoria.
We have no wish to contend for the publica-
tion of private documents. A large section of
the correspondence that passes through the
hands of a Government is judiciously with-
held, at least temporarily, from the public.
There are also documents which may be Avisely
sent to the Government of another colony
and as wisely kept from the people of
this colony ; and as to what documents should
be regarded as private and what as public the
Government itself must be the primary judge.
It is not too much, however, to insist that
there should be a proper xinderutanding and a
proper agreement between Governments like
those of Victoria and New South Wales, and
that any departure from the agreement on
either side should be made the subject of
immediate inquiry. We certainly cannot see
anything in Mr. Cracknkll's lost communi-
cations that should necessitate their being
confined to diplomatic circles. But, on the
other hand, such things cannot be claimed
by the public as a right. If these
and other communications have. been
sent to the Government of Victoria as
private documents, the Government of this
colony has sufficient ground to complain of
breaches of courtesy and of trust. If stich
documents are public, and not priA'ate, the
public of the colony to which they aTe sent
ought not to be dependent on Victorian
channels of intelligence for a sight of them.
Under any circumstances, it can hardly be
deemed satisfactory that we should be
dependent upon the Government of another
colony for a knowledge of Avhat is being done
by the agents of this colony to increase the
means of telegraphic communication between
Australia and the rest of the world.
It is certainly matter for congratulation
that Mr. Cracknell is so fully devoting his
leisure time to the task of duplicating the
cable ; and in one point, at least, Mr.
Cracknell's last letter reports material pro-
gress. The letter of Lord Caknahvon,
which reached us a Aveek or two ago, so
far as we were able to understand it, sub-
mitted the cable from Rangoon to Penang as a
question, the settlement of which Avould be
dependent upon the decision of the colonies.
Mr. Cracicnkll tells us that the new cable
I between thes9 two places has actually been
I shipped, and from this we may gather that
I this cable will be laid whether the colonies
| agree to pay the subsidy of £20,000 asked for
I or not. The object of the subsidy named is
the reduction of the rates, and bo far as this
' part of the line is concerned, the colonies will
have to choose between the payment of high
Tates and no subsidy, and the payment of low
rates and a subsidy of £20,000 a year. Tho
Eastern Extension Company has its own in-
terests to consider as well as those of the
colonies, and ic is not improbable that the
1 company have already found out that business
considerations Avili compel tbem to construct
the duplicate cable to Penang whatever the
decision of the colonies may bo. Under any
circumstances we may conclude, that in a
very short time there will be a duplicato cable
between London and Singapore.
The immediate question, "according to Mr.
| Cracknell, is the -duplicating of the cable
I between Singapore and Banjowangie. This
would remedy the evils of a very defective
1 section between Singapore and Batavia and of
the Java land lines, which ave Avorked by ,
Dutch operators. The distance ia about 1000
mile., and the subsidy risked for is £21,780,
inclusivo of interest and renewal. Mr. Crack
sru, thinks that tlio cabio from Singapore to
Baujowangio should ho arranged for at once,
I and about this there really ought not to be two
opinions. This is a part of the line that
specially concerns the Australian colonies, and
one that no company could bo expected to
establish -without au Australian subsidy
Mr Cuax'Kneli. thinks that a second cable
between Java and Australia is not a matter
of immediato importance, li it is found that
such a cabio is necessary, ho recommeuda
that the duplicate lino should extend from
Baujowangio to North-West; Capo in Weston.
Australia. Tho Eastern Extension Company
offer to construct a second Australian line,
connecting at theso two points, and covering
a distance of about 900 milos, for a subsidy
of £23,220. But Mr. Cäacknklt. think* that
prolonged interruption between Java and Port
Darwin is not likely to occur for flomo time,
and that a Becond lino this side of Java need
not be undertaken for tho next few years.
Wo hopo that tho Conference which is
promised for tho purpose of considering
tho whole question of a second cable will
be of a different opinion. It is
not likely that another interruption in the
Darwin-Banjo wan gie cable would ho as pro-
longed as the one that commenced about eight
mouths ago ; but experience has shown beyond
all question that on greaC couti al lines a
duplicate cabio is absolutely necessary, if
the cable is to bo relied upon for the transac-
tion of business of importance. Should we
content ourselves with one cable, wo may not
have another interruption extending over four
or fivo months for a long time to come; but
tho liability of an interruption for a month, or
even a week, may, under critical circum-
stances, involve risks which aro too serious to
be incurred, A second cable botween London
and nil the principal cities ol' Australia would,
under any ordinary circumstances,, auswer all
commercial and political purposes, but nothing
short of this will suiflco.
From Mr. Chackmet.t/s tole_j;rara we
learn that the Eastern Extension Com-
pany are prepared to lay a second cable
betwoen Singapore and Western Aus-
tralia for a subsidy of £4-"3,0OO. This, it
seems, is submitted as a definite offer, and if
so the question to be decided by these colonie?
is whether this offer shull be accepted or
not. The alternatives which present them-
selves are our lomaining as wo are, with the
inconvenioncies of a single cable, or the adop-
tion of another rouro altogether. Solar as we
are able to gather, the prevailing opinion in
Victoria is in favour of having the second
cable in the direction of the Mauritius or
Ceylon. The duplicating of a cable on the
present line is, however, the course that has
been advocated by the Government of this
colony. Tins course is strongty urged by Mr.
OiiACKNTtLL, whose opinion in matters of this
kind is certainly entitled to respect The same
course ia urged upon tue colonies by the Im-
perial Government, and it is said tn_,t it is not
improbable that that Government will as___t
in subsidizing a second cable between Singa-
pore and Java.
Should the Australian colonies agree to
accept the terms of the Eastern Telegraph
Company, there is no reason why Are
should not have a second cable around the
world in a very few months from the present
date. The non-acceptance of these terms
will, however, lead either to the postpone-
ment of the whole quesltion, or to no
inconsiderable delay iu the settlement of
it. When the duplicate cable reaches Singa-
pore it will be within less than 2000 miles
from the Australian coast. This is the
shortest route for the second cable,, and must
be the least expensive. Objection» may be
raised against our having a Becond cable on
the same route as the fit st, but objjectkms
more formidable may possibly be urged
against any other route that is suggested.
The most natural and the most reasonable
proposition for securing a supply of an
increasingly urgent public want is the one
that is now before the colonies, and it would
be well if some arrangement could b.e made
by which Mr. Cracknell could be kept ia
London until the terms for laying down a
second cable between Singapore and Australia
are actually agreed upon, and the work is
actually begun.
In accordance with the provisions of the
Sydney Corporation Restoration Act, eight
aldermen o£ the city of Sydney-being one
for each ward-will go out of office on the 1st
of December next, and an election will take
place in their respective wards to supply the
vacancies thus occasioned. The aldermen
who go out by eftluxion of time, are, unless
specially disqualified, capable of being re
elected. The present is therefore an exciting
time in aldermanic and municipal circles.
Our readers are aware that the municipal
laws which relate to the city, and the Act
which relates to municipalities generally
throughout the colony, are separate and distinct
statutes. The Act by virtue of Avhich the
affairs of the city are regulated is as remark-
able on account of ita incompleteness as are
the municipal efforts of the city aldermen for(
the want of appreciation of the importance of
the duties which are entrusted to them. At
every election we hear the cry that " new
blood " is necessary, and some frosli candidate
u damned with a fatal iiuency," comes forward
as a sort of municipal saviour, and promises
reforms without number. Hut after maldug
one or two ineffectual straggles, ho becomes
as tamo as his municipal brethren, whose
principal object appears to bo to fix upon the
treasury chest like so many horse-leeches.
The two grand characteristics of the Sydney
Municipal Council are a magnificent capacity
for borrowing, and a patient endurance under
deficient legislation' and ridiculously light
taxation.
A seat in the City Council has been for years
a sort of procrustean bed on which all alder-
men of more than ordinary mental and moral
stature have been dwarfed to the proportions
of aldermanic mediocrity. It is time that this
condition of things should be changed, and
as another opportunity is now presented to
the ratepayers, we hope that they will have
some regard to the importance of tho
occasion, and return men of sufficient in-
tellect to understand the position in which
the city is placed, and Bufíicienfc inde-
pendence and force of character to make
their influence felt. The city of Sydney
cannot go on much longer without fresh legis-
lation, it needs it quito as much as the sui
urban and country municipalities, and in
regard to the metropolis, of which Sydney is
the contre, we must have a radical change.
Nearly twenty years Lave elapsed since the
City Corporation was restored, and the altera-
tion of circumstances which has taken place
dnriug that timo bus completely altered" _,_
condition of things. The suburbs have bl«!
as populous as the city; they have interósea!
'£ *ndf. .imPortant, and it i9 uot lik£
that m this now country thuy will corf
sent to the creation o£ an anomaly like thnf
which exists in England in regard to It. chief
city and its metropolis. And, further t__
time is come wheu the reckless borrowin-of th
city must bo checked, and whon al) tue°muni
cipahties which con-tituto tho metrópoli, ,naaI
be placed upon an equal and ("tiBÍao:«.^
footing. '
Wo do not think that the ratepayers oC
Sydney havo heretofore exorcised th«j. ñi\\m<
cipal franchis, with very great discretion'
Mon have been elected to represent the cHv
and ita Municipal Council who have not _eea
qualified either hy education or by natural
talent. On tho contrary, many' person*
havo boen elected who have ais
played little capacity for bu.ines», and have"
been completely overwhelmed by the mngni.
tudo of the affairs which they have undertaken"
to manage and control. It is R mistake to
supposo that auy man will make an efficient
alderman, or ( that the best municipal repr«.
sentatives will be those who promise "a
liberality which they do not exercise-towards
their own employes. The most objectionable
candidates aro certainly those who have
individual or relative " axes to grind/' uni
who seek to attain their own ends by 1:0.
Cessions of profuso generosity. It ia desiriblj
that those who a i-f elected to fill the municipal
ofliee, both in Syduoy and the suburbs, should
be men of independent character and vigorous
intellect-who are above log-rolling and the
lowest aldermanio nits ; who will not htmc ia
any power which will scenic to them a few
extra votes-who will not iuvolve the city in
largo expenditure to promoto their own private
interests, but who will endeavour'to carryon
the municipal work on true municipal*
principles, and exercise their influence to
securo tboso r« Conns which are necessarv to
promote uumJeip.'J usefulness, Experience
has already shown that municipalities areno'
to bo trusted with matters affecting the public
health, and that in order to secure an eftlcient
system of dtainage and water supply for the
whoio metropolis, a Metropolitan Board of
Works has become nu absolute necessity.
Municipal duties thereforo will probably, it
no distant chite, be properly brought w_t_in
a much more narrow compass.
A good many theories on municipal "govern-
ment have been set up by candidates for
municipal honours. We have sometimes heard
| people who aspire to the oflioo of alderman
expatiate at considerable length upon th« sub-
ject ol' loca) taxation generally, us xlioufb,
they were about to be elected to a sxit in the
Legislative Assembly ^ Avheve tiley might hops
to give a vote for the purpose of determiniug
thi* important question. Occasionally casii
dates are eloquent on the subject of the eight«
hour question, in order to conciliate the support
of Corporation labourera and others. Some ate
grear, upon the subject of municipal endow-
ment , not as to the necessity o£ increasing
the c«.lnwment or otherwise, but U9 to the
mode in whioh that endowment ought
to be raised. rliie,> -want pnblicani'
licenses, wine and spirit merchante' licenses,
auctioneers' licenses, the proceeds of the dog
tax, and in addition to all these they want »
special endowment from the public Treasurr
of pound for pound extending over a number
of years. With thinse sources of income, the) Í
are of opinion that they could conduct tin
municipal business with great satisfaction
and financial success. They set forth a pro-
gramme so liberal as to draw forth unlimited
applause. But, after all, their opinions upon
points of this kind are of very small conse-
quence. They cannot give any practical
effect to them as members of the Munici-
pal Council, and the rate-payers will do
well lo remember that they are no*
about to elect men to perform purely
municipal duties, and not to take part
in legislation to amend the municipal law.
We are clearly of opinion that the munici-
palities are entitled to a more liberal endc-iî-'
ment, and that they ought to possess more
perfect and extensive powers of taxation. But
in connection with the present elections we
have to consider, not how we can best secure
an alteration of the law, but how we can best
securo a proper administration of the law
which at present exists. We hope that this
will bo borne in mind by the various rate-
payers, and that they will not give their votes
to mea whom they would not trust in private
life, or to men whose mental capacity and
moral status they hold in contempt.
TffE subject of forest vegetation and its effect»
on climate, dealt with by the Rev. W. B. Omsk
in a napier read before our Eoyal Society lut
week, ia one of special interest to this wüßt«?.
Any one who has travelled over the interior catt
testify to the truth of the prediction, "till tia
woods and lurests have been taken Mu« ft«
protection of Government many a district of rich'
timber will continue to be foolishly destroyed,
and many a scene of Bylvan beauty will
be desecrated." To many the ostbettc
argument may have little weight, but um
gent students of nature know that wt
combines the useful and the beautiful in »u
her operations; The vegetable kingdom u toe
source of human sustenance, the origin of our
artificial light and heat and motive power,T
producer of the raw materials which man uses
largely in all branches of industry, li there had
been a race of " pre-Adamite men " to prey upon
the primeval forests for cuccessive »8e8.,1*.
Aryan races are now doing, there would baw
beau left at the present time none of tQ0BB,v.i?
coal measurrs which Stkphenson designated toe
" bottled sunlight of former ages," and which are
so valuable in this age of iron and steam.
As the Aryan races have migrated west-
ward they seem to havo denuded ?«««
tracts of country, aud leaving them in df»1*1,1?"
passed on to other lands. With the fall oí »e
forest the climate tends to the extremes 01
drought and fl.iod. until finally the most lruiKW
lands b-come almost uuinhabitable, and .mannis
to seek virgin »oil elsewhere. Is the «ni««1"*
that ther* should bo no trees cat down ana no
clearings made at all ? That would be a «(<"« °
adabsurUtim, for aï tlw world's population in-
creases the area of wheat lands must increase, ana
the nia.Kiu of cultivation bo pushed further irom
the centr.3 of society. But judicious clearing
is one thing and wanton destruction is a"°'D^
A tree which has taken nature a °?to
years to rear ia worth something better to«« l
bo ring-barked and left to rot on the ground« u»
the course of its lifetime it must have reproduce»
itself a thousand-fold, and if left alone jhe«b?,
table kingdom would cover the whole toT*"
globe, and leavo no roora for the cities and inuw
trios of man. It is legitimate to use theme »«¡J
and the finished product, and also to wclamüro"
fue forest whatever area the increasing d«nara
for ¿nman subsistence may rrqmre. Bj-yon» T
denudatiou is waste and extravagance, the VTmj
of which will fall on future generations, jwu«
forests should be preserved somewhere to *»*.
nao Of the old ones, and the reck ess w«»»
La steel «iiould berestrained J**9^ J5
planted along our riven and » roams «¿g^,
¿áuuded watershed.. Patulles of euca-yP""

title: METROPOLITAN DISTRICT COURT.
content:
METROPOLITAN DISTRICT COURT.
FnlUAV.
EEI-OKE Mr. District Couit Judge Si-virsct.-.
MONAGHAN V. KAVANAGH. '
'Ibis was an application for new trial on tho ground
that, lho damages aw arded to the plaintiff were excessive.
HÍB Honor refused tho application bocauso the question of
damages had been left to tho Judge and determined by him
at tho trial. Mr. Pilcher appeared in support of the
application, and Mr. S. C. Brown opposed it.
HAM.SDON V. OAKMNEU.
This also was an application for now trial, made on
behalf of tho defendant, against whom a judgment had
been obtained on an order for tho payment of £30 tnado by
him in favour of ono O'Brien. Tho ground of tho applica-
tion was that the order was not an oidor in which tho
defendant promised to pay any amount. For tho pkintiff
it was contended that defendant's order'was a guarantee for
(ho perfommncoof a contract taken by O' Brien from the Cor-
poration. Tho aflidavit of one of the' professional gontlomon
engaged in tho caso slated that tho Judgo had held thnt
the order was a good and valid dooumont in law, and that
that was the ground of the decision. With respect to tho
| order, his Honor held a different opinion, and a new trial
must thcroforo bo granted. Mr. Gannon appeared in sup-
port of the application, and Mr. G. C. Davis opposed it.
îiAvrs v. iionoiiGir OP PADDINGTON.
The plaintiff in this caso h id been tho Council clerk to
tho borough of Paddington, and ho now sued the defendant
for wrongful dismissal. He claimed £160 damages. Mr.
Pigott appeared for the plaintiff, and Mr. S. C. Brown for
tho defendant. The agreemont undor which the plaintiff
served tho Council provided that the engagement
might be terminated by cithor party on a
month's notice. Mr. Brown objected that tho
new Municipalities Act conferred oxprosaly upon the
mayor of any borough power to diBmiss any of tho servants
of tho borough, and that it was not competent for the
Court to review the mayor's dotormination in that respect.
His Honor was ef opinion, on the provision cited, that tho
power of suspension was delegated to tho Mayor, and that
the power to dismiss rested with tho Council. He hold
that it was competent for him to review tho dismissal by
tho Council. Tho evidence showed that tho plaintiff was
suspended on the 9th of Juno, and that tho sus-
pension was confirmed by tho Council al its next
meeting, held shortly afterwards. Plaintiff's testimony
shewed that tho mayor of tho borough (Mr. Taylor) told
him that ho only suspended him because ho was askod_ to
do so ; Taylor admitted that ho had no fault to find with
him, and spoke highly of his efficiency, Messrs. Penfold
and Peate, aldermen of tho borough, gave evidence to the
effect that tho plaintiff had at all tunes performed tho duties
of his office in tho most efficient and satisfactory manner ;
while, on tho other hand, Aldermen Humphrey and Stone
states that tho plaintiff had inaccurately kopt the minutes,
withheld certain vouchers, whereby tho borough lost tho
Government endowment for tho half-year-that he had
diEobcyed orders, and had been disrespectful to tho Mayor,
in practically calling him a liar on the occasion of a public
meeting, and again at a meeting of tho Council. Theso
allegations were contradicted by the plaintiff. Tho minutes
of Council contained no record of the cause of plaintiff's
dismissal, and tho only evidence on this point was in tho
vorbal report of the mayor, who thon stated
that he had suspended the plaintiff because his
conduct was distasteful to a majority of tho
aldermen, and because he bad no confidence in him.
Mr, Taylor (the mayor of tho borough) sworo that ho did
sot dismiss Davis in consequence of any ill feeling, but
simply becauso on ono or two occasions Mr. Davis had
asserted that he (witness) was a liar, and that Davis had on
more than one occasion altered things in the account-books
in opposition to his (tho mayor's) instructions. Ho was of
opinion that Davis was out of his mind at times. [At this
Btagc of tho caBc, his Honor intimated ho was of opinion
that plaintiff had been wrongfully dismissed ; that
if there had not been any ill-feeling in exist-
ence, plaintiff would never havo been dismissed.]
Mr. Brown «intended that tho mayor of a municipality
had the power to suspend a clerk or servant, at any time,
who in his opinion was guilty of misconduct; such suspen-
sion, of courso, would bo subject to csnfirmation by tho
Council. In this instance, tho Council had confirmed tho
suspension, that Davis had no right, boing a servant of tho
Council, to have attended any public meeting of tho rate-
payers, and; that Davis, having charged the mayor with
telling falsehoods was quito sufficient cause for his dismis-
sion. Tho utmost that could bo claimed by tho
plaintiff was," a month's pay. Mr. Pigott con-
tended that plaintiff was entitled to a year's
salary, tho contract having been for that period.
His Honor was of opinion that he had jurisdiction to
consider the question whether tho plaintiff hod been
wrongfully dismissed. He did not think that it was evor
the intention of the Legislature that the Council clerk
should be entirely at the meicy of tho Council, and should
be deprived of all resort to a Court of law. As a matter i
of fact, he was of opinion that tho defendant had been
wrongfully dismissed by the Council. He was disposed to
think that the plaintiff had shown a spirit of |
par'ialify, and had been guilty of conduct
which was unbecoming, and which would havo
justified the defendant in giving him a month's
notice ; but he did not think that that impropriety of con- j
duct was sufficient to justify his summary and absoluto
dismissal. He was of opinion upon the ovidenoe that tho
plaintiff had not been dismissed for misconduct, but becauso
he did not givo satisfaction to a majority of the aldermen.
The contract was for a year¿ and that contract had not
been determined by the notice in writing required to be
given under it. Ho thought that £50 would bo sufficient
to compénsalo tho plaintiff, and ho directed a verdict to bo
entered for that sum.

title: OFFICIAL TELEGRAM.
content:
OFFICIAL TELEGRAM.
We are injtlebted to the Hon. Michael Fitz-
patrick for the following copy of an official
telegram :
« London, February 14.
Tho Russians are close to Constantinople,
and threaten to occupy the city if the English
fleet enter tate Dardanelles.
The fleet entered yesteiday, despite the '
protest of Turkey, which is now moie Russian
than English.
Russia, among other terms, demands portion
of Bessarabia, which may involve complica-
tions with Austiia and Roumania.
There is general excitement here. ii

title: SPORTING.
content:
SPOUTING.
I öi'ORTINO NOTES.
At the request ol a number of members
Mr. R. Grice lia» decided to stand for one of
the vacancies on the V.lt.C. committee, and
hi« nomination was handed in on Tuesday.
Mr. Grice haa previously acted as a com
mitlecman, and lie I as such a wide circle of
friends that hischunce of election is regarded
as a good «ne. Mr. J. C. Walker's nomi-
nation is also in, but Mr. J. C. Howden, who
has been mentioned as u certain candidate,
has not yet been uomiuated, though ho
probably will be in tho course of a day
or two. There are eight vacancies to fill
at the annual meeting of the members on
August 7. The retiring members of the
committee aro Mcsirs. W. If. Croker, C. B.
Fisher, C M. Ll^yd, W. Lonard, S.
Miller, F. Madden, J. Whittingham, and
G. Watson, all of whom, it"is understood,
will offer themselves for rc-clent.ion.
A New Zealand wiitcr thus speaks oí
Launceston and Loyalty, who aro engaged
in the Melbourne Cup : - " Among the
horse« doing useful work on the Riccarton
course are Launceston and Loyalty. Laun-
ceston, who is a light-fleahcd horse, lojks
in really capital irirn, and, in fact, BO
forward that it would probably not take
many week» to g^t bin fit. Loyalty,
on the other hand, U a particularly
gross colt, and although he lias already
?bown himself to be something out of the
common, I fancy ho will not be seen at hi»
very best until later on in Ids career. He
wi 1, of course, be rjy.ite fit to race next
»pring, but if his legs stand-and they cer-
tainly look a» if they will-he will continue
to improve with age, and hi» best perform-
ances »ill probably be registered when be is
four or five years old."
Mr. H, K. Falkiner has sold hi» well-per
farmed hone, Hopetoun, who will probably
find hi» way to India. The Bagct Handicap
winner was leased to Mr. S. Miller, with
whom Mr. Falkiner carno to an understand-
ing which permitted of the horse's sale.
Hopetoun is a good little horse up to a cer-
tain weight, and fit and well in India he
should be able to win a few good race».
Hopetoun has been scratched for the two
Cups.

title: Family Notices
content:
Births.
CALLAGHAN.-December 20, the wife of Dr. Callaghan, of Richmond, of a son.
WILD.-December 14, at her residences, Wildoaks, The Oaks,
Mrs. F. W. Wild, of a son.
Marriages.
CARRUTHERS-ROBERTS.-December 10, at St. James's
Church, by the Rev. W. Hough, Joseph Hector Carruthers,
M.A., solicitor, to Louise Marion, youngest daughter of William
Roberts, solicitor.
DURKIN-KILLALEA.-November 19, by special licence, at
St. Mary's Cathedral, by the Rev. Mr. Rvan, John Durkin, of
the county Mayo, Ireland, to Jane Killalea, of the county Ros-
common, Ireland.
GRAHAM-DONOGHOE.-December 20, at St. Philip's Church,
Sydney, by the Rev. W. J. K. Piddington, Alexander, seventh
son of Archibald Graham, Wollongong, to Esther, fourth
daughter of John Donoghoe, of Bungendore.
SWYNY-HAWKINS.-December 17, at the Wesleyan Church,
Vegetable Creek, by the Rev. Luke Parr, Edward John, third
son of George Swyny, Sydney, to Mary, second daughter of
William G. Hawkins of Vegetable Creek.
WILKINSON -MERRY.-December 17, at Enfield, near Sydney,
by the Rev. J. Graham, Tom Bradbury, second son of the late
David Wilkinson, Esq., of Thowesbridge, Huddersfield, to
Ellen Jane, eldest daughter of the late Alfred George Merry,
Esq., of Bristol, England.
Deaths.
AMBROSE.-December 22, at her parents' residence, Elizabeth-
street South, Waterloo, Ephemia Constance, the beloved and
only daughter of Morgan and Elizabeth Josephine Ambrose, of
diphtheria, aged 11 months 11 days.
HOLDSWORTH.-December 7, at his late residence, Queensbury
House, Denison-street, Woollahra, John Holdsworth, third
eldest son of Mr. John Holdsworth, Queensbury, Yorkshire,
England, leaving a wife and three children and a large circle of
friends to mourn their irreparable loss.
KINGSBURY.-December 20, in Redfern-street, Luella, infant
daughter of Fred. and Lizzie Kingsbury, aged 1 year and 6
months.
McKINNEY.-December 22, of congestion of the lungs at 137,
Elizabeth-street, Sydney, Isabella Sarah, infant daughter of H.
G. and Marian McKinney.
MYERS.-December 20, Solomon Myers, son of Mrs. P. Myers,
of Liverpool-street, aged 35 years.
WARK.-December 20, at Avoca, Bathurst, Margaret Anderson,
wife of J. N. Wark, aged 55 years.

title: CENTRAL POLICE COURT.
content:
CENTRAL POLICE COURT.
i . , TUESDAY.
BLI'OIIE . their ^Vorships the Police Magistrate,, Messrs.
Aunitage, Cohen, Hogg, and Dangar.
Of tuchoprisimeisï one was discharged and anothei was
lemanded.
Two peieons were fined Se. each, and three 10s. each, foi
drunkenness ; and one wag fined 20s. tor using obsceno lan-
guage.
Pet« Healey was yesterday charged with stealing from
tho person. Constable Short deposed that between 4 and 5
o'clock on Sunday morning ho saw prisoner and
»notber man loitering between St. James's iChurchr
(i(nd Hyde, Park;' "while he ¡was looking after
them n gcnflemon passsu (hera, andas he passed they mad0
a roth al bim ; he (witness) ran up and apprehended the
priMner, the other iiirin" making his escape; on searching^
prif-oncr at the lock-up under his coat was found a hacj
.(pitjduccdV ^vthifch was aftertt-ards« claimed \b}v"a, persona
l&n 111,0(1 Cole, who reported that kqliad been^rpbbed qf his';
*liat,>, j bodtsi ¡handkerchief,1 j and a*| purse f <con
r twining ¡money. v Cole {«(ott1 being fin ^attcnâkaca,<
f nirisoiterîWis ^remanded 'untilvthis morning, ,wuen -Xessey
H Cole^dcpôicd th'ot oh Sa'rurdajvnight" he vras under the
Mp'flucnco of liquor, and went lo H}de Purk, where he fell
nklctp ;"Mio awoko about 5 on Sunday morning,
and found that he had been robbed of lus
puree, in wkich were two £l-notos and about
os. in silver, his boots, "n . handkerchief;.-}, and
his lint; the hat produced i^ "his"" property, tifid was-'stolen
Tronï him "on the "occasion rcfened to." Prisoner, who
declared, his innocence of the charge, was committed for1
trial at (ho Quarter Sessions.
Surah Jones and Mar}- Mooney, idle and disorderly per
Bon>, having neither fixed abode nor lawful means of sup-
port, were kentenecd to bo imprisoned one month.
Andrew Gray was brought before the Bench, on warrant,
charged with having deserted Lucy, his wife, leaving ker
without ïhe meads of subsistence. Mr. Thompson ap-
peared for complainant, and Mr. Carroll for the defence.
Lucy Gray, a native of Limita, Fiji, deposed that
sho was married to défendant by Dr. Fullerton,
about two months ago, and tkey lived together
. until Saturday last, when defendant beat her,
kirkod ker, oud turned her out of the house ; he has sold
all the furniture and her clothes, and told her that he was
about to go to San Francisco ; sho is entirely without
means, having nolking more than sko stands up in ; wken
sho ninrricd défendant «ho had about £15 in tfio Savings
Bniik, and since marrineo defendant has given
her money to lodge with her» in the Savings
Bank, but ko has drawn out the whole amount both of tho
£15 and the money ehe deposited for him ; she has now no
money, he having received the wholo ; she was living in
hi r own house when defendant proposed marriage ; she at
first objected, but afterwards yielded, as ho promised
that he would bo a good husband to her ; her furniture
was worth £18 or thereabouts ; defendant lived with her
eight or nine months before ho proposed mnrriiigo. For the
delineo the defendant was examined. Ho deposed that on
Satuiday his wifo assaulted him, and then he merely laid
hold of her to prevent her violence ; ho has given ker about |
£40 since ho married her, £15 of which sho spent in clothes
and jewellery for herself ; ho has not hud moro than about
£5 of money, whioh was not originally his own ; they have
lived upon the best of everything, in which way the money
has been expended ; ho did not ill-treat his wife, nor turn
her out or tho house. Their Worships made an
order for payment of 7B. Gd. a week, and required
dofendant to givo »ecurity for twelvo months' payments,
or in default thereof to be imprisoned not exceeding twelve
months.
On tho summons paper wcro eleven cases. William
Smith was fined 10s., and Jeremiah Callaghan 20s.,
forl making ubo of obsceno language- John
Michael and William Chinnock wcro fined 10s. each,
for! riotous behaviour. Robert Drummoro was fined
5s. I for allowing a-horse, his property, to stray and
bo at largo. Henry Griffiths was lined 10s., for placing
gooda upon the caniago-way of Pitt-street and neglecting
to remove tkem whon required to do so. Thomas Hassan
and Joseph Hudson were (¡ned 10a. each, for standing witk
their omnibuses in George-street a longer time'than was
necessary to take up or put down passengers. Ono caso
was postponed.
TUB ROBTEII.-Messrs. Chapman, Day, and Renwick
kata been BUtnuioned for Bench duty on Wednesday.

title: ALBURY RACES.
content:
ALBURY RACES.
[By Telegraph.]*
(PROM OUR OWX CORRESroXnEN..)
ALBURY, Thursdat.
Tho attendance of visitors to-day was not so good as
yesterday. The weather was much hotter, and the wholo
affair less pleasant. Several disputes/occurred. The follow-
ing are the results :
Mares Produce Stakes.-Albert 1, Tams 2. Only
three started.
Corinthian' Cur.-Paton's bay filly Mavis 1. The
weights for this race being fixed too low to start amateur
riders, all entries but two wero scratched. The contest,
therefore, becamo a match which was won easily by Mavis.
Hurdle Race.-Prinoo Alfred came in first, but, in
consequence of certain circumstances brought under the
notice of tho stewards, the race was declared no race.
Prince Alfred and his owner were disqualified for twelve
months. Mr. Williams, for scratching a horse after weigh-
ing out, was fined £25.
Ture Club Handicap. - Albyn 1, Robinhood 2.
Only three started, and Albyn won easily in 2 minutes 45
seconds. Tho owner of Robin Hood entered a protest on
the ground that Albyn did not carry the full penalty for the
Cup, but the protest was dismissed.
Ladies' Mile.-Bonny Rose 1, Mavis 2, Eclipse 3.
Nine started. This was the best mee of the day. Time :
1 minute 48 seconds.
Consultation Stakes.-Kintmoa 1, Feathertop 2,
Hetmán Plutolï 3.

title: PRINCE OF WALES VISIT TO INDIA.
content:
P, RINCE OF WALES VISIT TO INDIA.
A supplementary navy estímalo has boen issued of tho I
sum íerjuired to defray tho charges conséquent on the visit I
of the ¡Princo of AVales to India, which/ shall como in
com so of payment in-the year ending tho 31st of March,'
1876. ¡ Assuming the Sorapis and Osborne leavo
England in October, 1875, and do not leave India
before ¡the close of the financial year_ 1875-76, tho |
additional expenditure for tho current year is estimated at
£42,850. The charges which will bo incurred in tho yeai4
18<(i-77 aro estimated at £9360, making a total for tho two
j ears of £62,210. The approaching visit excites great
interest'not only in India but throughout tho East, and not
less umpng tho nativo population than among,«European
residents. Tho Jiombay Gazette announces that "the
Mahai aja of Jeyporo is making great preparations for
giving tho Prince a magnificent, reception in his capital.
Ho is about constructing a racecourse, and introducing gas
lights.'i The formation of tho Camp of Exorcise at Delhi,
at which 20,000 men will bo assembled, will bo determined
ly the date of his Royal Highness' arrival in India. The
regiments that aro to take part in tho manoeuvres havn
ahcady[boen named. A public meeting of tho inhabitants
of Bombay is to be called to consider the best means of pro
?viding '¡a, suitablo reception Jor the Prince. The Chinese
papers expicss a hopo that his Royal Highness may he in
'__ccd t«J visit Hongkong after leaving India.

title: BRIGHAM YOUNG'S MESSAGE.
content:
BRIGHAM YOUNG'S MESSAGE. '
THE message of Brigham Young, delivered according
to the Salt Lake iVetci, "orally, on Monday, Feb-
ruary 22nd, to the Senate and House of Represent-
atives of the State of DeBeret," at Salt Lake City,
occupies nearly one and a halt columns of that paper.
We make the following extract :
We have met in the capacity of a State Legislature
with a view to preserve our organisation, and with an
eye to the time when, in the wisdom of God, He will
move upon the minds of Senators and Members of
Congrecs to give us oar legal, national, and legitimate
rights. We wait with patience to see this done.
Perhaps to some it «vould seem unnecessary to keep
up this organisation ; but it is that we may preserve
our identity as a part of the nation that we assemble
annually in this capacity. If the machinery
is kept in order, when the time shall come
for the water to be turned upon it there will
be no difficulty in starting it. It is not so much
to enact laws and to sit in a Legislative capacity that
we now meet, as to recognise our rights ; and in
doing so we do no more than others have done and no
more than is our right to do. If we who live in this
country were disposed to meet in this capacity three
hundred and sixty-five days in the year, it would con-
cern nobody but ourselves, except meddlers and those
who wish to infringe upon the rights of our neighbours.
In a republican government like ours it is our right to
meet as we do to-day. We have the undoubted right
to meet together and consult upon those points,of
governmental affairs that pertain to our future peace,
end to gather the necessary information to enable us
to proceed further in the'duties of life. Whether,lin
the providences of God, we Bhall be admitted aa a
State or not we leave with him. He will do as He
pleaseB ; the hearts of all living are in His hands, and
whattver condition He permits us to live in we shall
accept and conform to. Gentlemen, in coming together
to-day as the representa'ives of Deseret, we have the
proud satisfaction of knowing that we represent a people
capable in every respectif governing and controlling
themselves. We in this country have achieved a
freedom and independence such as are rarely pos-
sessed by any people in these days. We raise our
own bread and eat it ; we make our bridges and
streets and pay fur them ; we erect our public
buildings, develope our resources, sustain our Govern-
ment and officers, and are not in debt. That
which is accumulated as income from taxation is
appropriated for the benefit of the people. We have
no bondB in market for greedy financiers to speculate
in, to prove a cause of embarrassment to ourselves
or a vexation and announce to our children. Our
legislators have been wise enough not to go beyond
their ability, and burden the people with a heavy
indebtedness without having resources to refund the
same. Should we be aelmitted as a State, I look for
the snn.e policy to be pursued ; we shall
not fall into debt, _ but always live within
our mennB. This is the secret of succesB
with men, communities, and nations. Take men
in any capacity whatever, whether singly or
otheiwisc, and you will find that if they live within
their means they will be independent and powerful.
It is so in the case of a single individual, ana it is in-
creased))- so with a community or nation. We, as a
people, have had wisdom enough to perceive and act
upon this. A people or Government rtat will suffer,
itself to get entangled through avarice or other causes,'
and bring upon ita people war and indebtedness, and
then poverty and distress, proves that it is not capable
of exercising the proper lights of government. But a
nation that can maintain peace within i's borders and
with its neighbours, exhibits knowledge, wisdom, and
power that muBt eventually call forth the respect and
admiiation of the world. Thus far we have been able
J .to piestive ourselves from such contingencies. It is
true that war has been made upon us ; but the sword
of indignation has fallen harmless at our feet. Yet
o,ur own .wisdom did not produce this; it was by the
powtr and wisdom of God, which He imparts to those
who live eo as to receive them that they may preserve
themselves. j
ON POVEBTV.-111 informed in political economy,
the poor are worse informed in all matters of domestic
economy. Having scant wages to live upon, they
rarely spend those wages in the most prudent and
profitable wav s. They are too often the prey to their
own perverted tastes, and to the tricksters who trade
upon those tastes. They buy bad food, and cook it
badlj ; their bodies ore dirty," their clothes are dirty,
their hcmeB are dirty. Disgusted thereby, and
afflicted by the hopelessness of their condition, it is
almost a tule for them to stifle their feelings in un-
wholesome drink ; and thus they pass, from bad to
woice. Every clergyman, every dector, every one who
knows anything of the dwellings of the poor, can give
us instances. without number of the waste
ar.d unthrift that there abound. People whese
earnings are barely enough, with the strictest
economy, to supply their most pressing needs;
practise no economy at all. Families that
have, perhaps, twelve or fifteen shillings a, week
to subsist on, do not get more than eight or ten
shillings' worth of actual subsistence. The rest is
squandered foolishly or viciously. For this the poor
themselves are very little to blame, How can they
be expected to do better when they have never been
taught, when their cares are so overwhelming, when
they have every inducement to despondency and
none to hope ? Yet this is surely a matter in which
charitable persons, charitable women especially, might
exercise their charity with unspeakable advantage.
Much they do ; but very much more has to be done
befe re any important change can be wrought in the
eccnomic habits of our mulions of poor. So muoh
that any thorough reformation must be despaired of,
unlees another branch of education-in correction of
the third sort of ignorance here to be alluded
to, and the most ruinous of all-is also zealously
promoted. No great improvement in the con-
dition and prospects of the poor can be hoped tor
until they are taught to exercise ordinary prudence
in limiting the size of their families in accordance
with their means of decently and healthily maintain-
ing those families. Tbis ÍB not the occasion for dis-
cussing the general question of Malfhusianism, as it
is called. The great law of population, first enunciated
by the Rev. Thomas Robert Malthus in 1798-that
whilst, in the most favourable circumstances, the
food-producing powers of land can only he expected
to increase in an arithmetical ratio, population always
Ur.ds to incieaeo in a geometrioal ratio; and that
accordingly, unleBB the area of population can be
adequately extended, its proper growth U inevitably
restricted by famine, plague, war, and other in-
voluntary checks, if not by voluntary checks
resorted to by man himself-is SB simple and
ir controveí tibie as the Newtonian law of gravition.
At any rate, though many have ridiculed
it, and many more haTe ignored it, no one has
ever seriously attempted to controvert it. Multitudes
have rejeced it without consenting to reason upon it;
but all of the few who have reasonably considered it,
have been ferced to adopt it. The precise bearings of
the law and its detailed applications, however, include
many problems that have yet to be settled. We do
not vet know how rnanv inhabitants our own country,
for instance, can be fairly expected to maintain in
that measure of comfort which all human beings haye
a right to claim ; nor have the possibility and ex-
pedience of drafting off to other and thinly peopled
districts those of our offspring for whom there is no
room in. the me ther country, been properly taken
account of; nor have the special means by which the
law shall be ec forced been dulv investigated and
defined. These questions and others like them are
worihy of careful consideration, and will have to be
considered before long. But we need not, and may
Ineit, wait for that time before recognising the force of
trc law in its relation to the present state of the poor. I
- Vndtrtht C'totcn. t
BALANCE OF-THE ANIMAL AND VEOBTAHLE KINODOMS
IN AK AQUARIUM.-In Chamber ft Miscellany we find
the following :- In remarking .upon the result;
of his experiments, Mr. Warrington observes, " Thus
we have that admirable balance sustained between the
animal and vegetable kingdoms, and that in a liquid
element. The fish, in ita respiration, consumes the
oxygen held in solution by the water as atmospheric
air, furnishes carbonic acid, feeds on the insects and
ycung snails, and excretes material well adapted as a
rich food to the plant, and well fitted for its luxuriant;
growth. The plant, by its respiration, consumes the
carbonic acid produced by the fish, appropriating the
carbon to the construction of ita tissues and fibres«
and liberates the oxygen in its gaseous state to sustain
the healthy functions of the animal life; at the same
time that it feeds on the rejected matter, which has
fulfilled its purposes in the nourishment of the _ fish
and snail, end preserves the water constantly in a
clean and healthy'condition. While the slimy snail,
finding its proper nutriment in the decomposing
vegetoble matter and minute confervoid growth, pre-
vents their accumulation by removing them ; and by
its vital powers" converts what would otherwise act as
a poison into a rich and fruitful nutriment, again to
constitute a pabulum for the vegetable growth, while
it also acts the important.- part of a purveyor to its
finny neighbours." This perfect adjustment in the
economy of the animal and vegetable kingdoms,
whereby the vital functions of each are permanently
maintained, is one of the most beautiful phenomena
ef organic nature. In the marine aquarium, the pre-
sence of molluscs is as necessary as in the fresh-water
aquarium, to prevent an excessive growth of con
fen a.-, which otherwise soon make the water turbid
witn their innumerable green seeds or spores, and
obscure the glass by establishing themselves upon it
in vast colonies. The common periwinkle, topshell,
and limpet are very suitable for this purpose.
TUB New York Tribune uses the tallest language in
reporting the ceremony of the 4th instant. Mr.
Lincoln's words are recalled as " beautiful and elo-
quent," and " the sad spectacle of a drunken Vice
President" is flung at the back of the out-going
Chief Magistrate. There is not much exaggeration in
this ; indeed, it is not until the Tribune reporter
arrived in the ball room of the Waite House that he
wiitCB " high falutin." Then, possibly the united
effect of the scene and champagne induced him to pen
the following rapturous description of the Inaugural
Ball:-"Thebrilliant scene presented within and with-
out the building, radiant in colour, glowing with light,
brilliant like tropical flowers or the plumage of hum-
ming birds, and ever shifting and varying like a many
hued and constantly-changing kaleidoscope. Fahr faces,
lovely forms, penetrant perfumes diffused as the
brilliant robes moved about their wearers ; distin-
guished men, bearing names renowned in war, states
manship, letters, and the other activities of our
crowding life, clothed in the martial uniform, wearing
the orders and diplomatic insignia of their own
sovereignties, or, better still, in the simple if sombro
dress of the American citizen ; all these and much
more met and mingled here. Great waves of music
puh-ated along the heated and perfumed atmosphere,
and the witching mazes of the dance, and the moro
bewitching forms of the dancers-the ladies of coursa
-with all the brilliancy and beauty of colour and
fe rm, made up a scene worthy of pencil or pen*, yet
both must fail in any attempt to render it fitly."
POSITION OF THE WAK MINISTER.-The Royal
Older which defines the relation of the Commander-
in-Chief to the Queen, the Army, and the War Office^
was published on Saturday. Now that it has been
biought to light, the discovery of the Sangraal should
not be despaired of. Member after member of the
House of Commons has gone in search of it, blun-
dered, gone far astray, lost himself, and then re-
turned to sit down in dumb resignation. The jealousy
with which its official guardians kept their secret, and
their blank complacent look while the representatives
of the public were stumbling about in the dark after
it, vveie admirable in their way, but they are now
things of the paBt. The Order has become
a public document, and now that it is
submitted to the judgment of the country we
expect to hear no more of the dispute whether ^4
the Army is or is not under a dual government.
The Roj al Order, which is dated Balmoral, October,
1861-five years after the Duke of Cambridge had
been appointed to the chief command-defines the
position of his Rojal Highness in no mere incidental
mssner. The purpose for which it was framed is
declared to be "to prevent any doubts as to the
powers and duties of the Commander-in-Chief."
The Order does not, however, set forth what those
powers and duties are, but after staling to what
they relate-the government of the Army and the
administration of military affairs-it directs that
" they ßhall be excepted from the Department of
the Secretary of State for War." A second para-
graph of the Order completes the purpose of the
tim, by strictly appropriating to the Commander
in-Chief all the powers and business relating to the
matters - aforementioned. The latter are "to be
deemed to belong to hiß office," and to be ad
mini&teied, "subject to our (the Royal) general
control over the government of the Army, and to the
responsibility of the Secretary of State." Responsi-
bility for what ? Of course not for the act of the
Commander-in-Chief, whose powers and duties are
excepted from the Department of the Secretary of
State for War, but, as the* Order further explains,
" for the exercise of our Royal prerogative in that -
behalf, and subject to any powers formerly exercised
by the Secretary at War. No words could more
plainly mark out the position of a great and in-
dependent e fficer of the State, who has the power of a
Minister without a Minister's responsibility. We do
not now ask whether this is an objectionable arrange-
ment, or the best that could be made ; we are only
'calling attention to the evidence of the fact. The
meaning and intention of the Older are beyond
doubt, and so far BB they go they are in derogation
of the principle of responsible government which
Englishmen are sSipposed to value highly.-Daily
Neus.
THE DECAY 01 THE HOUSE OI COMMONS.
It is very unsatisfactory to find that before the new
Houses of Parliament have been fully completed, they
are actually decaying in parts ; and the same esti-
mates include votes for the building itself, and for the
appliances to arrest the progress of destruction. The
stone of which it is constructed was taken from a
Yorks!: ire quarry on the recommendation of a com-
mission appointed to inquire into the subject, but
almost immediately after being placed in position, this
particular stone began to shew signB of decay. The
facade of the building was marked by large patches,
and the Gothic tracery of the architecture was sadly
disfigured. So far back as 1857 various processes for
preserving the stone were tried on different parts of the
building, and subsequently Professor Faraday and Sir
Roderick Murchison were requested to give their opin-
ions on the relative merits of such methods. They con-
curred in awarding the pre-eminence to the process
of M. Szerelmy, of which the particulars are, of
course, a secret. Professor Faraday, in his report,
said that so far as a judgment could be formed upon
two years' experience, he believed that the process
would sustain its character for a lengthened period, of
time. '' I do not find," said the learned professor,
"in other parts of the building," where M. Szerelmy'»
application is more than two years old, any signs of
exfoliation, or defection of the prepared face of the
stone, or any grounds for fear in that respect." The
process has been applied with equal success to the
iron of the roof, which was deteriorating at an equally
rapid rate. Part of it had been coated with »ino or
galvanized iron. This had scarcely been fixed when
it showed signs of preihature oxydation. M.
Szerelmy's preparation was applied to one of the
affected parts, and also to the gilding of the clock
tower. On a careful examination last year, it was
found that the portion treated with the preservative
material was perfectly sound, while the rest of the roof
had suffered more or less from atmospheric influences.
The First Commissioner of Works has accordingly
directed that the remainder of the roof should be
covered with the composition. Meanwhile the stone-
work shews signs of disintegration, and there is som«
ground for the anticipation that, so far as external ap-
pearances are concerned, the new Palace at West-
minster will shortly look as ancient as the venerable
Abbey, which reckons as many centuries as Sir
Charles Barry's costly building can reckon years,
M. Szerelmy's process is capable of application to
many kinds of building materials. Experiments have
been tried on stone, brick, iron railings, and timber,
with very gratifying results. Pieces of timber coated '
with the preparation have been sunk for two year» in
he water at Portsmouth, and are now perfectly sound.
Textile fabrics are also rendered waterproof and in-
destructible by it.
Ar-pAux-iNo ENTERTAINMENT.-Mr. Howard Paul,
who is always indulging in some form of eccentric
advertising, announces in the Daily TsUgraph that he
will give JE6 fur a short sharp title for hil Entertain-
ment at St. James's Hall. We will present him with
one end forego the prize. " Cheek ! " That's short
and sharp enough, and in Mr. Paul'« case more or
less appropriate-which cannot be said of all titles.
Quiz.
A Cockney at the Falls of Niagara, when asked
how he liked the Falls, replied-" They're 'antoine
-quite so ; but they don't quite hanser my hexpecta
tions ; besides, I got vetted, and lost my 'at. I pieter
to l9ok at 'em in the ¿engraving, in 'ot weather, and
in the 'ouse." *

title: WATER POLICE COURT.
content:
. WATER POLICE COURT.
FRIDAY.
BEFORE tho Water Police Magistrate, and Messrs. Hole,
Lester, and Spence.
Several persons were fined for drunkenness.
Assam, a lascar seaman belonging' to' the barque Ash«
hulton, vas sent to gool for ono month for wilful dis-
obedience. '
William Stritch, alias John Stritch, appeared on remand!
charged with that ho did feloniously and violently assault
one Jone Roberts,'and did violently, and against her will,
feloniously ravish and carnally know hor. Prisoner waa)
further remnnded. ,
Georgo Marshall was charged on warrant with em-
bezzling the sum of £26 Os. 3Jd., tho property of John
Farrell. Tho money embezzled was received by prisoner '
for and on account of prosecutor. Remanded until Friday
next.
Neils Polisón was brought before tho Court hy special
constable Dunycr, charged with refusing to pay his faro by
tho steamer Egmont, which arrived from Rockhampton
yesterday morning. Mr. Beal, tho chief officer of tho
.vessel, deposed that prisoner was discovered on board two
da}B niter leaving Rockhampton, and when applied to for
-his f mc, ho said ho could not givo it, as ho had no money.
To pay a penalty of £6, in default to go to gaol for three*
months. i
Mary Ledwell, alias M'Donald, was charged with using"
threatening language to Mrs. M'Crca, and was bound over
to keep the pence for twelve months, herself in £10, and one)
surety in a similar amount. ' ."
SUMMONS SHEET.-The summons sheet contained five)
cuses, ono of which was postponed, ono dismissed» and in
one there wcio no parties. John L. Murphy was,fined 40s.,
and as. costs of Court, for allowing tho contents of a water
closet to soak therefrom. In a wages case the amount
cloimcd was paid into Court. '

title: THE HOLY SEPULCHRE.
content:
TUE HOLY'SEPULCimEÎ
"Wf, ti ansíate the following from our contemporary The
Ou I, vv hich publishes tho French toxt of tho circular, whioh
Ins convoyed the suggestions of the Empress Eigénio to
tho Queen-Sovereigns of Europe.
"Travellers who visit tho Holy Land are astonished at'
the dilapidation which tlio dome that covers and sholters
the Ilcijy Sepulchre has presented for many yoara. Thoy
ask how it is that the Christian Powers havo not hastened
to tut nu end to a state of things afflicting to tho faithful
of au communions. Tho roason, it must bo said, is that on
this land, stained with the blood of tho Redeemer, whioh
has leen the eradlo of tho roligion of brotherhood, of peace,
nnd concord, pitiful rivalries exist betwoen tho dînèrent
communions, and that in course of timo these rivalries have
become seriouB dissensions.
_ " Formerly tho Latins rebuilt the domo and ornamented
it vvith inscriptions and emblems which recallod tho kind
of precedence they then possessed in tho enjoyment of this
monument. Tho domo was burned in 1808, and circum
BtnnccB having given the Greeks a preponderance ia
Palestine, (hey profited by it to reconstruct tho church, to
he exclufion ot tho Latins. In their turn they applied
themselves to covering the monument vvith inscriptions
and images borrowed from their language and liturgy.
"At present, Greeks and Latins confront oaeh other.
Ono party demands tho reconstruction of the domo as it
inttcd before 1808 : tlio others demand a reconstruction
«Tourinp; their olnim of possession or of vested rights,
ino gi cat Powers, France and Russia, animated by the
ttost hoDiurablo sentiments, havo sought to put an ond to
those deplorable manifestations. Thoy first endeavoured to
Mine to nn 'understanding among themselves; thon, with
i n**' ' nn(?on SePtemDCr 5th, 1861, a protocol was signed
Ja CùHfctnntinople, J establishing tho accord of tho threo
Governments, and indicating tho conditions agreed to with
<j view of carrying out in common tho reconstruction of tho
«eme. JBut when thoy proceeded to execute tho project,
v'he-n the architects had prepared their plans, and it was
necessary to interpret somo slightly dubious clauses of tho .
protocol of September fith, now dissensions aroso undor tho t
lnfiuenco of local rivalries. Nothing was done, and all was '
once moro, left in* uncertainty. During this timo tho.ruin
oflho dome becamo more una more imminent, the personal
Jjj*ty of tho pilgrims -who carno to pray at the Holy.
«p*4chto'yrji¡' endangered, and the ovil .increased until ltl
«canio'a- Bcandal.''Hovr'could' tuvead'bo'ftif to'this cod>"
dillon of affairs ? It was a pions princess, St. Helena-the ,
mother of tho Emperor Constantine-*who at tho commence-
ment of the fourth century caused the Pagan templo built
above the grotto of.the Holy Sepulchre tobo demolished,
and on tho samo spot raised for tho first timo the sanctuary
destined to cover the tomb of Jesus Christ. Why should
not tho princesses of all Christian countries, animating
themselves with this glorious memory, como to an agree-
ment to carry'out at last, under conditions worthy of
themselves and of Christianity, tho work in which tho
(tim I« of diplomacy havo not hitherto boon ablo to succeed ?
Who would refuse to listen to their voice, when, placing
themselves boyond tho region of politics, strangers to all
contentious, ideas, thoy would speak in tho name of pioty
and of Christian charity, and would address an appeal to
iho fuithful throughout tho wholo world, on a, subject which
ought to bo cquallv dear to all> But, in order that tho
work should completely respond to tlio spirit of Christian
conciliation which has inspired it, tho simple reconstruction
of the domo should not bo tho only object aimed at. Tt
would be advisable, alter having obtained tho consont of
tho Sublimo Porte, to entirely rebuild tho Church of tho
liol} Sopulchro on n now plon, and on a larger scalo, so
that it might alford accommodation for all communions.
Thus, for example, there should bo on one side a chapel,
and even a navo, consecrated to tho uso of the Latins, and
on (ho other a navo and a chapel rosorvod for the ubo
of tlio Greeks. Tho principal navo should be open to all,
and (ho, access of tho_ faithful to tho Holy Sopulohro, at
present eo diiliuilt, giving rise to frcquont disturbances,
would be freed fiom all hindrances. Tlio majesty of tho
new ponctuai y should as much as pOssiblo equal that of
the snered associations which uro' rccallod by thoso sacred
place«. For theo reasons a competition might bo oponed,
m-which tho architects and artists of-all countries should
be invited lo toko part, and an international jury might
I select from among the designs sent by them that vvluch, in
a purely nrtjstic pouit of view, might bo deemed tho most
worthy of so great an idea. As io tho funds necessary for
commencing and comploting without delay tho new Clrarch
of the Holy Sepulchre, thoy coiüd bo-furnished by a uni-
versal subscriplion, at the hoad of which all the Christian
Fnuccsflcs would no doubt vis with oaoh othpr in inscribing
then names."- Ms Weekly Messenger, Maroh Uth. ,

TO GEORGE HARRISON PEMBERTON, formerly of
Quebec, in the dominion of Canada, Esquiro.
Bin,-A citation having beon iBsuod on the tenth day of'
August, 1872, out of bor Britannic Majesty's Suprcute Court
for China and Japan, addressed to you the said Ooorgo Har-
rison Pemberton, and as your address is notknown, notice is
hereby given to you thereof and that such citation is now
at my cilice where it may be inspected and is in the words

66, Hunter-street, Sydney.

In her Britannfo Majesty's Supremo Court for China and
J upan, at Shanghai.
Victoria, by tho grace of God of the tho United Kingdom
of Great 'Britain and Ireland Queen, Defender of the
Faith.
To Georgo li. Pemberton, of Quebec, in tho dominion of
Canada, Esquile.
Whereas it appears by an affidavit of CHARLES LYALL
GRANT, of Foochow, in tho Empiro of China, Morchant,
swoin on the 18th day of July, 1872. and filed in tho registry
of our Supicmo Court, for China and Japan, at Shanghai,
that tho said Churlos Lyall Grant, of !? oochow aforesaid,
claiming to be one of tho Executors of HENRY GUY
PEMBERTON, late of Foochow aforesaid, Merchant, de-
ceived, who died on or about tho 8t.li day of Dooombor
1871, at Benares, in India, intends to provo in solomn form
of law tho alleged last will and testamont of tho said do
cenked, bearing dato tho 2lBt day of Novombor, 1865, and
that the said deceased died a biicholor, without parent, and
that you tho said GEORGE H. PEMBERTON aro tho
natural and lawful brother, and ono of the naxt of kin of
' the said deceased, and ouo of tho portons entitled to hn
personal estate and eil'ects in ease ho bo pronounced to havo
died intestate. ?
Now this.is to command you the said Georgo H. Pem-
berton that within two mouths after service hereof on
j ou, inclusive oi tho day of such service, j ou do causo an
appearance to bo entered for you in our Supremo Court for
China And Japan at Shanghai in support of any interest
you may havo in tho pt rsoiml cstato and ciloets of the said
deceased : And take notico that in default of your so
doing tho Judgo of our said Court will proceed to hear tho
said will proved in solemn form of law, aud to pronounce
Bcntcnco m regard to tho validity of tho same, your absonco
notwithstanding.
Dated this tenth day of August, 1872, and in tho thirty
sixth year of our reign.
(L.8.) R. A. MOWAT,
Registrar.

It has como to our knowledge that a roport hns boon indus-
triously circulated by somo dishonest person to tho effect
that the CLARET, CHABLIS, SAUTERNE, and other
WINES imported and sold by us, with a label bearing the
above mark,,nnd tho name of A. VIGOTJROUS undor
neath, aro composed partly or wholely of colonial winos,
and that tho cases, bottles, &o. aro imported empty ! ! and
filled hero. However ridiculous this may appear to mer-
cantile men, and those possessed of tho modorato amount of
knowledge necessary to enable them to distinguish French
from Australian wines, it may mislead others. Wo will
therefore pay £50 to any person who will givo us such infor-
mation as shall lead to tho conviction for slander of the
originator of this report.
To set at rest any fin thor doubt on this subject, wo havo
determined for the future, whonovcr it is practicable, to sell
theso wines in bond, leaving tho purchaser to pay tho
import duty,

title: LEGISLATIVE ASSEMBLY.
content:
LEGISLATIVE ASSEMBLY. i
THURSDAY.
THE SrEAKEa took tho chair at twenty-oight minutes
putt 3 o'clock.
CORONER AT WAGGA WAGGA.
, Mr. BUCHANAN asked the Colonial Socretary,
" 1. Did the Coroner of Wagga Wagga write the Colonial
Secretary a letter in dofenco of his conduct in reference to
ihc inquest on the death of Mrs. Rush ? 2. In that letter,
<.r in any communication from the Coroner of Wagga
Wnggo, did ho state that the sistcrB and brother-in-law of
Rush informed him that Rush hnd been addicted to drink-
ing for mnny yenrs past up to the present time ? 3. Is tho
Colonial Secretary aware that the two sisters of Rush, also
his brother-in-law, havo made affidavits, which affidavits
have appeared in the public papers, to tho effect that thoy
never communicated to tho Coroner of Wagga Wagga any
such information OB the Coroner asserts they did, in his
letter to tho Colonial Secretary; and that thoy also,
in theeo affidavits, allege that Rush is now, nnd
nlvvnys han been, a temperate and sober man ? 4. Is tho
Colonial Secretary aware that Rush himself, aB well as
his sisters and brother-in-law, in tho affidavits referred to,
nllrge that, in consequence of tho cruelty and neglect of
duty on the part of the Coronor of Waorga Wagga, in oom
iptjKing Rush to bring the dead body of his wife a distance
of over thirty miles, BO that an inquest might be hold, in-
stead of himself going to whero tho woman died, and there
¡holding tho inquest, so pained and distressed Rush, tho
¡husband, that his mind gavo wny under it, and ho remained
¡for nome timo in a state of temporary insanity ? fi. Has
'the Colonial Secretary removed the Coroner of Wagga
j Wogga from his position, or ia it his intention to do so,
¡without further delay Í "
Mr. COWPER, in reply, stated that a lotter from tho
'Coioner nt Wagga Wagga had been recoived at his office,
and was rend by him to the Houso some time ago. He
, hardly thought it necessary to repeat the information whioh
, was eoniained in that letter. Yesterday certain affidavits
. wero received nt his office, but he had not yet had time to
, read thom. They would bo laid on the tablo on Tuesday
next. In the moantimo no docision had been arrived at by
' tLe Government.
ROAD l'ROM GOULBURN TO BRAIDWOOD.
Mr. GARRETT, for Mr. Butler, asked the Secretary for
Lauds,-"When will tho Government proclaim the road
iioui Goulburn to Braidwood, and tho deviation therefrom
frctn Taralga to Queanbeyan?"
Mr. COWPER enid tho road from Goulburn to Braid
w ood hnd boen proclaimed, and would bbortly bo proceeded
with. Tho deviation fiom Turnlga had been proclaimed,
but time would bnve to bo allowed for claims for compou
sntiou to be bent in.
MESSAGE.
Mr. SPEAKER announced the receipt of a Message
firm his Excellency the Governor, rerouiniendiug for tho
u usiderntion of the House further additional Estimates for
tho j car 1S70.
It was ordered thnt tho MesBngo nnd accompanying Esti-
mules should be printed, and taken into consideration in
Committee of Supply.
WATER SUPPLY.
Mr. WILSON moved, without notice,-"That the seleot
committee <.n tho question of the water supply to Sydney
and the tuburbs havo leave to make visits of inspection."
Tho motion was agreed to.

Your correspondent " G. II. C." has quoted, from a '

Those seasons ai o recoidcd to "have happened in cycles,
as follows, viz. ;
Wot period, 1799 to 1821 =22 years.
Diy period, 1821 to 1S41 = 20 years.
Wet period, 18-11 to 1804 = 23 years.
Jn all (iel years, divisible into periods approximately of 22 ,

of contact between the cold waters and tho hot waterB of
' the Gulf Stream (those aro the winter and European tem-
pests) ; tho others inversely produced at this limit by the
¡piedominanco of the Equatorial current and tho back Dow
¡of tho Polar current (theso aro the truo equinoctial hnrri
' ernies which reach us from tho intertropical region, start
iing from 10' north latitude-}. lho relation bctwoci»
i those two systems of cyclonic perturbations seem«
j to consist "in the fact that the predominance
¡and energy of the Polar current corresponds to the minima
]nf the spots, while the predonrinunM and energy of the
¡Equatorial current corresponds to tho maxima of spota."
¡From some unknown causo the sun spots increase and
¡diminish with perfect regularity in number and intensity.
I Their period is 11¿ years.
e Jt may at fust sight bo surprising that a mere spot on
i the sun's disc should be neec mpnnied by-I mav say phonld
j <ausc-violent disturbance of our urmosphere. But surprise'
I will disappear when we remember that a spot on tho sun
' means a burst of llnmo leuol-ing sometimes sixty or eighty
i thousand miles in height, ami that such flames instantly.
Í ¡.fleet the electric state of our ntinosphtTo. ns is shown'by
' tho way in which clcctroiiietrrs nie nfleoted by them.
Now. as it is found that the number and intensity of
j min spots cause a predominance of equatorial or of polar
.'liironts in our aimosphere in B'uince, at I he Antilles, and
1 in the open North Atlantic Ocean, where observations
have been made, it is quito fair, by analogy, to argue that
ihey direct the predominance, of similar eui rents aB over the
world, in places in which the conditions happen to be
favourable to it; and where more likely so than on tho hot
dry continent of Au' tralia, which is surrounded hy ocean ?
It has been amply ascertained, by theory aB well as by
observations, that all main enrrentsin the ocean and in the
ainiûj-pbore are to and from tho eeniator and tho poles, 'the
equatorial currents being, in tho southern hemisphere;
from the north-west, and the pnhir from the south-east.
During tho lost past six months tho weather in New
South AVales has been exceedingly dru, whilst in Victoria
it has been equally wet.
It is worth while considering whether the dry season
horn is not caused by a pred<<minanc o of the equatorial
(north-west) current, and lho wet season of Victoria by a
predominance of the return cuiTent-south-east-from the
poles, and whether that predominan, o is not traceable
indirectly to the state of tho sun's atmosphere as manifested
to us through his '. spot."
It is quite possible that a limiting boundary between the
currents differently affected may bo caused by the physical
features of tho country - perhaps by certain mountain
ranges. . ,
It might bo also worth inquiring whether a di ought, in
New South AA'alcs is usually nccomptini»d by a wet season
in Yierteria. If it were found so. it wmi'd not necessarily
follow that a wet one here would bo concurrent with a dry
one theie.
JOHN MARTIN. '
Tub "Wesleyaxs.-The financial district meetings
have this year, according to the published reports,
been of unusual importance. They have had to elect
a ministerial member of the Committee appointed by
the Conference on the subject of Lay Representation.
The following are the mimstei s elected hythe districts,
mentioned :-First London, Rev. R. Roberts ; Second
London, Rev. J. Hargreaves ; Bedford and Northamp-
ton, Rev. J. Clulow ; Kent, Rev. J. Hall ; Norwich,
and Ljnn, Rev. R. M. Willcnx ; Oxford, Rev. J:
Mason ; Portsmouth, Rev. L. Waterhouse ; Channel
Islands, Ilev.W. Lindley ; Devonport, Rev. II. Jones ;
Corn-wall, Rev.W. Andrews ; Exeter,Rev. S.E.Rowe ;
Bristol, Rev. T. Nightingale ; Bath, Rev. J. II. Lord';
Swansea, Rev. E. J. Robinson ; South Walch, Rev.
D. Evans; North "Wales, Rev. S. Davies; Birming-
ham and Shrewsburj', Rev. W. Williams ; Maccles-
field, Rev. J. S. Jones ; Liverpool, Rev. C. Garrett ;
Manchester, Rev. M. Randles ; Bolton, Rev. H. Hast
ling ; Halifax and Bradford, Rev. J. Hartley ; Leeds,
Rev. S. Coley ; Sheffield, Rev. J. Clapham ; Notting-
ham and Derby, Rev. II. Blown ; Lincoln, Rev. Ti.
B. Waddy ; Hull, Rev. Dr. Lyth ; York, Rev. F. "W.
Briggs ; "Whitby and Darlington, Rev. II. J. Staley ;
New castle-upon-Tyne, Rev. F. Grèves; Carlisle,
Rev. G. Alton ; Isle of Man, Rev. II. Graham ; Zet-
land Isles, Rev. T. Horrell. Though elected by the
district meetings, the ministers cannot be looked
upon in every case as strictly representative,
because they did not give a statement ot their views
before their élection.. There was scarcely any dis-
cussion of the subject of lay representation in con-
nexion with these elections ; but theie will be ample
discussion in all the district, meetings in May( next',
when the preparations and decisions of the pommittce?
are laid I'.c-le.ie theui for then considération and vote.
These élections have been held in accordance with
the following résolutions," wlïich.were adopted at the
?Inst Conference:-rL ".The Conference w of opinion
'that the tiní'é is appronehhig when a comprehensive
¿ilan should be devised for some direct and adequate
representation ¡ of' the .laity'in, the ¡transaction ot
the business of the Conference, in consistency
'-with the recognised' principles' of our economy
and the provisions of ¿he Poll Deed ; but the
difficulties which present themselves, after much
'deliberation, are so serious that the Conference re-
solves to appoint two committees to further consider
the whole subject, and empoweis the first-named ol'
these two committees to take such counsel as they
may judge expedient on the legal aspects of the
case." ¡ 2. " To carn- out the previous resolution,
the Conference appoints a committee of ministers,
consisting of the persons howinafter rained, togethoi
willi cue minister to be chosen by the ¡ninibteis of
each district assembled in the financial district
meetings. This committee shall carefully consider
the whole subject, and lay their report before the
ministers when assembled in the annual district meéV
ings, and before the Conference." The ministers above
referred to, who are now appointed by the Conference
aro the President, the ex-President, and the
Secretary of the Conference, the Revs. J. Lomas, J.
Farrar, Dr. Stamp, Dr. Osborn, John Rattenbury,
William Arthur, M.A.,' Charles Prest, John Bedford,
Dr. Jobson, Dr. James, George T. Perks, William B.
Pope, Alexander Macaulay, Dr. Rigg, George "W.
Olver, Marmaduke C. Osborn, T. Bowman Stephen-
son, Henry AV. Holland, John Bond, Theophilus
Woolmer, John Walton, John AY. Greeves, Thomas
M'Cullagh, Samuel H. Tindal, Charles Haydon,
George Bowden, Featherstone Kellett, Joseph Pos
nett, Owen AYatkins, AVilliaiu 0. Simpson,
and Robert N. Young. This ministerial com-
mittee, consisting of ministers appointed by the
Conference and ministers electee! by the finan-
cial district meetings, will meet in London on
Thursday, October 28. Sustentation funds havo been
referred "to in most of the financial district meetings,
the object of them being to augment the stipends of
ministeis in poor circuits to the sum of £150 per
annum for each married minister. The movement is
progressing in the following districts ¡-Devonport,
Newcastle-on-Tyne, First London, Bristol, Liverpool.
Manchester, Nottingham, Portsmouth, Bolton. In
the Bolton district there is only one circuit giving less
than £150. In the Liverpool district it was reported
that all the stipends were raised to the amount pro-
posed, and that £120 had been sent to the general
fund. The Newcastle district, after meeting all
claims, had sent to the general fund £110. - Steps
are being taken for the formation of sustentation funds
in the following districts :-Cornwall, Leeds, South
AVales, Exeter, &c. Many of the districts have ar-
ranged for special missions to be held in each circuit
during the winter months. A special convention . of
Christian workers has been held in Birmingham, and
one will shortly he held at Leeds. Arrangements are
being made for a large convention of AVcsleyan» in
London,-'¡'he T/'w-ï,
English v. Ammucak Watches. - Sir Edmund
Beckett, a scientific horologist, who is perhaps the
highest English authority upon the subject, in his
work upon " Watches, Clocks, and Bells," says :
"The liability of a watch, like any other piece of
mechanism, to require repair is in the ratio of the
number of separate parts which make up its unity1.
The English watch, with its fusee and chain, ia com-
posed ot (»38 more pieces than the American watch.
Dispense with these G38 additional chances ' of
breakage, and it is easy to infer the superiority 0/
American watches, in this one respeet at least. The
fusee and chain are_ rejected in the Waltham -waWh,
and the direct action of the mainspring adopted,
because the fusee and chain add giearly to the cost of
a watch, and its tendency to injury, and are of'ne)
practical \ alue for good timekeeping. This change is
aelvocated on the ground that there is greater
simplicity of action, less friction in the transmission
of motive power, increased facility for using a lighter
and more uniform spring, and more room for play iii
the other parts of the movements." In support"of
this view (says the British Trade Jout nal), Sir Edmund
Beckett speaks very favourably of the American
principle of onlitting the chain. After alluding to
what lie calls the mischievous and common accidents
of chain-breaking, and noting the tendency of
adv ¡meed watchmaking to do without, fusee and
chain, he says, " Accordingly, both) in Switzerland
and America, which are gradually stealing away our
| common watch trade, the fusee and the chain aro
almost univeisally omitted."
