title: SPECIAL SITTING AT NISI PRIUS.
content:
Special Sitting at Nisi Pnivs.
Before Ilib Honor tho Chiet Justice and n jury of
finir.
COOK V. 11Y11NEÍ, AND ANOTHEK.
Tho trial of this case, which had already lasted two
days, was resumed and concluded.
It was on action bj- Simon Cook, a farmer of Illawarra,
against James Bj-mcs and William Byrnes, proprietors of
tho Mount Pleasant Colliery, to recover damages for the
pollution of a creek or small stream of fresh water which
ran through tho plaintiff's land, by coal from tho defend-
ants' worts. Tho plaintiff'B declaration put tho case in
two ways, first, that the creek had been wilfully polluted
by tho casting of coal therein ; secondly, that tho damiegti
had been the result of ncgltgenco. Tho defendants had
pleaded-first, a general doninl that thej- had dono any
injury to tho plaintiff ; secondly, that whatever injury had
been inflicted lind been the unavoid.iblo result of what thoy
had done in the lawful conduct of their businoss as coal
lumera.
Sir William Manning, Q.C., Mr. Darloy, and Mr. Salo-
mons, instructed by Mr. Maguire, appeared for the plaintiff;
and Mr.,Butlor, instructed by Messrs. Allen, Bowden, and
Allen, for the defendants.
Tho plaintiff was the lessee of Spring G rovo, a farm of
fifty acres, at Fairy Meadow, Wollongong district,
in the vicinity pf the Mount Pleasant Colliery. His
case was that a small stream of water which ran through
his and other lands in that neighbourhood had been ren-
dered unfit for uso bj- tho deposit of n largo quantity of
slocOc coal from the collierj' in question, ana that his farm
had boen otherwise injured from the samo cause. Tho
defendants' caso was that there had been no such injury,
and that although the creek might have boon partially fillod
up by slack coal, this had not been the result of any care
lossnoss on tho part of tho emploj-ccs at the colliery, but of
n land slip, the result of a flood, for which tho defendants
were not responsible. The evidenco was very voluminous,
and in'many respects very conflicting. Tho amount really
in question was a small one, but tho object of tho contest
was rather, it would appear, to determine tho genorol ques-
tion whether or not tho proprietors of cool mines in that
district were to be held responsible for damages of this cha-
racter. According to the plaintiff and his witnesses the
creek had clearly been damaged by the presence of a
quantity of slack coal which hod como down from an
immense henp noar the mouth of the mine-a result bl ought
about by the carelessness of the minors in allowing bo vast
an accumulation at such a place. Tho supply of water from
this creek had previously been regular ana abundant. Tho
water, although a littlo hard for washing purposes, hail
been excellent for every other kind of domestic use, but
since the conl had come down it had been quito useloss.
Tho waterholes had boen completely filled up, so that the
constancy of tho supplj- of water was to it great extent put
an end to, and such as was still to bo had was very bad.
The flood, too, bad carried tho slack coal over some of tho
cultivated land, and hod destroj-cd or damaged tho crops.
Cook had about forty head of cattle which had boen accus-
tomed to drink at this stream, but which could
now scarcely use ii. He had boon compelled
therefore to sink a well. Ho had offered to toke £20
in full compensation for these injuries, and for this sum to
clear out the bed of tho creek himself, but tho defendants
had refused lo give him that amount and had offered only
£10. According to tho defendant«' wltnosses the water of
this creek, which had always been a littlo brackish,.had
been in no way injured by tie influx of slack coal, which
was far less than had been represented, and was occasioned
solely by a landslip during a flood which hod brought down
at the samo time a largo quantity of soil. The spread of
slack coal over tho land to a small extent had rather a
tendency to increaso its productiveness than otherwise, and
tho catUo had in no way suffered. The^offer of £10 had
been tendered, it was sworn, without prejudico-that is to
say without admitting any liability-and only in tho hope
by dealing liberally with tho plaintiff to save all trouble and
expense. Samples of tho water from . this
creek were exhibited in Court, whioh sample«
presented a very uninviting appearance. It was contended
tint they had not been fairly token, but that the water must
havo been btorcd up, but this was denied. Some of this water
was analysed by Mr. Watt, from whose evidence it would
appear that its" foulness aid not in all probability result
from tho presence of coal, but from that of organic matter.
It further appeared that watcrcrcsscs wore growing plen-
tifully in the creek, and that decomposed vegetable matter
might in dry weather help to make the water bad. Tho
water of the creek, according to Mr. Watt, was naturally
brackish, and tho slack coal from this'mino when settled
(as it. would, settle) ,at. tho bottom of theiBtreain when
' 'net flowing rapidly- would'« not pollute it as alleged.
There was nirtfccr evidence that a stream of water coming
.ut of the same seam of coal was quite pure, and was con-
stantly used for domestic purposes. Seme of the coal was
broken up in Court and placed in tumblers ef water, upon
which it left a slight scum, although without otherwiso
rendering the water apparently impure. The impurity, J
however, va« most positively «vom to by the plaintiff'« *
**"?"-~-i _.
.witnosBcs. Somo evidence was gone into on the part of tho
I ?'_.nti(T lo show that tho lond-slip, if it did canso tho dam-
age (which was denied), lind been the result of some mis-
management of tho excavation. This was mot by direct
contradiction on tho(pnrt of tho defendants. Tho ovidenco
was directly contradictory na to the quantity of slack coal
in tbo heap nenr the colliery, and in nearly ovcry other im-
portant particular, even ¡is to tho local features of tho
gi omul.
His IIokoh directed the jury that the plain ques-
tion for their deteniiiuation was whothor or not tho
plaintiff hnd mndo ont any claim to damages for
injurj" sustained by him through any want oi duo core on
tho p'nrt of tho defendants' employes. Evory man had a
right to work n coal mine, but ho was bound so to monago
it as that his neighbours should not bo injured. Against
lend slips nud floods no amount of caro could guarel ; but
tho miners wero bound to exctciso duo caro and forethought
so ns when buch accidents took placo their neighbours
might bo «s little injured as possiblo by any escapo from tho
minc.
The jury, without leaving tho box, found a verdict for the
defi'iidnnts.

title: AMERICA.
content:
AMERICA.
LONDON, OCTOBER'1. - I
The state of things in America, financially and
commercially, is steadily improving. The Stock
Exchange has reopened, trade in grain and cotton
is slowly reviving, and the Chicago banks have
resumed payment.

title: BOROUGH COUNCILS.
content:
BOROUGH COUNCILS.
ALEXANDRIA -A meeting of the Council was held on
Wednesday, 8th March. Present-The Mayor, Aldermen
Evans, Bretnall, Dart, Woods, Blackley, Osborne, and
Lewis. The minutes of the previous meeting were read
and confirmed. A letter from the Waterloo Council was
then read with reference to a debt of £49 Moved by
Aldeiman Osborne, seconded by Alderman Woods,-" That
the Council Cleik write to the Waterloo Council requesting
the amount to be paid immediately." Carried, The
report of the By-law Committee was then read and received.
A scale of charges for a new toll-bar to be erected on the
Mitchell Road was then passed with some amendments.
Moved by Alderman Lewis, seconded by Alderman Dart,
"That the by-laws as amended be adopted by this
Council " Carried. Moved by Alderman Dart, seconded
by Alderman Bretnall,-" That the Council Clerk be
appointed treasurer, and to enter into a bond of £30"
Carried unanimously. Moved by Alderman Bretnall,
seconded by Alderman Lewis,-"That the Council forn
itself into a comnittee to consider the tenders for valuation "
Move by Alderman Blackley, seconded by Alderman
Lewis,-" That the tenders of Messrs. Parker and Marland
for the sum of £10 be accepted " Amendment by Alder-
man Bretnall, seconded by Alderman Woods,-"That the
tender of Messrs. Davis and Root for the sum of £10 be
accepted." On the question being put, the amendment
was carried. The Council then rose,-JAMES JONES,
Council Clerk.

and Aldoimon Oalloj. Guilfojlo, Thomas, and Friend

title: The Sydney Morning Herald.
content:
. Ofce Ssönca iWornítts jQerattu
THURSDAY, OCTOBER 5, 1871.
THE terrible events of Paris have set all
persons accustomed to inquire into the causes
of things to endeavour to expound those which
Have led to this fearful episode in the history
of civilization. The strength of the rebellion
and the destruction which it wrought, the
terrible sacrifice of life in its suppression,
and the apparent reappearance of its elements
in another form, have filled the world with
wonder and with alarm. "Where is it all to
end?
The highest form of civilization existing in
Europe has, by common consent, been attri-
buted to Paris. The moat perfect examples
of skill, both in science and in art, have been
furnished by its population. It was the most
beautiful city, and had the greatest range of
pleasures of every kind, and in the most perfect
order. Europe received from the French
theatre its popular plays, It received from
the same source its universal fashions. Luxury
pf all kinds was carried to the highest per-
fection in Paris. Nowhere was the art of
cookery capable of producing such diet. In no
'country could all the adornments of the house,
of the person, of the table, be so readily
'assembled. The rich people of eveiy nation
hastened to Paris to partake of these splen-
dours and these pleasures, which continued
throughout the season without intermission.
The citizens of this great metropolis of gaiety
and enjoyment looked with complacency on the
. gathering of all people to pay homage to their
intelligence, skill, and boundless resources.
.Those who look back two or three years to
'what Paris was-say, when the Great Exhibi-
tion attracted all the world-and what Paris
has become, may well be stunned with aston-
ishment or moved with pity. All this
splendour and plensure passed away, and the
city finally fell under the power of its loweßt
inhabitants, who endeavoured to gain its con
tiol, to subject its wealth, its intelligence, its
refinement, all it possessed, to a domination
which, when embodied in the persons of
ihose who wielded it, strikes the mind with
absoluta terror.
A splendid paper has been contributed to
the Revue des Deua Mondes, by M. E. CAKO,
on one phase of this great phenomenon,
entitled, " The End of Bohemia, or the lite-
rary Influences in these Last Events.*' This
treatise attributes the Communist Revolution
to the ascendancy of that class created by the
refinements and the yicissitudes of the great
city. A Bohemian signifies, in French phrase,
a writer living by ephemeral literature, an in-
ferior artist of any kind, a member of the
medical or legal orders without patients or
clients.-any person, in short, thrown upon
the casualties of a calling, and dependent
day by day upen the fluctuating success of a
profession. It is from this class have arisen
the writers who have corrupted, or at least
expressed the ¡corruption of, Parisian society.
I They are principally persons who have no
recognised position, no established reputation,
who live day by day having this question
continually recurring, Where shall we dine, and
how shall we pay for our meal ? They live on
the margin of society, in isolation. They are
devoured by envy. Their chances are an
election to the academy of France, or a place in
the hospital or^in the morgue. These persons,
having no recognised status in society, have
made themselves the expounders of every senti-
ment which divides and corrupts it. They
have produced a literature only copied faintly
| in the English publications. All the bad
passions of mankind have been analysed and
laid open in the mocking tone of those who share
them, who have boasted of them, and who haye
been destroyed by them. They have professed
no moral principle, they have offered no ideal,
they have animuted no effort for the improve-
ment of mankind. They have put, without
disguise, the defects and disordeis of society
into the language of derision, and, while they
have lessened the respect for human nature
as a whole, they ha\e been equally opposed to
all those institutions which have been de-
signed to raise the fallen and solace the dis-
tressed. Their lessons have been intended to
excite a hatred against the persons of men, an
envy of their good fortune, and of those
superiorities which arise from knowledge or
industry. The only tone in which they have
been known to addiess the unhappy portions
of society has been calculated not to relieve
but to exasperate their resentment. They
have said to the vicious that they have been
made so by the organization of society; to
those who have found it difficult to live, that
the rich have taken away their natural right to
their portion in this world. All that society
has secured by united labour foi the go»d of
the State has been treated as deductions from
the daily enjoyment of the workman. The
employers of labour have been always spoken
of as criminals, who are joined together in con-
spiracy against the operatives.
The consequence of thiB kind of "education,
continued for twenty years under the shadow
of an Imperial system, was to produce a fixed
hatred of everything that existed and a
desperate determination to reverse, to over
tlnow, and to sweep all that had been ex-
hibited as the representative of wealth or dis-
tinction. It is this literature which has found
in tiie daily Press a full development for the
last two years. The relaxation of the
laws and the fall of the Empire gave
still fuller scope for these opinions.
The conduct of many prominent persons
afforded the text of satire and denunciation.
During the siege of Paris the clubs were j
ruined, and the Bohemian class made them the
medium of their propagandism. Men, women,
and children attended these assemblies, and
the most extravagant oratory found the
warmest reception. There were two classes of
speakers. Commonly the orators of the work-
ing class had somo degree of sincerity. But the
old leaders weie mete actors ; they were
. obtaining a living or a place without any
faith in the principles which they proclaimed.
They had experienced a long trial of patience.
Their contribution* to the Press could not in
ordinary times provide them with bread. The
revolution carne lo float them upon the surface.
When the Commune was proclaimed they
seized its guidance. They appropriated
the profits upon which they could
lay their hands, and, without believing in the
permanence of anything, turned to present
account the wild rage of those who were
incapable of discerning their delusions. The
number of men of this class who assumed
omeo in the Commune was remarkable. They
had a degree of education, of science, and
knowledge of society, but they had long been
nmong the disinherited. What a change,
then, to become, even for three months, the
dignitaries of a great city, and to command
an army of 100,000 men.
A remarkable development of the Commune
was the prominence it gave to some female
politicians. The emancipation of woman was
a grand cry. Lectures were delivered and
journals published by them in this interest.
The incidents of the last revolution show how
frightful was the demoralisation of Communist
women. i
Among the stimulants of mischief with
which the Bohemian had been long familiar
is to be reckoned the use of absinthe. This
dangerous liquor produces a special kind of
frenzy more pernicious than ordinary spirits,
and more maddening than opium. It is im-
possible to say how far even this agent of
human degradation is responsible for the crimes
of the revolution.
The author attributes the character of this
insurrection to the utter absence of religious
principle in the Bohemian class. While the
savons and philosophers have been propound-
ing the doctrines of atheism in elegant lan-
guage, and as the means of liberating the
mind from all prejudices, the lower classes
of writers have accepted their conclusions, and
surrounded them with all the decorations of
an obscene literature. Every excitement to
the indulgence of the passions has been pro
¡ duced in their writings ; and their whole
s) stem - has been based on negations. Is
there a GOD? No. Is there a future
state'? No. IS there a soul? No. Is
there responsibility for tinknown actions'?
There is none. Is theie any compensation
for patient suffering? Never. Is there any
reason for the relations of social life ? No
These have been the set of principles with
which Communism has started There are
numbers who have professed to substitute
others for them ; but these at present have
remained in all their deadly influence, and
havö shown themselves in the terrible events
of this last civil war.
AN , interesting discussion took place a few
.months ago in the Ilouse of Commons in
relation to harbours of refuge on the English
coast. The question involved the considera-
tion of a large variety of facts, commercial,
humanitarian, and national. The debate arose
on a motion by Lord C. J. HAMILTON, whose
object was to obtain a grant of public
money for the construction of a harbour of
refuge at Filey in Yorkshire. The policy
of making further grants of public money
to construct and improve harbours of refuge
on the coasts of Great Britain and Ireland
had been the subject of inquiry and solici-
tation during the previous fourteen years.
A committee recommended that national money
should be granted for the construction
of harbouis of refuge, and that funds
should also be voted towards the extension
and improvement of existing harbours. It
was also proposed that a commission of
inquiry should -visit the coast for the pur-
pose of inquiry. This was delayed by
change of Government ; but the commis-
sioners having been appointed, brought up
a report recommending that £2,365,000
should be granted, with loans at a low
tate of interest for harbours, on condition
that cci tain stated local suma should be
raised to meet the national grants. These
facts were stated by Lord HAMILTON, who
also gave an account of the numerous
attempts which had been made in vain to
give practical effect to the report of the
commissioners, which, however, was opposed
on the ground that it was " altogether too
sweeping." Mr. MILNER GIBSON, when Pre-
sident of the Board of Trade, incurred con-
siderable odium by his opposition, and when
sailors were drowned on the coast, there
were those who did not hesitate to speak
of the widows of those unfortunate
seamen, as " MILNER GIBSON'S widows."
Attempts to induce the House to adopt the
report of the commissioners were renewed in
each session from 1862 to 1865, and the sub-
ject was revived in 1866 and 1869, but without
any results satisfactory to its promoters.
Among the commercial facts adduced during
the debate it was stated that the trade was
most extensive on the north-east coast, and
that its harbours were barred, and there-
fore not approachable at all tides. It was
ghen in e-vidence that the entire tonnage of
British sailing vessels clearing coastwise from
ports in England was 8,162,000 tons ; coast
wajs and foreign together, 15,796,00<>; and
that the annual loss to the nation by wrecks
ivas a million and a half sterling. But since
that e\idcnce was given there had been a very
laige increase in the foreign as well as in
the coasting trade. The total foreign and
toasting trade in 1857 was 23,178,782 tons
(Blitish ships), or an average per month
of 1,931,565 tons. But in February of the
present year, the total foreign and coasting
trade was 5,156,000 tons. Taking the coasting
trade only there was a considerable increase
shown. In 186-9, the coasting trade for the
month of February showed 2,587,000- tons.
In February, 1871, it represented 2,684,900
tons. Lord HAMILTON, speaking of the
fisheries on the coast, quoted from the report
oí the Commissioners of Fisheries in 1866,
to show that the annual value of the fisheries
on the east coast was £2-,000,000, and that
"the north-east coast fisheries were of the
same extent as the supcrfitial area of
Ireland, and were annually increasing in
value to the extent of £10,000 per
annum." The Boaid of Trade re-
turn showed, iL that the number of re-
gistered fishing boats in England was 16,195,
representing 127,013 tons, and employing
I 47,290 men, and 7467 boys."
These figures, indicating the large commercial
interest at stake, were not disputed, and facts
were given te show how gieat are the advan-
tages which may be expected from an improve-
ment of the harbours on the coast. As in this
colony in regard to railways, so there appears
to have been in the House of Commons on
this matter much local rivalry, and
the question divided itself into two main
branches - first, as to the expediency
of spending large sums of money on one
harbour of refuge, when (it was arguod)
" unless '.they were multiplied almost ad
wßnitum they would be of very little use;" |
and, second, as to how far Government
assistance ought to be extended towards the
improvement of harbours. It was stated by
one member that the Government had advanced
money on easy terms to the Tyne Harbour
commisioners. Another observed that the
sum of £1,600,000 had been spent during the
last few years in improving the approach to
the Tyne Uiver so as to render it a good
harbour of refuge ; that most of the
money was made a local charge ; and
that, in consequence of the improvements
effected, a herring fishery had been estab-
lished there. By an Act passed in 1861,
money may be granted for harbour improve-
ments on condition that it be repaid, with
interest, in twenty years. The Tyne Harbour
commissioners had availed themselves of
these harbour loans; but it was remarked
that they had not done so to such an ex
lent as they would otherwise have been
glad to do had the interest not been in-
creased. They obtained £100,000 at 3J per
cent., and another £100,000 at 3.J per cent. ;
but the Government after that refused to
lend to them at less than 5 per cent.,
and the commissioners became reluctant to
borrow on those terms.
From a national standpoint it was argued
that Filey ought to bo made a harbour of
refuge. It was contended that the events
of the past few months had altogether
altered the military position of the country;
that England had now to look for danger
norn the East, and that therefore the |
construction of a naval station on the east
coast was a matter of serious moment. It
was also remarked by the mover that
Filey was recommended by the committee of
1857 from a strategetical point of view-1
that it would be good as a look-out, and
safe for shipping in time of war. Several
authorities were quoted showing the import-
ance of a naval station on the east coast,
and these were supplemented by arguments
based on local considerations.
The humanitarian reasons urged recall the
dangers and sacrifices annually made in the
cause of commerce and navigation - the
terrible disasters which occur to vessels baffled
by winds and unable to weather rocky
points - ships with torn sails and broken
masts left to the fury of a gale - the
foundering of vessels unable to find a
pott of refuge, and long lines of coast
black with wreck. The members were
reminded of " scenes of agony which
beggared description," and certainly the loss
of life shown is most lamentable. All this
was admitted by the Government. Mr.
GLADSTONE quoted from a Parliamentary
paper the number ©f shipwrecks which had
occurred during eleven years, showing that
1480 lives had been lost on the south coast,
1240 on the north coast, and 2772 in the
Irish Sea. But the inference he drew from
the figures was, that there was no
material différence to be traced be-
tween those portions of the coast which
had harbours of refuge, and those which had
not. The policy of the Government was
clearly stated to be in favour of an improve-
ment in the mercantile marine, and it was
held that a reckless plan for a wholesale
creation of bar-harbours would have the effect
of retarding that improvement. It was argued,
however, on the other side, that much re-
mained yet to be done, inasmuch as it could'
not be denied, in the face of wrecks so
numerous, that many ships went to sea in
an unsafe condition.
But the most fatal objection to the propo-
sition appeared to be its local- application ;
and upon this point Mr. GLADSTONE and
Mr. LOWE spoke out boldly. The former
said he could not do otherwise than euter
his protest against local propositions of the
kind, " because they were a fruitful source
of political demoralization." Mr. LOWE said :
-" The noble mover did not propose to fol-
low the general spirit of the recommendation
of the Commission, but picked out one iso-
lated point, with respect to which the Consoli-
dated Fund was to contribute all, and local
resources nothing. A more fatal blow, not
only at the Exchequer, but at the reputation
of that House, could not be imagined. He
had some experience on such a point. He had
been a member of a Colonial Assembly, the
greatest part of the time of which was taken
up in discussing measure» such as the noble
lord now proposed, involving the application
of general revenue to local purposes, such as
the making of a road in one place, or the con-
struction of a railway in another. The main
time of the Legislature was occupied in that
most discreditable manner, and he, therefore,
ventured from practical experience to warn
the House not to encourage such motions as
the present, for it would find no course so
injurious to the respect and estimation it
should be held in by the 'public as countenanc-
ing the grant out of the general revenue of the
country of money to be expended for local
purposes."

head a correspondent complains that on arriving, at the
Church ef _tagla_d school OB Monday noising to com-
mence business as usual, he found the windows of a
recently erected lavatory " thoroughly guttoi/'-" an
offering doubtless to the goddess of muoblof. There is
some ambiguity about Hie epistle. The operation of

dess of mischief " oouM have boen, is not very olear ; bat
the letter as a whole leads to the inference that semothing
ought to bo done to suppress "larriHnism" at Padding-
ton. No doubt the Inspector-General of Police, it he fully
realise the force of the sent-loe, will give an emphatio ne-
gative to the inqniry of our correspondent ; " must wo
pale our inefloctual tiro, before cowardly doapotio ruülan
ism ï "

Another thing ho complained of was nllovvang stills to be

title: The Sydney Morning Herald.
content:
®t>e cSgÖttCB JÄcrmwg p/îralïw »
TUESDAY, JANUARY 19, 1875.
We commented, a few days ago, on the fucij
thatr Sir Redmond Barhy had been sworn-in
as ActiDg-Governefvof Victoria almost immedi-
ately upon the departuie of Sir George
Bowen-a fact that in itself, under the eil .
cumstancee which rendered immediate action,
by an Administrator of the Government Impe-
ratively necessary, was in no degree incom-
patible with the existence of a discretionary
right on the part of the Ministry to have
held, under different circumstances, the dormant
commission in abeyance. Later events
have shown still more clearly that the
whole'Question requires, to, be more carefully
looked into, and that contingencies may aribe
which,involve doubt as to whether they have
been adequately (as they have not been ex-
pressly) .forseen and provided for.
- Ihe difficulty in Ifew South Wales arose
from doubts as to whether the telegram from
the Secretary of State, which the Govern-
ment interpreted as 'constructively sanctioning
their arrangements,<,was sufficient to cure tha
omission on the part of the Queen's instruc-
tions or commission to provide expressly for
the absence of the 'Governor during a longer
period than a month without ¿ailing in ai
Acting-Governor to take his place. The
difficulty in Victoria was not as to the
swearing in of Sir Redmond Babiiy. That
was disposed of by the force of circumstances
which left the Ministry but one course to
follow. The difficulty there arose from tho
absence of the Chief Justice (the Acting-Go-
vernor designate) at the time when an Acting
Governor had to be sworn in, and from his
return whilst the duties of the office were being
discharged by the senior Judge, the official
designated by the commission to take the
office if the Chief Justice were ab.ent.
Was Sir W. Stawell, the Chief Justice, to
assume the Acting-Governorship on his return,
or was Sir Redmond Baeiiy, in whom the
powers of Governor were legally vested, to
retain and exercise them ? Doubt was felt
amongst the lawyers as to whether the power*
of the commission under which Sir Redmond
Bakey had been appointed were not exhausted
bj his appointment. These doubts, however,
were overruled. Sir W. Stawell was sworn
in on the 11th, Sir Rldmond Bakry art
ministering the .oaths. And it is said that in
the event of any embarrassment occurring,
a telegram will be sent to London, asking for
[the execution of a fresh commission.
As this is cutting the Gordian knot, instead
of untying it-a process thati may be ver)
¡agreeaole to ,'Ministries tin Victoria, but is
hardly excusable' on constitutional 'principles-~
the difficulty remains still undisposed of. Let
us, then, inquire into its nature more closely,
The Argus describes Sir W. Stawell as
" assuming " the administration of the Govern-
ment, But how was it possible for hira to
assumo it ? Did Sir Redmond Barry give it
up, or was it taken from him, or did it pass
from him by the operation of the commission? I
The last supposition is untenable. If Sir
GroROE Bowen had leturned before Sir W.
Stawell, this sort of self-acting transfer i
would certainly have taken place. Sir Red- I
mond Barry having become Acting-Governor
during the Governor's absence only,- the
Goveinor, in viitue of his own commission^
would have resumed his full powers on te
entering the territory of Victoria aB a matter of
course. Sir George Bowen was Governor
before he left, was Governor whilst absent, and
would have been Governor on his return, his
commission having been neither cancelled nur
withdrawn, but simply suspended as to its
operation during his absence. Not so with
Sir W. Stawell. He "assumed" the ad-
ministratorship ; he did not resume it, because
it was not his to resume. He had not held it
before. If he had held it before, and had then
left the colony, and if Sir Redmond
Barry had then become administrator
in his place, there would have been
an analogy between the two cases, and Sir
W. Stawell might have claimed, like the
Governor, the right to resume the powers
which by his absence he had become tempo-
rarily incapable of exercising. As it was,
when he reiurned, he returned as Chief Justice,
not as Acting-Governor. He could not become
Acting-Governor till he was Bworn in. He
could only take office by assumption, not
by resumption, as Sir George Bowen
could. Sir George Bowen, on returning,
would have resumed power as Sir George
Bowen in virtue of a personal appointment
by a commission still operative. Sir W.
Stawell could neither reaBon1 nor assume aa
Sir W. Siawell. lie had not been
personally named in any commission. And the
onl} circumstances under which he could have
claimed a right to assume the administratorship
as Chitf Justice-as the official designated to
fill the vacant office-were manifestly when the
office wat, \acant. But was it vacant? ' !
Ai Sir Rj.dmoîsd Barry was not absent on
Sii W. t>TAWH.L's return, and not suffering
Irom incHpucitv, a vurancy could not have
existid unless he had been deprived of the
office or resigned it. But, having taken the
oaths, «ho was.to deprive him of the office had]
lie chocen to hold it, adopting Marsh ii
MacMamon's motto, "J'y suts;j'y reslc'1'"
He could have held his footing in
the Malakhofi' agnvnst anybody short
of the Secretary of Stnte. The sup;
position, then, is that ho re_igned.(
But will that resignation hold together on'
being shaken ? When Sir George Bowen
left the colon), he did not resign the Gover-I
nort-hip. He simply went away, and left the
office to fall into the hands of the official first
I in rank designated to fill itj' whensoever
'hat official should he duly eworn in J
[ But Sir Redmond Barky did hot go away.]
If he resigned, he resigned and still
remained, able, if not willing, to discharge the
duties of the office. But had he the powei'
thus to resign and remain? He_ was, bo to,
speak, seised of the business of administration,
and had he a right of his own motion to relieve
himself of it, and hand o\er his duties to
another who, bo long as Sir Redmond was
Acting-Governor, was his subordinate ? If Sir¡
George Bowen had resigned he would have'
sent in his resignation to his superior officer,)
the Secretary of State, and have awaited
his reply. Sir Redmond Barry, derivingj
his authority as Acting-Governor from the
same source, could presumably resign it only
in the same manner. Resignation, apart from
supervening incapacity, implies a reference^
to an authority competent to accept or decline«
it. But there was no such authority in Vic-
toria in Sir Redmond Barry's case. He
could not tender his resignation to the j
Ministry, for their status was not superior;
to his own. When once he had been,
s worn in, they were rather under his
authority than he under theirs. He could not
tender it to Sir W. Stawell, of whom
as defacto Governor, whilst Sir W. Stawell,
was only Chief Justice, he took precedence.'
On the whole, the theory of resignation seems
as little tenable as that of transfer by the mere
force of the commission, which, if our reasoning
be correct, could only have taken place if Sir1
W. Stawell had been the Acting-Governor,
first sworn in, and had returned after a tem-*
porary absence, during which Sir Redmond i
Barry had been his hourn (mens. A j
vacancy might have been created readily]
erpugh, ifSir Redmond Barry, who is now I
in New South Wales, had arranged for an'
earlier i isit, and quitted Victoria the day before '
Sir W. Stawell's arrival, or if the Govern-
ment had delayed swearing in Sir W.
Stawell until after his departure. But he
remained, and the question is, how while he
remained could the office become legally
vacant ? '
It appears to ,us that, just as it was only
though the absence of Sir W. 'Stawell
when an Acting-G o vernon ,was required, that
Sir Redmond Barry obtained the office, bo,
when Sir'Redmond Barry had once obtained
it and been duly sworn in, it was only by his
departure from t the colony, or by supervening
incapacity, that Sir W. Stawell could rightly
assume it. ' Sir Redmond Barry became
Acting-Governor because the swearing
in of an Acting-Governor was requirod
by , the public interest. But no such
necessity aroBe. on the return of Sir
W. Stawell, because the office had been
filled and itB duties were being discharged' in
the manner provided hy the Royal Instructions
und Commission. The provisions of the Com-
mission and the Instructions were intended to
show how a vacant office was to be filled, and
not, when the office had been duly filled, to
create a vacancy in order to substitute another
officer for the one in whom the powers attach-
ing to the position legally vested.
\ Wir at a mine of wealth there would be in the
\inej aids of Australia if only we had a market
I under our lee, such as France has in Europe.
I'the day may come perhaps when in America,
¡if not in Europe,, Australian wines maybe a
popular drink, but at the present time the costs
'of production and carriage aVe against us, and
dhe reputation 'of our vineyards and wine
icellsrs is not high enough, and in the main the
! market for Australian wines is still in Aus-
tralia. *
j As some compensation for the disasters it has
'latelv undergone, France was last year blessed
with an unusually splendid vintage. Notwith-
standing the oidium, notwithstanding the
¡phjlloxera, and notwithstanding hailstorms,
'the vintage was productiv e to an extent which
has only once been equalled, and that was in
¡the year 18G9. The produce is estimated at
170,000,000 of hectolitres, and sr a hectojitre ;s
Twentr-two-1-4 gallons," ttíiB'Ms "s equal1'* to'
1,540,000,000 gallons. The growth of
the trade out of which France makes
so much money will be visible by |
noticing tViat in 1854, that is only twenty years
ago, the product was only eleven millions of
hectolitres; in tho following year it rose to
fifteen; during the eleven years from 1863 to
1878 inclusive, it rose to an average of fifty
three millions ; "but in 1873, which was a very
bad j ear, it dropped to thirty-six millions, and
now, in the following year, it is very nearly
double, hating risen to seventy millions.
There are only ten departments in France
which produce no wine, and the vine covers
4} per cent, of the whole surface of the
country, or in round numbers about five million
acres. There are, however, three chief wine-
growing districts, namely the Bordelais, Bur-
gundy, and Champagne, and the produce from
those districts has not yet been rivalled by any
other part of the world. The number of
people employed in thia industry is in propor-
tion to the acreage covered, for it is reckoned
to give occupation to no fewer than seven
million labourers ; that is to say, one industry
in .France alone, and that an industry which
produces an article of luxury, finds wages for
more than three times the whole population of
Australasia. '
Nor is there any fear at present of France
over-producing. There is an indefinite market
for all the good wine that is made, although it
is possible that a great or sudden glut might to
some extent lower the price, in order to allow
.-?ales to be effected rapidly. But in its wine
Fiance has an article which tbe world
eagerly buys ; and, as the world is grow-
ing richer every year, and becoming more
and more luxurious, there is more and
more eager demand for wines of the' best
quality. In this way, France is taxing the
whole world to help it to pay its debts ; and
everyone who sips his claret or his champagne
assists towards the pa} ment of that satisfaction'
which Bismarck and Von Moltkk exacted. <
It is impossible not to notice in this yield of
(he French vineyards how much the commerce
of the world has gained by the greater humanity
of modern methods of war. When we read
ancient history, we hear of conqueTorB who
..eemtd insatiable in their revenge, who razed
cities to the ground, and who ploughed up the
cultivated fields and sprinkled them with salt.'
and who seemed never to be able to do enough
lo tatisfy themselves that the people who had
piovoked their wrath should be ruined hope-
lessly. If the samo spirit had animated modern
war-if the Germans, not content with conqu_
luig, had sought only to devastate-if they,
had pulled up the vines and destroyed
the wine-presses, in how different a
situation would France have been! How
heavy would have been the pressure of
the taxation, and how cramped the resources
lo meet that taxation. What numbers would
have been out of employment, and what years
would have been waited by capitalists till vines
could have been replanted and again become
productive ! But, as it was, the German occu-
pation did. not appreciably affect the vintage,
which even, during the disastrous year of thç
war kept up its''average. <** * ,
It is quite true that this more humane pian
mils the conqueror quite as well as it suits* thfct
conquered. The victor takes it out in monej
inptead of having his payment in revenge. lV
Geimany had destroyed the productive industij'
of France, it would have had to content itself
with a far smaller indemnity. The credit of
France would have been too prostrate for it io
have raised the necessary loans with the'
promptness that it did, and Germany i1-'
iewar.de,d for not having destroyed French ¡
vineyards by the receipt of hundreds of million«
of French gold. Doubtless to a Christian
spiiit this mode of reí enge is more satisfactory,
and to the wine-drinkers of the world it is moie
satisfactory also.
It is impossible also in connection with this
subject not to notice how much of the wealth ',
of France is due to it being a producer for the
luxury of the world. In the way of exporting
the necessaries of life it does not do mucn,.
and produces mainly for its own popu-
lation. It exports but little of com' or of
meat ; but with regard to all that comforts the
stomach or adorns the person, France stands
in the first rank of producers. It is the grand
purveyor of luxury, and, in a world that is
getting every year richer and more luxurious,
it does not fail to find a splendid market.
France, though it has no monopoly of the busi-
ness in luxuries, has the undisputed lea-1.
Italy provides many objects of art, and English
manufacturers are improving yearly in tbiii
productions of taste and ingenuity. Still it is to
France that the world turns for models and foi
its choicest objets de luxe; and there seems no
likelihood ' of its pre-eminence in this depart
ment being interfered wi li. The French
manipulators seem to have as great an aptitude
for work of this sort as their soil and climate
have aptitude for a special class of wines. The
commercial position of France in these respects
| brings it wealth, in spite of all its foreign wai s
and its intestine discords, and of the damage in-
evitably done to trade when capital is alarmed
by insecurity and labour is oppressed bj
taxation.

The WHOLE of thoir INTEREST in the LEASES,

Tho 2.3-ACRE LEASE has 1800 foot on tbo course of
the îeef known as " White's," and was worked some years
ago in block claims. Several thousand tons at that tima

without the aid of such powerful machinery as has been

A MAIN SHAFT, 9 foot 3 inches x 3 feot 6 inches in

No. 2 SHAFT is sunk 124 on the undorlay, or a vortical

mainder. Tho agreement expires on the 28th of Juno next. *
Another 400 adjoining, on the north, aro about being let,
the ti ¡bitters by their agreement being bound to equallyjhaul
free of ixpense fi oin both. The termination of tbo oon
tine Is M ill be on the same day.
'Hie MACHINERY at No. 1 abaft consists of a 30
horfe power horizontal ongino, with two Cornish boilers,
each 20 feet 6 inches x 5 feet, and brisk stack 40 foot high,
driviup: a battery of 15 head of stampers and pumps for
mnin shaft, twith T bob and all bob mountings, connecting'
and sky rods, &c. The battery is so placed that stone front
No. 1 shaft goes direct from the cages to it. Thero ara
250 feet of C-incb cast iron discharge pipos, one 8-inoh
' plunger pump, and one S-inch lift pump, together with
' rodi-, coupling bolts, &c, complete. The poppot-heads are
80 feet high.
For AV1NDING there is anoigbt-horso-powor horizontal
| engino, fitted with link motion tor revorsing and receiving
steam flinn one of tho largo boilors ; tho barrels, ropes, &o.,
i aro ¡u first-rate ordor. Engine-house and buildings covered
,' with galvanized iron. The ostimatcd cost of Binking th»
' main shaft to tho reef is £650 ; and were this done, and the
mino opened out there, the presont expongo of working the
i No. 2 shaft, carting Btone to the battery, &c, involving;
about 8s 4d a ton would bo saved, and from 120 to 130 tona
eould be easily raised a-weok, fully employing tho battery ;
the actual expenso of crushing at winch has nover cost the
! prêtent company more than 3s 4d per ton.
; The Auctioneers believe that tho judicious expenditure of
a comparatively small outlay upon this property would
j piovo highly remunerativo, and invite an inspection of it,
for which purposo abundance of time has boen purposely
given, confident that such will do more to establish tha
' truth of what they now assort than anything thoy might
j write in support of suoh a statement.
I Tht Mino has been tested to no appreciable depth, nor
, bas iinv attention been bestowed upon the numerous other
' refis that travor«o the ground.
, The alluvial ovor the whole surface of tho Company's
| property has been rich in the extremo, parts of it amongst
the richest over found in Tins, one of the richest of tua
. New South Wnlcs Fields.
Tho whole plant is new-fresh from tho manufac-
tory-having boen erected but ten months, and is in porfeot

treatriunt of stono, including quicksilver, acids, &c. Ia
1 the i-hnpo of blacksmith and mining tools thero is both,

TWO DAMS, conveniently placed for use, hold a con-
stant and sufficient supply of water for all purpose»
throughout the year.

I [l\ W. C0SEN8' CIRCUXAIt.] ' -, ' I

'j Be same inactivity wh'cb bas characterised tue trade lu wiaes

quirements. Prices remsia without alteration, hut, In the event
of any pressure to realise, prices would have to be in favour.of
the buyer. ' The bonded stock of brandy in London shows a fo
duction compared with April, 1872, of about 11,600 hogsheads
of thin y a decrease reaching 2480 butts-upon port a slight
increase of 88 pipes, and French 2673 hogsheads. Brandy
in lair request but no advance of price is' noted. Bum
slightly lower ior all but Jamaicas, wkloh, maintain their
values. Gin has advanced. In wines, quotations unchanged
Sherry: But for the political state of Spain tho prices of sherry
would probably have advanced, the last vintage having yielded W
sliort and unsatisfactory a crop. Fine wines with quality and
character are (difficult to he found even at full quotations. The
export fromrCediz is still considerable. . !
Fort-The long delay in shipments caused by the impayable
state of the, river Douro has ceased, and several BUamers-hvve

very scarce at stlffer rates. . !

har been without .¡movement; prices, however, are un-
affected-the demand is quite of a retail* chtraotcr. .The prognss

title: LATROBE.
content:
LATROBE.
The death of Mr. Maurice Nathan, of
this town, removes from our midst one of the
oldest merchant pioneers of the Coast.
Qeneralregrot was expressed on Thursday lint
when |it beaame known that he had suddenly
taken seri'iusly ill from some throat affec-
tion, but it caine as a, very painful surprise to
those who knew lum when told on Saturday
morning that on the previous «vening he had
passed to his last rest. Mr.Nathanfiist became
connected with the various interests of the J
North-West Coast close on 40 years ago,
wheo he established himself os a general
dealer at Fort Sorell before Latrobe had
become the business centre. He eventually
removed to Latrobe, commencing business
as a general storekeeper in premises adjoin- j
ing the old Commercial Bank, which he sold
subsequently to Messrs. E. ana W. L.
Bartlett.proceeding theucoto Launceitonaud
Melbourne, returuîug to Latrobe some
six or seven years ago, again setting up
business as wine and spirit und produce
merchant in premises built for his oivn use,
but which he retired from list year. He
was appointed a Justice of the Peace for
Latrobe during 1887, and was one of the
best attende» to the various duties such
appointment imposed upon him. The de-
ceased leaves no family, and was S3 years of
age at the time of his death, his widow being
a sister of the Messrs. Bartlett of this town.
During his long business career he bas
become known to pretty well all who reside
in the district, and general regret will be
expressed at the news of his demise.
The manager of the U.A A.A. is evidently
bent upon making the forthcoming exhibi-
tion u gigantic success. Ho lus just re-
ceived a letter from Nick Long, editor of tho
Olympian, California, with extracts from
I that and other papers, publiabin-* a chal-
lenge for £300 to the champion axe-
men of the United States und Canada,
and stating that the challenge had
been Bent to the various lumber
districts of Michigan, Wisconsin, Cali-
fornia and Canada, also stating tout an
effort was being made to secure the entry
of J. A Muiray, of Vancouver, the champion
axeman of Canada, for the forthcoming con-
tests, which take place in November.
lu all probability an entry will be received
for tho sawing contest from oue of the best
sawyers of British Columbia.
September IS.

title: ORA[?]GE ASSOCIATIONS.
content:
OUA..GK ASSOCIATIONS.
TO TUB I3DIT01I t)P THU HltltAI.I).
Su IJiav e read with that tttentivc consideration to
which any BtttrAnenfunder the hand of my excellent
and learned friend Mr Alexander Gordon, ib entitled,
the letter which appeared in the Harold ol Saturday
last, on the subject of Orange Asspciationa, and I
desire to ¿tate candidly what effect it has had upon
my own mind and what I believe will be its general
c fleet
That I may not be supposed to be a bigot, in-
capable of calm and rational investigation of the
subject, I may as well say at the outset that I am not
an Orangeman (unless, indeed, to be an honest and
consistent Protestant, a loyal subject, and a good
citizen be the principal elements ot Orangeism), nor
have I ever been a member of any secret society what
ever I have never had a difference with any man on
the subject of his religion, nor ia the ordinary trans
actions of life, or in giving assistance or employment
have I ever been influenced bj the consideration
whether the parties were Protestant or ltomarust
I or the last fifteen years and upwards, I have con
tinuousiy had in my service th.ee or more Roman
C athohes, and I liiv e never made inquiry on the sub
lect of their religion, except for the purpose of afford
uif, them convenient and regular opportunity of
ittendiH¿ confession and the public sen ices of their
Church
But although I am not a member of any Orango
Association there arc icisons which compel me to
look into the evidence upon which the objections to
0nnoei»m are founded, and to be well satisfied as to
their validity betöre I can concur in the denunciation
of suth institutions
It is an luidoubted fact beyond any doubt or
question, that the Orange Associations havo at all times
included amongst their members noblemen, gentlemen,
mid clergymen of every Protestant denomination,
whose learning, ability, pietv, punt) of life liberality
chant) and brotherly kindness to men of every creed
have never been exceeded and I will not I dare not
ujrn the word of any min or upon any re oin
tton of my Parliament or Assembly m the
we riel, withe ut the most eonvmciii¿ evidence
believe tint nil these learned most excellent
dud tmly good men were 6o blinded by bigotry tint
they bec une nul tontimud îiieiiibeis of an associa
non whose amis and objects mid princioles were
vvholh opposed to the teaching of that pure uid holy
religion vi Inch they professed
Hie knovvledae ol the character of such men has
iceustomed me to look upon Oringe ass îeiitions as
religious, loyal and most reputable societies entitled
to the respect and confidence of all good men ind
e&i coally of all t,ood Protestants and unless my
gre itly rcspeettd lnend is able to show that there is
something inherently wrong m the principles of the
institution-th it it is in some respecta opposed to the
te tching of that Church of which he is so distill
gunhctl and useful i member th it it acknowledges
prn eiples or requires approves of, 01 permits in its
ii embers conduct opposed ti the teaching ofthat
Book winch they recognise ns their only rule of faith
I must continue to reDird them with the sime
feelings of respect and confidence is I h eve done
hitherto
It is timte possil le that I m ty hal c very erroneous
»lews of the pin tq les and objecte, of Ornveism but
it so I shall afioril my esteemed fnenel an opportu
nity of setting me right
It is to bo regretted th it instead ef setting before
yrur readers extricts which afford no inform tuon, he
ebel i ot tell them whit Orangeism really is-what are
it« pnneiples ind the objects it is designed to
ucee i push-that he ebel not listinctly point out
v\l at there is in it tint is opposed to he dictates ot
our common Christianity, to loy alt) to our beloved
Queen, and to our dutv as good eiti/ens If he hid
eloi e this, and I had been convmeed that the state
nicnts were-»veil founded I should have |omeel him
nie st hcartilv, and done ill in my power to dis
teuragethem But it is useless for Mr Gordon to
tell any intelligent and thinking men, who know tho
history of the misgov eminent of Ireland foi the 1 ist
century, that it has been the vvcik, vacilUum0 mis
tiktn and miserable policy of a government who,
ben " incapable of dealing with the gnev mees thtt
leallv existed soubht from time to time to appease
the clamour of the Horn mists, which they could
not otherwise sitisfy by trying ulmost beyond human
eneluraneo, the loyalty and obedience to law of the
1 rotcstants of that country until at length, by their
last act of despoiling them of that property which the
¡state never gave, thev haye aroused i spirit which
they -will lind it difficult to allay Let me brmg
under the notice of Air Gordon the language of our
own beloved and truly Piotcstant Bishop in his last
charge, where, in speaking of the Irish Church, he
says -
W c in this colony shall not be unmindful that we
arc raerrber3 of the United Church ol Lngland and
Ireland, and shall, I trust, remember the Irish
portion of the United C burch ol England in our
prayers Lvil times have come upon it, and a
Chinch which in these later years has borneare
mul ibte and faithful witness *o the truth ii i/i
ilanyti of being sacrificed io gratify personal and
j olitical ambition The people oj Ireland have no juU
i une of complaint against the /ruh ( huron Roman
tallolits did net Jound it Roman Catholics do not
¡ian lain it and while the proposed disen
dowment of the Irish Church is uuconsti
tutioi al and dii/onest, it is also a mistaken
and useless surrender of a scriptural institution, in
the vain hope ot propitiating an implacable toe le is
i "rent national calamity Sion of high character and
ot undoubted benevolence are ally ing themselves to
the idolatrous sy stem of the Church of Home, and are
thus making 'hat possible which without their aid
eould never have been accomplished Hie plea is
that Ireland may be pacified Ireland would be at
i cet it aDitatois would allow her to be so One w ould
think that his'orv had never been wntten Did the
Church of Home ever willingly accept any articles of
peace but those which gave lier the entire supremacy
of nund, and soul, anti body Did any pokey ot
conciliation ever satisfy that Cnurch, or was not that
which was granted made the basis of fresh demands
"What solemn vows and promises were heard when
the repeid ot Romish disabilities was sought ' what
confident hopes expressed-as, for example, by the
late Dr Clialuiers, who is reported to have said,
' lhat, with the Bible in one hand and the Roman
Catholic Relief Bill in the other, Ireland would
speedily be conv erted to the Protestant faith
It would have been cantUd if Mr Gordon had told
us that which is as much a certain matter ot his
tory as the Parliamentary speeches and lcsolutions to
which helios refirred-that the Orange associations
had then origin tit necessity, foi the purpose of
defence, and have never been tggressive
Allison, in lus 'History of Luiope, says, " there
was this essential difference uetweeii the Orangemen
and the I mteil Inshmen-the combination of the
Oranqcmtn was defensive, induced by necessity, that of
tie Catholics aggtesitie, stimulated by an.bitton lheie
is nothing, however, m Mr Gordon s letter that I so
much regret as the inference he desires to be drawn
from the conduct of Colonel I airman va. refusing to
give up the books with which he had been
confidentially entrusted I believe the infer
euee to be most ui lair, nnd entirely unvvar
ranted In his lefusal he did piecisely
what anv honourable man voultl do-what Mr
Gordon w oultl do ui bimilar cireums'ances Suppose
the Gr mel Master of the Freemasons were ordered by
oui Legislative -Vsaembly to give up the books of the
Ordei, and divulDc to the world those tlun0s which
v» ere intended to be kept from all but the initiated,
does mv fnend believe it possible that any amount of
threats or punishment would lead to compliance
lhc question Mr Gordon proposes is-If it was
right and proper to dissolve these associations in
Lngland and Iieland in lSe¡6, why are thev to exist in
l8 el and m this colony My niisuci is that there
are good and suibeient reasons for theu continuance
that there are the same reasons-but in a tenfold
aggravated form-foi the existence of Oiangeism.thut
induced the late able and v cnerable Dr Chalmers, in
the last few y ears of lus lite to believ e in the neces
sitv lor the establislunent ot the Lv angelical Alliance,
whose pnneiples and objects were the same It is
well known that that eminent divine was not an
opprctsoi of Romanists, but that, on the contrary,
lie battled for them most valiantly endeavouring to
secuie Catholic emancipation and y et when addiess
ing the G encrai Assembh in Glasgow in the v car l8 lo
he concluded his speech on Chinitian umem with these
| words-'And 1 just conclude with observing that
now is the time to rally about the common standard
ill th it is pure and vital in Protestantism for now it
is that vv o bhall h iv e to make head a"ainst a new fonn
and revival of Antichrist, whethei m the form
ofl'operv-n ikeel Pupcix-or Popery m disguise -
even that Antichrist which tia eatons to bhake a most
witheimg mildew over the whole ol Christendom
lwo xears later in lfelo (and within two years of the
close ot his honouied and useful life), when he felt
elie nceeseitv for the combination of Prot»stants
without retjUid to forms of Church government, he bj
a pamphlet promoted the establishment ol ' the
Alliance, from w Inch 1 desire to give one or two
exti lets, which I believe as truly and definitely set
forth the principles of Orangeism and the justification
tor their existence as the principles anil objects oí the
"Alliance, with which I bébete it is thoroughly
identified m all its pnneiples lu that pam.«
phlet Dr. - Chalmers' write«-" Wa feet all euh
ÎTelèncc irï rctomniending that they should stand
forth in 'the character first Of a great anti-Popish
association, and secondly of a great homo mission,
believing, as ive do, that to walk together in the field
erf Christian philanthropy is a likely preparation for
thinking together on the questions of Christian faith."
As serving to mark moro distinctively what he con-
ceived should be the primary object of the institution,
he proposed that it should be ejalled "The PaoTBfl
tant" rather than the Evangelical Alliance; and,
after describing the benefit which might arise from
this change of name in the way of warding off the
perplexities which might arise from any attempt to
define the evangelical doctrine so as to obtain for the
definition a universal concurrence, he proceeds thus :
-" There is another argument in favour of our pro-
posed title. Its single watchword not only describes
very clearly the qualifications of the proposed mem-
bership, but it intimates, with equal clearness, what
the precise work is in which, when brought together
and formed into au association, they are expected to
engage. It is an alliance in defence of Pro-
testantism. Where there is no danger to be warded
off, there might be no reason in pleading for such an
association as we now advocate, or for its title either.
But who can deny the existence of a most imminent
and daily increasing danger r Who eau be ignorant
of the bus}- aggressive proselytism and undermining
policy that are now in active operation, under the
conduct of agents and emissaries from the Church of
Kome? Who can be blind to the evidences now
springing up in vnrious lands, that the old priestcraft
of the Middle Ages is lifting its head again, and
shedding baleful influence over Churches that were
wont to boast of theirs being the foremost place, and
theirs the first-rate services in the cause of the
glorious Reformation ! Whether the Antichrist that
is now reappearing be in the ancient and unmitigateel
torm of Popery, cr in the no less dangerous though
milder form of Puscyism (in these days he would
Write liitualisw), surely there is most urgent call
for vigilance and alarm ; and, should it be made tho
first and most ostensible object of the Alliance to repel
the inrcads of this threatening mischief, ive are con-
fident, if such an undertaking were to give
forth its certain sound, that thousands
¡ind tens of thousands would hasten to
its summons, in the sacred cause of religious freedom,
and Scriptural Christianity, and the rights of private
judgment. It will be miserable indeed, if the hostile
demonstrations from without do not lead us to look
outwardly; or if we shall waste our energies on the
yet premature attempt to settle the account between
the various modifications and distinctions of Pro-
testantism, when the common enemjr is at the door,
and if not met with a systematic and combin'd reiistan<~c,
might bury Protestantiim, throughout all its varieties, in
one common »«in. We tell of a distinct thing to be
dene, and a distinct thing to correspond about, when
we state how desirable it is to ascertain the statistics
of Popery all over the world, and more especially the
statistics of Puseyism and High Churchism (Ritu-
alism)-these great feeders of Popery in our Island ;
anel furthermore, when we state as most fitting objects
for deliberation, what the best methods aro by which
to arrest the progress of the threatening mischief, not
only at home, but in America and the British colonies,
and the continent of Europe, and every other place
where Jesuitism is playing her wiles, and practising
with deadly success her manifold elelusions. Anei
reverting to our own affairs, as well as making an ad
vance from deliberations to doings, what more patent
than the various methods by which our literary and
ecclesiastical and influential men might arouse the Pro
\ testant community of Great Britain, and put our contti
tuincKS on the alert ; and also funds for the niultipli
I eation of scriptural schools, aud outrival our adver-
saries, who at this moment are labouring with all
| their might to obtain possession of the masses by their
linn earied attentions in the houses of the common
| pctiple, and doing whatever in them lies to influence and
Kain 01 cr our heretofore sadly-neglected population."
These ure what I understand to be the principles and
objects of Ornngeism-and if they are, I say to the
Orangemen-go on and prosper-be true to your
principles-true to your Bible-loyal to your Queen
-obedient to the laws-and brotherly affectioned to
all men of every creed, and you need not fear attacks
from any quarter. It is quite certain that the ranks
of the institution will be increased more by the
slanders of false brethren than Irom any other cause.
I know of nothing which aroused the feeling of quiet
soberminded Protestants so much, as the fact of a man
who calls himself a member of the Church of England
daring in the Legislative Assembly to compare
Orangemen with Fenians.
Believing that I have truly stated the principles of
Orangeism, and the only objects they have in view,
I must say that I never have been able to understand
how it is that loyal subjects of her Majesty-and
above all, men who are sincere Protestants-could
apply such rancorous language and such insulting
epithets as have been applied to those whose only
crime is that they dare to keep in remembrance
and to celebrate those great evento which enabled the
i late accomplished Lord Macaulay to write, " It is
* because we had a preserving revolution in the seven
i teenth century, that, we have not had a destroying
' revolution in the nineteenth. It is because we had
j freedom in the midst of servitude that we have order
I in the midst of anarchy. Por the authority of law,
for the security of property, for the peace of our
\ streets, for the happiness of our homes, our gratitude
is duo under IIi.m who raises and pulls down nations I
at his pleasure-to the Long Parliament, to the Con
vention, and to William of Orange." I
I will conclude by simply stating it as my deliberate
conviction^that if I had a desire to become an Orange-
man, there is nothing in Mr. Gordon's letter that
would cause me to pause for an hour, and I predict
that it will lead fifty persons to join for one it will
deter from becoming connected' with the Orange
1 Association.
With thanks for your kind permission,
I am, Sir, yours &c..
WILLIAM BARKER.
Elizabeth-street, 17th July.

Pursuant to tho Order of Iho Day,
The Bov. A H. t>TE. HEN moved that tho Tribunal
Ordinnnco bo now read a third time.
Mr. DAHLE\ moved that tho third reading be postponed
fill tho next session of the Synod. Ho could scarcely con-
ceive anything likely to bo more disastrous than hasty
legislation on thin subject, and it appeared to him that they
had run too rapidly through the measure to give it all tho
consideration its grcut importance demanded. By tho 20th
section of the Church Temporalities Aot, the Bishop of
S)dney had power, on caune shown, to revoko the license
of ntlergjmnn, indeed, bo took it, this was the section
which gavo the Bishop general control over the clergy of
bia diocese It was now, howevor, proposed to
create a new tribunal for the trial of cloigy,
not only for ordinary offences, but for doctrinal
offences. Ho ventured to say that not five members of tho
¡>) rod appreciated duly the importance of the stop thus
Icing taken The establishment of a tribunal like this re-
quired tome little the/Ught before n woll matured decision
eouldbe arrived at AB the law now stood, tho Bishop of I
h)dEoy was the tribunal for tho trial oi theso offences, and
it was sought to tako that power from him Why such
hnsto 5 Hid thoBishop exorcised unduo proesuroupon tho
elerey, or had bo on uny occasion failed in his dut) by
making inquiry, or bj ubBtaining from inquiry, as to
i ffences - lhcro were two or three points in this measure
that required the gruv est consideration. 1 ho third clauto
wns the key of the whole bill. It bad boon thought advis-
able that this power should be taken from the Bishop, and
be vested m a tribunal If thon it was advisablo to take
away this power from tho Bishop, why give the Bishop (as
wus provided in the first portion of this clause) the right of
an absoluto veto, whether a tlerg)uian should be tried or
not ? Here was a condition procèdent whereby tho aotion
of the tribunal might bo actually barrod. Hereafter wo
might hnvo bishops of opinions stronger or weaker than
thoso held by our present Bishop, some of whom
un¡,ht regard as importnnt mature what others looked upon
an trivial, and it win, posible that complaint might properly
be made against a ulcrg) man on a question oi elactnno,
when a.bithop would veto the charge on tho ground that tne
doctrino complained of was held b) himself, but ostensibly
cn tho ground of unimportance He (Mr. Darley) was
quite willing (hat tho pou or should be vosted as now in tho
hands of the Bishop, bul if ho woro to be deprived of it, do
not let bim have the right to bar tho action of tho tribunal
to which his power was transferred This peint did not
oppear to havo received any consideration at their hands.
Ly tho next clause it was provided that " if the onmmittoe
shall report that thero is not sufficient ground for the charge
made npainst the accused olerg)mnu, then the Bishop may
uletain from taking anv furiher proceeding in the matter."
Hero nn absoluto discretion was vested in tho Bishop, and
ho might, m spito of the committee's report, proceed
against theclerg)man Theeowere two matters of princi-
ple which did not seem to have boen propsrly considered
J here also appeared to be «overol oversights-first, in not
catrying the amendment in clause 7 into clause 8, whore it
w OB equally necessary. He had in practice seen tho disas-
trous effects of banty and crudo legislation, and they ought
to bear in mind tho possibility of some question in rcferonco
to the provisions contained in this ordinance being brought
btforo the Supremo Court The 9th clause provided that,
"If mont cose the accused clorgymanehall rofuso or neg
bet to appear either in person or by counsel or agent m
obedience to the citation BO issued and served on him as
hereinbefore mentioned, tho Tribunal ahall proceod so hoar
the cause in his absence " Tho condition precedent was
refusal or neglect, there waa no provision in referonce to
occident, or inability on account of ill health No doubt it
was provided that a new trial nug) t be granted m case
juaneo required it, but it would be a mee question for tho
judges to decide whether what had taken place
in the nbsenco of the accused could be regarded
as a trial or not, when that absence was unavoidable,
and whether in case of future proceedings they could be
regarded OB a second trial. It might be said this ordinance
was in effect tho copy or transcript of an ordinance in an-
other colony, still he conceived that it had not yet received
all the requisite consideration. Why take these powers
from the Bishop and veBt thom in another tribunal, which
hod no precedent in any other colony or m tho mother
ciunlry-(" Oh, oh ")-consisting of laymen andclericj-a
tribunal whose functions were not to bo exercuod unless
the Bishop gave leovo ' He moved that the third reading
be postponed, in order that membeis might bave timo to
consider tho principles upon which tho measure res'ed,
Tho Rev. Conon AILWOOM seconded tho mot on.
The Rev A H STEPHEN hoped the Synod would hast-
íate-before acceding to the motion With regard to the
otjection raised as to hasty legislation, it ought to be borne
in mind that this was not an experiment, and it would bo
found that the very points of principio to which Mr Darley
teok exception were contained m the English Church
Disciplino Act, from which the comunttoo copied
largely. With regard to the Synod being too
eager to transfer the power which the Bishop had
under Iho Church 1 eraporahties Act, the learned gentle-
men muBt have forgotten a decision of tho Supreme Court,
to which an appeal was modo a few years back, when it
nae decided that tho Bishop had no power to constitute
tuen a tiibunol na that by wbieh the appealing olorgyman
bid been tried Iho Svnod now had power unaor her
I galised constitutions to relieve the Bishop lrom a position
which all understood to bo distasteful to him Of tho two
instances in which the learned member objected
to prinnples in tho measure, precedents existed
in the English Act which had stood the test
of experience and which had been adopted by
the Australian Synods It seemed strango too that with a
complaint against depriving the Bishop of tho power ho
poetessed there should be associated an objection to the
discretion this bill gave to the Bishop That discretion
was allowed in the Church Discipline Act to anv English
Bishop With regard to the oversight referred to in clause
8 tho learned gentleman would perceive, on reading both
clauses, that tho amendment m the 7th was not required in
the 8th clause Then, agnn, in the Oth clause tho learned
gentleman said there was no provision made for cases of
absence through accident The last lino of tho 8th clause
cured any defect of that kind Every clause and line ot
tho measure bad been carefully considered, and he hoped
the Synod would not, unless much weightier reasons were
eli own, consent to tho postponement proposed
The Bov H A PALMEII supported the amendmont and
signified bis approval oi what the mover thereof had said
with regard to hasty legislation He thought thoy had
not sufficient time to consider tho matter, and as m the
divison on tho 8th clause nearly half the clergy present had
voted against it, ho thought that to ask for a postponement
was not too much, more especially as that clause deeply
affected the interests of the clergy Whatever might be the
inherent excellences of tho bill he would like to see it re
jeeted rather than that clause should pass The 8th
clauee was like the dead fly which made the whole of the
ointment unsavoury (Hear, hear, and laughter ) The
mover ol the bill had said that it was taken from an
English model but bad forgotten that there the law
referred to tbo vvholo of the English diocese, so that
there could bo no différence between the tribunals
If we could have a law hero which would be binding on
the whole of the tribunals it might be of advantage, but I
hero wo had a tribunal of one kind in one dioco«e and 1
another tribunal of quite a different character in another, j
so that the Church here might come to bo regarded as a I
divided Church administering matters of doctrino and
ritual in different ways and deciding upon quite different
standards of faith He did hope that the matter would
be postponed until next session , if not, he must ask leavo
to liter his bumble protest against the eighth clause
The amendment waa thon put, and declared to be
negatived
