THE MA1UUAOF QUEBTION
Tbo DTAN oi SIDNEY rose to move (ho adoption of the
report of the committee on tbo Marriage question Since
bo gato notice of this motion, which ho was permitted to
lioonltidny evening, it bad been suggested to him that
the moro convenient way of discussing the whole matter
would bo by the Synod resolving itself into a committee cf
the wholo to ce nsider tho report With tho permission of
the Synod, he moved " That his Lordship leave the chair,
and the Synod resolve itsolf into a committee of the whole
to consider the recommendations of the report "
Mr RICHARD JONES seconded the motion, which was
put and passed, and the Synod went into committee
The DFAN or SIDNEY then said that ho rose for the
purpose oi rawing certain resolutions foundod upon the
recommendations of the Committeo's report upon the mur-
ringo queelton, and before he proceeded to move theBe
resoiutionp, it would, perhaps, be expected of him to give
some explanation of the grounds on which tho Committee
had arrived at their conclusions The members of the
St nod bad had the report m their hands for eovoral days,
and it might bo expected that they had made themselves
acquainted with lis contente Ho trusted that it was BO ,
that the report bad been carefully read and considered, for
if it had been, that circumatanco would much facilitate the
Lusineea before them He would, however, mako a few
explanatory observations with reference to the matters
contained in the report It would be observed by tho com
inittto that the clergy had reported various causes ua having
ltd to the dccrenfe~in the number of mnrriogos celebrated
[ ly the clergy of the Church of England, and ho regretted
to say that this diminution bad gone on increasing during
tho post 3ear, for he found that the number
of marnagea celebtated by the clorgy of the
Church of England in this colony dunn g
1PGG v os thirty lesa thamnl8G5 Thisdecreaso was, how-
ever, not so v try great, e onMdenng that tbo total decrease
in the number of marriages bad been also great But there
vue one consideration which ho thought should hftvo con
e-ielcrable weight with the clergy and laity, vi/ , that un
lerfector cironcous opinions with regard io Iho marriage
Tito WOB one great caupe which led to the diimuutiou, and
vhith had led to it in this ws)-from a desire to be married
in private If the divine institution of marriage nnd ils
clinrnctcr were duly considered, and the solemn responsibi
hues connected -with that Holy Ordinance were connilered,
people would not desire this privacy Thoy would feel that
tbcro was nothing to bo BBhamed of, they would think
tjnt they were going about a very honourable
thing,-would desire their friends to be acquainted with
what thej were going to do, und would not wish to onter
Fecretly that hoi) stato which vi OB instituted by God at the
lepinning of man s eMBtence, and which Scripture bud said
tr Lo honourable in nil and symbolical of Christ s Church
He did hofatbat tbo clergy would consider this carelully
Pn bablv they had been to blamo in not endeavouring to
inform their people on thiB suljtct Ho saw no better way
e t benefiting them than by informing them of tho ov ii and
giving them more correct views A number of reasons
were, given ne to the causes which had led to thedeciease
111 ken of, and amongst them was ono he would refer to,
viz, the facilities afforded for prívalo marriages
Ho had co doubt that the ministrations of
LIB brethren had brought under their notice painful
citcum«-tanceB of this nature He remembered one instance
cf a young woman leaving the house in which she was a
sei vont-ueking permission to go out and seo a friend
HermistrcES wos sick in bed , her master was aw ay from
bone, and she did not return until II o'clock at night,
when ehe told her mistress that sho was married Ho
knew of other persons having been married in the same
hiiMv manner. TheEe wero evils, however, that could
bat di) be rectified without an alteration in the marriage
lim of the colony A great numbor of recommendations
had been made by clergymen, in reply to questions pro
pofcd to them, and ho would mention them as they were
pieced before tho Sjnod in tho report. Some proposed
» i eduction of the marriage fees, others tho abolition
of fees altogether Others proposed that banns
t-hculd bo dispensed with altogether, and others that licenses
bhould be dispensed with altogether. But the most im
rortant recommendation, and one which seemed moro
likdy than any other to havo a practical result was that
the hours should te extended to 8, or half past 8 o'clock, in
the evening. He might state that that recommendation
proceeded frem a number of clergvmen, some of whom had a
ci risiderable experience in the colony, and appeared to have
given the matter a great deal of careful consideration
Another tery important recommendation contained in these
icpheB of the clergy was with reference to the necessity
for persons being married in the church of the
parish in which one of tho parties resided. This
WSB a question which he hoped the committee
would consider very carefully, and be prepared
to deal with after that careful deliberation that it deserved,
1er his own part, he must eay that he was acquainted with
e number of cases m which a great hardship had been felt
1 y perEons who wiBhod to be married in another church than
i but of their own pariBh. There were, it was true, moana
sf getting over this great difficulty. Persons giving notioe
ot their intention of being married in a particular church
nnd going to reside for a short time-sovondajs- m tho
(arish to which that church belonged, could obtain their
desire Ho knew of such cases "Very strong feelings had
existed, and be might cay prejudices entertained and unkind
fedings generated, by this res notion , and ho did not
wonder that the clergy ana tomo of them strongly, pro
poied the abolition of this restriction Passing from these
general observations, with reference to the cau«0B
ned tbe remedies, he carne to the proposition of the first of
these resolutions, and the resolution he had now to submit
to the committee was as follows -"That this Synod
having under consideration the report of the committee
appointed by the Synod to inquire into the causes which
have operated to bring about tho large diminution which
bos taken place in the number of marriages celebrated by
the clergy of the Church of England m this diocese, and
to consider and report what measures it is advisable to adopt
vnlh a view to remedy the evils resulting from members of
the Church resorting to ministers of other denominations to
le matried, resolve that it is expedient -Tirat, that all
fetB now charged m connection with the celebration of
nmiriBge, whether by banns or license, bo abolished.'1
Members would observe that this stood number one on the
recommendations of the committee, and he now proposed
them as resolutions of the Synod. It had appeared to the
coii.mitteo who bad charge of this measure not
desirable that tbe fees should be diminished, as
that would hardly meet tho difficulties of the
case, but cons'dered it would bo preferable
to abolish all compulsory payment of fees whether the inar
iicgo were celebrated by banna or license, and that persons
con ing lo the celebration of the mnrnago rito should merely
make wbat voluntary offerings they choto upon the occa
tun. Ho believed that would be a wiso courso AB we
n ode no charge for baptism and other rites of tho Church,
he thought people should receiv e this nie without being
compelled to pay for it It would remove difiiculties out of
the way, and would draw numbers to tho Church to be
married if all the fee6 they were required to pay before tho
celebration of tho marriage were abolished Of course ho
WOB aware that certain expenses were paid by means of these
feet-that out of them a certain provision was made for the
salaries of tho registrar of the diocese, and the Bishop's
fceretary , and ho wae well aware that some other provision
would bave to be made, it the Synod should resolve to carry
out this resolution It appeared to the committee that there
would bo other ways and means found for providing for
meso minga , ont that was a question he should be able te
moot at a later stage of the proceedings. He hardly ex-
pected that there would be much objection to the report, end
therefore ho did not like to occupy tho time of the committee
by dilating upon it any longer Whatever the decision of
tho question might be, he should receive it with good temper
and Christian feeling
The Rev Canon ALLWOOD seconded tho motion.
The Rev ALriiED STEI HEV, though entirely approving
of the abolition ti all marriage fees, felt it right to move an
amendment, which was, that ali the words after the word
' licence," m the second line, bo omitted, with a view of
inserting the following words, "except a fee of ±1, be
abolished " He believed that it would be inexpedient,
however desirable, to abolish the fees altogether. Tho
parish would be taxed to pay the salaries of the registrar
and tbo Bishop's secretary, and even at present there was
Eome trouble in gotting the Synod expenses The payment
of ¿1 es a marriage fee would not be felt aa irksome, while
it would provide the money requisito for the sálanos he
had mentioned
The ¡Rev R. W YOIAO seconded the amendment.
The Bev G N. WOOJJD objected that the abolition of
fees was contrary to the Kubnc, in which it waa laid down
that the bridegroom should present the " accustomed duty
to tho priest and clerk "
The Rev THOMAS SMITH objected altogelher to tho
proposition of the Rev Alfred Stepben Ho said that no
compulsory charge should bo exacted for the performance of
the marnago rite. He believed m popularising the Church,
but cot at the expense of principle, and he believed the
Church had been too long fettered by an obnoxious system
in connection with our marriage fees The best thing
waa to throw our doors aa wide open aa possible,
and let the people give what they considered to
be a proper and sufficient remuneration He believed
tbat a fee of £1 wouldlbe as distasteful aa a larger one, and
that tbo reduction would be of no use whatever. He hoped
I the Synod would come to the conclusion to take away every
particle of fees from the ritee of the Church. By meeina
of tbeae feea we now onlyllurncd people away from our doora
to get wbat thoy wanted at some of these matrimonial
huoketere' tahona. He supported the original motion.
Tbo Re-v Mr. BAKMLR roae to oppose the amendment
moved by the Rt-v Mr. btephon, desiring to sea the subject
moro fully and fairly discussed He foareá that the rotontion
cf the£l fee would tnvelvo all the difficulties which wore in-
cidental to the- present plan, and fail to effeot any impr v>
ment whatever, there wore, nevertheless, aa he thought,
many eases m which fees might yet bo left
jin) able to clergjmen who in tho interior bad
often to ride to a great distance to perfirm
the rito of mnrtiago It waa not so muob. a nutter
of money with them as it was a matter of sincero daiire
that they should not loso their people at a ontical and im-
putant penodof their Uves
The Rov. C F. GAIUSSEI had boen afraid that tho
Standing Committee were going *o say that no fee w ia to
be puid for the celebration of mamago because marnago
was a sacrament, but ho waa relieved to find that tho whole
matter was to be considered only OB a mattor of expediency
He did not think that the clergy of other religious bodies
did make a matnmonial.huckstenng shop of their ministerial
position ia tho celebration of the marriage rite He was tho
more anxious to have thus ui dcrstoud, as they were about,
it seemed, to ai-similato to their practice In p lint of fact
they were, it seemed, to be mado bogging friara rather than
butksterers, they were to a»k for nothing, but to take what
might bo given to thom Ho hoped that tho resolution
would be carried, but that no mputations would bo thrown
uj on tbo ministers of other denominations. They could
surely carry on their deliberations without resorting to any
such gratuitously oljectionablo romarks |
The Rev THOMAS SMITH said that ho must repeat and
insist upon what bo had said. He did think that thoro
were certain ministers who were not ashumod to make their
churches matrimonial h lekstor shops, as it wore, when thoy
public! ed in the newopapora tho rate of fees that thoy
charged for the solemnisation of marriage,
Mr JV'IL'ES hoped the fees would bo abolished, and
thought it certain that such a chuugo would be the means
of largely lncreacingthc number of the marriages celebrated
ni f he Church of England
IboRov P. W YOUNO had supportod the amendment, but
slill hoped that the time would come whon all feos would be
done away with, not onl) in respect of the solomnisntion of
matrimonj, but fees for the burial of tho dead and for the
churching of women.
'1 he Rev Mr I"o\. was stroigly in favour of the origi-
nal motion Ibu influenco that u clergyman exorcised in a
family, es a consequence of hi» having been the mmistor
who had married tho father and mother, was a very im
portant influence, which it wis most desirable to extend and
to maintain
Mr RICHARD JoivES strongly opposed the amondmoat
The Rev A H STEI HEN said that, as the feeling of the
comrmtteo appeared to be decidedly ogainBt thu amendment,
he uhould (b) leave) withdraw it.
IhoBifeitoi thought it was essential to the wtllbeing of
the diocese that such an officer as the registrar should bo
rammed Iho feo fora morriogo license was duo hythe
low of the Church to the registrar of the dio
cfsc Thcro waa a necessity for the provision of
s mo monev for the support of the registrar, in caso
of the contemplated chango Ho thought that thore
bad been muth practie ii wibdom in tho Rev Mr
Stephen s amendment If they abolish tho fees thoy ought
to tuko sleps to provide for the support of the registrar
1 ho amendment was put and negatived, and the original
motion (moved by the Dean of Sydney) vas carried
the DEAN or SIIINTA moved the se ond resolution,
vhieh was as follows -" I hat persons bo allowed to have
their marunga solemnised in any church or parish v.nich
thev may infer, without respect to thtir residence in that
perish ' Tbo regulations, which it was now proposed to
abrogate had been found to work very bidl) Iho refusal
of the clergyman to eolemniso marnago as requeuted had
enuKd tbo«o who were BO refused to cease to attend the
c1 urch thev vvete in the habit of attending, it had cauaod
irueh ill feeling, and had even beea found to cstran¿o such
| pi rties altogether from the Church
Ihe Rev. HILTON S KINO objected to the term» of the
uso ution, doubting whether, on technically legal grounds,
II WHR penible thus by a mere resolution to do nwiy with
ile Ciinens let them bo careful not to make any Buch
(bungo OB would involve n breach of their constitutions
He was prepored to votoogaiubt the «solution
The Rev C F GAIIN->E\ would bo very eorrj to loso
any of tbo rubrical laws of their Cliuich He should
oj pete the resolution If they pa«sed it, thoy would cer
lemly be ogreeing to what was coutrury to tho law end to
, iho Canons of tho Chuich of England
Mr. OWEN was oppot-ed to tho resolution as being
in contravention of the constitutions of the Church of
Ln¿land
'the Eev. Mr MOTCETON thought that tho discussion wis
nrcdlcstly hampered by an unduo consideration of what
«OB called tho "Parishes" of tho Church m this colony
lhere was no euch thing horo as apaiishmtho English
tense of Iho term. Ho thought that they had no right to
ltatst that tbo pecple should bo married m this or that
church In removing tho marriage fee they had removed
ere obstacle, but they would not effectually attain thoir
nlject if they did not further amend the law in tho
manner proposed He ehould cordially support the resolu-
tion
The Rev, E M SALIN IFIIE Bhould oppose the résolu
tion, because it would, in his opinion, tend to subvert the
p> rocbial system. In his opinion, it was clearly within the
iflico of a Bishop to assigna territorial limit to a euro of
B( uln Ho was quite Euro that tho chango contemplated in
I Le feeB would be all that was required
T he Kev. THOMAS SMITH Baid that all tho clergymen
pttsent contributed to break these peculiar restrictions as to
pnritb (No) Well, certainly a great many did. Ho
the light that it was an evasion of the law for parties to ba
i ccemmodated wnh (croponry residence in a pariah for
ti vin days to qualify thom to evade the law. His own
pi rii-b, as it was called, was very îndtstmctly defined
It vi as preposterous to have to state that people might be
ni ov-ed still to come to a church situated as his was, for the
I em bt of tho sacraments and for public worship, and never
iheltEB to bo actually compelled to go to a great distance
to getmorned.
The Rev G. N. Woonrj objected to the resolution, as
Leirg opposed to tho 102nd Canon If the license that he
held in bia band bad any validity, he waa bound to respeot
thnt Canon, which waB most explicit on this point. He
hoped that in tbis and in every other proposed regulation
they would adhere to the wordB of the wise man-'. Stand
on tbo old paths, and medole not with them that are given
to orange .'
Mr, FoSTEit said that thoy had not in this colony any
such things as the " Parish " or "Parish church," as they
ixisted in England. |
Mr. A, QortDON could not accedo to the résolution as it
now stood, because ho believed it to be directly opposed to
iho Canon. In regard to the ecclesiastical districts of this
colony, they were accepted by the clergymen of the dioceBo
who were licensed by the Bishop, and became to them what
the parishes at home were by the express terms of the law
of England. He thought the clergyman was bound
to carry out tho provisions of tho canon which
had been aptly quoted by his rev. friend Mr. G. N. Woodds.
The Canons of 1603 were as binding upon the clergy of this
colony, as a matter of contract, as thoy were upon the
e'ergy in England.
The Bev. A. H. STEPHEN suggested that the resolution
be so modified as to allow the marriage in the church where
ene of the parties proposed to be married resided.
Several Voices : " That is what it is now."
The Rev. Mr. STEPHEN pointed out that it was not quite
the some.
Mr. M, METCALFE suggested an adjournment of tho
debate, in consequence of the lateness of the hour.
On tbe motion of the DEAN or SYDNEY, the chairman
l( fr the chair, and reported that the committee had adopted
tbe iirft resolution of the committee.
The Synod adjourned at 11 o'clock until to-morrow
(.Tuesday), at hnlt-paat 3 o'clock.

title: INTERCOLONIAL TELEGRAMS
content:
! INTERCOLONIAL TELEGRAMS
I m
(UV SUBMARINE CABLK.-COPVItlClHT.
[TASMANUN FBKSS AHHOCIATION.]
WOTOMA.
MELBOURNE, FUIDAV.
The first general meeting of the members
of the United trade Defence Association was
held this afternoon, when rules were
adoptod and a strong central council formed.
The Chairman (Mr. A. McCrackcn) said the
period' had now been reached when those
interested in the different branches of the
liquor trado would have to act together in
order to proteut themselves against class
legislation.

title: CRICKET.
content:
CRICKET.
On Wednesday afternoon last, a match, the Audit v.
the Treasury Departments was commenced, end concluded
yesterday in favour of tho former by 10 runa only. The
idea of commencing shorth» after 4 o'clock, which gives
over two hours play, for more reasons than one is an ex-
cellent one, and it is" not at all improbable that other depart-
ments next season will follow the example. While it does
not nnctoach upon ofliuiiil time, there is une other advantage
about it that, plenty ot grounds are obtainable, tho time
selected being on off-days, when other clubs cannot use
them. It may be noted that the Audit had one man absent.

title: THE FARNELL LAND BILL, AND ITS FATE
content:
TEE EAENELL LAND BILL, AND ITS FATE'
TO THE EDITOR OF THE HERALD.
Sir,-I respectfuly ask a few shoit lines of space to bring
under criticism tho vote of the House on the second reading
of the late Government's Land Bill That bill did not in any
way interfere with tho mam principle of tho bill of 1861,
it left that principle intact, and on this giound alone should
havo been read a second timo by a House piotessmg to be-
lieve m the land legislation ot 1SC1 Su John Robertson
tried to introduce a Land Bill at the beginning of the
session which he stated, embodied all the amendments
required, evory principle m vthich bill was in the bill of
tho late Government, which Su- John Robertson voted
against
The rejected Land Bill greatly favoured tho free
selector, adopting all the main principles put
forward by tho free selectors at their Confer-
ence , and yet strange to state, Mr B irbour, the
President of that Conlerencc, voted against it In the
rejected bill tho free selectors were favomed to a degree foi
beyond their wildest hopes or expectations, nnd yet dozens
of members who havo always pioiessed to be the free
selectors' fast and steady fnends voted against tho bill
If any one can pluck out the heart ot this mystery, 1 ask
him to do so, because to me it is in olublt Iho free
selectors will never again get a bill so f ivoumblo to Ihcir
interests, and this was confessed bv such wami friends of
the freo selector as Messrs Dav, M'Elhono, and Bennett
Tho principal objection to tho bill, as enunciated bv most
of tho speakers, was the very (,rav o niattei oi interest on
tho balances of futuio freo selectois Ot com se, there
were many other objections, but I submit not one ot a vital
character-that is, that could not havo been easily
amended m committee I do not know anv bill ihut
over carno before Faihament that was better entitled
to bo read a second time, alwa\s bearing m
mind that the wholo Paihamont favoined the principio
of tho 1861 legislation Tho House could have stiuek out
with ease eveiy bo-called defect that was riomtcd out during
the lengthy debate, and a bill could havo been passed in
harmony, at least, with tho opinions of honorable members
This was not done, for reasons that I do not attempt to
fathom, but it might have ha\o been done it men had
acted up to their opinions If any Land Bill is introduced
by tho present, or any future Government, I will ventaie
to make this small prophecy with legaid to it uinneh,
that it will contain every manciple of the late rejected bill
with the exception of the abolition of interest on the balances
of futuro free selectors, and one or two other matta s or no
great moment
lhe proposal to raise tho squatters' rent to the extent
of £400,000 a year secured, m my op mon, the -elec-
tion of the bill, but let any Government attempt to
introduce a Land Lill without this must ughteous pio
posal, and that Government wul meet with \erv sudden
death I am sorry the people h id not a chance of speaking
and acting ou this most important matter
I obseire the Albwy Mannt) stiongly condemns "Mr
Barbour for voting against the second loading of the bill,
stating that it contained threc-fomths ot vhat the Tiee
Selectors' Conference put ioith.as their wants
There cannot bo a doubt of thi3 that the whole body of
free selectors would have voted for the bill to a man, as well
they might, for they will never got such another bill
If there is to be no attempt to separate the two great
interests, pastoral and agricultural, the people will not m a
hurry get so good a bill as that which has just been
rejected, which with a few easily made alterations would
have been in unison with the opinions of every member of
tho House From what has happened the free selectors will
have little difficulty m discovering who are their li lends,
and I believe the lesson will not bo thrown away upon
them __ I remain, yours, dLc,
DAVID BUCHANAN.
Sydney, December 23.

title: PEAK DOWNS COPPER MINE.
content:
PEAK DOWNS COPPER MINE. I
I , ? - .1-T., - ? Il
I " TO ÏHE ETJ1TOK OP TH*" HElUUD^ ^ ¡ |
Sir,-Just now'when so much'dependí upon bona fido
mining investment« it would bo well to examine tho recent
report of so prominent a company as the Peak Downs,which
has caused such a consternation in -tho minds of the invest-
ing public. After tho progress of the mino had culminated
in to splendid a success as that shown last half-year when
the whole of the nominal capital was returned, we had a
right to expect that the affairs of tho company were based
upon n really solid footing-a footing too «ure to bo upset
by the causes set forth in the last report. A comparison
between this and the previous report forces upon one the
conviction that neither the one nor the other represented tho
fair Btato of the company's position ; that if not both, cer-
tainly the last was written to havo tho effeet which it cer-
tainly had. There is no doubt about the effect of tho report
m July last, and I observe, in passing, that with this com-
pany the effect of the half-yearly report invariably pre-
cedes with singular accuracy its actuol issuo. The com-
pany's etock was raised to tho highest point it has yet
touched, while tho prcEcnt report tends to send it down to
o figure far below tho real value of tho shares. Every line,
evciy word tends to depreciate the company's position.
But let us take the points seriatim. ,
1. In July wo were told of the arrival of the
first shipment of Cornißh miners and of another
ihipnieut "hourly expected," and that "this acces-
sion of labour w ould allow tho mining operations to bo
pursued on a larger scale, the furnaces to bo constantly
supplied with n proper ossoitmcnt of oro, and the quantity
of me at grass to be much increased." What has bocomo of
thiB other shipment ? Did the men over arrive, or did thoy
go to the bottom ? And if they arrived, how comes it that
the production of oro is Icsb than it was P How is it that
no mention of them is now made, but that wo aro only told
of a botch of miners to soil in Fobruary, and who cannot
poEsibly nrrivo in time to affect the production of the mino
during the now current six months t
2. Wo wero told last half-year what tho actual produc-
tion of the mino was, viz., 1449 tonB of refined copper.
Whereas now there is no information whatever vouchsafed
to ns, wo aro only told vaguely of thedecroosoof production
caused by a temporary want of fuel ; and wo know this,
that tliis "decreased production," whatever it may hove
been, has cost £65,377, whilo lost half-year 1440 tons' of
refined copper cost only £60,671 ; that the smaller mun thus
expended gave a return at the rate of 200 per cent, per
annum, and the larger expenditure gives nil.
3. In July, when the object was to pay a big dividend,
every item which could swell tho company's profits was
set down. Storesand materials were valued; the stock at
the mino, the office furniture, and the petty cash found
their ploco in the balance sheet. Whero aro they
now ? They oro certainly not mentioned in tho bataneo
sheet presented to the shareholders.
4 In the last, as in all previous reports, tho balance
sheet has shown the actual balonco (Dr or Cr ) ot the
Bank of New South Wales Tor what reason, I should
liko to know, is this left out of tho present report? Ihero
must surely hnv e been n balance on ono side or tho other
6 In July, the directors were bo particular m estimating
the vnlno of oro nt grass that wo were told, even to an
eighth per cent, what it was worth,-viz , 164 per cent of
copper to tho ion of ore Every reasonable man would
suppose, with an exnet calculation like this, that such
extreme caro hod been taken that all possibility of mistake
was excluded, especially as m tho previous half-year the
oro was valued roundly at 20 per cent But it turns
out now that the valuation was nil wrong , and if the last
estimóte of 12J per cent bo correct (though there is doubt
cost upon this, for it does not tally with what the chairman
in his remarks gave os the average during the post six
months) it would almost seem from the successive grada-
tions that the intrinsic value of our ore has been sensibly
falling oft-first 20 per cent, then 16|, and now 12|
6 With the60 facts before the directors, and n diminished
value of copper m London, what justification hnd they for
paving on the 1st October tho final 5s of the July dividend
thereby absorbing £25 000 of tho company's funds, and
which ought to have been available for tho present half
year? lossy thot this only "discounted the prospects of
the shnrcholdcrs " is a mere gloss, and a very poor answer to
thoso who, like myself, bought upon tho strength of the
July report It was m fact misleading tho public os unmis
tokobly as it was possible to do, creating a fatal confidence
and giving the shares a fictitious valuo, and that by using
for the benefit of tho July shareholders, funds properly
belonging to the present shareholders
"A"SHAREHOLDER AT SIX POUNDS TEN
SHILLINGS.
Goulburn, February 6.

title: ADELAIDE.
content:
ADELAIDE.
THURSDAY.
It is reported that Mr. Boucaut takes the Public
Works, and that a member of Council will succeed
him in the Crown Lands.
The thermometer stood at 103° in the shade yester-
day.
A proposition to throw the Wesleyan Conference
open to the public, or to church members, was
negatived.
Theodore Voges, an agent, attempted suicide by
cutting his throat.
Wheat is still wanted at 4s. 8d. Freights are
easier ; offerings at 46s. to 47s 6d.
Mr. Duffield's Victoria Mill at Gawler has been
gutted by fire ; it is insured in the Imperial for £4500,
the Cornwall Office for £1500, and the Queen for
£1000 : the Imperial had a reinsurance with the
Australian Alliance, Commercial, and Victoria.
Large wheat stacks in the stores and in the open air
were saved. The cause of the fire was apparently
accidental.

title: SPORTING.
content:
SPORTING. I
[By Teh-.ouai'ji.]
FORBES RACES.
WJUNESDAY. I
The weather was cloudy and fine ; the attendance on
the course was numerous, and everything passed off
well.
Maiden Plate.-Molong 1, Lottery 2. Four
started ; a capital race.
Hurdle Race.-Sampson 1. Only ttwo started,
and the other baulked at the second jump.
Town Plate.-Gratis 1. Plunger 2. Molong
bolted before starting and went twice 'round the j
course. _
L-AnuV Plus?.-Aristocrat 1. Only two started,
biit it was a good race.

title: ADELAIDE.
content:
ADELAIDE.
MONDAY.
Tho Chamber of Commerce has called a special
meeting this afternoon, to consider the question of a
landing place for the English mails.
Mrs, Douglas, wife of a hawker, in good circum-
stances, at Nailsworth, has been found in her house
murdered.
Considerable- anxiety is felt at the non-receipt of.
news of the Penola.
Wheat is very firm at 5s. 8Jd.

title: A CASE OF SUTTEE.
content:
A CASE OF SUTTEE.
(From the Pioneer, May 4.)
THE following are the circumstances of the suttee case
which occurred in the Cuwnpore district : -
. On the 16th ultimo the brother of a woman named
MuBsumat Rahusia, living at a village six miles ironx
the police station of Sheolee in the Cawnpore district,
brought her tidings that her husband, a Brahman»
Omeid Tewarree, had lately died at Mhow. The
widow showed great emotion ; she broke the bangles
from her wrists, and shortly after began to crj|
" Stitt Ham, Stitt Pam," repeatedly at short inter-
vals, announcing her intention to sacrifice herself.
The Pundit of the family advised the test to be
applied, vi-/.., that her hand should be placed over a
lighted lamp, to see if she could bear the pain. The
lamp was brought, the -widow herself placed lier handt
over the flame, and kept it there until it waa black»
ened and blistered, declaring that she felt no pain ;
Bhe was then declared worthy to perform the sacrifice.
A large number of the neighbours assembled, and
there appears to have been a good deal of apprehen
sion among them at this time as to the consequences
which would ensue if the suttee should toke place.
The members of the woman's family declared that
they would not allow it, as it was the " Angrezi
amul," and the results might be serious to them.
The matter was left undecided that clay, though the
widow herself never seems to have faltered in her de«
termination. The next morning some of the family
started with the widow for Bithoor, for the purpose
of performing funeral rites for the deceased husband»
but the Pundit recalled them, Baying that the day wass
inauspicious. The widow continued throughout the
day to chaunt "Stitt Pam, I will go and burn with
my husband." Many people came to see her.
Towards evening she addressed some Thokoor zemin-
dars, and begged them to grant her the bson of a
piece of land for the sacrifice, At last one of the
Thakoors present appeared to be overcome by h I
solicitation, and said, " Come, I'll give you a fisld,
be the consequences what they may," notwithstanding;
the protest of many present who prophesied the
danger of the proceedings. After this, however, less
opposition was offered, and large numbers of peop'e
come to make their obeisance to the holy woman. It
appears to have been understood this evening that the
suttee would take place. Early the next morning «
circumstance occurred showing the feeling of the
people. A man obtained admittance at down to the
house, and falling down before the womnn, addrcsserl
her, saying, " Maharanee, I am moonblind, when,
shall I regain my sight ?" evidently having faith in
the miraculous powers with which the intended sacri-
fice was supposed to endow the vie im. The woman,
however, who had eaten nothing for two days, and
drunk nothing but some Ganges water, appeared
much exhausted on this morning, and after begging
the people of the house to hurry on the preparations
lay down for some time gasping on her back. Hoc
friends thought she was dying and the Pundit ad-
vised a gnrment fangurkhee) of her husband's to be
given to her, saying that her soul was longing for her
husband, and perchance the Bight of his co.it would
revive her. The angurkhe» was brought by her son,
and it really seemed to pioduce the desired c-ilect, foe
clasping it to her breast she rose and called for the
musicians, and again addressed the zemindars presento
asking for a piece of ground for the performance oE
the suttee. The Pundit here improved the occasion to
address a sermon to his female parishioners :-" Few
wives now-a-days," he said, " love their husbands
lo well as this woman loves her huBband'saHjiirMfe.",
The Thakoor who had come forward the previous
evening again declared his readiness to give a field,
and hurried out to give orders for wood to be cut and
carried to the spot. Several men gave their assistance
in cutting and carrying wood, and as Boon as a pyre
was constructed, information was carried to the
widow, who, after putting on jewels and otherwise
preparing herself, lost no lime in proceeding at almost
a running pace to the field, followed by a procession
of some two or three hundred of the neighbouring
villagers-the males first, and the women in the rear,
succeeded by a band of village musicians pressed into
the service. On arriving at the field, the suttee, as
the woman is now called, mounted the pyre, on which
she set herself cross-legged, and gave instructions
that her son should set fire to it. This son, a youth of
about eighteen years of age, had brought a 'nundle of
grass with which to set light to the wood, and as soon,
as his mother was prepared he fired the gross. On
the flames rising the suttee half rose from her sitting
posture, on seeing which the spectatoas murmured in
dissatisfaction, but the woman immediately resumed
her seat, and signed with her hand that she had no
intention of evading the sacrifice. Shortly after some
of the bystanders threwTin more wood, the flames
rose and surrounded the victim, and the sacrifice waa
consummated. The spectators then brought flowers
and offerings of various kinds, threw them on the em-
bers, and dispersed.
Now it must be remembered that this suttee was
first agitated on the loth, and that it was not consum-
mated till the 17 th, and that during this time hun-
dreds of people were thinking and talking of little
else. Yet the police, it really appears, did not hear
of it until a chowkeeelar started from the guilty village
for the police station of Sheolee on the 17 th at anhouc
carefully calculated to make this information too
late. When the chief constable, Azeezoolah, reached
the scene of the tragedy about 1 o'clock, he found
nobody, and nothing but ashes. When he pushed
his inquiries, he was told that the woman had herself
collected wood and gruss without assistance, aid had
secretly, without accomplice, burnt herself to death.
The native police elicited no other information,
and they did < not communicate even this.
The District Superintendent, Mr. Goad, saw
this chief constable, Azeezoolah, on the fol-
lowing day, the 18th, and talked at length with
him regarding other offences in the district; but the
chief constable made no mention of the sulcce. It waa
not indeed until the 20th that the Azee/.ooloh sent
his diary, containing the false account which the vil-
lagers had in the first instance attempted to palm off
upon him, by post to his superiors. Mr. Goad at
once proceeded to the guilty village Where the vil-
lagers bolted their doors, and at first assumed almost
a menacing attitude. By great intelligence and firm
nfss, however, he ultimately succeeded not only in
obtoining|a full and true history of the caso, butin
arresting all the zemindars and others at a'l compro-
mised. The chief offmder, however, the widow's
son, Bohadoor, who had actually kindled the funeral
pilo on which she was consumed, has absconded, and
has, we believe, not jet bi en apprehended.

title: LATROBE.
content:
LATROBE.
The death of Mr. Maurice Nathan, of
this town, removes from our midst one of the
oldest merchant pioneers of the Coast.
Qeneralregrot was expressed on Thursday lint
when |it beaame known that he had suddenly
taken seri'iusly ill from some throat affec-
tion, but it caine as a, very painful surprise to
those who knew lum when told on Saturday
morning that on the previous «vening he had
passed to his last rest. Mr.Nathanfiist became
connected with the various interests of the J
North-West Coast close on 40 years ago,
wheo he established himself os a general
dealer at Fort Sorell before Latrobe had
become the business centre. He eventually
removed to Latrobe, commencing business
as a general storekeeper in premises adjoin- j
ing the old Commercial Bank, which he sold
subsequently to Messrs. E. ana W. L.
Bartlett.proceeding theucoto Launceitonaud
Melbourne, returuîug to Latrobe some
six or seven years ago, again setting up
business as wine and spirit und produce
merchant in premises built for his oivn use,
but which he retired from list year. He
was appointed a Justice of the Peace for
Latrobe during 1887, and was one of the
best attende» to the various duties such
appointment imposed upon him. The de-
ceased leaves no family, and was S3 years of
age at the time of his death, his widow being
a sister of the Messrs. Bartlett of this town.
During his long business career he bas
become known to pretty well all who reside
in the district, and general regret will be
expressed at the news of his demise.
The manager of the U.A A.A. is evidently
bent upon making the forthcoming exhibi-
tion u gigantic success. Ho lus just re-
ceived a letter from Nick Long, editor of tho
Olympian, California, with extracts from
I that and other papers, publiabin-* a chal-
lenge for £300 to the champion axe-
men of the United States und Canada,
and stating that the challenge had
been Bent to the various lumber
districts of Michigan, Wisconsin, Cali-
fornia and Canada, also stating tout an
effort was being made to secure the entry
of J. A Muiray, of Vancouver, the champion
axeman of Canada, for the forthcoming con-
tests, which take place in November.
lu all probability an entry will be received
for tho sawing contest from oue of the best
sawyers of British Columbia.
September IS.

title: ADELAIDE.
content:
ADELAIDE.
FRIDAY. 4 P.M.
Mr. Anderson,'of the firm of Mathews and Ander-
son, solicitors, died yesterday from breaking a blood-
vessel.
The report of the manager of the Destitute Asylum;
shows a large increase in the number of inmates, and .
an increase in general destitution.
The Parramatta mine dividend is*5s. per share.
The return of the import and export of live stock
shows an excess of imports.
Wheat is nominally Gs. 6d. to 7s. ¡ flour, £18 to
£19, with a depressed market.
ARRIVED.-Murray, from London ; Bravo, from
Newcastle.

title: COMMERCIAL.
content:
COMMERCIAL.
London, December G. ¡ j
Colonial securities are firm.
1 The movements in connection with the bank
reserve of bullion are favourable. i
Wool Market.-There has been a fall of 2d.
per lb. on inferior parcels. Thero waa a brisk
competition yesterday j 43,000 bales havo been
sold. The sales close on the 12th December, and
the next series will commence ou the 12th
February.
Copper.-Present cash quotations, £92 to £03.
Tin.-Transactions in tin aro of an average
character ; Australian, £115.
Wheat.-The corn market is firm and steady ;
foreign arrivals are very large. '

title: THE LADIES' SANITARY COMMITTEE.
content:
THE LAMES'SANITARY COMMITTEE. |
¡..m, - Having read from time to time
their reports as sent in to the Municipal
Council, and particularly tbe last one, I
caunot but express my thorough disapproval
of them. They have been, lo say the least
of it, thoroughly misleading," to use a very
mild expression. That they have done a lot
of mischief in this way by keeping any
number of visitors from 'coining to our
shores cannot be denied for* a moment.
Their reports were mainly supported by
hearsay information. I was very p'ojsed
thit they got from the Mayor, on their last
interview, such a dressing down. He showed
them that they spoke without book, and
virtually all tbeir complaints were moon
snlue. Thoy were completely (to uso a
familiar expression) knocked iuto a " cocked
h-t."
I should think a thorough collapse will
now follow ; and that tbo public will hear
no more of their sensational and misleading
reports. A consummation devoutly to be
wished. I think I could direot their ener-
gies into a n.ore useful and betittiog channel,
viz., to go and visit the poor of our city
(many of whom no doubt would be found
to be parishioners of St. David's), and ruined
by the collapse of the Van Diemen's Land
Bank. Find such out and give them suoh
relief us tbeir respective cases deserve, not
only from their own pockets but from con-
tributions they could obtaiu if properly set
about from the uhaiitably-disposed of our
city, many such I am fully convinced being
among us. Acting upon these principles
tbey would theu be really doing some good,
and for which they svottld deserve the praise
of every charitably disposed person in the
community. Hoping then that the above
coinmlttco will now Hi*baud and resolve
themselves into a philanthropic one upon
I the liucB herein indicated.
-Yours, etc,
JAMES THOS. ROBERTSON.
Franklin-chambers, February 15.

title: ALBURY RACES.
content:
ALBURY RACES.
[By Telegraph.]*
(PROM OUR OWX CORRESroXnEN..)
ALBURY, Thursdat.
Tho attendance of visitors to-day was not so good as
yesterday. The weather was much hotter, and the wholo
affair less pleasant. Several disputes/occurred. The follow-
ing are the results :
Mares Produce Stakes.-Albert 1, Tams 2. Only
three started.
Corinthian' Cur.-Paton's bay filly Mavis 1. The
weights for this race being fixed too low to start amateur
riders, all entries but two wero scratched. The contest,
therefore, becamo a match which was won easily by Mavis.
Hurdle Race.-Prinoo Alfred came in first, but, in
consequence of certain circumstances brought under the
notice of tho stewards, the race was declared no race.
Prince Alfred and his owner were disqualified for twelve
months. Mr. Williams, for scratching a horse after weigh-
ing out, was fined £25.
Ture Club Handicap. - Albyn 1, Robinhood 2.
Only three started, and Albyn won easily in 2 minutes 45
seconds. Tho owner of Robin Hood entered a protest on
the ground that Albyn did not carry the full penalty for the
Cup, but the protest was dismissed.
Ladies' Mile.-Bonny Rose 1, Mavis 2, Eclipse 3.
Nine started. This was the best mee of the day. Time :
1 minute 48 seconds.
Consultation Stakes.-Kintmoa 1, Feathertop 2,
Hetmán Plutolï 3.

title: LEGISLATIVE ASSEMBLY.
content:
LEGISLATIVE ASSEMBLY. i
THURSDAY.
THE SrEAKEa took tho chair at twenty-oight minutes
putt 3 o'clock.
CORONER AT WAGGA WAGGA.
, Mr. BUCHANAN asked the Colonial Socretary,
" 1. Did the Coroner of Wagga Wagga write the Colonial
Secretary a letter in dofenco of his conduct in reference to
ihc inquest on the death of Mrs. Rush ? 2. In that letter,
<.r in any communication from the Coroner of Wagga
Wnggo, did ho state that the sistcrB and brother-in-law of
Rush informed him that Rush hnd been addicted to drink-
ing for mnny yenrs past up to the present time ? 3. Is tho
Colonial Secretary aware that the two sisters of Rush, also
his brother-in-law, havo made affidavits, which affidavits
have appeared in the public papers, to tho effect that thoy
never communicated to tho Coroner of Wagga Wagga any
such information OB the Coroner asserts they did, in his
letter to tho Colonial Secretary; and that thoy also,
in theeo affidavits, allege that Rush is now, nnd
nlvvnys han been, a temperate and sober man ? 4. Is tho
Colonial Secretary aware that Rush himself, aB well as
his sisters and brother-in-law, in tho affidavits referred to,
nllrge that, in consequence of tho cruelty and neglect of
duty on the part of the Coronor of Waorga Wagga, in oom
iptjKing Rush to bring the dead body of his wife a distance
of over thirty miles, BO that an inquest might be hold, in-
stead of himself going to whero tho woman died, and there
¡holding tho inquest, so pained and distressed Rush, tho
¡husband, that his mind gavo wny under it, and ho remained
¡for nome timo in a state of temporary insanity ? fi. Has
'the Colonial Secretary removed the Coroner of Wagga
j Wogga from his position, or ia it his intention to do so,
¡without further delay Í "
Mr. COWPER, in reply, stated that a lotter from tho
'Coioner nt Wagga Wagga had been recoived at his office,
and was rend by him to the Houso some time ago. He
, hardly thought it necessary to repeat the information whioh
, was eoniained in that letter. Yesterday certain affidavits
. wero received nt his office, but he had not yet had time to
, read thom. They would bo laid on the tablo on Tuesday
next. In the moantimo no docision had been arrived at by
' tLe Government.
ROAD l'ROM GOULBURN TO BRAIDWOOD.
Mr. GARRETT, for Mr. Butler, asked the Secretary for
Lauds,-"When will tho Government proclaim the road
iioui Goulburn to Braidwood, and tho deviation therefrom
frctn Taralga to Queanbeyan?"
Mr. COWPER enid tho road from Goulburn to Braid
w ood hnd boen proclaimed, and would bbortly bo proceeded
with. Tho deviation fiom Turnlga had been proclaimed,
but time would bnve to bo allowed for claims for compou
sntiou to be bent in.
MESSAGE.
Mr. SPEAKER announced the receipt of a Message
firm his Excellency the Governor, rerouiniendiug for tho
u usiderntion of the House further additional Estimates for
tho j car 1S70.
It was ordered thnt tho MesBngo nnd accompanying Esti-
mules should be printed, and taken into consideration in
Committee of Supply.
WATER SUPPLY.
Mr. WILSON moved, without notice,-"That the seleot
committee <.n tho question of the water supply to Sydney
and the tuburbs havo leave to make visits of inspection."
Tho motion was agreed to.
PETITION.
Mr. DODDS presented a petition from Mr. John Fullor
Forster, contractor, for carrying the mails from East Mait-
land to Mount St. Vincent. Tho petitioner set forth that,
in conrequence of the sudden alteration of the timo-tablo
by the Postmaster. General, ho had_ been compolled to
employ an additional man and an additional horse, nnd ho
prnj ed tho Houeo to tako his case into consideration.
MRS. MARIA CHARLOTTE PLUNKETT.
Mr. PARKES moved, as a formol motion,-" That this
Hcuso will, on Friday ne-xt, resolve itself into n Committeo
of the Whole, to consider of an address to the Governor,
praying (hat hiB Excellency will be pleased to cauBO to be
placed on tho Supplementary EatimatCB for 1870 the sum
of £200, as a pension for Maria Charlotte Plunkett, in
consideration ti ibo valuable public services of nor late
huBband, the Hon. John Hubert Plunkett."
The Houso divide i with the following result :

i 1 be postponed estimate of £1,248 000, undor tho hoad of

inilwnjsfroro Murrurundi towarda Tamworth, Bathurst to

Mr bAMUEL thought that, after tto discussion whioh

him to detain tho committeo with ai y remarks beyond
saying that the Government, boforo undertaking thoso

Mr WILSON wished to know why tho Government

sion thoy had been guided by the advicoof thoso sciontulc
' (lieera whom tho Government wiro bound to consult m
such a case
Mr SUTHERLAND eaid the estimate Aad baon nub
muted in accordance with tho roport of the officers
Sir JAMES MARTIN enid ho could not imagino for a
moment thnt the Government had tho loast oxpeclntion of
carrving this vote It so happouod thnt on tho previous
evining tho Houso was not afiordod an opportunity of ex-
pressing its opinion on tho proposal originally submitted to
it, Tho roport of tho committeo waB brought up, and a
motion was made that tho recommendations contninod in
thnt rinorl Bhould bo ndopted. J ho Houso had not pro-
nounced its opinion on the matter. Ho gathered from
what wns taid in tho courso of tho dobato by mimbors of
the Government, thal tbey at this moment woro not in a
l>osition to snj whit hmd of n rnilnav it w s most expe-
dient to construct, provided further extonaions wera uutlio
nsed Hon numbera wero not in u position to do'ernnno
that question at the present moment, and ho undor-mmd
from members of the Goicrnment that they wore equallj
unable to determine a ma ter of that kind His lion mond
at iho head of the Government read nn interesting ixtnct
iiom n recent numbir of tho Itmes m which it
wns stated that the Russian Government, who v^oro
liut to construct lines of rnihvnj fir moro extensivo
than we wero ever likely to requir , wera ut this moment
mi 1 inc. inquiries in Liigland for Diu purposo of uscrtam
ínL. wbnt lind of railwaj was most suitable for the
leqiiitenients not only of tho Russian Empira, but
¡.(rernllj It waa nlso Btitod in tho ÎIIIIÎJ that somo
ixj itmicnte were to tul.o placo Tho nowsprpTS r intainmg
nn uctount of tboso experimente would not inch bvdncj
for some limo, but thtre could bo no doubt fiom their
(Xtcnt, nnd from the number and ability of tho
kiiitlcmcn who wero eugnged in conducting tho exami-
nation, that tho result would bj of n most
inn resting and vnlunble chnrnetor Ho tboreforo
contended that befoio tho Government proccodod with
further railwnj extension, this mformntton bhould bo
obtained und considered, for if, ns the extract would
lead IIB to believe, tho country hadmado a miBtako in oon
s/ructing lines of railwaj» with n broud gaugo, with heavy
locomotives and trucks, when nil the ndvintigcs of railwvy
communication could bo secured bj narrow lines with light
echini B and other miling stock, it waa timo tho Government
paused lo deliberately consider tho question. Tho fact was
before them that tho Russiun Government somo joara ago
cunmcnccd a railway from TeBtiniog to Portmadoo, a
distanco of \¿\ miles, at a cost of something like £2000 por
mile This lino, ho obsorvod, had originally been com-
ún need at great cost, but upon the recoinmeudation of nn
English engineer-Mr. Fairlie-tho Russian Goiernment
stoiped the works morder to mnkcinquiries into tho ex-
penditure necessary for tho construction of nnrrow gaugo
railwnjB. Iho result was that the roBt of ihn line was not
onlv constructed with a nnrrow gnuge, but twolvo miles
which bad nlrondy been laid down wis taken up The
Russian Government also sent BODIO of its most ominent
engineers to inquire into tho matter, who j unod with
D nmiirk, Trance, Germany, and England in experiments
to test the value of the narrow guage sjstom If wo
could construct railways at a cost of £2000 per milo with
ly.Lt engines, carriages, and trucks, the country would bo
much moro inclined to sanotion nn expenditure to carry su"h
a svsttm into tho interior than to sanction a further expen-
diture of £10,000 or £15,000 per mile to go »n with the
prisent extensions If tho result of tho experiments which
had been rondo in Europo was before the Government
thi j would boin a much botter position to say what system
thej intended to ndopt, nnd thoj would bo acting wisely in
withdrawing the cstimnto until such information had
rinched them, He hoped, therefore, that tho Government
Honld net upon such advice, and not ask tho Houso to givo
a decision upon the voto, for ho did not wish tho Houeo to
tolo any step which would reflect upon their policy. Tho
lino of roilwny to whioh he hnd referred was 1 i', miles ia
length, nnd had been in operation for ooiuo years, and had
cost no moro than £5000 por milo including the oxpendi
turo on a tunnel which extended to n distance of 700
ynrdp, a work much moro cxponsivo than the tunnols on
the Bnthui st line
(An hon member " What is tho state of labour in the
country r ')
Sir JAMES MARTIN said that labour was cheapor
than it wns here, but the cost of land made up for that,
whilo in the colony land WOB much cheaper It was proved
that the cost of tho wenr and tear of our linos aroso froa
tbo enormous weight of the rolling stock. Wo took an
ongino weighing 35 tonB with a vory heavy rolling stock,
while in eomo instances the trafilo was confined to a fow
flooring boards or a few louds of hay, amounting to one or
two tone Iho materials which wero convojed woro, thero

title: CENTRAL POLICE COURT.
content:
CENTRAL POLICE COURT.
FRIDAY.
BEFORE the Mayor, with Messrs. Pinhey, Jolly, Levey,
and Senior.
Seven persons were fined for drunkenness.
Kate Summerfield, charged with having made use of
obscene language, was sentenced to pay a penalty of 40s.,
or to be imprisoned one month; and Ross Stanbury, in
respect of a like offence, was sentenced to pay 20s., or to be
imprisoned seven days.
Sydney Lakin, 15, and Henry Lakin, 18, were brought
before the Court by constable Ryan, charged with riotous
behaviour on the Botany Road. It appeared that about
9 o'clock last night he found a great concourse of young
and old people in the vicinity of a house at which wedding
festivities were in progress, and, among other noises made,
these defendants were doing the " tin-kettling " arrange-
ment with kerosene cans; he took them into custody. The
Bench sentenced them to pay 40s. each, or to be imprisoned
seven days.
Ann Caffpry v>as cbaiged by Henry Baylis witUJ, having
put him m fear by threatening that sh,o yvould --O/hiVlife,
and yias ordered to enter into «. reoogni-ncp (yy|th two
sureties in d310 each to keep tho peni o six. months; or, m
default of sureties, to be impiisoned si«c months i ( . « £
Solomon Lev«,, charged w ith having stolon ten pigeons,
of,, tho vuluo oi 10b ; the property of Charles H Key.,
pleaded guilty, nnd v,as sentenced tobo imprisoned three
fnionthsi , < v - i
Before Messrs Oatloy; G- HiU,iPahng, and Popo.uf

Simpson mob find 10«. for keqnpc opén'his pubtié-îiouso

found in the act of convejing liquor fiom Simpson's houso

'eny yvcro each fined ßs for using obsceno language
AViUinm Chappell, John ï inlay* Daniel liennedjs,i nnd
Timothy Bromley wore sovprnlly fined 10s. under tho
Drunkards' Punishment 'Act Daniel Creasy yyas fined
40s for driving cattle during-prohibited hours *'

title: COURT OF QUARTER SESSIONS.—MONDAY.
content:
COURT OF QUARTER SESSIONS.-Monday.
j (Before his Honor Judge Dowling.)
Mr. A. P. Backhouse prosecuted for the Crown.
JUllYMKN PINED.
The following jurymen wero fined 40s. each for non
attendance ¡-Peter Charles Carravan, St. Leonards ; Edwin
Gcorgo Barker, Camperdown ; Benjamin Dyer, Jamieson
etrect, Sydney ; J. G. O'Connor, Marrickviuo ; and Walter
Akhurst, Balmain.
OUILTY.
The following prisoners pleaded guilty and were re-
manded for sentence :-Ami Boon, illegally pawning, two
counte ; John Caiman, obtaining money by false pretences,
two counts ; William Edward JJangerfield, stealing jewel-
lery.
STEALING FROM TUB PERSON.
William Gould was charged with attempting to steal
from the person1 of Ellen Sparkes on tho 9th of Novembor.
Tho evidenco was that on tho day in question the proseoutrix,
who was waiting in Georgo-streot for an omnibus, was
bumped against hy the prisoner, who tumpBred with her
pocket, aud that when arrested the latter confessed that he
had'stolen .> handkerchief. The jury, without retiring, re
tamed a verdict of guilty, and the prisoner was sentenced to
12-months' imprisonment, with hard labour.
ASSAULT AND ROBBERY.
W, Gardiner .waa chqrsed wit_h.aasaul(_n__Clara yoraon
Harcourt on the 4th instant, and stealing from her her
purso, which, with its contents, was wotth 14s. 6d. Tho
pi osocutrix was walking in Bathnrst-Btreat on the day in
questiou, when tho prisoner cnnio behind her and struck her
on tho urra, after whieli ho snatched her purso from her
hund and mu away. Mifs Harcourt gave information to
the police ; constable Barker, who had seen tho prisoner
hanging lound tho neighbourhood, arrested him on sus-
picion ; and tho lady identified him as her assailant. Tho
jury, after a briof retirement, found Gardiner guilty, and
ho was sentenced to 12 months' imprisonment.
LAUCENY.
1'atrick O'Donncll was charged with stealing a coat and
a pair of trousers, thu property of William Richardson, on
tho loth September. The evidence was thatMr. Richardson
left the articles in his room on tho day in question, and that
in the evening ho niicsed thom. Next day a man, who was
identified as the prisoner, pawned both articles with Mr.
Woolf. Ho was arrested by detective Tindall. The jury
found him cuilty, and ho was sentenced to 12 months'
imprisonment.
ASSAULT WITH ATTEMPT.
Michael Kennedy wns charged with assaulting William
Way on the 30th Novembei, and attempting to rob him.
Tho evidence was, that on the day in question, early in the
morning, tho prosecutcr was invited by tho prisoner to havo
a drink. Ho complied, although the prisoner was a stranger
to him ; and, after a time, they went outside, and Kennedy
knocked him down, and tried to get his watch and
chain. Ho called for help, and constable M'Dermot
ran up and arrested tho prisoner. The latter said " You'vo
just como two or threo minutes' too soon," and tried to escape
soon afterwards. Tho prisoner pleaded not guilty. The
jury, after a briof retirement, returned a verdict of " Not
guilty," and ho was discharged.
LARCENY.
John Wrightani WilliamGra/iainvrerechM-poà with steal-
ing £15, tho property of Alfred Ring, on the 10th November.
Tho evidence showed that this was a case of tho venerable
" matchbox trick " and " three-card trick." The pro-
secutor, a 6imple-lookiag young German, fell in with the
prisoners, and after each had shouted several times, Wright
aud Graham produced a matchbox, and, betting him that
he could uot open it, won £10 from him ; after which they
won £5 troin him over tho " three-card trick." Discovering
that ho had been swindled, ho gave information to the
police. Constable Carroll arrested Wright next day, and
detective Williams seemed Graham, about a week oftor
wardsj in York-street. The defence was that Ring had
lent Ino prisoner Graham some of the money, and that
Wright had fairly won tha rest. Tho jury returned a ver-
dict of guilty against each prisoner, and both weio re
manCed for sentence until half-past 9 a.m. next day.
The following is the list of cases for trial to-day (Tues-
day) :-Thomas O'Brien, burglary and larcony ; John
Leigh Oakes, false pretences ; Robert Montgomery, assault
with, intent to commit rape ; Kate Ryan, larceny as a
servant ; David Burgess, feloniously wounding ; James
Howard and another, breaking and entering ; Thomas
Carroll, ntterapt to stab ; Charles Harkness, larceny and
false pretences ; Homy Brown, stealing in a dwelling.

title: LAW. CENTRAL CRIMINAL COURT.
content:
LAW.
CENTRAL CRIMINAL COURI'.
BEFORE his Honor Mr Justice Wise, and a general jury
PERJURY
Mniy Workman Dickson (on bail) nppoared to auswoi an
information which charged her w iib having, on tho 10th

tho hearing of an information against William Gibb, for

horses in question wore Kildare, Rockingham, and the maro
Zenobia lhere were five sovoral assignments of perjury
in tho indictment refornng to tho following assortions -
1 " Thcso horses belonged to my mother" 2 "Zouobi»
novei belonged to mo ' 3 "I novor in conversation with
nnv one said that thcso horses were my property ' 4 "I
never told Mr Mullen that these horsos wore my proporty "
0 "1 never gave tho liamos of tho horses Zenobia, Rock-
ingham, and Kildare in tho list I gavo to Mr Yeomans to
ho entered m tho bill of Bale "
Defendant pleaded not guilty.
Mr Butlor, with whom was Mr YVindoyor, prosecuted
foi the Crown Mr Isaacs (lnsttuctod by Mi R B
Smith) was counsel for thodofonco
Mr BVTLI ii,having stated tho ca»o for tho Crown, called
the follow mgwitnosses -
William Meares, Clerk of Petty Sessions, Central Pohco
Office, doposcd that tho information produced (in whioh tho

James Ormiston, deposition clerk in tho Central Pohco
Oflico, remcmboiod a man named Gibb being chargeel on
that information before Mr R S Ross, J P , Miss Dick-
son was examined as a witness, I saw her sworn, and
saw bei sign tho deposition, I have no doubt sho waa

Bv Mi Isaacs I did not see Gibb bonne that day Tho

By Mi Butler It was the book all witncsscs are svvotu
on-i ho New and Old lcatamcnt
Bv -Mr Isaacs I did not look at it It had " Polico
Office stamped on tho outside, and I did not look at tho
inside-I took it for granted it was tho Biblo
The deposition was then put in as cvidoncc
Rowland Qeorgo Y'oomans, auctioneer. Maitland do
Íiofcd In January, 1864, I saw Miss Dickson at Mait
iind, and lent hci some money , she had requested mo on
several occasions to advance her monoy on her horses, which
, she I lion had m Maitland, I think there worofivo, tho horses
1 paw were Zenobia, Kildare, lind Rockingham,, I did not
sec Stratford and Snrsfiold then , I refused sovonil times to
ndvauco monoy lo hoi, but having at lost consented 1

viously drawn a bill of sale on the horsos , the document
pioduccd is that signed in my presence
By Mr Isaacs 1 ho names of tho horses had been filled
in when MIES Dickson signed the document, Mr Mullen,
MIKS Dickson, and my seit were present, Miss Dickson at
tho tuno said sho was in haste te got back to Sydnoy, and
we met bv appointment ut Mr Mullen's office, between 1
and 2 o clock of the day on which it was oxocutod
I had a portion of the monoy on mo and drew a chequo for
the balance , I w ent out of the oflico to tho bank boforo thobill
was executed, but it was not signed by Miss Dickson whilst
I was away at this timo I believed tho horses were at
Grancv s, Hunter R v cr Hotel, East Maitland , and I
believe she afterwards took them to Sydnoy, on tho third
psgo of the bill of salo thoro is a receipt, the signature to
thal and to tho bill wore signed at tho samo timo in tho pre-
sence of Mr Mullon and rnysolf, I boheve Mr Mullen
rend over tho document to Miss Dickson before sho signed
it
Bv Mr Bu 1er She mentioned fo mo the horsos , thoy
woio thoso then at Maitland , she luid the nnmeson a slip of
paper I know Rockingham, Zenobia, and Kildare, and
saw thrm at Maitland moro than once when negotiating
with her, sho was racing thom there, the money
was lepavablo m four months, when tho bill
of snlo fell due, she brought the (ho horses
to Maitland (Rookiugham, Zenobia, Kildare, Sara
field, and Stratford) to deliver over to me, she told mo
she was not ablo to meet tho bill of salo, and had brojght
the horses up to dohverover, and to roihse upon them,
how over, sho begged of mo not to sell them then, as races
wero coming off in Queensland, and if I would allow hw tj
take them there and make hor another adv ance, she thought
they would havoagood chance of winning, and probabh
put hci in a position to pay the amount of tho bill, I at
first refused, hut ovontnailj consented , tho further advtuico
made the sum up to £300, tho balanco wa3 £40 odd she
ÇTv c Mr Mullen and my solf a promissory note, dated ¿6th
Mm, ns an acknowledgment foi tho £300, the
promissorv noto producod is tho one she signed
it wns given as a collateral security to the bill
of salo, tlirco of tho horses were Rockingham,
Kildare, and Zenobia, that promissoi y no1 o has not been pud,
there was onlv one bill of sale between us thelettoi pro-
duced (nc'uug that tho dobt should remain a fow months
longei^-dated tho 9th May) is in Miss Dickson s hand
?writing and bears her signature
Bv his noNoit lhere was n promissoi) note given as i
mattet of accommodation botwecn Mr Mullen and unsolf
Bv Mi Bullei I received this letter before miking tho
further advance, and when she got tho advance she took the

fie ni Queensland, about the 19th or 20th Septembor, 1804 , sho
a ked mc if the horses wore brought up norn Sydney, and
?wlelbci 1 waa going to sell them, as I bad possession of
tht m it this timo, 1 got thom fruin \\ tUon, who brought
tin m from Queensland and they wero iu my rented stables
I E iu G lbb on t but occasion he and \\ fison handed ov cr the
lioisrstomc, thev wore tho three horses Kildare, Zenobia,
mid Ivockinglmni I told her 1 should »eil them next dav
nt noon unless sho lound the money to releiso them sho
siid she would endcov oui to get tho money by 10 o clock
next morning but failed and when the timo of salo c uno
sho askea me as a fin our lo put up tho horses in ono lol, as
if separated she would have no chanco of getting them ,
wlitn they weresoldthey woio bought in for me (through
Mi YVndo) at her request, she stutiug that sho would find
the money to pay for them in a week, they wero bought in
at £405, and nt this time there was due to mo nearly
£500, I believe sho soon,after went to Svdnoy, I
received two letters (produced) from Mess Dickson, and
?wrote an answer to the first, Ihiivo received no portion
of tho money up to tho present ümo, whon the bill
of salo wns drawn I askod her if tho horses wero her own
bona fide property , sho said " Thoy are, Mr Y'oomans, so
help mo-" , I asked her if any person hnd a prior claim,
lion, ormortgago over thom, and she said no, sho gavo
the samo answer to Mr Mullen , I saw a slip or memo

sale was oxecutcd, it was given to Mr Mullen for the

and I believe sho gave it to Mr Mullen
By Mr Isaacs Mr Mullen said he had no (uno
to moko search for any prior hen upon tho horse»,
Miss Dickson being in a hurry to got to
Sydnov , it might havo been between 12 and
1, or 1 and 2 o clock, I cannot recollect exactly,
I bolievo the bill of sale was signed on tho 8th January , I
do not recollect Miss Dickson sa ing she was in a hurry to
catch tho steamer at Morpeth , I saw Mr Mullen put his
signature to tho hill of salo ns a witness , Miss Dickson did
not then, that I am aware, sign any other document thau
the bill of sale and receipt, tho note produced (dated 26th
October) is in reference to the accommodation given mo by
Mr Mullen, tho othcrnotonow produced (dated28th August)
is in my handwriting on the day tho bill of salo was
signed I saw Miss Jhckson at Granoy e, East Maitland ,
I had some con\els,ntion with Dr Dickson then, ho
thanked mo for lending the money to his dauehtei , ho had
previously said I could take security over his daughters
horses , ho did not paitieularly montion tho names of any
horses , the simo day, or tho day following tho
execution ol the bill if sole, I saw Zenoni i Rockingham,
and Kildare as thev w oro being taken to Morpeth, thev
?were at Graney s door, the first tm e I saw the horses was
at Maitland races, I think I saw the smill slip of papor
containing tho names of the horses before Miss Dickson
gave it to Mr Mullen I saw the horses at Randwick, but
never asked Miss Diekson to sell thom, I did not ni tho
saddling vnrd olfei £1000 for Zenobia and Kildare, she did
not on that ocuiMon tell me the horses wero not hera, Mrs
Dickson never churned tho horses until two or throe months
after they were put up to auction and tho first claim I
heard her make was sometime in November, sho did not to
mo claim them on tho night of the sale (Advertisement
handed to witness) Ihe horses were advortised to
be sold on the 22»d September, and this advertisement
might have appeared a day or two before, Mrs Dickson did
sot, the night boforo thoy w ero adv ertised for salo, chum
the horses as her own, the horses were bought in at the
solicitation of Miss Diekson, I havo sworn previously,
that "tho horses woio bought in expressly foi Miss Dick
eon," and I gavo an explanation of that statement, in my
account I charged Miss Dickson a commission for the pur-
chase of the horses I considered I put thom up under tho
bill of sale, and that, therefore, I was entitled to a commis-
sion , I do not ehargo a commission to persons for whom I
do not buy , I did not nttempt to dony that I used thoso
words, 1 might have sworn at tho Insolvent Court that,
along with tho bill of sale, Miss Dickson gavo mo
a promissory note tor £243, which I discounted
at the bank, and which I had to take up,
Miss Dickson having failed to meet it, I did discount a bill
given mo by Mr. Mullen it was pay able at Maitland , I
do not think I ever discounted a bill given mo by Miss Dick-
son for £243 , I do not remember Miss Dickson giving mo

for £243 that Mr Mullon had given I might havo

son was not present then, when tho further advance was

as the horses were coming round the corner of Granoy's

excepting In that way. Miss Dickson never dehvored the
horses to me, sho did toll mo whon the further advance
«as made that aho had brought tho horses for the purpose
of delivering them over to me, when they returned from
_r>-\""A M,« H»i!«r«r«d themj*)"my »«at^M&jaibb,
horecs, and won a little monej ou thom, though altogether

By Mr Butler AVhon ltib horses landod from Queens
land. Miss Dickson owed mo about £500 (Dominent,

By Mr Isaacs Mr Mullen wos my attornoy al luis timo

By hiB HONOR Tins document was drawn after tho

William Honry Mullen, nttorney, AVcst Maitland, do
posed In Januarj, 1864, Miss Dickson called at my

ho could bo secured, she said ho could bo

papci, a bill of salo was préparai, with tho exception of
the schedule, which was put m afterwards, betöre «ho

other incumbranco upon the property, and sho said, " AVhy
waste time and put mo to tho expense of koeping tho horses
hore*' I said aro j ou sure there is not any other mortgago
upon the jropcitj, sho said, "So help mo-thora is
not, I did not know tho names of tho horses but she
gai e me a lu>t in her ow n handwi lung, 1 comn »red each of
the names IH tho schedule with the names in the list, s i>i rig
"right ' with regard to each as 1 found thom agroo, Mr

there is no other claim upon these horses r"' she
mado to lum the same rotnaik she had mado
to me , I ha\o received from the counsel for tho defenco a
Rubpana to produce, and I know tho dooument roftrroa

THE LONDON WOOL SALES.

Tho CiiAntMAN having reud tho advertisement in whioh

Mr T S MORT roso to move tho first resolution Ho

of theso colonies ebould havo Bpecial warnhousos for their

m London and connected with Australian interests '
A subsequent resolution would show the way in which

11 ject of this mooting was moro of an inquiring rathor than
a dcclaiutory character Wo desired to know tho truth
Wo were the people directly interested , wo wore the pooplo
ho grow tho wosl, wo wore tho peoplo who had to pay tho
piper, and tho pee plo whn warn in «very sense justified in
innutrino-into this question He behoved that the charges
!¥"?> ,7 ,tho, warehousemen ln England were very great
in«ÎJS,,°ñi?í tho modeat lB M PC bilo, which was
that could bo adduced than was« _No bottnr Proof of
had been addresBod to tho wool brokorB"iñ îloLnia£,,,,f,IoU
large numbor of mercantile hou»es in this city It was a

and ho (Mr Mort) would read it -
' Believing that tho wool brokors ona importera for
somo timo past havo entertained a dobire to concontrato tho

time caupcd by tho warehouses being spread over so many

[Tho Millwall Dooks Company were, no doubt, iutorestod,
as (hey would get the ships into their dooks, but it

" 1 hcao docks adjoin tho West India Docks and aro now
within twenty seven minutos of the Tenchurch stieot
.Station, wheoco trains start overy quarter of an hour A
ehort branch lino from tho Blackwall Railway is now boing
constructed, which will place tho docks in communication

Great Eastern railways
" Tho amount of warehousing charges paid list yoar by
tho wool trado nmounted to very niarlj £200 000 Of
this turn about forty per cent was onsumod in working
ehnrges, tho balance, upwards of £100,000, boing for
interest on money expended in providing warehouses, and
for pre fit
"Owing to the greater part of tho warehouses boing in-
land, iho working expenses oro increased largely by tho

" 1 his company has nearly a hundred acres of land with

" The directors would also bo willing thattho wool trado,

nn.l receivo it- own charges, and occupy, i" «."Poet to the
Dock Oomponv, tho situplo nosi«'"» oilessees of the land
occupied.
" At present rntes considerably lesB than two yoars'

fHow much did they think one-half would bo ? To thoso

very considerable to his (Mr. Mort's) mind.]
i " The land availablo being ample, the show warehouses
<ould adjoin ong another, and bo on one floor only.

" Adjacent to the warehouses could bo erected brokers'
i ffictH, lavatories, refreshment rooms, and other conve-
niences,
" 1 sholl bo very happy lo wait upnn you at any timo to
(lipoues the question, or to supply further information,"
This circular was signod by Mr. G. R. Birt, the general
manager of tho Millwall Dock Company. Now though ho
(Mr. Mort) granted that this carno from an interested
hourre, trom a dock, company anxious to get vessels into
their docks, and so secure the chargea upon thoso vessels, it
waa not the less pertinent as regarded our interests. "Wo did
not care BO long as we got tío charges upon our wool
reduced. A gentleman, largely connected with the wool
trade in this colony, had handed him a statement of the
consolidated charges upon wool at tho warehouses. The
rent for threo months upon an ordinary bale was 5s., and
the prices increased as tho weight inoreased up to 8s. per
bale. Then thero were extra charges for damages, and' so
forth, but this was about the average thing. At the prices
quoted hero ho was satisfied that not only were we at a dis-
advantage in tho exhibition of our wools, which was an im-
portant point, for the distances at whioh tho ware-
houses were, and the woy in which tho wool was
i-rammed into inconveniont places, injured our sales,
but we paid through tho nose most enormously. If we
i-ould only adopt a system whereby these colonies could
become their own warehouso-koepors, wo should save our
pocket 8 very largely indeed. He moved with somo little
hesitation in a measure with which ho was not acquainted
. by personal observation, but he might state that the dif-
ferent parlies with whom he had conversed, and who had
teen theto things, had given him positive assurances that
nothing could be worse than the syetom now adopted. He
had enid when ho started that tho object of this mooting was
lather one of inquiry than declaration. Ho did not state
positiv: ely that these evils existed ; but he said that matters
.bould bo inquired into, that tho time had, arrived when
these colonies should BOO whother they would not
lo benefited by having their own separate warehouses.
There was another point of view from which this mattor
was to bo considered. Our wool was coming into contact
witti nil other descriptions of wool. Ho was under tho im-
pression that if you wont into bad company you wore sus-
pected of hi ing bad yourself ; and if our wool wore placed
with Cupe and other low-priced wools, thoir inferiority was
reflected upon our own wool, and tondod to lower its price.
He -WOB quite satisfied a sufiiciout caso was made out if not
for declaration, at least for inquiry. Ho know thero were
gentlemen in England, and in tho colonies too, who dis-
couraged this movement ; that there woro gontlemen hore
who would endeavour to shew that it waa not dosirablo to
liisturb this system, but that tho question should be re-
ferred te the existing committeo in London who regulated
these Eales. Ho did not wish to say a word
ngaihfvt these gentlemen. Ho had no doubt thoy
did the'r duty conscientioUBly ; but we wanted to get
people who wero themselves largely interested in wool-
ton ing, und not merely in wool selling. Ho was largely
interested in woolgrovving himself, and ho thought the
I lai get t possible advontago would result from this meeting,
if it were unanimous in sending homo an expression of ita
withes. Tho resolutions were modoBtly worded, woro not
' offensive in any senso or form, and would elicit an auswor
to the effect either that things should remain as they wore,
or that it was time to look out and make other arrange-
ments. At present thero was a general feeling of discon-
tent among the wholo community, and it was desirablo to
set that feeling at rest, inj'ustico both to the community
of England and ourselves. The resolution did not
attack the present system of sales, although it was
found that the brokers charged muoh. too high.
They wcro said to charge both the huyors and sellers, and
certainly their charge of half per cent, did look very bad
indeed. It was just possiblo that we might be, to uso a
colonial phrase, "barking-up the wrong troo" now, but
whatever came of this meeting could ouly bo for good if
they wei e unanimous in their resolutions. If theso charges
vveio right no alteration would be sought for; ifthi'y wero
wrong wo should have theui altered at once. Ho was
strongly of opinion that our interests ought to ba entrusted
lo the class of persons who hud to pay the piper, and ho
hoped tliis point would be boroo in mind whoa tho raao
lutious were put to tho meoting. Ho was largely interested
in steck in Ibis colony ho WBB corry to Buy, and ho was
1'ioking aft« his interest by attending this meeting; and
he t-liould i n happy if the'little trouble ho had taken in
this matta- should lead to n good result. Ho bogged to
move tho resolution.
Mr. A. Ki-MMEiiER was happy to second (ho resolution,
and could only tay that lost 5 ear wo paid about tenpenco
per bale more thnn wo did before, nlthough the prico of

hea\y. Some of tho warehouses wei¿ convenient. The

Tho buj ore congregated at the London wool sales from all

Mr BINNIE drew attention to the injury which the

Mr S D GORDON suggested that the resolution ought

which Bomo ono took it Thoro was no pauae The
moment a bidder said ho would take tho wool, it was

could not buy it in or prevent its being knocked

These were things that the shippers of wool should con-

ferring to the resolution which had already boen passed,
but it had Btruck him 'h-1 -i.- MJ'°">!1 Dock Company,

Mr. JOHN HAT did not seo that tho agreement of tho
