title: COURT OF QUARTER SESSIONS.—MONDAY.
content:
COURT OF QUARTER SESSIONS.-Monday.
j (Before his Honor Judge Dowling.)
Mr. A. P. Backhouse prosecuted for the Crown.
JUllYMKN PINED.
The following jurymen wero fined 40s. each for non
attendance ¡-Peter Charles Carravan, St. Leonards ; Edwin
Gcorgo Barker, Camperdown ; Benjamin Dyer, Jamieson
etrect, Sydney ; J. G. O'Connor, Marrickviuo ; and Walter
Akhurst, Balmain.
OUILTY.
The following prisoners pleaded guilty and were re-
manded for sentence :-Ami Boon, illegally pawning, two
counte ; John Caiman, obtaining money by false pretences,
two counts ; William Edward JJangerfield, stealing jewel-
lery.
STEALING FROM TUB PERSON.
William Gould was charged with attempting to steal
from the person1 of Ellen Sparkes on tho 9th of Novembor.
Tho evidenco was that on tho day in question the proseoutrix,
who was waiting in Georgo-streot for an omnibus, was
bumped against hy the prisoner, who tumpBred with her
pocket, aud that when arrested the latter confessed that he
had'stolen .> handkerchief. The jury, without retiring, re
tamed a verdict of guilty, and the prisoner was sentenced to
12-months' imprisonment, with hard labour.
ASSAULT AND ROBBERY.
W, Gardiner .waa chqrsed wit_h.aasaul(_n__Clara yoraon
Harcourt on the 4th instant, and stealing from her her
purso, which, with its contents, was wotth 14s. 6d. Tho
pi osocutrix was walking in Bathnrst-Btreat on the day in
questiou, when tho prisoner cnnio behind her and struck her
on tho urra, after whieli ho snatched her purso from her
hund and mu away. Mifs Harcourt gave information to
the police ; constable Barker, who had seen tho prisoner
hanging lound tho neighbourhood, arrested him on sus-
picion ; and tho lady identified him as her assailant. Tho
jury, after a briof retirement, found Gardiner guilty, and
ho was sentenced to 12 months' imprisonment.
LAUCENY.
1'atrick O'Donncll was charged with stealing a coat and
a pair of trousers, thu property of William Richardson, on
tho loth September. The evidence was thatMr. Richardson
left the articles in his room on tho day in question, and that
in the evening ho niicsed thom. Next day a man, who was
identified as the prisoner, pawned both articles with Mr.
Woolf. Ho was arrested by detective Tindall. The jury
found him cuilty, and ho was sentenced to 12 months'
imprisonment.
ASSAULT WITH ATTEMPT.
Michael Kennedy wns charged with assaulting William
Way on the 30th Novembei, and attempting to rob him.
Tho evidence was, that on the day in question, early in the
morning, tho prosecutcr was invited by tho prisoner to havo
a drink. Ho complied, although the prisoner was a stranger
to him ; and, after a time, they went outside, and Kennedy
knocked him down, and tried to get his watch and
chain. Ho called for help, and constable M'Dermot
ran up and arrested tho prisoner. The latter said " You'vo
just como two or threo minutes' too soon," and tried to escape
soon afterwards. Tho prisoner pleaded not guilty. The
jury, after a briof retirement, returned a verdict of " Not
guilty," and ho was discharged.
LARCENY.
John Wrightani WilliamGra/iainvrerechM-poà with steal-
ing £15, tho property of Alfred Ring, on the 10th November.
Tho evidence showed that this was a case of tho venerable
" matchbox trick " and " three-card trick." The pro-
secutor, a 6imple-lookiag young German, fell in with the
prisoners, and after each had shouted several times, Wright
aud Graham produced a matchbox, and, betting him that
he could uot open it, won £10 from him ; after which they
won £5 troin him over tho " three-card trick." Discovering
that ho had been swindled, ho gave information to the
police. Constable Carroll arrested Wright next day, and
detective Williams seemed Graham, about a week oftor
wardsj in York-street. The defence was that Ring had
lent Ino prisoner Graham some of the money, and that
Wright had fairly won tha rest. Tho jury returned a ver-
dict of guilty against each prisoner, and both weio re
manCed for sentence until half-past 9 a.m. next day.
The following is the list of cases for trial to-day (Tues-
day) :-Thomas O'Brien, burglary and larcony ; John
Leigh Oakes, false pretences ; Robert Montgomery, assault
with, intent to commit rape ; Kate Ryan, larceny as a
servant ; David Burgess, feloniously wounding ; James
Howard and another, breaking and entering ; Thomas
Carroll, ntterapt to stab ; Charles Harkness, larceny and
false pretences ; Homy Brown, stealing in a dwelling.

title: ADELAIDE.
content:
ADELAIDE.
FRIDAY. 4 P.M.
Mr. Anderson,'of the firm of Mathews and Ander-
son, solicitors, died yesterday from breaking a blood-
vessel.
The report of the manager of the Destitute Asylum;
shows a large increase in the number of inmates, and .
an increase in general destitution.
The Parramatta mine dividend is*5s. per share.
The return of the import and export of live stock
shows an excess of imports.
Wheat is nominally Gs. 6d. to 7s. ¡ flour, £18 to
£19, with a depressed market.
ARRIVED.-Murray, from London ; Bravo, from
Newcastle.

title: FIRE AT THE REDFERN TERMINUS.
content:
FIRE Aï THE REDFERN" TERMINUS.
Inquest.
Ai» inquest was held yesterduj morning, before Mr Shioll,
City Coroner, at lho Railway Hot 1, Creergo street South,
relative to tho origin of a bro which occurred in a black-
smith's shop at the Redfern railway station, on Saturday,
tho lGth instant lho inquiry on tho ino was set on
foot in consequence of ita boitig suspected that it hid boon
tho vi otk of un incendiar)
The jurj, having been sworn, v lowed tho premisos, and
relumed to the hotel, where tho following ovidenco was
taken -
Charles Spring, engine-driver m tho employ of tho
Railway Department, eaid, that or the afternoon of tho
Saturday tho tiro occurred ho waB thoro omployed , shortly
after 6 o clock in the afternoon ho hud occasion to pass the
doctfttlhe vicBtern end of the blacksmith s shop , ho thon
saw flarncs proceeding from the north-east cornerof the shop,
witnets was awuro that there vins a cupboard in tho corner,
from which tho fire appeared to proceed , ltBtiuck him that
the liro carne from tho cupboard , ho at onco went und in-
formed the locomotive foreman, William Scott, of what ho
hud seen , ho then roturned with some men tt> tho sceno of
thofuo, when he got back he lound that the liro had
reached the rafters at the north eastern end of the shop ,
witness uBtisled to extinguish the bro , at the north eastern
corner tho îoof vins partially burnt, witnoao had not been
cngeged m the shop that da) nor had ho oocaaion to go to
the cupboard, tho building vi as erected out of old wooden
cnscB, and it was covered with an iroa roof, the beards
fomnng tho sides of tho building were not close together,
and there weie interstices loft
William Scott stated that ho was locomotive fore-
man at tho Redfern terminus , on Saturday morning
ho was engaged in his ofhco , tho black
sn ith s ehop tumo under his control as the loco-
motivo foreman, the men engaged at work m the black
Bniths shop left olf work on tho afternoon of tho lGth
instant, at half past 1 o clock, and no work waB done in it
on that day after the hour montioneJ, witness was in the
shop about 1 o'clock in the afterno in, about o o clock m the
ofternoen, while engaged in his office, the hat witness carne
and told him that the end of tho shop waa on Uro , accom-
panied by ¡several men, he proceeded there, and found that
the north-eastern corner was alight, the fire apparently pro-
ceeding from a cupboard in that pait of tho building, and
the flames running up the riftcia, with tho assistance of
the other men who w ero with him, ho soon succeeded m
extinguishing the contlagration, lho fno not having taken a
great hold of tho building , in spite of this a certain amount
of injury Lad been efkctcel, tho comer cupboard appeared
vei) much burnt, as wero ilao the corner pillara
and tho rufters, after tho mea hud knocked
of! work m the early part of tho duy, ho saw
nomoicof them that da), ob far as ho vv as aw ai e, thero
had been no quarrel or dispute among tho men, toola were
kept in the cupboard, and perhups a small ejuantit) of cot-
ton waste, thero vvae no oil kept in it so far as ho knew ,
thero might havo been a little potash and some borax kept
in the cupboard, but nothing that would bo likely to induce
Bpontancoua combustion , a tank of oil vv ib kept under tho
cupbonid, during the alternoon an ongmo had occasion to
pa s tho north-east corner of tho building, which travelled
on a rail distant about 42 feet from it, ho had occasionally
noticed sparks coming from an engine when travelling, and
also thntthoy remained alight for some time after the) had
fallen, ho had Been sparks travel 12 feet after coming
from tho funnel of a locomotive, ho did not suspect anyone
of hav mg sot fire to the blacksmith s shop
By the jury lhere victo no dosrs to tho blacksmiths
shop , the sietes of the cupboard at the noi th east corner of
tho shop wero open , the box was detached from the
builâinp
James Tisdnle, a blacksmith in the employ of the Rail
vn) Department, stated that ho was emplo)od at tho Red-
fern station on baturdoy, tho 14th instant, thero wero about
ten other men engaged in the shop besides witness , they
all left off work tit hilf past 1 o clock they then loft the
premiss nnd did not return that day, witness did not
retain, and therefore; did not know an)thing about
the hie , tho lire in tho forgo was put out before ho
lett, thero was a fire in the littlo forge at the other end ,
he VMiB the foreman of three forges , ho had nothing to do
w ith the oie in the middle of tho shop, vvhero the fire took
pi ico , it was in tho chargo of the man who worked at it,
vvhoEe name was Hill, Hill's was alight vv hen thoy lof t
off woik , thoro was a cupboard in the north cast corner
of the shop, it was nindoof an old eise, they kept tools
m it and somo potash and borax, and some waste in the
top part of it, the waste was not saturated with oil, the
cupboard was for tho use of his forge , thoy (the men)
all left the shop together at half-paet 1 o clock, ho did not
see any smoking m tho Ehop bo far as ho saw , smoking
vv is i lohibittd , a man named Paul put away tho toola in
the cuj boe rd on Saturda) afternoon , thero had boon no
row amongst the men , he did not hear any ono threaten
to set bro to the shop , ho had no reason to suspect that
ntiy ono would do so , there wero no matches kept m tho
cupbourd , thero waa no oil kept thoro , he had boon
employed there for fifteen years , there was a tank of eil
under the cupboard
By the jur) Tho hammer-men wero oxoected to see
that the fires were put out, the fire ia the nnddlo forgo
was ntceEBonl) left, it waa a hollow firo for Monday, and
would go out whenever the blast was stopped, thero was
not much waste m tho cupboard, tho bro scorned to have
taken j lace under the waste, ho could not tell whether any
Bj-uibs from the engine could get into tho cupboard,
no hot irons were put into tho cupboard , thoy
wero 1 e pt aw ay from it, thero was a lock to tho c ifo , ho
Eiiw Paul lock it on Saturday, an1 put the ke) in its usual
pHce under the cupboard , witness, White, and Paul know
vvhero the key waa kept, all thoao mentioned loft
the shop together on Satuiday, thero wero no matches
kept m the shop, they lighted their iiros rrom the cDgino,
he did not know who was the last man on tho premiaos,
the) generally all left about half-past 1 o'clock
Philip Paul, ernplo)cd at tho Redfern station, was
ci gage el on Saturday laßt in the blacksmith's shop at the
rulvvn) terminus, ho was emplovcd at tho same forgo
with Tisdnle and W)ke , thero was a cupboard in tho
north-east corner, ho put tho tools away thore about
twent) minutes past 1 o clock, he hckod it when ho left,
ho put the ko) on a ledge below the cupboard , thors was
se me clean watte on tho top shelf, the waste was clean,
and thero vvasno oil on it, thero were no matches in tho
eui board, thiro was oil underneath, he did not again
return, witnefs aid not smoke, ho abstained from it on
pi maple , he had never done so either in tho shop or else-
where, every hing was all right when ho left, he did not
know how tho fire occurred, he did not hear of it till
Sunday at dinner time, he had novei heard anything
among his fellow-workmen to lead him to suspect that
the i-hop would ever be fired, he did not see any ^no in tho
shop in tho forenoon smoking, ho did not know of nnv
cno doing so at any time, witness put away everything
and le eked tho cupboard
By tho j ury Ho saw the cupboard on Monda) morning,
there was then somo waBto on tho sholf, it wis then
blackened, witness behoved that it wis in the cupboaid on
Suturday ?*
Peter Ferguson, employed by tho Railwa) Department as
engine-driver, eaid that hu vi as engaged drawing an cngmo
on baturdny afternoon, be waa shunting «aggons « ah clay
tilla o'clock m lho afternoon, ho was working at the
oaMein end of tho blacksmith s shop , he left work at 4
o tloek m tho afternoon, he did nut see nnyono about the
blacksmith's shop during tho afteinoon , ho did not notice
any sparks coming fioin tho engine, they usually did, he
dm not hear the alarm of firo, it muat havo been given
aftir he had left fho place, which ho did eomowhere ibout
4 o clock, ho was burning wood in hts engino , going up
and down the lino ho might havo seen fires m tho shop, ha
did not notice one, bo did not seo an) smoko proceeding
from the îoof, ho did not notice anything unusual abuut
tho building, witneas wbb not in it duiing the whole of
the Saturda)
JJBv tLo foreman Ho last Baw tho roof of the black-
smith's shop about 4 o'clock in the afternoon
Helensch W)ke was in tho omplo) of Railway Depart-
ment in tho blachHmth'fl shop nt tho railway terminus, ho
waB thero on Saturday, the 10th instant, ho left tho placo
at half-past 1 o'clock and did not return again that day , to
oil appearance everything was right when ho left, ho
could not B8) whether all the fires vitioout when he loft,
his firo was out, theio was a cuuboaid in lho >. E cornor
of tho shop , thero wero tools kept in the shop, thoro was
about a handful of waste m tho cupboard, it waB cloin,
freo from oil, and j Übt from tho store, thero was no greasy
w net o in the cupboard , there was no oil, witness was m
tho habit of smoking , ho did not smoko m tho shop, ho
did not eco any ono smoking in the shop on Satuiday , he '
saw Paul put lho tools in it, ho did not 6eo him put
them all in, when ho vient aw a) on Saturda) uftomoon,
evil) thing appourcd to bo ma proper or 1er, ho did not
I see ot hear on) thing to cause hiai to suspect that tho Bhup
would bo Bet on bro, thero had been no eiuarrtlhng amouç,
the men worthy of menti u , ibero had boon no ono dis-
charged from the premises
I William Scott, recalled When ho went to the shevo first
th" door of lho cuso wag locked.
Hill mt h Wylo, recalled, stated that on his going
to tbo cupbrnrd on Monday, he found a pioco of charred
wood which hod been broken off tho door; tholo:k was
attach«! to it ; it was locked.
Hie jury retired fo crnMiler lheir verdict, and after de-
liberating for some fimo thfy fsand the following vordict:
" That the blncksmHiB' shop nt tbo Redfern railway ter-
minus was dnmnged by firs on Saturday tho 16th iusfnnt ;
but ihntin what mnnner the bro originated thora was no
tvielenco lo shew."

title: MINING.
content:
MINING. I
The Launceston quotation for tin oro
ycstorduy was 12s. Od. per unit,
Wcstoru t-t.M, Co, puys a dividí-nil of Is,
per shara on the Kit li hist. Transfer jnurii.il
will close on the Cth.
Porfoitcd shares In the Tumiiuiiian Silver
Prospecting Cu. will be sold ou Ililli hist.
Lucy Prospecting Association meeting at
Launceston on '22nd ¡nut. to receive reports
and consider future operations.
Negotiations with the ugonl of an English
syndicate in respect of the Now Golduu
Guio Kxtenikd property hive been success-
fully carried through, und work will shortly
be commenced to continue the present shaft
and thoroughly prospect the mine, and should
ii provo as unliciputcd, capital will he forth-
coming for worimi«- and dovclnpiug it. Tho
company retain onc-fouith intercut.
A party of minors left in tho H.A. Yolla
last night to dcvt'lop tim new tin lind at
Whalu'u Head, near Corinna. This piuco
must not lu confounded with the Whnlo's
Head near Reohcrche.
'Hie s.s. Out ¡mu which left hero for
Sydney lust uiuht took 4,791 bags of silver
ore, weighing 2115 tuns.
The r.s. lileuelg, from Strahan, landed
2,700 bags of silver ore yesterday.
Messrs. Benvcr, Starr und Anson, Mel-
bourne director» of the Salisbury, Beacons-
field Hydraulia Sluicing Co., have roturned
from a visit to the property of the company
at Blue Tier. They wore accompanied by
the local directors, Mesa». Wackmnuth and
Siinii.ons. A thorough inspection of the
works and tailrace was made, and eatitfac
tion expressed at their progresa and ¿the
prospects of the company, it is expected
that the company will bo in a position to
commence miniug operations proper in tbe
oourae of six weeks or two months.
An extraordinary meeting of shareholder«
in the Mount Michael Hydraulic Tin-mining
Co, will he held at the Hobart Coffee Palace
to-night «t 7 to consider increase of the com-
pany . capital.
In oon»eqitenoe of the dry weather before
Christmas the water «apply at Roy's Hill,
where a patent Mudie crusher ha« been
fitted up, gave out ; but during the 14 days'
holiday a race ha« been out for a diatance
of 40 chain», tapping another oreek. It is
expeotcd that the frcah supply will be avail-
able to-dsy. A Launceston syndicate pur-
chased one of these muohinei to be placed on
a tia mine near Branxholm. That machine
has luff Launceston, and will be erected iu
the course of a few day«. Much interest is
manifested in tho introduction of these
simple and cheap machines on tho tin and
gold-fields of the co'ooy, as they ure so well
ndaptud for the opeuiug up and äoveloplng
of mines lu their curly stages.

title: MINING.
content:
MINING.
TUESDAY EVENING.1
THERE was almost an absence of buyers ia
the Share market to-day. A few Beyers and
Holtermans at 6s. 6d., and some Daysprings at
3s., were all that met purchasers.
Our Aucidand correspondent, writing on
Tuesday last, quotes latest sales of Tookeys
(first and third) at 7£.
Williams's O. M. Co.-Tho mining manager reports na
follows under dato of 1st instant:-" 200-feot lovel : Thoro
is no chango in any of tho stopea above this lovel. Tho
lodo keeps about tho samo thickness as of late, and shows
coarse gold. 320-fcet level: Tho north main drive Ima
not been extended nny fnrther this week, tho men being
engaged putting in timber and laying tramways. Tho lodo
in tho taco is at present abeut 9 inches thick, mid of
good quality. In tho etopes Noa. 1, 2, 3, and 4 there is
no poieeptiblo chango since, my last report, eitlior ia
quantity or quality. In tho undorhand slopes tho lodo
still keeps well defined and large. A quantity of this will
bo taken down during next week. Tho south main drivo
keeps tho samo as last ropoitcd. Tho south, stopea also
continuo to look well, the averngo thickness of tho lodo
being fully 2i feet, with nico patches of coarse gold ooca- .
sionally seen. Tho main shaft has been deepened 4 foot ;
the lode uveiageB about 22 inches in thickness, and quality
continues to improve. Wo havo raised 107 tons stono
during tho week.
Prowse and Woodward's G.M.Co.-Tho mining manager
sends tho following report for week ending 1st instant :
" Tho main shaft has boon sunk an additional 5 foot during
tho past week, making tho total dopth 8338 feet. In tho
last few feet sinking tho lode has considerably improved in
quality, gold being freely seen in tho stone from'.tho last
bench taken down. This lodo is^at prosont 12 inohw-thick,
well defined, und has every appearance of being a pormanent
lodo."
The Junction G. M. Co.-Tho mining manager reporta
that the quality of tho quartz is greatly improving.
During tho past week 424 tons were crushed, which yielded
148 oz. 5 dwta. amalgam, being at tho rate of 7 dwls. per
ton.
Glen Innes Tin M. Co.-At a special general meeting of
the shareholders, held on Friday, the 31st October, tho
directors' final report and balance-sheet wore adopted.
The balance of cash on hand was resolved to bo applioi to
the payment of a final dividend of 2d. por share on con-
tributory shares, and the residue to the directa?» as a, ro
numenuon *or l^çir services, ,
. ., > '- .i. . > <

title: ST. JOHN'S PRESBYTERIAN CHURCH.
content:
ST. JOHN'S PRESBYTERIAN
' i CHURCH.
' Tho annual meeting in oonucction with St.
John's Presbyterian Church, Maoqiiarlo
stroet, was hold in the chuich school-
room last ovouing. ' Prior to' tho busi-
ness me'otlngv membcis of the congre-
gation ' and friands eal down to an ex-
cellent tea, provided by tho ladies of the
congi ogalion, Thoro , was a vary good
attendance.' ' Tei being concluded the ltov.'
I. K. Mcintyre, minister of Iho church, took
tho chair.' Tho following reports, which were
all of a sitiBiuctoryobaructor, weio road:
Sossion, Board of Mnnageis, Sabbath School,
St, John'B Prcabyleiiau Church Association,
Young Mou'sFellowship Aasocutlon, Young
People's Society of Christian Eudoavour,
St. John's Poor Fund, and the Sewlug Meet-
ing, New Hebrides Mission. The finunoial
pa,rt of the report was also satisfactory, the
bilunoe-slicot shoiving:-General Fund-j
4\ 7d., loavlng a balance in Ininti of £22
7s DJ. Organ Fund-Credit balances trans-
ferred to general account, Gi. 7d. Sabbath
Sahool Aooount-Balance in hand,£3 13s. 0 1.
St. John'd poor fund-balance in baud, £2
JOs. 3Jd. The reports and baluncc-Bheet
were unanimously adopted. Mesara. J.
| Musterton, 'A. B. Buyers, N. Ree«, P. It.
| Henry, and J, Johnson were re elected
I church managers, and Mi, F, Mcpherson
i secretary and treasurer. All these officials
I were present, willi the exeeptlon of Mr.
RecB, who was indisposed. Tho Chairman,
in-speaking on the repotts, congratulated
I the members of tho congrégation on their
satisfactory nature. Tho Rolief Restaurant,
(about which somo people of Hobart hud
boen saying unkind Ihiuge, had relieved
« their poors' fund to a considerable cj.teut,
{some " of thoao whom they wore
relieving having boen directed to tho
restaurant. Still, he feared that bofoio the
prcsont winter was ove] thora would lia
much need in the parish, although ho felt
sure the St. John's people would do their
utmost to aid deserving cases. Their charity
might in soma cases bo abused, still they
could not allow « ives and children to be in
nocd of broad. It was suggested that
members n[ the congregation should
subscribe 3d. or CJ. per vvc.k to
this fund. At intervals duiliig the busi
noss musical items wera rendered, the
following being among the contributors :
Mr. W. T. Bat-s, cornet solo ; Mr. J. N.
Waterworth, musical balla ; Mr. McLean,
song ; Misses Henry, M. Mills, and Willi-
son, songs. Mr. Percy R. Henry played
the accompaniments. A presentation was
mad o to Mr. Henry, the orginist% and to
tho blower. On the motion of the Chair-
man, votos of thanks to the ladies u ho
orgauisod tho tea und decorated tho room,
und tho contributors to tho ovening's outer
tahutiant,, wcro curried by acclumation.
The proceedings olosed willi a hymn and
pruycr und the pronouncing of the benedic-
tion by the Ghaii man. . i i ' ' : '

title: CONTAGIOUS DISEASES: HOOPING-COUGH.
content:
CONTAGIOUS DISEASES: HOOPING
COUGH.
I (Hy "An Old Hushman,"in the Australian AcclimatUtr.) \
IB medical science keeping pace with the times, or has
it become a science of fee» and protected privileges *
With the exception of a few discoveries by master
uund<!, one or two of -which have appeared in isolated
generations, is anything more known to the followers
of the mctliLal oit or medical science than was prat-
tled by the profession hundreds of years ago > If
these ciuesttoiiB arc fairly weighed, the conclusion
nust be arrived at, that the medical profession is
lamentably remote from that perfection to which it
ought long »go tn have attained The fact is, that
the diKiples of yLsculapiua arc pitchforked into the
profesnon through maternal or paternal influence,
quite ns muth OB are the ministers of religion. There
IB no neccsBity in either COMO that the mental qualifi-
cations of tile youth, his tastes or predilections, i
shou'd bt consulted, lhc notion is entertained that
the inspiration of schools and culleges will make a
bright genius out of the most commonplace materials
Hence it is that both professions-yes, and many other
profitions besides-are erowded with shams , the
medical, with those who know nothing except how to
blistir, administer a bolus, and charge a fee , and the
ecclesiastical, with those whose only mission u to
afflict and punish their hearers
Following the example of Stemc-who founl his
sympathy to be bifit called forth by taking one unfor-
tunate victim under consideration at a time-the
truth of the foregoing remarkB will be moBt fully illus-
trated by a reference to one solitary disease which
hue affected childhood from the days of the ancient
Greeks to the present time. The ancient Greeks
called hooping-cough the "wild or untamable
cough," a name which, for anything medical science
hoB done, may be given to it at the prisent hour. It
would be ns vam to ask the profession what hooping
cough ii, as to inquire philosophically " What l8
heat ?" Tho duty of the medical profession ia to euro
the patient, but not to prevent disease arising , hence
it need not be expected that any but a few minds will
ever bo directed to search and find out tho cause of
dicebse, what particular diBenses re illy are, and how
they might be prevented
As a non-profesMontl, I have been led to make
these remai ks from obberung closely some cases
of the above-mentioned disease which have come
under my notice. I shall give the whole particulars,
in the hope that other non-professionals will observe
for themstlveB whatever diseases may happen to come
within their notice. During avery wet day two boys
were returning from school, one at them put on three
pairs of trousers, and the other put on a thinner pair
than usual-each in this acting nccording to hia own
judgment Before reaching a railway station both
got wet, and had to Bit in their wet clothes till nearlv
home. The boy of the three pairs of trousers showed
symptoms of a bad but ordinary cold next day , the
other was none the worse for his ducking. Tho hrst
boy had a hatsh cough for about a week, during
which time mustard applications to the chest wore
used ; his feet were bathed in hot water and mustard
every night prior to his going to bed ; ipecacuanha
and other expectorants were admimstere I The
cough continued, nnd increased in violence On the
bLventh or eighth day the other boy begun to cough,
and another and younger boy-all of them slept in
the tame room-began ubont the same time. On
the eleventh or twelfth day, a child six months'
old, m the same family, began to cough. It was
therefore evidently a contagious disease, lhis was
more clearly proved by adult persons in the sime
family becoming slightly affected in the throat and
chest. It was from sixteen to eighteen days after the
iiist attack before any decided hoop w AS observed, or
about the time when expectoration set in.
Here, then, is a disease which appears to bo con-
tagious, bul not in the first stage. How is it com-
municated ? What is it5 lias it spores, like certttu
vegetable fungi, floating m an extreme state of sub-
division in the atmosphere of a room where a p-iticnt
is ? 1B it a disease which can be prevrnted ' A» it
appears to be a disease which a person is liable to ex-
perience only once in his life, could it not be prevented
bj inoculation ? These arc questions intended merely
to suggest inquiry. I feel certain, however, that
by inoculation this disease would soon be as
little known as small-pox In the successful înooula
tion of cattle for pleuro-pneumonia, we moy easily
see that inoculation ior the hooping cough would
aa\e the life of muny an infant, lor it is to infants
that the hooping-cough pro\es chiefly fatal. Fur
anything that is known, the pleuro-pneumonia dis-
ease of cattle may be similar to the hooping cough m
thebumantubject, and the hooping-cough might provo
as fatal to the higher as pleuro-pneumonia is to the
Um cr clafB of animals, were it not for the more easily
excitable spasmodic action in the case of the human
subject. Having some knowledge of pleuro-pneu
mouia, from observation and experience, I have been
struck with the remarkable similarity the expectorated
matter in hooping-cough bears to that found in and
around the respiratory organs of cattle which h.i\e
died from pleuro-pneumonia.
BituTAL TouTunn ov ,v Ciutn BY HIS FATHER -At
Lambeth Police Office, on tho 3rd of March, William
Fry, a jobbing carpenter, who had been taken on a
warrant, was placed at the bar before Mr. Elliott on a
charge of torturing a child. Mr. Clifford, the re.
lieving cflicer of Camberwell parish said, that on
Fiidby afternoon last a poor little boy ef eleven ycai«
of age, very thinly elad for such a time of year, and in
astute ot greatexhaustion, was brought to him to the
workhouBe, and on examining him he was quite
shocked at finding an iron manacle weighing upward"
of two pounds, made fast to his instep. It consisted
of a thick iron belt, Becured at both ends with a strong
bolt and screws, and attached to this bolt was passed
the end of an S hook, of sufficient strength to control
an elephant. On questioning the boy he said that f >r
at least ten months he had been compelled to wear
this formidable shackle, and that it was by the
merest accident he was enabled to get at u
chopper, by which he had managed to release hi-n
self from the blcck to which it had been made fait,
and then escaped from the houee of his father. So
BGCure was the manacle he (Mr. Clifford) had at-
tempted to describe, and which he produced for his
worship's inspection, that he had to go to a black-
smith's Bhop to get it off ; and after it was removed,
and the poor boy attempted to wulk without it, he
could scarcely do BO. lie bent backward and for-
ward several times before he could move from the
Bmith's anvil. On examining that part of the right
leg round which the iron belt had been placed, he
found it much wasted, and apparently bent, and
very different from the left leg. His whole frame
also appeared emaciated, so much so that it was per-
fectly apparent the pour little fellow had been
giOBBly neglected, and had not had sufficient food ;
and in proof of this, on placing him in the scale he
only weighed 36 lbs. The psor little fellow
seemed in the greatest terror of being taken
back to his father, and, crying piteously,
begged of him (Mr. Clifford) not to do so. On
Fiiday night the prisoner called on him, and he then
told him he must attend before a magistrate at this
court to answer the charge of assaulting his son. The
prisoner, however, said he should not attend unless
compelled, and he (Mr. Clifford), in consequence,
applied for and obtained a warrant for his apprehen-
sion. Mr. Clifford here placed on the table in front of
the bench the manacle spoken of, and the block to
which it had been attached, the latter being found
in the washhouse from which the poor child had
made his escape, and both weighing nearly twelve
pounds. The exhibition of these extraordinary and
formidable implements of torture applied to a mere
child, created a perfect feeling of astonishment and
diEgust. John Purdy stated that on Friday afternoon
UBI he was at work in a nursery ground adjoining
Woodbine Cottage, the residence of the prisoner,
and Baw the little boy come through the hedge
with the irons attached to hiB left leg. He told him
he had just released himself from a block, and he
(witneBBj took him to the next police station. Mr.
Rogers, a retired mariner, residing next door to the
prisoner, Baid that for the last niue or ten months he
had frequently seen the boy in the yard of his father's
house dragging the log produced about, and carrying
pBils of water into the house. He was generally
lightly elad, and did not appear near the size now
that he did twelve months ago. Harriet Coggins,
who also lives next door to the prisoner, deposed to
the same facts, and added that she had frequently
seen prisoner's children locked up in the wash-house,
and had on many occasions given them food, as
they complained of not having had enough to eat.
Edward Mark Fry, a poor emaciated little fellow,
who was clothed in the workhouse dress, was here
examined by Mr. Elliott respecting the nature of
an oath, and having answered with much intelli
gt ne'e, he was sworn, and said he was eleven years
old, and that his father's family consisted of a sister
older than bimBelf, a brother younger, and a step-
mother. He had been to Behool, but it was so long
»ince that he forgot the time. Towards the latter end
of the winter before last it was that his father first put
the irons on his leg, and made them fast to the block,
and the irons remained on from that time until Friday
last, when he by chance got hold of a chopper and
chopped away until the staple came out, and ho mode
his etcape. Mr. Elliott : What was the cause of the
irons being put on ? Witness : Because my little
brother and myself spent a halfpenny I found under
the grate in the buck parlour. Mr. Elliott : I suppose
the irons hutt your leg very much ? Witness : Yes,
sir, it did at first very much, but not so much when I
got used to it; it used to hurt me much to drag the
log after me. Mr. Elliott : What was done at night ;
WOB the log tnken off? Witness: At first
I used to sleep on an old coat and
trousers in tho washhouse, and at that time
father used to take the log and make the iron fast by
a lock to a staple in the floor, close to the place whore
I lay. In the morning he unlocked it again, and
Inste ned »n iron to the block again ; but for the lost
ele-ten months I think it haB not been off a', all. I
had to carry it up stairs cverv night, and down in the
morning. Mr. Elliott-What ! and always sleep
with it on ? Witness-Ye«, sir, it was always on.
This question and answer produced a perfect burst of
indignation from all parts of the court. The witness
here repeated the manner of his escape, and said a
gentleman had just taken him to the station-house,
and he was sent from there to the workhouse.
In answer to further questions, ? the poor child
said that neither himself nor his little brother
was allowed to toko meals with his father and
mother, in.law-, but his sister was sometimes. They
were locked in the wash-house, and were allowed a
small quantity of meat on Sundays, but on other days
they hod nothing but dry bread and a few potatoes,
but not enough. Policeman 81P said he apprehended
i he prisoner on the day beforo on a warrant, and on
telling him the natuie of the charge, he replied,
" Here's a pretty mc66 I'm in for merely correcting o
boy. Had I let him run about the streets he would
have been in a reformatory." He also said that there
were two others as bad as thiB boy was, and that he
could not keep his tools from them. The prisoner, in
reply to the charge, said that before ho began to
" correct " the boy, he waa connected with a gang of
thieves who infested the neighbourhood ¡ bul this the
boy denied. Mr. Elliott observed that he could not
truBt himself to speak of the conduct of the prisoner
as he felt, and should therefore send him beforo
another tribunal to be punished as his serious offence
deserved. The prisoner was then fully committed for
trial at the ensuing Surrey sessions.-London Evening
Sun.
AmtKST Ol' A MuiinmiBli.-The Cornwall Chronicle
says :- Flanders, the supposed murdererof the poor in-
fant. Mary Ann Riley, near Bagdad, has been arrested.
As Flanders, like the murderer Healy, fled towards
Jeruselem (as if that quiet village was an actual city
of refuge), we presume he has been arrested in that
locality, or in the direction of Mount Dromedary,
alhough on that point there is, as yet, no positive in-
telligence : all we know having been received as a
telegram.

title: METROPOLITAN DISTRICT COURT.
content:
METROPOLITAN DISTRICT COURT.
FnlUAV.
EEI-OKE Mr. District Couit Judge Si-virsct.-.
MONAGHAN V. KAVANAGH. '
'Ibis was an application for new trial on tho ground
that, lho damages aw arded to the plaintiff were excessive.
HÍB Honor refused tho application bocauso the question of
damages had been left to tho Judge and determined by him
at tho trial. Mr. Pilcher appeared in support of the
application, and Mr. S. C. Brown opposed it.
HAM.SDON V. OAKMNEU.
This also was an application for now trial, made on
behalf of tho defendant, against whom a judgment had
been obtained on an order for tho payment of £30 tnado by
him in favour of ono O'Brien. Tho ground of tho applica-
tion was that the order was not an oidor in which tho
defendant promised to pay any amount. For tho pkintiff
it was contended that defendant's order'was a guarantee for
(ho perfommncoof a contract taken by O' Brien from the Cor-
poration. Tho aflidavit of one of the' professional gontlomon
engaged in tho caso slated that tho Judgo had held thnt
the order was a good and valid dooumont in law, and that
that was the ground of the decision. With respect to tho
| order, his Honor held a different opinion, and a new trial
must thcroforo bo granted. Mr. Gannon appeared in sup-
port of the application, and Mr. G. C. Davis opposed it.
îiAvrs v. iionoiiGir OP PADDINGTON.
The plaintiff in this caso h id been tho Council clerk to
tho borough of Paddington, and ho now sued the defendant
for wrongful dismissal. He claimed £160 damages. Mr.
Pigott appeared for the plaintiff, and Mr. S. C. Brown for
tho defendant. The agreemont undor which the plaintiff
served tho Council provided that the engagement
might be terminated by cithor party on a
month's notice. Mr. Brown objected that tho
new Municipalities Act conferred oxprosaly upon the
mayor of any borough power to diBmiss any of tho servants
of tho borough, and that it was not competent for the
Court to review the mayor's dotormination in that respect.
His Honor was ef opinion, on the provision cited, that tho
power of suspension was delegated to tho Mayor, and that
the power to dismiss rested with tho Council. He hold
that it was competent for him to review tho dismissal by
tho Council. Tho evidence showed that tho plaintiff was
suspended on the 9th of Juno, and that tho sus-
pension was confirmed by tho Council al its next
meeting, held shortly afterwards. Plaintiff's testimony
shewed that tho mayor of tho borough (Mr. Taylor) told
him that ho only suspended him because ho was askod_ to
do so ; Taylor admitted that ho had no fault to find with
him, and spoke highly of his efficiency, Messrs. Penfold
and Peate, aldermen of tho borough, gave evidence to the
effect that tho plaintiff had at all tunes performed tho duties
of his office in tho most efficient and satisfactory manner ;
while, on tho other hand, Aldermen Humphrey and Stone
states that tho plaintiff had inaccurately kopt the minutes,
withheld certain vouchers, whereby tho borough lost tho
Government endowment for tho half-year-that he had
diEobcyed orders, and had been disrespectful to tho Mayor,
in practically calling him a liar on the occasion of a public
meeting, and again at a meeting of tho Council. Theso
allegations were contradicted by the plaintiff. Tho minutes
of Council contained no record of the cause of plaintiff's
dismissal, and tho only evidence on this point was in tho
vorbal report of the mayor, who thon stated
that he had suspended the plaintiff because his
conduct was distasteful to a majority of tho
aldermen, and because he bad no confidence in him.
Mr, Taylor (the mayor of tho borough) sworo that ho did
sot dismiss Davis in consequence of any ill feeling, but
simply becauso on ono or two occasions Mr. Davis had
asserted that he (witness) was a liar, and that Davis had on
more than one occasion altered things in the account-books
in opposition to his (tho mayor's) instructions. Ho was of
opinion that Davis was out of his mind at times. [At this
Btagc of tho caBc, his Honor intimated ho was of opinion
that plaintiff had been wrongfully dismissed ; that
if there had not been any ill-feeling in exist-
ence, plaintiff would never havo been dismissed.]
Mr. Brown «intended that tho mayor of a municipality
had the power to suspend a clerk or servant, at any time,
who in his opinion was guilty of misconduct; such suspen-
sion, of courso, would bo subject to csnfirmation by tho
Council. In this instance, tho Council had confirmed tho
suspension, that Davis had no right, boing a servant of tho
Council, to have attended any public meeting of tho rate-
payers, and; that Davis, having charged the mayor with
telling falsehoods was quito sufficient cause for his dismis-
sion. Tho utmost that could bo claimed by tho
plaintiff was," a month's pay. Mr. Pigott con-
tended that plaintiff was entitled to a year's
salary, tho contract having been for that period.
His Honor was of opinion that he had jurisdiction to
consider the question whether tho plaintiff hod been
wrongfully dismissed. He did not think that it was evor
the intention of the Legislature that the Council clerk
should be entirely at the meicy of tho Council, and should
be deprived of all resort to a Court of law. As a matter i
of fact, he was of opinion that tho defendant had been
wrongfully dismissed by the Council. He was disposed to
think that the plaintiff had shown a spirit of |
par'ialify, and had been guilty of conduct
which was unbecoming, and which would havo
justified the defendant in giving him a month's
notice ; but he did not think that that impropriety of con- j
duct was sufficient to justify his summary and absoluto
dismissal. He was of opinion upon the ovidenoe that tho
plaintiff had not been dismissed for misconduct, but becauso
he did not givo satisfaction to a majority of the aldermen.
The contract was for a year¿ and that contract had not
been determined by the notice in writing required to be
given under it. Ho thought that £50 would bo sufficient
to compénsalo tho plaintiff, and ho directed a verdict to bo
entered for that sum.

I öi'ORTINO NOTES.
At the request ol a number of members
Mr. R. Grice lia» decided to stand for one of
the vacancies on the V.lt.C. committee, and
hi« nomination was handed in on Tuesday.
Mr. Grice haa previously acted as a com
mitlecman, and lie I as such a wide circle of
friends that hischunce of election is regarded
as a good «ne. Mr. J. C. Walker's nomi-
nation is also in, but Mr. J. C. Howden, who
has been mentioned as u certain candidate,
has not yet been uomiuated, though ho
probably will be in tho course of a day
or two. There are eight vacancies to fill
at the annual meeting of the members on
August 7. The retiring members of the
committee aro Mcsirs. W. If. Croker, C. B.
Fisher, C M. Ll^yd, W. Lonard, S.
Miller, F. Madden, J. Whittingham, and
G. Watson, all of whom, it"is understood,
will offer themselves for rc-clent.ion.
A New Zealand wiitcr thus speaks oí
Launceston and Loyalty, who aro engaged
in the Melbourne Cup : - " Among the
horse« doing useful work on the Riccarton
course are Launceston and Loyalty. Laun-
ceston, who is a light-fleahcd horse, lojks
in really capital irirn, and, in fact, BO
forward that it would probably not take
many week» to g^t bin fit. Loyalty,
on the other hand, U a particularly
gross colt, and although he lias already
?bown himself to be something out of the
common, I fancy ho will not be seen at hi»
very best until later on in Ids career. He
wi 1, of course, be rjy.ite fit to race next
»pring, but if his legs stand-and they cer-
tainly look a» if they will-he will continue
to improve with age, and hi» best perform-
ances »ill probably be registered when be is
four or five years old."
Mr. H, K. Falkiner has sold hi» well-per
farmed hone, Hopetoun, who will probably
find hi» way to India. The Bagct Handicap
winner was leased to Mr. S. Miller, with
whom Mr. Falkiner carno to an understand-
ing which permitted of the horse's sale.
Hopetoun is a good little horse up to a cer-
tain weight, and fit and well in India he
should be able to win a few good race».
Hopetoun has been scratched for the two
Cups.

title: MILL'S DISSERTATIONS AND DISCUSSIONS.
content:
MILL'S DISSERTATIONS AND DISCUSSIONS.
{From the London Review.)
ONE of the most remarkable facts which the
historian of the future must take into account
in estimating the forces that have governed
progress in our age and country is, in spite of
Mr Buckle, the individual influence of a great
man. At whatever department of thought we
glance, we distinguish, by comparison with the
conditions of twenty years ago, the unmis-
takable stamp of one mind. Within the period
named, the experiential school of philosophy,
which had almost disappeared from the country
of Locke, driven out by a crude deluge of
German transcendentalism, has been raised
almost to scientific perfection, has been formu-
lated, criticised, cleared of obscurities. In-
ductive logic, since Bacon's time practically
regnant in England, has vindicated as well a just
philosophical supremacy The great problems
of social and intellectual freedom have been
boldly shaped into a grand code of tolerance, to
which even bigots are now compelled to yield
at least a lip worship Among our public men
and writers a broader view of responsibilities,
class pretensions, and national claims has begun
to prevail Both in theoretical and practical
politics the narrow selfishness, which aped
Utilitarianism but was really its antithesis, has
been to some extent discarded and now, if we
have not quite escaped the taint of party bitter
ness in political discussion,we have at all events
the gratification of seeing that the number is
ever increasing of thinkers and even statesmen,
who set philosophy above intrigue and petty
private interests On the whole we are
justified in the boast - though we see
more promise as yet than performance
that this generation is less the slave of
prejudices and formulas, more earnest, more
thoughtful, more logical than that which imme-
diately preceded it It would be difficult to
over-estimate the share in this distinct and
welcome advance which is due to the personal
influence of Mr John Stuart Mill.
Mr Mill's earlier appearances as an anony-
mous wrnter were of a very varied kind
Poetry, history, and fiction, were among the
subjects of his keen impartial criticism But
after the publication of his great works on
political economy and logic, wc find that he
limits his labours to the severer walks of study,
in which he has become illustrious is an
authority 'Hie third volume of his collected
essays, which lies before does not include
any enuc d discussions such as these on Alfred
de Vigmy in the first volume, and on Michelet's
History of France in the second Politics and
metaphysics divide tins latest republication of
Mr Mill's periodical writings Under the
former he id ni ty be included the valuable papers
"'Thoughts on Parliamentary Reform," and
"Kettnt Writers on Reform," winch appeared
during tht discussions attenelant on the appear-
ance ol Mr Disraeli's Bill of 18V), as also ' A
Few Words on Non-intervention," and " Hie
Contest in Amené i," rejinnted from /Vene; t
JUai/tizitir 'Hie el.iboi ite and exhaustive
criticism on ' Vustin s Lectures on Juris
piudcncc" occupies to s0nie extent a neutral
ground between the foregoing strictl) political
et-sajq, and the two importint contributions to
mental science whim lorni pirt of the same
volume-tin disstnations on Ham's Pi)clio
log)," and " Grotc's Plato '
The governing principle of all Mr Mill's
teaching, whether in polities, in social science,
or in philosophy, may be fairly descrubed as an
enlightened and systematised individualism li
we assume, »t is tlie almost tinivcrsjl custom
with Englishmen, that any attempt to base
society on the idea of fraternity must be per
nicious. and is to be denounced as Socialist and
revolutionary, we shall find in Mr Mill's system
the most admirable type of modern develop
ment Where the political economy of others
is hard anti narrow, his takes a broader view,
and docs not arrogate an irrational dominion
over the higher instincts of human nature
Thus we find that ulonc, after Adam Smith, Mr
Mill has put Ins favourite science into i form
not repulsive to those bene'olent aspirations
which no science can extinguish in man In
the same way he has softened down the harsher
traits of the utilitarian philosophy, as it derived
itself from Bentham In politics, the tin
Radicalism of his fathtr, James Mill, and his
school, has been vivified and informed with i
new soul by that noble chapter in the " Political
Economy ' on ' '1 he Probable Futurity of tne
Labouring Classes, ' by the " Essay on Liberty,
and the ' Representative Government" And
those students ol mental philosophy who wotilel
have rejected the gross materialism of Hartley
and Condillac can recognise in the refutation
of Hamilton a metaphysical theory which
neither revolts the logical sense nor the
spiritual nature It is this apt combination of
the strictest principles of individualism with a
generous enthusiasm for everything that is just
and noble, which has gained for Mr Mill his
wide and potent sway over the mind of
England Resting as that sway does, on the
free allegiance of the mest enlightened and the
most ardent spirits among the younger genera
tion of Englishmen, it must, beyond question,
be extended and strengthened with mere lapse
of time How far this philosophy can be con
sidered an ultimate growth admits of more
doubt It ein only be supplanted, however, ii
at all, by a system based on the solidarity of
mankind, and on theories which only a few
thinkers in this country regard as other than
hopeless unattainable dreams
Almost cvtiy page of ihe volume befoie us
furnishes us with in example of Mr Mills
power over opinion To him is due the grow-
ing interest felt by the public in Mr. Hare's
scheme of personal representation, and the
glowing toleration accoided to its discussion
'lins plan is very cekariy the very apothcosis of
individuihsm in the domain of practical politics,
and, as such, will never meet with the approval
of those who regard rather the action of the
popular will through masses than the divlsion of
the State into little groups of personal interests
It is so very improbable that we can go so far in
the wat of recasting our institutions as to adopt
Mi Hare's ingenious machinery, that the ques
tion is practically taken out of the sphere of
useful debate, since we believe even Mr Mill
himself, in bringing it under the nonce of the
House of Commons, rather desires to assert
the principle than hopes to establish the
actual change A more real benefit, in our
present effort to complete some satisfactory
representative Reform, may be derived from
Mr Mill's sensible statement of the advantages
of grouping, in a redistribution of seats Wh lt
ever ma) be the fate of the fianeluse clauses of
the present Government Bill, no one believes
that Mr Disraeli's redistribution plan has an)
chance ol fav omable acceptation In this
point, however, the scheme of last year was
very little better, and was open to all the ob
jections which Mr Mill ably urges against
Lord John Russell's Bill of 1852 in view of
some probable modifications of the grouping
system being proposed by one or other party,
the following remarks on the radical vice of
previous propositions will be found interest-
ing -
" "i et, if the principle of combining several boroughs
was once admitted, what course could be more obii
t>ovb than to taut all the present boroughs, and nil
unrepresented towns of more than a certain amount of
population (bay, for example, oOOO), and leaving out
all those, w hellier existing as boroughs or still tobo
created, avhose importance entitles them to one mem-
ber, or more than one, of their own, to arrange the
others in groups according to geographical conveni-
ence, care being taken lo give to each group something
like the same number ol electors No reason is appa-
rent tilly this plan was not adopted, except the mis-
placed scruple against merging two existing boroughs
into one if what is now i borough is to beeomo
one ol a group, what difference can it make to the elec-
tors whether thev ure bound up with existing, or only
with newly enfranchised re electors 5 What couldbe
more abnurd than lhat dine anil ( hippeiitiam both
nommant n boroughs, and actually conterminous,
should (as m 1 ord John Hut-sell s scheine} subsist as
a «ort ol e'ouble bt»r, with each it« se par ile svstom of
planète, or that Amtbbury and Djvvnton should be
recalled from schedule A to furnish a supplementary
constituency to the little boiough of Wilton, instead
of adding it to the adinccnt city of Salisbury > The
proper iif.(,rcgate number of members for Bmall towna
being first, after due consideration, determined, all
pim o of «ueh bi?c ns to be politically entitled to the
designation of towns should bp admitted to a Bhare
in it 1 he greater the number of places included in
euch district the better prospect of a creditable choice
Hie local influences of families and corporations
would then have more chance of neutralising one
another, and with the aid of stringent measures
against all forms of corruption, tnere would bo some
prospect that the choico of representatives might
octiisioiiftllj be made on public rather than on pnv ite
grounds
'Hie papers in this volume, which onginally
appeared in I ra^r s Mm/iutur, were so widely
rend in their original form, that we need hardly
do more th in point to the fact of their rcpub
hcr.tion In " llecent W riters on Bcforni '-a
criticism on the theories of Mi Austin, Mr
Hare, and Professoi Lorimer-was developed
that philosophical bias in favour ol plural
voting which was outlined in the " Bcpre
sent itive Government, ' but to which, perhaps,
experience in practical legislation has since
weakened Mr Mill's ittachnicnt A more
import int production in every sense was the
eloquent and keen sighted examination of the
American contest lins more than inytlnng
else tint was published on either side of the
Atlantic, set clearly before the educated mind
of Lngland the real issues involved in the Civil
War We are wise ifter the event, but even
had facts disproved Mr Mill's forecast, we
should still admire the generous sympathies
which nrompt sucha passage as this -
' For these renions I innnot join with thoüc who
cry ' Peace, peace I cannot wish that this war
should not have leen engaged in by tho North, or
that, being engaged in, it should be terminated on
any conditions but such as would retain the whole of
the territories as free soil I am not blind to the
possibility that it may require a long war to lower the
arrogance mad tame the nggressive ambition of the
slnvc owner«, to the point of either returning to the
Union, or consenting to nniainoutof it with their
present limits Hut war in a (,ood ciusc is not the
(,n Mest ivii which a nation enn suflcr War is an
uglv thing but not the ugliest of things , the decaj ed
nnd degraded state cf moral and pntnotic
feeling which thinks nothing worth a war, is
worse \A hen a people are used n« mere
human instruments for bring cannon or thrusting
bayonets, in the service anil for the selfish jnir
poFcs of a master, sue li war degrades a people A
war to piotect other hum in beings against tyrannical
uijustiii - a wnrto give victory to their own idea of
ri(,ht and pooel, and «Inch is their own war, carmel
on for an honest purpose hy their free choice-is eilten
the means <f their regeneration A man who ha«
nothing which he is willing to fight for, nothing
?which he chtcs more about than he docs about his
pcriional safe tv, is a miserable creature who has no
chance ofbeing free, unless mnde and kept so bv the
i xe rtioi s it better men than himself As long as
justice anel mnisticc have not terminated their ivor
renewing t ghi for nsceiiilniuj m the alfairs of m in
kind, human beings must be willing, when need is, to
do battle for the one against the other I am far
frevn faying that the present struggle on the pitt
ol ti c Northern Ameritan* is whollj of this cxn ted
cliniacter, that it lins arrived at the stnge of being
altogether a war for iiistite a war of principle lint
t) ere was from the beginning, and now is, a large
infusion of that elimrnt in it, and this is increasing
will mi reuse, and, if the vvnr lasts, will til the end
predominate Should that time come, not only will
the greatest enormity which still exists among min
kind as an institution rrccive far earlier its coup de
gruce than there lias ever, until now, appeared any
probability of, but in effecting this the 1 ree States
will have raised themselves to that elevated position
in the stnle of morality Bnd dignity which is derived
from great sacrifices consciously made in a virtuous
cause, and the sense ot an inestimable benefit to all
future ngc«, brought about bj their own voluntary
rfiorts "
In this brilliant appreciation of the great
cause which was the ob|cet of the American
contest, the individu ihsm of Mr. Mill's
philcsoph) shjifi somewhat out of sight
and it seems no less over-mastered in
the " Exposition of the theory of Non-
intervention 'Hie common Badical creed
would scarcely admit of the large exception
which Air "Mill lays elown as neccssiry to the
proper working of what may be called Cobden
ism 'Ihough the prospect opened up in this
passage be alluring, we feai that it is, for the
present dt least, unatt unable -
"Hut the ease of a people struggling ngamst a
foreign voice, *>r ngiiinst a native tyrannv upheld bj
foreign arms illustrates the reisons for non interven-
tion in an opposite way , for in this case the reasons
themselves do not exist A people most attached to
freedom, tho most capable of iliftndinr and of miking
a good use of free institutions, nmv he unable
to contend stiticWullr for them a^unst the
military strength of another nation much more power-
ful lo assist a people thus kept down is not to
eiisiuri) nie uanna ui lorccs on windinie permanent
niMiiliiiancc i t freed mi in v c iiuttrj deptiuls, but t >
redress ihnt balance when it is already unfurlv and
violentlj diBtmbcil Hie doctrine of non intervention
to be a li "inmate priiicinle of morilitj, must be
ncctptedbj all govtriiiiicnts 1 lip despots must con
sent to be bound bj it as well as the free Sítales
Unless thev do the profession ol it bj free countries
comes but to this miserable issue-, that the wrong side
maj help the wrong but the nDht must not help the
right Intervention to enforce non intervenu m is
alwavs rightful, iilvvavs moral, if not always prudent
Though it bo a mistake to "ive lreedom to a people
who ilo not value the boon, it cannot bul be right to
insist that if >thi j do v ailie it, thej ah ill not
be hindered from the puisuit ot it by foreign
coerrton It might nut have been right tor
Lnglnnd (even apart from the question of prudence)
to 1 ave tiiken part with Hungarj m its noble struggle
ngamst Ausiriu , although the Austrian Government
in Hungary was in some sense a foreign joke But
when, the Hungarians having shown themselves likely
to prevail in tins struggle, the Kussian despot inter-
posal, and joining his force to that of Austria, de
livered back the Hungarians, bound hand and foot, to
their exnsperated oppressors, it would have been an
honourable and virtuous- act on the part of Lngland
to have declared that this should not be, and that if
Russia gave assistance to the wrong side, England
would aid the right It might not have been consultent
with the regard which even nation is bound to pay to
its own safety for Lngland to have taken up this posi-
tion single-handed But Lngland and Prance together
could have done it, and if thej had, the HusBian
armed intervention would never have taken place, or
would have been disastrous to ItuBsia alone ,
while all that those Powers gained by not
doing it, was that thej had to bght Kussia five years
afterwaids under more dilhcult circumstances, and
without Kungari for an tilly Hie hrst nation which,
being powerful enough to make its voice effectual, has
the spirit and courage to saj that not a gun shall be
fired in Luropc bj the soldiers of one Power against
the revolted subjects ol another, will be the idol of
tile friends ot freedom throu"hout Europe That
declaration alone will insure the almost immediate
emancipation of every people which desires liberty
sufhcientlj to be capable of maintaining it and the
nation which gives the vv ord vv ill soon hnd itself at the
head of an alliance of free peoples, bo strong as to defy
the eflorts of anj number of confederated despots to
bung it down Ihe pn/e is too glorious not to be
matched sooner or later by some free country , and
the time may not be diBtant when England, if she
does not take this heroic part because of its heroism,
will be compelled to take it from consideration for her
own safety
We might pause with pleasure over Mr
ALU's " Criticism of Austin's Jurisprudence, '
in which the utilitarian theory of positive hw is
formulated Wc might examine the two com-
panion essays on "Bain's Psychology" and
Grote's " Plato," which, like the famous criti
cisirs on ( olerulge and Bentham, correct and
supplement cich othei , and, with the " IX
rnunation of Hamilton's Philosophy," complete
Mr Mill's metaphysical system But we have
said enough, and quoted enough, to show that
this volume is one which will eminently repiy
the t isk of penis d-th it it is no way mfen >r
to any of Mr Mill's previously published works
May we heie cull the attention of the author
and publishei to an eimssiwn which seriously
detracts from the value ol Mr MiU's works as
at present printed ? Wc mean tho absence of
an index. In the ease of books which are so
constantly required for reference as well as
study, this is a grave defect-one, let us hope,
that will be remedied in future editions.

title: Family Notices
content:
THE FRIENDS of the late Mrs. M'FARLANE who
propose attending her obsequies are informed that
the funeral will start from King-street East, and proceed to
the Presbyterian ground, adjoining the Railway Terminus,
at 9 o'clock, THIS MORNNING.
R. STEWART, undertaker.
FUNERAL.-Ancient Order of Foresters, No. 2000,
Court Lincoln,-The Officers and Brothers of the
above Lodge are respectfully invited to attend the Funeral
of Brother WILLIAM FERGUSON, the procession to
move from his late residence Crown-street, Glebe,
WEDNESDAY MORNING, at 10 o'clock precisely.
HANSLOW, undertaker, No. 760, George-street South,
and South Head Road.
FUNERAL.-The Friends of Mr. R. DARBY, rail-
way guard, are respectfully invited to attend the
Funeral of his deceased wife, HONORA. To move from
his residence, 85, Campbell-street, THIS (Tuesday)
AFTERNOON, at 3 o'clock. JAMES CURTIS, under-
takor.
FUNERAL -The Friends ol Mr. FRANCIS
HEARLE, gas-fitter, are invited to attend the
Funeral of his deceased daughter, MADELINE ELIZA-
BETH. To move from her residenco, 82, Prince-street,
THIS (Tuesday) AFTERNOON, at a quarter to three,
o'clock. JAMES CURTIS, undertaker, No. 59, Hunter
street.
