title: THE LATE GUNPOWDER EXPLOSION. INQUEST ON THE BODY OF GEORGE GAMBLE.
content:
THE LATE GUNPOWDER EXPLOSION.
INQUEST ON THE BODY OF GEORGE GAMBLE.
[FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT.]
An inquest was held before Mr Brown, coroner for the dis-
trict, at the Weatherboard Inn, "Western Road on the 17th
instant, upon the body of George Gamble, nineteen years
of age, who was killed on Thursday evening, while driving
a dray loaded with blasting powder, which exploded.
William McManamey, on oath, deposed: I am a senior
constable of police, stationed at Pulpit Hill, Bathurst dis-
trict , about 8 o'clock last evening, I was informed at the
station that there had been an explosion of two tons of
blasting powder, that was being conveyed on a dray owned
by James Melville, and driven by deceased, the powder
was the property of Mr. W. W. Watkins, railway con-
tractor; I proceeded to Spring-hill, five miles from the
police station; I there saw the body of deceased, it was
forty feet from where the dray was when the powder
blew up, the body was quite naked, the skin
being scorched off all over, it was lying on its
stomach, the hands stretched forward, some of the
bowels were twisted round the fence that encloses
the railway cuttings, I found the left foot of deceased was
about four yards from the body and through the fence; it
appeared as if it had been torn off by striking against the
fence; there were marks on the post of the fence as if the
body had struck against it; on examining the body I ob-
served that the head was nearly torn from the trunk, it
was only held on by a small piece of skin on ths lsft side of
the neck, the right side of the head, face, and neck had
a black, burnt appearance, tha skin and hair of the head
were torn off for several inches, the right ear was wholly
gone, the eyes were black and scorched , the jaws and face
were smashed, the arms broken, the right hip was very
black and torn inwards for a depth of from two to three
inches, and for a circle of six inches the flesh was gone. It
appeared as if the right side of deceased was nearest the
fire, the right leg below tbe knee was broken , the axle of
the dray lay on the side of the road, ten feet from
where the dray was at the time of the explosion, one tire
of wheel is some considerable distance further off, there
is no other trace of a dray left, one of the horses was lying
on his near side about five yards away , the entrails
were strewn over the road, the heart laying some distance
from the body, another horse appeared as if he bad been
forced along the road with great velocity, his back was
broken near the shoulders, and entrails forced out; a
third horse was found about thirty yards away, and had
been lifted from the road over the railway
cutting and fence enclosing it, he was quite blind; a
fourth horse had the off hind leg tom away, was scorched, and
blind, since dead , a fifth had the hoof torn off the hind leg,
blind, since dead, the sixth is very much scorched and
nearly blind , the harness is all destroyed; the banks at the
side of the road were much torn up , the telegraph wire was
blown off half a dozen of the posts, three panels of fencing
were broken, and posts and rails split about 40 feet off.
John Keegan deposed I have a contract with Mr.
Watkins for the cartage of blasting powder from the railway
station, Penrith, to No. 4 section Great Western Railway
extension, I1 helped to load deceased's dray on Monday
last, I objected to take the powdor in its then unfit state
for transit, numbers of the casks being loose, and the
powder escaping from them, Mr. Francis, and Mr. Watkins,
clerk of works, said if I did not take the powder some one
else would, and that my security (£100) would pay for a
good deal of the carriage; I, to save my security,
loaded deceased's dray, and two others driven by
my self, I felt the risk my drivers incurred
so much that I begged Mr Watkins not to
allow the powder to be sent, he did not interfere, as the
teams proceeded along the road theo powder was dropping
out, when riding up from Pennth this morning there
were traces of the powder all the way along, and on several
occasion when my horse trod on it the loose powder ex-
ploded, sending flame up to the horses girth.
Michael Redden deposed; I am a carrier, and was about
seven yards ahead of deceased at the time of the explosion,
had been travelling with him for two or three miles, de-
ceased was, when I first saw him a few minutes before the
occurrence, walking at the side of the dray, he was sober;
I saw powder along the road, it had dropped from the dray
in front of me, driven by Pat Keegan, after the discharge
I found one of deceased's shaft horses had been driven
under my dray between the wheels, I had some difficulty
m gotting the horse extricated from its position, no part
of deceased's dray or loading was visible after the explo-
sion, I saw deceased's body after it was found.
John Redden deposed; I was about fifty yards behind
deceased's dray, when the powder took fire a turn of the
road intercepted my view, mv horses turned round on the
road and knocked me down, when I recovered no dray or
loading was to be seen, deceased was sober, and did not
smoke, I saw the body of deceased after it was found,
powder was strewn along the road from the drays that pre-
ceded me; I helped my brother to get the horse from under
his team.
Patrick Keegan deposed; I loaded at the same time with
deceased, I heard my father (J. Keegan) refuse to
take the powder in the drays, which he after-
wards did at the instigation of Mr. Francis, the
casks were quite unfit to be moved , half on each load were
loose, hoops broken, and heads not tight, from the start
the powder was strewing on the road, they said to them-
selves often that they would be blown up , my father fol-
lowed as far as the top of Lapstone Hill, to caution us to
use every care for this time, and he would throw up the
contract before he would expose us to such risk again;
when the explosion took place he was about thirty yards
ahead, I was standing on the shaft of my wag-
on, I was thrown off , as I was descending I
was struck near theo eye with the telegraph wire, that was
just at same instant blown off the posts; I did not perceive
that it was deceased's load that exploded at first, I thought
it was my own , I started to run away, but seeing my load
untouched, I proceeded to where deceased's dray had been;
I saw deceased's body found, he did not drink any intoxi-
cating liquor, or smoke, after we started from the Plains.
The jury found a verdict of "Accidentally killed, by ex-
plosion of gunpowder," adding the following rider, viz :-
'The parties in charge of the powder belonging to Mr.
Watkins, at Emu Plains, have not used proper precaution,
by not seeing that the casks were in a fit state to convey
powder."

title: NEWS OF THE DAY.
content:
NEWS OF THE DAY.
.
Uva oable messages of this morning supply in a
brief form the opinions of several of the leading
English journals on the Victorian Constitution ques-
tion. Epitomised as these opinions necessarily are in
our telegrams, they are sufficiently comprehensive to
.how that Mr. Berry's policy is regarded with
much disfavour in England. The increase of
the German army is not alone obnoxious to
the Russians, but the German peasantry have
been memorialising the Chief Marshal of the
German Empire for a reduction, instead of an increase
of the army. Count Moltke told the people that such
» step was impossible now, and would only be possible
When European nations, acting under religious and
moral influences, recognised war as a national
calamity. The death of the Parliamentary representa-
tive for Liverpool has created a vacancy, the filling of
which is to be regarded as a test of the public feeling of
England with regard to the Beaconsfield regime. A
Tory and a Literal have been nominated. The advo-
cates of home rule for Ireland are supporting the
Liberal candidate, but the Liberal party seems to be
»putting up. It will be seen, also, by our telegrams,
that the Duchess of Marlborough, who inaugurated
the Irish Relief Fund, has repudiated the aspersions
cart upon the subscribers by Mr. Parnell's untimely and
ill-advised speech in New York. A South Australia 4
per out. loan of three and a quarter millions is on
the London market. Our commercial telegrams from
London do not report any change of consequence.
Thb P. and 0. Company's steamship Indus, which ia
to inaugurate the new fortnightly mail service between
Melbourne and London, will leave Sydney at noon to-
day» for Melbourne, en route for Ceylon and
Southampton, via the Suez Canal. She will remain
at Melbourne two or three days. It will be seen
by the mail notices in another column that mails
intended to be forwarded from Sydney by the Indus,
Jill be made up at and forwarded from the General
*Mt Offioe. on Tuesday next. Unregistered letters
will be received up to 8.30 on Tuesday morning. The
Indus is to leave Melbourne on Friday next
A third paper on the subjeot of the proposed aban-
donment of the Southhampton mail route between
Great Britain and Australasia, has just been issued
from the Government Printing Office. The rirst item
is a tolegram from the Chief Secretary of Vic-
toria to the Colonial Secretary of New South
Wales, as follows :-" January 6,1880. Southampton,
and Suez contract being abandoned by the Imperial
Government, this Government purpose tosend all mails
after January via Brindisi and charge present
Southampton rates on letters, packets, and newspapers ;
division of postage between Imperial and Colonial
Governments to bo matter of future arrangement.
For the present, other colonies to account to Victoria
same rates as now. Your concurrence invited in
transmission of mails by fortnightly service via
Brindisi in accordance with foregoing. Favour of early
reply requested." In reply to this the fol-
lowing telegram was sent by the Govern-
ment here to tho Government of Victoria :
" January 9.-If we are to continue to pay your pre-
sent charges on correspondence both ways, and the
amount retained by England on correspondence com-
ing this way, besides Continental transit rates, we can-
not consent to reduce our present rates from here on
correspondence via Brindisi." The Postmaster-General
in Melbourne then addressed our Postmaster-General
in the following terms :-" 14th January, 1880.-In
reply to your telegram of 9th instant, I would beg to
point out that the proposed reduction in postage rate
on correspondence sent via Brindisi under new fort-
nightly contract will be no special advantage to Vic-
toria. The public of each colony adopting the
reduced rate will derive the benefit The ques-
tion of transit rates to be accounted for to Vio
toria by other oolonies can be better considsred when
sufficient data are obtained upon which to base an
equitable arrangement, as it is not the object of this
Government to make a profit out of the contract at the
expense of the other colonies. You are probably aware
that Italian transit rates have been reduced. South-
ampton route having been abandoned, it is believed
that Imperial Government is prepared to reconsider ar-
rangements as to division of postage." Mr. Samuel
se_t a telegram in reply on the following day as
under :-" Re your telegram of yesterday, we can only
deal with the present position of matters. If we reduce
to 6d. and hare to pay you that amount on all letters
both wave and have to pay England 2d. on inward
letters besides Continental rates, we shall sustain .
further loss on ocean mail services ; and, as we are not
prepared to do this, cannot consent to any reduction of
Brindisi rates." Then in consequence of a paragraph
i which appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald
our Government, on the 20th instant, dispatched
I tho following cablegram to Sir Daniel Cooper, the
acting Agent-General of this colony:-" Last Septem-
ber Imperial Government notified proposed abandon-
ment Southampton route and reduotion Brindisi postage
to sevenpence. We replied,-No objection, provided
penny would meet Continental rates. Victoria has
since proposed reducing to sixpence, to which we have
objected. Now rumoured Imperial Government favour-
ably considering Victorian proposal. Strongly protest
against any reduction that will prevent our receiving
the fourpenco already agreed to be allowed on every
half-ounce letter." I
At a'meoting, yesterday, of the Commissionappointed
to conduct the representation of New South Wales at
the Victorian International Exhibition, it was decided
to telegraph to Melbourne, asking for the allotment of
20,000 feet of space for New South Wales exhibitors.
It was stated during discussion that £10,000 would
probably be required to secure the fitting representation
of New South Wales at the Exhibition to be held in
tho sister colony this year. j
Several deputations waited upon members of the
Government yesterday, the majority of the interview»
being with the Minister for Works. Representatives
from the southern suburbs waited upon that gentleman
to protest against the proposed soheme of drainage by
way of Shea's Creek, on the ground that it would be
an intolerable nuisance to the people living in those
suburbs, and dangerous to health. Mr. Lackey pointed
out that the official reports he had received were
I opposed to the views put forward by the deputation,
but the representations the deputation had made
should receive the most thorough investigation.
In reply to a deputation who advocated the connection
of the Great Northern Bailway with Sydney at some
point near Newcastle, Mr. Lackey said that no time
was being lost in making arrangements for connecting
the Northern line with the Southern and Western line.
It was premature now to say where the junction would
take place, but he did not think the Government could
ignore the trade of the Lower Hunter when deciding
upon the point of junotion. Another deputation that
waited upon the Minister for Works urged upon
the Government the necessity for extending
the Great Western Ballway from Orange towards
Wilcannia, or some part of the Darling. Mr.
Lackey said that nothing could be done in the matter
until the surveys were completed. When they were
ready there would be very little delay in extending the
Great Western Bailway. A deputation representing
the fire insurance companies waited upon Sir Henry
Parkes, to ask if he would re-introduce to Parliament
the Firo Brigade Bill, which provided for the appoint-
ment of a general superintendent of brigades, and other '
changes that were much required. Sir Henry Parkes
said he was disposed to undertake what the deputation
required; but the measures already laid before Par-
liament by the Government must have consideration
before any other.' The subjects of the other deputations
had reference to the necessity of weighbridges at
railway stations, the removal of an encroachment on
Driver's Boad, Burwood, and a wharf at Greenwich
Point.
Early yesterday morning misty rain began to fall,
and by noon a steady drizzle set in, and continued with
but little intermission all afternoon and night. After
the warm dry weather we have had of late, this
change to rain and a cooler atmosphere has been very
acceptable, especially to those lucky enough to possess
gardens.
The Mayor of Sydney, Mr. P. A. Jennings, and
Mr. J. Davies, M.L.A., yesterday waited upon Pro-
fessor Reuleaux, the German Commissioner, as a depu-
tation from a preliminary meeting, for the purpose of
asking that gentleman to attend a complimentary ban-
quet which it was proposed to tender him prior to his
departure for Europe next nwnth. Professor Beuleaux
thanked the deputation, but stated that he would ac-
cept it as a favour if the whole of the foreign commis-
sioners were invited to attend the banquet. This
request will be aoted upon, and an influential com-
mittee is being formed to make the necessary arrange-
ments.
Mr. M'Dougall (of the firm of Sands and M'Dougall),
Mr. John Sands, Mr. Hugh George, Mr. Franks
(of the firm of F. T. Wimble and Co.), Mr. Dunlop
(of the firm of Dunlop and Edwards), and other
gentlemen interested in typographical pursuits, visited
the Government Printing Office yesterday, at the
invitation of Mr. Thomas Richards, to witness the
operations of a printing machine made by Messrs.
Dryden and Ford. Mr. Richards selected the
machine on the occasion of his visit to London in
1877, and also endeavoured to ascertain the most econo-
mical purposes to which it could be applied. At that time
he saw 32 demy-octavo pages printed at one impression,
but having great confidence in the capabilities of the
machine, he determined, if possible, to Increase the
number. The chases were rearranged and improved
here by Messrs. D'Arrietta and Potter, and the result
has been that the machine as it was worked here
printed sixty-four pages at a time. Mr. M'Dougall,
who has a knowledge of all the modern improvements
in the art of printing as it is pursued in London, ex-
pressed his satisfaction at the working of the machine,
and several other gentlemen present said they thought
it indicated a marked advance in economical printing.
The impressions were pronounced to be excellent and
the register good. The Government Printer has four
of the machines at his command now, and could, if
required, print with them in one day 1000 copies of
a book of 500 pages.
At the annual meeting of the Parramatta Hospital
held last night, the Bev. Canon Gunther was re
elected president.
The Quarter Sessions were continued yesterday
before his Honor Judge Wilkinson. Ah Pin was found
guilty of stealing a horse and cart, and sentenced to
three months' hard labour. James Singleton and
James Nicholson, alias Horace Dixon, for imperso-
nating at the recent eleotion for East Sydney, Were
bound over in their own recognisances for £40, and
one suretv in £40. to appear when called upon to re
ceive sentence. The case against Cornelius Biordan,
for inflicting grievouH bodily harm upon Joseph Brad-
ley, was not concluded when the Court adjourned till
Monday.
At the usual meeting of the Hibernian A. C. B.
Sooiety (St. Patrick's branch) the president, Brother
B. Gaffney, in the chair, which was held at the meet
. ing rooms, Punch's Hotel, it was resolved, on the
i motion of Brother P. P. Matthew Quinlan,-" That
the whole of the proceeds of the forthcoming celebra-
tion of St Patrick's Day be devoted to the alleviation
of the distress now existing in Ireland." The secretary,
Brother D. J. O'Connor, was authorised to communi-
cate the above to the other city branches.
A mew Public school at Bungendore, was opened on
Thursday by Mr. J. B. Bourke, J.P. There were a con-
siderable number of Catholics and Denominational school
children present, and several members of the local
Board united in the ceremony. There was a grand
demonstration, and addresses were delivered by the
Eevs. J. C. Dodwell, G. L. Nairn, and Messrs.
M'Jannet and Johnstone. Afterwards the National
Anthem was sung. The children and- parents wero
abundantly regaled. Prizes of books were given to
the children attending the Public school, and sports
and varied amusements were heartily indulged m by
all. The usual votes of thanks terminated the pro-
ceedings, which were very successful.
Tas annual meeting of the members of the School
of Arts, Balmain, was held in that institution last
night;-Major Jaques occupying the chair. The report
of the committee, for the past year, was laid before the
meeting. It set forth that the building was in good
condition, that means for easier exit in the event of
fire had been constructed, in the arrangement of which
the thanks of the committee were due to Mr. J,
M'Donald for tho valuable assistance he had rendered.
A new floor had been laid incurring considerable out-
lay towards the meeting of which the sums received
from the Skating Club had proved useful. The
financial position was very satisfactory, and the income
was economically employed. A regret was expressed
at the limited number of subscribers, and a suggestion
pnt forward to the effect that a person should be en-
gaged to enlist subscribers, to whom a life membership
might be offered, or membership at the rate of 12s. a
year. A referenoe was made to the successful scientific
entertainments lately given in the hall by Mr. W.
Mao Donnell, and »hope of their continuance held out,
provided sufficient encouragement were given. Tho
receipts for the year were £189 6s., with a balance
of £1 8s. 4d. from last year, making a total of £190
8s. 4d.; and the expenditure was £177 16s. Id.,
leaving a balance of £12 12s. 8d. to the credit of the
institution, and a deposit of £50 at interest Captain
Trouton moved, and Mr. J. D. Cronin seconded, the
adoption of the report. On the motion of Captain
Trouton, seconded by Mr. W. Mao Donnell,-Major
Jaques, Messrs. J. M'Donald, H. Perdriau, H. A.
Perkins, and J. D. Oronin were elected members of tho
committee, and, after a vote of thanks to the chairman,
the nrocee ____.« terminated.
About half-past 7 o'clock, yesterday morning, an
accident of a rather exciting nature happened at tho
Circular Quay. A carrier had just delivered a dray
load of goods on board one of the vessels lying opposite
Tslbofs wool stores, when his horse suddenly com-
menced to back ; and before the driver could reach tho
reins, horse and dray went over the wharf into tho
water, turning a somersault in their descent. Several
persons assisted to rescue the animal, but only suc-
ceeded in getting him olear of the cart. Some men in
a berat then towed the horse to the steps at the bottom
of Phillip-street, and attempted to get him out of the
water there > but in doing so the winkers carno off, and
he returned to the water and swam about for nearly
half an hour. At length a South Sea Islander got into
the boat, which again proceeded in the direction of the
horse. As soon as it got closo enough, the darkie
sprang on to the horse's back, fastened a rope round his
neck, and by this means tho animal was towed to the
wharf and eventually got on shore. Numbers of
similar accidents have taken place at or near tho same
?pot through the unprotected state of the Quay ; and
the matter of taking some steps to protect their recur-
rence is worthy of consideration.
A cobbispoîtdekt writes to the Perth Inquirer :
" A West Australian from Sydney states that he and a
friend were three hours looking for the W. A. Court in
the Exhibition building; when sergeant Bowe, hap-
pening to come across them, politely showed them into
a corner with a paper placard on a few spear, and two
natives' skulls, which were the sole representatives of
the productions of the colony."
A JIETUEN of the quantity of land in South Aus-
tralia alienated from the Crown up to the end of last
year is thus stated in the 8. A. Advertiser :-The total
area of South Australia proper is 243,244,800 acres,
and the quantity of land alienated for cash or on credit
up to 31st December, 1879, was 8,477,813 acres 3
roods 83 perches, the amount of the purchase money
being £11,444,600 11s. 2d. Of this amount,
£4,490,245 18s. 9d. is still outstanding. The cash
sales by auction during last year were 4908 acres 3 roods
22 perches. The area of land sold by private contract,
including small blocks in excess of area allowed on
credit purchased for cash, was 8623 acres. Purchases
completed are represented by 167,601 acres 8 roods.
The acreage of land alienated on credit during 1879
was 428,114, the purchase money being £585,537 11s.
6d. The total payments on account of land during
1879 amounted to £433,402 Os. 9d., as compared with
£484,919 6s. 7d. in 1878. The total area of land
alienated during 1879 was 436,645 acres 8 roods 22 I
perches, as compared with 680,251 acres 3 roods and 21 j
perches in 1378.
Thb Atg\t* states that some interesting experiments
with signalling rockets were carried out on Saturday
night, with a view to ascertaining at how greata
distance large rockets may be seen. It was arranged
that a number of them should be sent up from the
summit of the Observatory Mount in the Dandenong
Banges, and that observations should be made at tho
Melbourne Observatory. Mr. Walter Draper, of
Elizabeth-street, at whose instance the experiments
were made, conducted the display at the mountains,
and most careful and patient observations were made
at the observatory, under the direction of Mr. B. L. J.
Ellery, Government Astronomer, by whom the altitudes
attained by the rockets and the results of the successive
experiments were noted. Able assistance was rendered
to him by gentlemen connected with the torpedo
corps. The experiments extended over an hour, and
during that period rockets of from half-a-pound to six
pounds, and of various colours, were sent up. A largo
proportion of the rockets could be seen by the naked
eye, but the colours could rarely be distinguished
without the use of the theodolite and suitable glasses.
There wero occasionally long intermissions in the dis-
play, which conveyed the impression that somo of the
rockets could not be seen. The night was tolerably
favourable but for a little haziness in the atmosphere
at times. The experiments showed that the largest
rockets can be seen at a distance of at least 20 miles
from the spot at which they are discharged, but that
their colours become dim and mixed beyond that dis-
tance. The display on the whole was fairly successful
as an illustration of the value of rookets for signalling
purposes.
Fo» some months past (says the Tamworth News)
very little advantage has been taken of the right of
conditional purchase, the number of free selections
becoming "smaller by degrees and beautifully less,"
until this week we have to announce that not a singlo
conditional purchase was made at the local Land Office
last Thursday.
The Lismore correspondent of the Tenterfield Star
reports that on the 19th instant a lad stated that while
carrying the mail from Ballina to Lismore, as ho was
coming down the "Postman's Bidge" (just beyond
Lismore), he heard a very loud explosion, and on
reaching the town a few minutes later he found that
the boiler at Glasgow's steam saw-mill bad burst, and
the fireman had been blown some distance, his skull
being out and perforated in several places, a large
wound having been inflicted under the jaw and a gash
in the temple, besides which the body appeared to bo
burnt and scalded all over, and a leg and an arm were
broken. The unfortunate man, who had only recently
given up the occupation of cook at an hotel in Lis-
more, died in a few hours. At an inquiry subsequently
held, the engineer of the a. s. Queensland, who was then
in Lismore, gave it as his opinion that the boiler was
not well constructed; but, as the fireman did not
take the precaution of blowing through the
gauges to see that they were unobstructed,
it would be hard to say whether the boiler
was too full or otherwise; consequently the cause of the
accident could only be surmised. The engineer of the
-yard ÍKjúght) (tates that ha told deceased, to keep up
plenty of steam, as he had let it get very low recently,
which he attributed to the man not being used to hi»
work. No verdict could of course be arrived at, but it
seems to mo that poor Robert Bowley's death was
lost in trying to do somewhat dangerous work with
which he was unacquainted, and which he should not
havo been allowed to undertake. His age was 36, and
aB he was only a short time in Lismore, and not very
communicative, nothing is known of his antecedents.
The boiler was driven about 40 feet backwards out of
its bed, an'l would probably have killed several others
about the mill but that it was just breakfast time ; it
Went through the rooms used as carpenter's and black-
smith's shops, and pieces of ii ou and debris were driven
100 yards away across tho river in front The ex-
plosion occurred at the open end of the furnace, or
ather abovo it.
Old mon seem to havo a hard time of it in the
Hobart Town Hospital. The Mercury says :-"Another
old man, described as 95 years of age, has been received
at the depot from the hospital. He was taken up in a
car, and when lifted out, for he could not move by
himself, wa. found to be in an utter state of collapse.
He was suffering from bed sores and was quite deliri-
ous. His attention could only be attracted by pushes,
and then his answers were incoherent and wandering."
We are requested to state that Mr. Ashdown, solicitor,
did not instruct Mr. G. B. Simpson to prosecute in the case
of David J. Nowton.
An advertisement appears in another column notifying
that special evangelistic services will be conducted in the
new Gospel tent, Abercrombio-street, off Parramatta-street,
every evening, at half-past 7 o'clock.

title: NEW TOWN.
content:
NEW TOWN.
The annual meeting of the Board and
election of three members in place of Messrs.
F. M. Young, C. C. Nairn, and G. Currey,
who retired under the provisions of the
Town Boards Act, 1891, was held at the
Public Library rooms, Main-road, New
Town, on Saturday afternoon. Mr. W, P.
Brownell had been appointed by the Board
to preside, and at 1 o'clock opened the
meeting, fixing the close of the poll for 6
o'clock. The candidates were the two re-
tiring members, Messrs. Young and Currey,
with Messrs. G. C. Bernard, F. G. Knight,
and J.G. Steele, Mr. J. Jeffrey, though
nominated, having withdrawn from the
contest. Considerable interest was taken
by the electors, and canvassers were at work
for most of the candidates. Mr. Brownell
was assisted by Messrs.1 R. J. Ellis and A.
Strathern as poll oUrks. The result was
made known at 7 p.m. to a considerable
number- of eleotors outside the Library
rooms, as follows :- G. C. Bernard, 198 ;
J. G. Steele, 153 ; F. G. Knight, 152 ; G.
Currey, 118 ; C. C. Nairn, 114 ; Jeffrey,
10 ; informal votes, 7. Mr. Browuell de-
clared Messrs. Bernard, Steele, and Knight
duly elected, all of whom returned thanks.
The Chairman of the Board, Mr. F. W.
Piesse, proposed a vote of thanks to Mr.
Brownell, but the electors (or some of them)
declined to hear him, and the vote was
eventually carried on the motion of another
elector, Mr. Brownell acknowledged the
compliment, and the proceedings closed with
three cheers for the Queen.

title: INUNDATION OF THE TIBER.
content:
INUNDATION OF THE TIBER.
ROME, Nov. 16.
The Tiber has overflowed its banks, par-
tially inundating Rome.

title: QUEENSCLIFF.
content:
QUEENSCLIFF.
TOSSDAY.
ARRIVED.-Lucy and Adelaido (schooner), from
Sydney; Leonidas (schooner), and William Ackers
(barque), from Newcastle ; Royal Shepherd, from.
Adelaide.
SAILBD.-Ecliptic (barque), Ann and Jane (barque),
and Hebe (schooner), for Newcastle; at 7 p.m., You
Yangs (s.), for Sydney.

Loss OF THE SciiooNsa lit BT.-On Tuc«d»y lut tn Inquiry into
the lot» of the Mary was held before the Marine Board. Tho
Prest wes not admitted, but from the information wo btv« been
enabled to glean, the following may be considered as tolerably
corren t. From the statement« of Ctptain Potten, the chief officer,
second mate, and several of the crew, it appeared the vessel sailed
from Melbourne on the 2nd instant, in ballast, for Newcastle
At 1 o'eloek on the monning of the 8th instant, the otpttin and
crew weio horrified to find that they had g t on to tht land at
Wreck Bty. On examining her compite, it was fonnd to be five
degree» in error, whioh led the vessel half a point too
much westerly. This was aoctnnted for from the ftot tail
tn iron lamp had been used in the binoaole instead of lone of
topper or brass, a circumstanoe it does not teem tho captain wa»
wa» made aware of until it wat too late. The Board felt to satis-
fied with the statements made before them, that they returned tht
captain and officers their certificates. The finding of the Board
was. we understand, to the following effect :-" The Board find it
unnecessary to hold any farther inquiry, at they find ne blame to
be attached to Captain Postetl or his officer!, exospt that the dis-
turbance of the compass should have been discovered at ta earlier
part of the voyage ; otherwire overy ordinary précaution appears
to have have been used. They recommend, therefore, that they
retain their certificates, with a caution to be more careful in
uture."-Ifeiccaitle Chronicle, Februtry 19.

title: SPECIAL SITTING AT NISI PRIUS.
content:
Special Sitting at Nisi Pnivs.
Before Ilib Honor tho Chiet Justice and n jury of
finir.
COOK V. 11Y11NEÍ, AND ANOTHEK.
Tho trial of this case, which had already lasted two
days, was resumed and concluded.
It was on action bj- Simon Cook, a farmer of Illawarra,
against James Bj-mcs and William Byrnes, proprietors of
tho Mount Pleasant Colliery, to recover damages for the
pollution of a creek or small stream of fresh water which
ran through tho plaintiff's land, by coal from tho defend-
ants' worts. Tho plaintiff'B declaration put tho case in
two ways, first, that the creek had been wilfully polluted
by tho casting of coal therein ; secondly, that tho damiegti
had been the result of ncgltgenco. Tho defendants had
pleaded-first, a general doninl that thej- had dono any
injury to tho plaintiff ; secondly, that whatever injury had
been inflicted lind been the unavoid.iblo result of what thoy
had done in the lawful conduct of their businoss as coal
lumera.
Sir William Manning, Q.C., Mr. Darloy, and Mr. Salo-
mons, instructed by Mr. Maguire, appeared for the plaintiff;
and Mr.,Butlor, instructed by Messrs. Allen, Bowden, and
Allen, for the defendants.
Tho plaintiff was the lessee of Spring G rovo, a farm of
fifty acres, at Fairy Meadow, Wollongong district,
in the vicinity pf the Mount Pleasant Colliery. His
case was that a small stream of water which ran through
his and other lands in that neighbourhood had been ren-
dered unfit for uso bj- tho deposit of n largo quantity of
slocOc coal from the collierj' in question, ana that his farm
had boen otherwise injured from the samo cause. Tho
defendants' caso was that there had been no such injury,
and that although the creek might have boon partially fillod
up by slack coal, this had not been the result of any care
lossnoss on tho part of tho emploj-ccs at the colliery, but of
n land slip, the result of a flood, for which tho defendants
were not responsible. The evidenco was very voluminous,
and in'many respects very conflicting. Tho amount really
in question was a small one, but tho object of tho contest
was rather, it would appear, to determine tho genorol ques-
tion whether or not tho proprietors of cool mines in that
district were to be held responsible for damages of this cha-
racter. According to the plaintiff and his witnesses the
creek had clearly been damaged by the presence of a
quantity of slack coal which hod como down from an
immense henp noar the mouth of the mine-a result bl ought
about by the carelessness of the minors in allowing bo vast
an accumulation at such a place. Tho supply of water from
this creek had previously been regular ana abundant. Tho
water, although a littlo hard for washing purposes, hail
been excellent for every other kind of domestic use, but
since the conl had come down it had been quito useloss.
Tho waterholes had boen completely filled up, so that the
constancy of tho supplj- of water was to it great extent put
an end to, and such as was still to bo had was very bad.
The flood, too, bad carried tho slack coal over some of tho
cultivated land, and hod destroj-cd or damaged tho crops.
Cook had about forty head of cattle which had boen accus-
tomed to drink at this stream, but which could
now scarcely use ii. He had boon compelled
therefore to sink a well. Ho had offered to toke £20
in full compensation for these injuries, and for this sum to
clear out the bed of tho creek himself, but tho defendants
had refused lo give him that amount and had offered only
£10. According to tho defendant«' wltnosses the water of
this creek, which had always been a littlo brackish,.had
been in no way injured by tie influx of slack coal, which
was far less than had been represented, and was occasioned
solely by a landslip during a flood which hod brought down
at the samo time a largo quantity of soil. The spread of
slack coal over tho land to a small extent had rather a
tendency to increaso its productiveness than otherwise, and
tho catUo had in no way suffered. The^offer of £10 had
been tendered, it was sworn, without prejudico-that is to
say without admitting any liability-and only in tho hope
by dealing liberally with tho plaintiff to save all trouble and
expense. Samples of tho water from . this
creek were exhibited in Court, whioh sample«
presented a very uninviting appearance. It was contended
tint they had not been fairly token, but that the water must
havo been btorcd up, but this was denied. Some of this water
was analysed by Mr. Watt, from whose evidence it would
appear that its" foulness aid not in all probability result
from tho presence of coal, but from that of organic matter.
It further appeared that watcrcrcsscs wore growing plen-
tifully in the creek, and that decomposed vegetable matter
might in dry weather help to make the water bad. Tho
water of the creek, according to Mr. Watt, was naturally
brackish, and tho slack coal from this'mino when settled
(as it. would, settle) ,at. tho bottom of theiBtreain when
' 'net flowing rapidly- would'« not pollute it as alleged.
There was nirtfccr evidence that a stream of water coming
.ut of the same seam of coal was quite pure, and was con-
stantly used for domestic purposes. Seme of the coal was
broken up in Court and placed in tumblers ef water, upon
which it left a slight scum, although without otherwiso
rendering the water apparently impure. The impurity, J
however, va« most positively «vom to by the plaintiff'« *
**"?"-~-i _.
.witnosBcs. Somo evidence was gone into on the part of tho
I ?'_.nti(T lo show that tho lond-slip, if it did canso tho dam-
age (which was denied), lind been the result of some mis-
management of tho excavation. This was mot by direct
contradiction on tho(pnrt of tho defendants. Tho ovidenco
was directly contradictory na to the quantity of slack coal
in tbo heap nenr the colliery, and in nearly ovcry other im-
portant particular, even ¡is to tho local features of tho
gi omul.
His IIokoh directed the jury that the plain ques-
tion for their deteniiiuation was whothor or not tho
plaintiff hnd mndo ont any claim to damages for
injurj" sustained by him through any want oi duo core on
tho p'nrt of tho defendants' employes. Evory man had a
right to work n coal mine, but ho was bound so to monago
it as that his neighbours should not bo injured. Against
lend slips nud floods no amount of caro could guarel ; but
tho miners wero bound to exctciso duo caro and forethought
so ns when buch accidents took placo their neighbours
might bo «s little injured as possiblo by any escapo from tho
minc.
The jury, without leaving tho box, found a verdict for the
defi'iidnnts.

title: THE AUSTRALIAN TEAM v. NEW SOUTH AVALES AND VICTORIA.
content:
THE AUSTRALIAN TEAM v. NEW SOUTH
AVALES AND VICTORIA.
! Second Day. i
The above match was continued on Snturdaj, and was
again favoured by fine sunny w eather until about 4 o'clock;
and the increased inteiest taken in the contest was appaient
by the splendid r iterance on tho ground during the after-
noon Beforo tbo luncheon hour thero were not more
than 3000 spectators piesent, but as soon as business
was ovei m tne eity, visitólo bpgan to arrive aB
fast as tramcars, omnibuses, and hansoms could convev
them to Mowo Park Indeed the traffic for several
hours was co heavy tüat theie was considerable
difficulty in meeting it and the necessity of a double lino of
tramway along Oxfoid and Botany sheets was nerei so
fullj ieali7ed At 4 o'clock there must hive been 12,000
people r> lthm the cricket enclosure and the scene \ lew^d,
irom tho pavilion, was nxtiemelr pleasing The tenace on
the eastern side was thronged and round the ground, and
especially in the ncith vy estent corner, the spectators
weio packed m rows-in some places hnlf-a dozen deep
The fair sex patronised the grand stand m large numbers,
and tho accommodation hore was fully taken up Tho
pav ilion, too, w as w eil patronised, and in fact dunng-the after-
noon a considerable number of subscnbeis were unable to
find seats Many prominent citizens were present, and a
general opinion was expressed that tho asspmblage was one
of the most brilliant ev er seen on the Association Giound,
surpassing ev on the second day of the Intercolonial match
Hundreds of people walked to the giound, and no doubt
benefited bj the exercise until they reached the
load which runs lo the gate, wheie they viere
perforce compelled to swallow a large quantttv of
dust, which was raised bv the continuous passage of
hansoms and omnibuses borne attempt was made to
repair this road before the intercolonial match took place
but the stone u=ed was not suitable for tho purpose ns it
soon became pulverised and it is to be hoped that beforo
next season tho Corporation will remedj the present un-
pleasant stato of things lhere cannot bo a doubt that the
match now proceeding vnll result m a bumper benefit to the
Australian team, who will piobably receive between £600 and
£S00 as thei- share of the gato money , audit is therefore to
bo regretted that thoso who had the man igement of affairs,
huyo been so ngia in their economy of expenditure It
was expected that, m view of a liberal amount of patronage
on Saturday, a good band would have been provided, as in
usual on such occasions, but this compliment was not paid
to tho public, who wera not slow to notice tho circumstance.
Peihaps tho Australind team considered, with pardonable
v anita, mat their appearonco after a orilhant tour in
the mothei country gave tho spectators moro than
an adequate return tor their money but a good
many poison1- thought otherwise and ii was evident horn
the enthusi istie npplauso which greeted the eftorts of
the combined team on Saturday- that the Australian Eleven
would hay o acted wisely bvmnkinga bidlor populanty as
well as pounds shillings and pence However, thero
is no piolability of tho team playing in Sydney
again, and that ma* make all the difference The
cncl et displayed was very good all round though
soy oral of the Auatnnan team-notably M'Donnell-failed
to sco"o A Bannerman, who, it was expected, would
make a considerable addition to his tuns, did not do so, and
it was not until Blackham got m vy ith Murdoch thut tho
combined team experienced much tiouble Thnso two
batsmen kept then wickets up until the luncheon hour,
incieasing the scoro from 83 to 123 After luncheon the
runs weio fuithor increased to lZo, when Muidoch, nftei t
splendid innings foi 05 was disposed ot bj thoiedoubtablo
Lvans, vy ho bowled him Aftei this tho remaining bats
mon gave veiy little trouble, nnd when Evans
scattered the last wickot, tho scoro stood at 165,
oi 42 behind tho combined team Tho bowling
of Lvana throughout tho inmn_s was admirable,
and Midvvintoi and M'Sbme also performed success-
fully, but Gregory, Coopei, and others did not
como oft Tho fielding all lound was remarkably
good, and Elliott, though fal fiom vrcll, was only
second to Blackham behind tho wickets A\ hen tho com-
bined team made a start for then second innings an
ominous rumbling oi thunder in the south-vvoat heialdcd a
change in the-weather, and in a shoit time the skv became
overclouded, rendering the light cxtieruely bad foi the
batsmen Massie and C Banneiman again went to
the wiel ets fitst and were not long m commencing opera-
tions, Massie, much to the delight of tho stjectators scoring
veiv lapidlv Bannerman retned lust after getting into
double figures, but his companion remained at the wicl ets
until ho liad scored <j0 ruis, and was then bowled by Alex-
ander Massie played moio íecklessly than ni his lust
innings, and ought to hav o been caught out but it is moro
tliun likely that tho approval that gi rated his rigoi
ous hitting encouraged him to let out, when defenco would
havo been more prudent Upon the rotnoment of Massie,
Horan and Evans becamo paltn°rs, but thev had not beeu
togethei many minutes when the ram sot in steadily, and
compelled the plaj ers to seek the shelter of tho pavilion At
this ttmo a large number of spectators loft tho ground, but
eey eral thousands remained in the hope that the wcathor
would clear. As the rain continued, however,-the captains
o ; the respective teams agreed not to resume play until
Monday, and a general rush was made for the trams and
omnibuses, which returned to town uncomfortably crowded.
The Play.
Murdoch and A. Bannerman resumed their innings a fow
minutes after 12 o'clock, to the bowling of Evans and Mid-
winter. Tho first four overs wero maidens, and Murdoch
then drove Midwinter to tho on for a sinclo, but tho last
ball shot quickly, and took Banneruian's wicket. (2-21-60.)
M'Donnell followed, but in Midwinter's next over ho
attempted a drive, and was splendidly caught by the
bowler, who secured tlio ball with ono hand. (3-0-60.)
Slight succeeded him, and Murdoch hit Evans to tho terrace-.
fence for 4. Slight then drove Midwinter for a single, but
in trying to tit a "yorkcr"from Evans he had his bails
trimmed. (4-1-65.) * Groube now joined Murdoch,_ and
scored a single off each bowler. Murdoch then snicked
Midwinter to the southern fence for 4, which brought 70
np. Three to Groube and two singles to Murdock resulted
from the next S overs, and then Murdoch getting a chance
at Evans, drove him grandly aloutr tho carpet for 4. (SO
np.) Seven successive maidens followed, the bowlers being
too well on to be trifled with, and Murdoch then
put a ball from Evans to mid-on for a single. Edwards,
who had Fhortly before relieved Midwinter, bowled a maiden
to Murdoch, and Groube, after cutting Evans for 2, was
smartly caught in the same over by Gregcvy in the slips.
(5-7-S3.) Blackham followed, and opened off Edwards
with a good oil drive for 3 : and cut Evans for a single.
Midwinter hero went on again in place of Edwards, and
' Blackham hit the third ball of the over for two. Murdoch
negotiated an over from Evans without scoring, and Black-
ham after getting a singlo off Midwinter, made a fine off
drive for 4 in Evans' next. The score was increased to 95,
. when another change in the bowling was deemed advisable
Coopev taking the ball from Midwinter. Blackham imme-
diately hit the first ball to tho terrace fence for 4 ; put the
third to log for a couple, and Murdoch out the last for 2.,
. The "century" had now been passed, and Blackham, by a
fine hit to the grand stand fence, added another 4 ; Mur-
doch now faced Cooper, and got a lucky snick off the first
ball for 4, finishing -the over with a hit to the off
:for n single. (110 up.) Threejmaiden overa followed, and
Blackham then hit Cooper twice for a brace each. A double
change was now tried, Garrett going on instead of Evans,
and Gregory relieving Cooper. The batsmen, however, kept
their wickets up until the luncheon hour, the score standing at
123. Upon resuming, the number of runs was increased in
three overs to 135, when Evans went on in place of Garrett.
Tho change proved a judicious one, as Evans in his first
over broke through Murdoch's defence. (6-65-135.) The
Australian captain played a fine innings all through, and
was applauded from all parts of the ground as he retired
to the pavilion. Jarvis succeeded him, and Garrett took
the ball from Gregory at the southern end. Two maidens
were bowled, and Blackham scored a single off Garrett,
Jarvis snicking the third ball to the fence. (140 up.)
Scoring now became very slow, only 3 runs resulting from
five overs. M'Shane then went ou instead of Garrett, and
?in his third over bowled Blackham, who had played a fine
vigorous innings for 36. (7-36-143.) Boyle, who was
apparently lame, succeeded him, but was beautifully caught
in the same over by Elliott. (S-0-143.) Palmor came
next, but after scoring a single was also well caught behind
the wicket by Elliott off Evans. (9-1-146.) Alexander
was last man," and he and Jarvis brought tho score up to
155, when the South Australian, after a useful innings for
11, was clean bowled by Evans. Alexander carried his bat
out for 6, and the inning's closed for 155.
About half-past 3 o'clock Massie and C. Bannerman went
to the wickets once more, on behalf of the combined team,
to the bowling of Spofforth and Boyle. Massie immedi-
ately commenced operations by driving " the Demon " for a
single. Pie then cut Boyleto the pnvilion fence for 4, and
in Spoffortli's next over, Bannerman hit the
first ball to the grand stand fence for 4, and
got tho next past the wicket-keeper for a single
' This biought 10 up, and Massie added another single for a
drive in the same over. A single to Massie, off Boyle, was
the next item, and tho same batsman hit Spofforth towards
the pavilion fenco for 3. Notwithstanding the bad light
the batsmen continued to score rapidly until 30 runs had
boen put together, when Boyle managed to get a ball past
Bannerman. (1-11-30.1 Horan now joined Massie, and
soon afterwards .Massie made a high hit towards
tho southern fence off Boyle, giving a chance to
Slight, who dropped the ball. Palmer now relieved
Spofforth. Two maidens wero then bowled, and in
Palmer's second over Mnssio hit him twice for 4, and
finished the over with a hit for a single. Ho then faced
Boyle, hit the second ball to long-on for 2 ; snicked the
next past fhe wicket-keeper for a similar figure, and drove
the last ball for a sincle. This brought 60 up, and an over
or two later Massie was nearly run out. The escape,
however, made little difference, as he was bowled by
Alexander, who had relieved Boyle. (2-50-60.) The
retiring batsman was loudly applauded on his way to tho
pavilion foi- his innings, which was marked by
dashing and at times lucky play. Evans joined
Horan just as 1he rain commenced to fall, and the latter
batsmau hit Palmer to long-leg for 4. Evans then drove
Aloxauder foi- a single, and negotiated the next over from
Palmer without scoring. The rain now carno down
steadily, compelling the players to return to the pavilion,
and, after waiting for some time, it was decided that play
Khoulel bo resumed on Monday, at noon. Tho following
uro the scores :

title: Family Notices
content:
BIRTHS
On the 8th December, 1869, at her residence, 540, Bourke-
street, Surry Hills, the wife of Mr. J. PECK, of a daughter. 
On the 21st December, 1869, at her residence, Apsley Store,
Walcha, the wife of Mr. T. O. HARDAKER, of a daughter.
On the 25th December, 1869, at Surry Cottage, Australia-street,
Newtown, Mrs. W. K. DIXON, of a daughter.
On the 25th December, 1869, at her residence, 228, Riley-street,
Mrs. J. WINNING, of a son.
On the 29th December, 1869, at Apsley Cottage, Cooper-street,  
Mrs. FERDINAND ROWOHL, of a daughter.
MARRIAGES
On the 25th December, 1869, at Forbes, by the Rev. J. H.L. Zill-
man, ROBERT, youngest son of the late JAMES BARNIER, of Dublin,  
to CLARA, widow of the late Dr. CHARLES ASHENHEIM, of Forbes,
and fourth daughter of Mr. John Tarplee, of West Maitland.
On the 27th December, 1869, at St. Peter's Church, Woolloo-
mooloo, by the Rev. G. H. Moreton, Mr. WILLIAM LEWIS,    
saddler, Kiama, to JOHANNA ANNIE, youngest daughter of the late
JOHN MURRAY, Sydney.
On the 27th December, 1869, at Holy Trinity Church, by the
Rev. Edward Rogers, PATRICK JOSEPH O'CONNOR, of Harring-    
ton-street, to HENRIETTA PRISCILLA PARSONAGE, of Gloucester      -
street, Sydney.
On the 28th December, 1869, at the residence of the bride's father,
by the Venerable Archdeacon Lillingston, HENRY GINGHAM, eldest
son of J. A. BROUGHTON, Esq., Deniliiquin, to ELIZABETH ANN,          
eldest daughter of REES JONES, Esq., Taemas.      
On.the 30th December, 1869, by the Rev. R. Lewers, St. An-
drew's Scots Church, Mr. EDWARD BOWEN, Bathurst street, to    
SARAH STANTON, Elizabeth-street, Sydney.
DEATHS
On the 12th November, 1869, at her residence, M'Iver-street,
Sandhurst, Victoria, JANE, the beloved wife of Captain TRAPAND,
and daughter of the late Mrs. John Eccleston, of Campbelltown  
Road, aged 52 years.
On Friday, 24th December, 1869, at the residence of Mrs. Alex-
ander, Elizabeth-street, Redfern, ELIZABETH JANE, infant
daughter of Mrs. EDWARD FRANCIS, Surry Hills  .
On the 29th December, 1869, at St. Leonards, REBECCA, the
wife of EDWIN JOHNSON, Esq., Inspector of Schools, aged 30
years.
On the 30th December, 1869, at the residence of his mother-in-law,
Mrs. Bruester, No. 96, Phillip-street North, after a short illness,
Mr. HENRY CANNY, late compositor of the Government Printing  
office, leaving a wife and five children and a large circle of friends
to mourn their loss. Aged 32 years.

title: LISMORE.
content:
LISMORE.
i thursday. 1
4942 acres of land were selected here to-day.
The cane crops look well, and promise good yields.
The weather is unsettled, and the roads are very bad.
Business generally is quiet. " j

title: NEW ZEALAND.
content:
NEW ZEALAND.
NOTES ON PASSING EVENTS.
[KItOM OUU OVWX COWIES I-ONDKNT.)
AUOKT.AXJ), 20th January.
Tin; news from lho East Coast is hy no means
so good Ihis last week. At Opotiki, there is a
return of a stale of filings which is very far from
pleasant in the recommencement of hostilities
by (he natives in the line of murdering any
European or loyal native they can catch. All
along they were of course ripe for this, if the
opportunity had been considered favourable, and
the fact that for a considerable time nothing of
the sort was tried went to show that they were
deterred by fear from the course. They have,
it appears, entered upon it again, and this, more
than anything of more decided want of success
to our troops or loss to our men, is the real bad-
ness of the news.
The Auckland papers are a little too much
affected hy it, I think, and seem to lay stress
upon it as if it involved the loss of prestige, and
the undoing of work supposed to be done
already; but 'there is no good ground for sup-
posing that any change at all affecting the
ultimate position of the campaign has taken
place.
Colonel Lyon, who commands at Opotiki,
has, I believe, already taken measures to
repress the forward movement of the rebels,
and a short time will, 1 have no doubt, see
them driven back once more to their fastnesses
where they were to have been attacked some
weeks ago-a course which, if taken, would, no
doubt, have put a stop to the present evils.
Although a good many ambushes have been
set by the rebels, we only know of one victim
having been secured-a Maori of the native
contingent, named Johnson, who was toma-
hawked and brutally hacked to pieces. There
are more than suspicions entertained regarding
the position of many of the natives professedly ,
friendly in the district. No doubt, many arc
traitors, but that is not so remarkable as the
readiness with which we seem always to trust
these people again.
Lower down the coast the last stronghold of
one section of the natives seems to have fallen
to our attack with but trifling loss ; and we may
now consider that, with the exception of the
force at Opotiki, which is a conglomerate of a
good many sections of rebels,-there is now no
fear of a formidable resistance being offered to
our aims on the East Coast. Of course, it is true
that these people arc very easily moved from
place to place, and a little vigour displayed at
Opotiki rntiy soon cause the re-appearance of
ícbcls at Turanga-mii or at Waiapu. This, in
fact, is a main difficulty of our position, and one
not easy to provide against but by constant care
and watchfulness.
On the "West Coast, at "Wanganui, it is grati-
fying to find that something vigorous is at last
being done. The operations of General Chute
have not been characterised by any startling
display of military science or of original genius,
but they have been vigorous and well-timed,
and as such have produced better effects than
many more correctly planned operations would
hove done.
The loss of another field officer in Colonel
Hassard, of the 57th, is a great pity, as the
officers hare been very heavy sufferers already
in comparison with the men in this war. How-
ever, the moral effect on the natives of finding
Ile soldiers able to storm pas off-hand and
follow them boldly into the bush will be excel-
lent indeed. To the colonist, too, it is no small
gratification to find that the troops are to have
tile chance before they go to remove the re-
proach which was made against them of being
afiaid of the bush and of native forts. It is no
pleasant position for people of British race at
any time to hear sims cast upon the good name
of the British aimy, of which they arc proud
almost by instinct. A little beating will be
enough for the AVaneanui natives, for they arc
a chicken-hearted race, too cruel to be really
brave, and so esteemed even by their own
people.
1 hope General Chute may see their submis-
sion complete before the troops are all with-
drawn from the colony.
In my account of my experiences of the
northern part of this island (which is the result
of a careful personal inquiry into the facts), your
readers will have learned most of the local facts
of interest al present.
The discovery of a fine vein* of copper at the
lower Thames, in the neighbourhood of the
place where gold has been found in payable
quantities, but inaccessible, owing to native
jealousy, is a fact of some importance.
Copper has been known to exist for some
time in the neighbourhood, and the
proprietor (native) of the land is quite willing
to have it worked. It is said that there is a
good deal of the silver with the copper, which
will of course enhance the importance of the
discovery, if correct.
I am informed that a cominmy, with a capital
of £20,000, is in course of formation to work
the New Zealand flax on the plan discovered by
Mr. Purchas, some of which was in the Sydney
maiket previous to the Avar, and commanded
excellent prices. The present effort promises
well, as some of the best names in Auckland are
concerned.
AUCKLAND, 2'Jlh January.
To-day is the twenty-seventh Anniversary of
the founding of this colony, and all Auckland is
holiday-making in consequence. The weather
seems not to have proved particularly favour
i able to the regatta, which is our way of holding
high festival here on this occasion each year,
I and the absence of the old Maori element to a
great extent from the scene lakes much from
the romance of the affair. Formerly
it was the Maori festival j.ar excellence,
but for the last two years the natives
have not been on sufficiently cordial terms,
excepting to the North-and the Northern
natives never did much in canoe-racing-to come
in any considerable numbers to the regatta.
Were the Northern tribes removed or unfriendly
we should soon be much in the position of the
Australian cities, where an aboriginal native is a
comparatively rare sight.
The position of matters on the West Coast is
veiy greatly improved by the operations "of the
troops under General Chute. In a former
letter I gave some details of his earlier
operations in taking the pas at Manu
taki and Manapawa, where Colonel Has
sard, of the 57th, was unfortunately mor-
tally] wounded. These successful operations
were, however, only preliminary to his larger
scheme, which he has now, in great measure,
accomplished. That was to penetrate from
Wanganui to Taranaki by an inland route, and
to take all the fortifications, and destroy all the
houses and plantations he could find on the
way. Starting with about 750 men in all, of
whom about 500 were her Majesty's troops,
and 250 colonial forces, either natives or Forest
Bangers, he forced his way through serious
difficulties of all sorts, the chief of which was.
the want of food, which was moro than once
very seriously felt, to the extent of obliging the
troops to eat horse-flesh, as tho commissariat
J»
fe "*- -*
could.not keep up with them. On the march
about ten days seem to have been consumed'
and it is stated that in the various fights that
occurred on the route not less than 150 natives
were killed. Every fortified place was assaulted
and taken by storm, on the principle established
by the colonial forces on the East Coast, and in
all cases the defenders of the pas seem to have
been panic struck at the apparition of soldiers
actually rushing a pa before a single shot had
been fired at it from the traditional great guns.
General Chute had reached New Plymouth at
our latest dates, and had been received with the
greatest possible enthusiasm, which displayed
itself in the form ol triumphal arches and ad-
dresses.
The General's work, however, is not yet done
by any means. This march indeed is but the
first blow, which must be followed up with
others in rapid succession, unless it is to be
forgotten. He is quite aware of this happily,
and is about to recommence his march back
again, only taking the coast line instead of the
inland route.
At Warca, near the Patia Uiver, and on the
wonderfully fertile plateau that stretche3 away
southwards from the base of Mount Egmont,
there is reason to believe that the natives will
be found in very considerable force, and with
formidable works of defence. The country is
difficult, owing to the heavy scrub of manuka
and flax which occupies most of the district
and the natives are so fully competent to take'
advantage of this that it may safely be said
that the heaviest part of the work is yet to
come.
A continuance of the same fearless tactics
will, however, in the opinion of every compe-
tent judge, lead to the complete and early
success of the operations at Warca as elsewhere,
and loo much credit can scarcely be given to'
General Chute for the ready and able way in
which he lias adopted and applied to regular
military practice the lessons to be learnt from
the experience of the colonial forces.
The native contingent on the East Coast has
been gaining fresh laurels, and the rebels we
may hope have been gaining new experiences
within the last few days. The rebels who were
defeated so often by the combined native and
colonial forces under Major Frazer, retreated on
the difficult country at the head of the river '
Wairoa, where in the very inaccessible district
round the Waikarcmoana Lake, where the river
takes its rise, they considered themselves safe
from molestation. Such was not the view of
either Major Frazer or the friendly chiefs who
followed them up with about 400 fighting-men.
On the 11th and 12th days of this month a
severe scries of skirmishes were fought close to
the banks of this large and romantic lake
where the rebels had erected a pa of some
strength. The struggle seems to have been
severe, and the arts of the defending party were
so clever that it seems hard that they
should have proved so ineffectual. On the
second day the victory of our men was so well
established that the rebels, having lost their pa,
took to their canoes, and favoured by the fine
weather-in windy weather the lake is too
stormy for ennocs-made their escape, leaving
forty-one dead bodies behind them. Many, no
doubt, were wounded in the affair on their side,
as thirteen were on ours. The greatest chief of
the Wairoa was left dead by the rebels, as well
as five or six men of leading rank. Amongst
the loyal dead (twelve) there were no men of
note ; but old lhaka, a great chief and warrior,
who was, in fact, commander-in-chief, was
rather badly wounded in the thigh.
There is no news of further fighting at
Opotiki, but some may be daily expected. The
escape of some fifty-three native prisoners from
the hulk at Wellington, effected hythe removal
of a port and dropping into the water or a boat
on a stormy night has caused some sensation.
The principle of keeping these men shut up in a
hulk doing nothing beyond eating and sleeping
has long been condemned by the colonists, and
this second escape may perhaps stir up the
Governor to consent to some more reasonable
plan. They were offered to Otago as hard-labour
men, it may be remembered, bul the offer was
not accepted owing to a mistaken notion that
the chiefs would not work. The old proposal to
deport them to the Chatham. Islands
seems better than allowing the poor wretches to
make their escape and lose a large percentage
by drowning in the attempt-no less than six
out of the fifty-three arc known to have lost
their lives.
'Hie confiscation of half a million »f acres at
Opotiki, will throw into the Government's hands
some of the first land in New Zealand, and the
settlement of half the 1st Waikato Regiment
upon part of it will give security, and therefore
value to the remainder, which can at no distant
date be sold for a good price. The province
of Auckland is promised a further loan of a quar-
ter of a million to enable her" to deal satisfac-
torily with the ceded Waikato territory, but
how the money is proposed to be used by the
Provincial Executive does not yet appear.
Mr. Weld, the late Premier of this colony,
has announced his retirement from public life
owing to ill-health. Had he done so before he
headed a Ministry he would have carried far
deeper regrets with him than he now can do
from most of the colony.
From the papers, per tho Prince Alfred steamer, wo quote
as follows :
Under the head of Native Intelligence, in the Southern
Cross, that journnl publishes somo "gleanings" on the
nativc question, which are not without thoir significance, and
for the accuracy of which it vouches.
Wo learn that many Europeans havo recently ponotratod
into tbo bcai t of the disturbed districts, amongst the Pal
Mnrire fanatics. With several of those tourists, wo have
had an opportunity of speakincr. Starting from Auckland, and
going up to tho Waikato and Thames countries, ono remark
is made by all tourists-namely the diminished numbors of
tho natives. On being questioned regarding the cause of
their decrease, they state that the loss by war did not nearly
so much niTect them as tho loss by disease. Affeotiona of
the throat and chest have been the chief agency in carrying
off (he native people ; and as they have, as a rule, gono book
to the licentious and communistic practices, in voguo
twenty-five or thirty years ago (amongst othors, the whare
piihi), theie can bo little doubt that the mortality witt
increase. . ,
Several gentlemen who penetrated into a comparatively
unknown country, in tho interior, were treated ovcrywhere
with marked respect and kindness. They attribute tats to
what took place a short time previously at Matamata, wita
Thompson. It would appear, as the natives report, that a,
deputation from all tho inland tribes, numbering about tut)
men, waited on Thompson, asking him to lead the tnbos ut
an attack on Auckland. Thompson isBaid to liave asked
.'Do you know tho way to Auckland?" After a pauso,
the deputation repliod-" No ; but wo look to you to shoir
us tho wav." Thompson said-" I tried to take Aucklani
once, and! lost one eye. If I try to take it again I fear to
'otc tho other eyo. I made war on Auckland once, ano
Waikato is gone: if I mako war again I may lose
ho Waiho (Thames)." The deputation said no
more. Thompson then added-" As yea represent
all the native tribes and villages inland, mw
that vou aro here, I may ns well toll you what I want
you 'to do. When any Europeans want to go
through your disfrute, they are not to be touched. \ ou.
aro not to murder onv ; you aro to help thom and treat morn.
with kindness." Thedepulatton loft, carrying thismessaga.
to their villages; and the tourists to whom we refer hoard it
in a remoto district, through which Hereopa, with tho tewi
of a European, travelled only two day« previously. This
Bpeaxs volumes for Thompson's influence. .
Our informants often spoke on war subjects ; and oa being
questioned whether it was peace or war, the natives invau
ably answered, " It will bo peace or war as Thompson
decides." They are quito ready to fight-, and do not appear
I to think themselves lese ablo to drive tis into the sea, witt»
diminished numbers, than boforo thawar. .
| From Ngatimaniopoto wo learn that Rowi is anxious tor
peace, but that his fighting chief-his " back;bono -
wants war. The tribe is divided.-; and wo are convince! mat
an acceptable agent would hnve. no dtfUouUy in eeourwg «BQ

Alderman Taylor thon moved.-" That a rubblo gutter bo

title: THE FARNELL LAND BILL, AND ITS FATE
content:
TEE EAENELL LAND BILL, AND ITS FATE'
TO THE EDITOR OF THE HERALD.
Sir,-I respectfuly ask a few shoit lines of space to bring
under criticism tho vote of the House on the second reading
of the late Government's Land Bill That bill did not in any
way interfere with tho mam principle of tho bill of 1861,
it left that principle intact, and on this giound alone should
havo been read a second timo by a House piotessmg to be-
lieve m the land legislation ot 1SC1 Su John Robertson
tried to introduce a Land Bill at the beginning of the
session which he stated, embodied all the amendments
required, evory principle m vthich bill was in the bill of
tho late Government, which Su- John Robertson voted
against
The rejected Land Bill greatly favoured tho free
selector, adopting all the main principles put
forward by tho free selectors at their Confer-
ence , and yet strange to state, Mr B irbour, the
President of that Conlerencc, voted against it In the
rejected bill tho free selectors were favomed to a degree foi
beyond their wildest hopes or expectations, nnd yet dozens
of members who havo always pioiessed to be the free
selectors' fast and steady fnends voted against tho bill
If any one can pluck out the heart ot this mystery, 1 ask
him to do so, because to me it is in olublt Iho free
selectors will never again get a bill so f ivoumblo to Ihcir
interests, and this was confessed bv such wami friends of
the freo selector as Messrs Dav, M'Elhono, and Bennett
Tho principal objection to tho bill, as enunciated bv most
of tho speakers, was the very (,rav o niattei oi interest on
tho balances of futuio freo selectois Ot com se, there
were many other objections, but I submit not one ot a vital
character-that is, that could not havo been easily
amended m committee I do not know anv bill ihut
over carno before Faihament that was better entitled
to bo read a second time, alwa\s bearing m
mind that the wholo Paihamont favoined the principio
of tho 1861 legislation Tho House could have stiuek out
with ease eveiy bo-called defect that was riomtcd out during
the lengthy debate, and a bill could havo been passed in
harmony, at least, with tho opinions of honorable members
This was not done, for reasons that I do not attempt to
fathom, but it might have ha\o been done it men had
acted up to their opinions If any Land Bill is introduced
by tho present, or any future Government, I will ventaie
to make this small prophecy with legaid to it uinneh,
that it will contain every manciple of the late rejected bill
with the exception of the abolition of interest on the balances
of futuro free selectors, and one or two other matta s or no
great moment
lhe proposal to raise tho squatters' rent to the extent
of £400,000 a year secured, m my op mon, the -elec-
tion of the bill, but let any Government attempt to
introduce a Land Lill without this must ughteous pio
posal, and that Government wul meet with \erv sudden
death I am sorry the people h id not a chance of speaking
and acting ou this most important matter
I obseire the Albwy Mannt) stiongly condemns "Mr
Barbour for voting against the second loading of the bill,
stating that it contained threc-fomths ot vhat the Tiee
Selectors' Conference put ioith.as their wants
There cannot bo a doubt of thi3 that the whole body of
free selectors would have voted for the bill to a man, as well
they might, for they will never got such another bill
If there is to be no attempt to separate the two great
interests, pastoral and agricultural, the people will not m a
hurry get so good a bill as that which has just been
rejected, which with a few easily made alterations would
have been in unison with the opinions of every member of
tho House From what has happened the free selectors will
have little difficulty m discovering who are their li lends,
and I believe the lesson will not bo thrown away upon
them __ I remain, yours, dLc,
DAVID BUCHANAN.
Sydney, December 23.
